HEADLINE: Break a (Bendable) Leg, Barbie!;
It's Show Time for a Cast of Thousands at the Toy Fair

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Barbie was rehearsing her lines yet again, gesturing and smiling in a glittering fantasy showroom inhabited by workmen who were too desperately busy to listen. "This year," she was saying, "we have Barbie and Ken featured as Dana Scully and Fox Mulder of 'The X-Files.' It's the first time Barbie and Ken have been featured as F.B.I. agents!"
A designer, pushing a paint roller to touch up a wall in Barbie white, never looked up. An electrician took no notice. Barbie surveyed the room after completing her spiel and shook her head. "Got to get this on the tip of my tongue before show time," said Barbie, a New York actress whose real name is Jeanne Jones. 
 It is showtime with a vengeance at the American International Toy Fair, the most prestigious trade show of the $20 billion toy industry, which opens tomorrow.
For weeks, throughout the six-block toy district in Manhattan, an area bounded by 21st and 27th Streets, Madison Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, workers have been toiling to prepare the industry's annual carnival, stage set and high-stakes crap shoot, in which companies gamble millions on attracting buyers, retailers and securities analysts.
"It's not just like opening a Broadway show -- it's like opening all of them at once," said Thomas S. Arbuckle, director of the Toy Center at Fifth Avenue and 23d Street.
This year 20,000 buyers from 50 countries will check out the wares of 1,695 exhibitors from 23 countries. For five days, the fairgoers will jostle one another in the city's 430 toy showrooms, and jam the famously overcrowded elevators in the Toy Center. Then the fair, which is not open to the public, will continue at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center for four more days.
The trade show is a Brigadoon of extravaganzas, summoning up an elaborate multimedia universe for a week or so, then fading into the mist. And though toy companies pay from $20,000 to $100,000 in annual rent and maintenance, the majority of the showrooms rented by out-of-town toy makers are unused for the rest of the year.
With only 320 shopping days before Christmas, the toy companies are spending $28 million to prepare the showrooms for the fair this year, according to the Toy Manufacturers of America, the industry's trade group, which sponsors the show.
Beneath its sparkling, fun-loving surface, the Toy Fair is an engine of employment for thousands of display builders, designers and construction workers, as well as about 800 actors and actresses who are hired as toy demonstrators. New York City derives more than $200 million in economic benefit from the trade show, according to the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.
Mattel and Hasbro, the two largest toy makers, will not discuss their spending, but David A. Miller, president of the toy manufacturers' group, estimated that their Toy Fair presentations and showrooms cost $5 million apiece, including cafeteria operations to feed thousands of buyers.
Backstage last week was a bedlam of whirring drills and thwocking hammers, a ballet of unloading and lugging. Corridors were jammed with porters wheeling in displays, trying not to run over workers scurrying to fix everything that was broken.
"Yesterday we put in 16 hours; that's about average," said Oscar Gruchalski, an electrician working in the Toy Center.
On the streets outside the Toy Center, there has been Ryder-truck lock. Drivers have arrived as early as 3 A.M., lining up to deliver showroom stage sets and merchandise. "The line of trucks backs up from the Toy Center all the way to Seventh Avenue," Mr. Arbuckle said.
The fair has been an annual event in the Toy Center since 1934. "The current emphasis on lavish showrooms began in the 1950's, when the manufacturers began to use television to market toys," Mr. Miller said.
"We feel competition with the other showrooms," said Gene Morra, the marketing vice president at Bandai America Inc., who conducted three dress rehearsals during the week. "The pressure is tremendous. Last year, there were 65 action-figure lines here, but 10 did all the sales. The other 55 gambled everything and lost."
Bandai, which sells the Mighty Morphin Power Rangers and the Tamagotchi electronic pets, has five galleries in its showroom, and its construction crew of six has worked 18 hours a day, 7 days a week since the beginning of December. Bandai employs 13 actors and actresses as demonstrators.
All week in the showrooms, knots of actors have been running their lines, monitoring audition calls and asking each other questions like, "Are you going to yoga tonight?" In the toy corridors, the joke has it, the show-business good-luck greeting is not "break a leg" but, rather, "break a poseable limb."
The toy demonstrator jobs are much sought after, bringing actors $200 to $400 a day. "Thousands of actors are struggling for jobs while I get to play with these cool toys," said Christopher Wilkes, who wields a light saber as Luke Skywalker in the Hasbro showroom.
"I love it, this is the fast food of acting," said Kent Heacock, a New York actor who plays the Red Power Ranger in the Bandai showroom. "And it's a nice cash infusion," he said, adding that this will be his sixth Toy Fair appearance.
The pre-fair frenzy is a festival of incongruity. One afternoon Mark Smith, an art director, was encountered on West 23d Street in the company of Reptar, a five-foot-high green dinosaur with angry orange eyes. The problem? The three-foot-wide dinosaur, a character in the Nickelodeon series "Rugrats," would not fit through the Toy Center door, which is two and a half feet wide.
"At Toy Fair, everything that can go wrong will go wrong," Mr. Smith said. Soon, he solved the problem: he directed his crew to take the door off its hinges.
Behind the scenes, in the Hasbro showroom, there are eight "toy doctors" on call to fix broken demonstration toys and prototypes. In the Bandai showroom, Mikako Kawai walks about the hallways carrying a key chain holding 10 electronic Tamagotchi virtual-reality pets used in showroom demonstrations, making sure they don't expire.
Then there is Jennifer Simon, a "floater" in the showroom of Oddzon, a Hasbro subsidiary that makes Koosh toys, which resemble furry rubber balls. Ms. Simon has mastered the acting parts of six other demonstrators, and stands in so they can take breaks.
Invariably, a Toy Fair opening is a last-minute operation. "I remember one year at 7 A.M., while the buyers were coming through the front door, the carpet was still being swept at the back door," said Jean McKenzie, who heads the $1.9 billion Barbie business for Mattel.
In past years there have been disasters, ranging from snowstorms to elevator failures and wildcat strikes. Toys have broken in mid-demonstration before key buyers.
Last year at Hasbro, days before the show, a malfunctioning sprinkler system dumped 300,000 gallons into the showroom, flooding it with a foot of water and drenching exhibits.
"The show must go on, so we turned it around in 24 hours," said Gene Barbieri, the construction superviser. Hasbro celebrated by handing out "I Survived the Flood" T-shirts.
And Mr. Morra of Bandai recalled the year that the chief executive of another toy company that he once worked for "surveyed the showroom at midnight before the opening," he said, "and told us that he wanted the first room of the show to be the last, and the last to be the first." The exhausted crew worked all night to reposition the exhibits, facing them in the opposite direction.
Toy giants devote tremendous resources to the fair. Hasbro, the second-largest toy maker, offers 50 galleries full of toys and games in the three floors of its building on West 23d Street. The company hired 56 toy demonstrators this year and employed 214 full-time workers to prepare the showroom.
Hasbro's showroom statistics might impress Ripley: this year the company revved up 70 tractor-trailers to deliver sets and merchandise. The displays required 60,000 nails and screws, and enough paint to cover 1,333 houses. During the Toy Fair, Hasbro will use up 700,000 watts of electricity (enough to light 70 houses) and will generate enough refuse to fill a football field three feet deep with trash.
Mattel, the world's largest toy company, has 200 rooms on four floors of its building at Sixth Avenue and 22d Street, 20 of the rooms devoted solely to Barbie. Mattel hired 180 actresses and actors to demonstrate its toy lines this year, and employed 300 people on site to assemble its showrooms.
This year Mattel will introduce its "Teen Scene" Barbie, the first of the new dolls offering a Barbie with less makeup, softer features, a wider waist and smaller bust.
"I feel I have the range to play both Barbies," Ms. Jones said with a laugh.
Ms. Jones had paused to visit the Mattel cafeteria in the company of Flip 'N Dive Barbie (actually, Jennifer Clippinger) and International Barbie (Sharon Polo, by name). "You feel some pressure, representing the hottest-selling toy in the market," said Ms. Clippinger, a New York actress -- who, when not flipping and diving, is a Rockette.
And what of the after-show letdown? "It's like the carnival in winter," Mr. Miller, the toy manufacturer's president, said.
But for now, Ms. Jones was heading back to the showroom again, to perfect her "X-Files" presentation. "As you can see," she intoned to a room that seemed without ears, "Barbie and Ken are carrying their authentic F.B.I. badges and credentials, on their continuing search for the truth."

HEADLINE: At Bellevue, Luring Back New Mothers With Luxury

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
Kevin Masaquiza was born last Wednesday in a big double bed, in a room with glorious views of the East River. Flower-flecked paper covered the walls, which were decorated with bright framed pictures. In the corner of the room was a glass-enclosed Jacuzzi, where his mother could have relaxed while she was in labor.
By the looks of it, Ines Masaquiza could have been delivering her second son in a luxury Manhattan hotel. In fact, Kevin's mother, a sewing-machine operator, was the first woman to give birth in Bellevue Hospital Center's new birthing center, which opens officially tomorrow. 
 The lavish birthing room hardly squares with the image of Bellevue, the oldest public hospital in the country; Bellevue is better known for providing care to prisoners chained to their beds, police officers injured in the line of duty and all manner of trauma victims.
Luxury and Bellevue might never have appeared in the same sentence, but the new birthing center is gleaming, beautiful and luxurious, and it is part of a multimillion-dollar attempt to reverse a trend that is troubling to public hospitals in the city: the defection of low-income, Medicaid-insured pregnant women to private hospitals that once shunned them.
"There was a time when public hospitals could depend on their Medicaid deliveries because nobody else wanted those patients, but that time has passed," said Larry Gage, president of the National Association of Public Hospitals and Health Systems, a trade group in Washington. "Investing in holding on to those maternity patients is essential because it affects the overall economic well-being of public hospitals and their mission of caring for the poor."
Struggling to generate revenue when managed care companies have slashed reimbursement rates and shortened patients' hospital stays, private hospitals in the city and around the country have turned their marketing efforts to pregnant women with Medicaid coverage.
Medicaid rates once seemed low and undesirable, but managed care companies have whittled the fees they pay so much that Medicaid rates are suddenly attractive to all providers. In 1996, the average Medicaid fee for a normal delivery was about $3,000 -- competitive with many managed care payments.
Dangling free infant car seats, baby formula and fancy night-of-birth dinners as lures, private hospitals in New York and around the nation have persuaded expectant mothers on public assistance to give birth in their maternity wards.
Left in the lurch, however, have been the public hospitals, which cared for these low-income women when private hospitals had no desire for them or for the comparatively meager childbirth fees that Medicaid was willing to pay.
Although private hospitals have embraced Medicaid patients for other medical treatments, health experts say that the courtship of pregnant women has been especially fierce because births are considered lucrative for several reasons:
*Deliveries are generally considered low cost and low risk.
*Women tend to make the medical decisions for their families, and if they are pleased with the maternity care, they are likely to return to a hospital for all their family needs.
*Word-of-mouth is strong among expectant mothers, so a woman who has a good experience is likely to recommend a hospital to her pregnant friends.
The Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the 11 public hospitals in New York City, has been stunned by the shift of Medicaid deliveries to private competitors. From July to December 1997, about 80 women gave birth each day at all of the corporation's hospitals -- 10 fewer than in the same period of 1996. That drop cost the system at least $11 million last year.
"We saw that trend, and we knew we had to reverse it," said Dr. Luis R. Marcos, president of the hospitals corporation. In many cases, he noted, women who went to public clinics for their prenatal care, for which there is a fairly low fee, jumped to private hospitals for the births, which involve larger payments.
In response, Dr. Marcos said, the public hospitals corporation began a major effort to dress up its maternity wards, beginning with Metropolitan Hospital Center in Manhattan, Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx, Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn and Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens.
The corporation has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars to hang prettier curtains and soft-colored wallpaper, put framed prints on the walls and add comfortable easy chairs, making the rooms feel more like bedrooms than like hospital rooms. Some have private showers and bathrooms, a previously unheard-of comfort in public hospitals.
The centerpiece of the strategy is the $3.5 million renovation at Bellevue, beginning with the $720,000 construction of the natural childbirth center.
Midwives assist at the births, which involve months of prenatal classes to prepare the women for drugless labor. The women are free to move around and even to eat during labor, and to have as many people with them as they wish.
Bellevue's plans for the next 18 months include redoing the rest of the maternity ward and adding homey decorating touches and better amenities to rooms where women will stay from labor through delivery, even when they are not using the natural childbirth model of the birthing center.
Officials at the hospitals corporation say that their immediate goal is to stop the exodus of their traditional patient base. On Bellevue's maternity ward, for example, about 70 percent of the patients have Medicaid, 10 percent have private insurance and about 20 percent are called self-paying, which generally means no payment: namely, the uninsured.
Officials of the public hospitals hope that the comfortable accommodations will eventually attract more women with private insurance.
Bellevue officials said they hoped that the new birthing center and the remodeled maternity ward would help improve the hospital's image.
"We've got to dispel that 'Midnight Cowboy' image of Bellevue," said Dr. Charles Lockwood, director of obstetrics and gynecology at Bellevue. "People are going to see this center, they're going to stop and say, 'This is Bellevue?' And they're going to look at the whole hospital in a new way."
Nursing her baby in the late morning light, an hour after she had given birth, Mrs. Masaquiza said that she would have been as thrilled with her son no matter where he was born. But she said she would not have been nearly as comfortable, emotionally or physically.
Though she chose not to indulge in the Jacuzzi, she said she had the greatest luxury of all in the beautiful room: having her husband and the midwives there -- sometimes actually on the bed with her -- helping to bring Kevin into the world.
"I will tell everyone, all my friends, it was so wonderful," said Mrs. Masaquiza, embracing in turn all the nurses and the midwives who had been by her side, and putting a glint in the eyes of Pam McDonnell, the hospital's head of publicity.
"Can we put that in an ad?" she asked.

He also ordered 40 more planes to the Persian Gulf, including bombers and attack fighters. And he warned that some diplomatic efforts were misguided. 6

Brazilian Chooses Austerity

Tremors for Indonesia

HEADLINE: Economic Troubles Back Home Squeeze Asian Students in U.S.

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
The surprise economics lesson came straight from home in the form of panicked telephone calls and televised images of the sagging, dispirited faces of the rich and powerful.
As the won, ringgit, rupiah and baht -- the currencies of South Korea, Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand -- fell hard over several months, students from those countries studying in the United States suddenly saw the value of bank accounts halved, parents thrown out of work, family businesses dissolved. 
 A number of students have merely toned down spending habits that had been fed by boom times back home. But others are struggling to stay in the United States, where they have found a broader range of programs in technology, business, science and the arts in a less stringent teaching atmosphere than back home.
They are taking on two or three roommates to help pay the rent. Some have illegally taken jobs in restaurants and stores -- foreign undergraduates on student visas are not permitted to work -- to help pay tuition and other expenses. A few never returned to class after winter break because families summoned them home, while many of those who stay fear the same fate.
Yusung Hwang, an architecture student from South Korea, learned in December that his father's construction company had gone bankrupt at the height of the financial crisis.
Mr. Hwang, 22, owes the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn $6,000, he said. Even though Pratt is allowing students to stretch out tuition payments, Mr. Hwang said he cannot count on money from home and will leave for South Korea next month unless he finds a way to pay off his debt.
"The situation is terrible now," he said. "I don't want to stop my education."
In less dire straits but almost as anxious, Yoon Nam, 22, a communications major at New York University, has stopped buying new clothes, rarely goes to the movies and cooks her meals at home now: sacrifices she says have muted the New York experience she craved.
"My mom told me maybe I should marry somebody with a green card so I could stay here and work here," said Ms. Nam, of South Korea, unaware that the wait for a legal residency card can take several years. "I want to help my family back home, but I don't want to end my dream of studying here."
To prevent an exodus to Asia, college administrators across the country have responded with special aid and breaks on tuition payment schedules.
In many cases, students have until the end of the semester to pay, with no late fees.
"It's been extraordinary, the response from local campuses," said Peggy Blumenthal, vice president of education services at the Institute for International Education, a private nonprofit group based in New York.
Leonard Pramudinatha, a 22-year-old graduate business student from Indonesia, got a break when the University of Denver deferred indefinitely the $6,000 quarterly tuition payments for students from the affected countries.
Mr. Pramudinatha said he had never worried about money before, but now he plans to seek money for groceries from a $20,000 fund that business school patrons set up to help Asian students with rent and food costs.
"God knows when this whole thing is going to get better," he said. "It's so scary."
Jimmie White, a lawyer for the Office of International Students and Scholars at the University of California in Los Angeles, said his office had given loans of up to $4,000 to about two dozen students from the affected countries.
He said that two graduate students -- one from South Korea and one from Japan -- had had to drop out of school because of money problems tied to the faltering stock and bond markets in those countries.
"They were sad about leaving," Mr. White said. "This was a major disruption of their studies, and they had a fear that they would not be able to come back."
Most institutions will not know the full effect of the crisis until final spring enrollment counts come in over the next few weeks. Most students arrived last fall with enough cash to pay their way through the spring semester, officials said.
But some officials worry about the fall semester, if students don't return from summer break and new recruits can't find the money for study in the United States.
"Colleges are feeling the impact both in students not returning and not in the pipeline," said Linda Heaney, president of Linden Educational Services, which organizes recruitment trips overseas. She estimated that 200 to 250 colleges and universities actively recruit in Asia, up from a handful 15 years ago.
"We're going to see enrollment from Asia ratchet down a bit," Ms. Heaney predicted.
Aside from diversifying a college's student populations, foreign students also provide revenue for campuses and the cities where they are situated, contributing $7 billion to the national economy, according to the institute. Two-thirds of the students pay their own way entirely, with the rest on scholarships provided by their governments or by corporations in their homelands, the institute said. Fewer than one percent receive financial aid under United States Government-sponsored plans.
At least two foreign governments are rolling back the number of students they sponsor in this country.
The Thai Government had sent 200 to 300 students a semester, mainly to study engineering, computer science and medicine. But for the spring semester this year only 40 will be sponsored, and it is uncertain if the program will continue beyond that, said Chamnong Sangmahachai, the minister counselor of education affairs at the Thai Embassy in Washington.
Malaysia last year sent almost 500 students for a range of study, but this year that number will go down to about 140, mainly for business training, said an education official at the Malaysian Embassy.
Officials at the South Korean and Indonesian Embassies said that no decision had been made on cutting back the number of government-sponsored students.
South Korea, Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia account for almost a third of the 457,984 foreign students studying in the United States, according to the Institute for International Education. South Korea, with 37,130 students, sends the third-highest number of students, behind Japan and China. Malaysia (14,527 students) is seventh, Thailand (13,481) eighth and Indonesia (12,461) ninth.
International students account for a significant portion of the student population at many schools. Boston University has the most foreign students (4,657, or 15.7 percent of its total enrollment), followed by New York University (4,491, or 12.5 percent) and the University of Southern California (4,183, or 15.2 percent), according to the Institute for International Education. Columbia University ranked fifth, with 3,807 students (18.8 percent.)
At New York University, which has 660 students from South Korea, 35 from Indonesia, 25 from Thailand and 24 from Malaysia, officials have seen some students "for whom there is an immediate crisis," said Gail Szenes, director of international students. A few have taken a leave of absence, she said, while others are arranging delayed tuition payments with the university on a case-by-case basis.
Likewise, Columbia University has offered small loans to tide students over, said Richard B. Tudisco, associate provost and director of the international students and scholars office.
Nevertheless, schools generally are not dependent on one group of students. Although officials said they regretted the students' hardship, the institutions are "not going to be decimated if one sending country drops off for a while," one administrator said.
John Pearson, director of the Bechtel International Center at Stanford University, said the Asian students' predicament recalled the wave of students who rode in on OPEC's wealth and rode out when economic and political tides shifted.
Not so many years ago, there were 45,000 students from Iran in the United States and virtually none from China; now those figures have nearly reversed.
And some colleges and universities said they were unprepared to dole out much aid.
Jerry Wilcox, director of international students at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., where annual tuition and living expenses can reach $30,000, said: "Cornell does not have the wherewithal to go in and rescue a lot of people. The students really have to ask their parents what's up."
Some students, mainly at the graduate level, are managing well. Graduate students on a student visa are allowed to hold academic-related jobs, like teaching or serving as research assistants.
"You have to realize that the good graduate students are like blue-chip football linemen," said Jerry McTier, director of student financial aid programs at Georgia Tech. "They're sought after by many colleges and they're offered very attractive financial packages. So they're not financially dependent on money from home."
Indeed, Paulus Kristanto, a doctorate candidate in industrial engineering at Georgia Tech, said the financial crisis at home in Indonesia had not caused him much grief.
"I have a job as a research assistant here, so I'm not affected at the moment," Mr. Kristanto said. "Of course we are always concerned about the situation down there."
Other students, who thought they were financially secure on corporate sponsorships, learned otherwise.
Three of four South Korean students in the graduate program at Emory University's Goizueta Business School in Atlanta have been forced by their sponsor, the South Korean-based electronics giant Samsung, to return home.
"We had four students in the program," said Julie Barefoot, admissions director for the business school. "One of them was very close to finishing his degree and he was allowed to stay. The other three were just starting and they were told to come home. It's really a shame because they were wonderful students and a real asset to the school."
And those trying to make it only on family money see a more austere future.
Eun Min, 23, a New York University senior from South Korea, gave up her student meal plan, which was costing $4,000 a semester, canceled a Rome vacation, and buys only used or bargain books, she said. Formerly a regular diner at Greenwich Village restaurants, she now eats at home.
"I cook egg salad sandwiches and noodles," she said.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THE NEW YORK STROLL;
Live . . . From 125th Street

BYLINE: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
125th Street is not what it used to be and many people would agree that is good news.
 While the eastern end of 125th near the Triboro Bridge is still quite rundown, and the western end, past Morningside Avenue, by the Grant housing projects is largely ignored, the street that is the commercial artery of Harlem has experienced a kind of a renaissance. 
 Within the last five years, many new businesses have moved in and the area has been cleaned up. Large retail chains, like Duane Reade, Blockbuster, the Body Shop and Portabella, now dot the landscape.
 The street is also part of an Empowerment Zone created by Congress in 1993. Loans and grants totaling $300 million, as well as $250 million in tax credits, have become available to stimulate the economy.
 The sidewalks themselves, while crowded, are less congested than a couple of years ago because many of the street vendors that were a ubiquitous presence have been pushed out. New construction, particularly east of Fifth Avenue, signals that development and rehabilitation are continuing.
 Despite these changes, the street has not been completely transformed. It retains a great deal of its history and distinctiveness, from the names on the streets it intersects to the aromas of the sweet potato pies eminating from its bakeries.
 It also retains some of the marks of its recent problems. Many old and architecturally beautiful buildings are boarded up and damaged, a sign there is still much to do. In addition, some major projects, like the International Trade Center, have fallen through, while others, like the huge Harlem USA development, have often been postponed.
 But many are buoyed by the general direction things are going in.
 Barbara Askins, executive director of the 125th Street Business Improvement District which was founded in 1994, said: "Everyone is saying that the renaissance is coming. I think that's going to take some time. But is it happening? I say yes."
 Here is a guide to some of the places on 125th Street. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Remedial Students Play An Integral Part at CUNY

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
In his budget address last month, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani portrayed the community colleges of the City University of New York as squandering their resources on teaching basic skills to students who are not ready for college and urged that those students be sent to privately run remedial programs so that CUNY could concentrate on delivering better college educations.
But even though CUNY officials promised this week to try to address the Mayor's concerns, they said that getting rid of students in remedial classes would be so costly and would so deplete the university that its ability to educate the students who remain would be hampered. 
 Not only do remedial students make up a significant portion of CUNY's enrollment, but remedial classes are a vital source of revenue for the university, the officials said.
"A precipitous reduction in the number of students could have a really devastating effect on the whole university," said Christoph M. Kimmich, CUNY's interim Chancellor. "If we are to be serious about addressing the issues the Mayor wants us to address, the city and state would have to help us deal with them.
"If we could separate the budgetary support from the remedial questions, we could have a better idea of what our role should be and what should be done," he added.
The Mayor's office said it did not have an immediate solution, but seemed to leave open the possibility of some help. "This is a plan in its formative stages," said Colleen Roche, the Mayor's press secretary. "All that is to be worked out."
There is a lot to work out. To remove all remedial students would leave a gaping hole, because 14 percent of the classes at CUNY's six community colleges are remedial and about 33 percent of the approximately 65,000 students take at least one remedial class. Even removing the weakest remedial students -- for instance, the ones who fail all three of CUNY's placement examinations, in reading, writing and mathematics -- would leave a large gap. In 1996, for example, about 37 percent of the community college freshmen -- more than 5,500 students -- failed all three of the exams.
What is more, the remedial programs that the Mayor wants to privatize are not an economic drain but actually subsidize more costly programs. Excluding remedial students would not only reduce the colleges' total budgets, but it would cut the money available for more expensive courses like nursing and science.
"The remedial courses help offset our higher-cost programs," Kurt R. Schmeller, president of Queensborough Community College, told a CUNY trustee committee on remediation Wednesday. "This is a very big issue."
Nor is Queensborough unusual. Although the exact figures are hard to pin down, the pattern appears to be the same at CUNY's other community colleges as well as nationally.
"There is no question that remediation costs less everywhere," said Henry M. Levin, a professor of economics and education at Stanford University and a visiting professor at Columbia Teachers College.
The reasons are not mysterious. Dr. Levin and others point out that remedial courses in reading, writing and mathematics are usually taught by adjunct professors or graduate students with low pay. Fancy equipment is rarely used and class sizes are usually large.
Remedial classes cost less, but just as important, students who take them pay the same tuition as other students, and the colleges receive the same government aid for these students as for others.
Tuition for local students is $2,500 a year, and the colleges get $1,900 a year in state aid for each student. (Ironically, under state law, that aid would be cut by $400 per student if the colleges no longer offered open admission.) City aid, which is not tied as directly to enrollment, amounts to about $1,200 a student, bringing the average revenue per student to about $5,600.
It is money the colleges count on.
"Our solvency depends on having some lower-cost programs," Dr. Schmeller said.
Remedial education is not the only low-cost program at colleges. Liberal arts courses like English and history cost less than science and engineering classes that require special equipment, or professional training programs like nursing or teaching that require close supervision of students.
Even though the remedial students pay their own way, the colleges have long struggled to balance their needs and those of other students. As an urban university, CUNY receives many poorly educated high school graduates and many immigrants who speak little or no English, and remedial programs play a significant role on most of its campuses.
At the community colleges, which offer admission to anyone with a high school diploma or the equivalent, 86 percent of last fall's entering students failed at least one placement test, and 63 percent failed all three. Some students need a little brushing up to be ready for college-level work. Others need extensive tutoring in basic skills.
Despite his reservations about the financial implications of the Mayor's proposals, Dr. Kimmich said the university is looking more carefully at the students who do not succeed, and should see whether there are better alternatives to offer them.
Even though the money is there to support them, he said, "what troubles me is that it is a demoralizing experience for them, for their instructors, and for the institution at large."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 10, 1998, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about remedial students at the City University of New York misstated the percentage of incoming students at the community colleges who fail all three of the system's placement examinations. It is 33 percent, not 67.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Laid Off? Dismissed? To Sue or Not to Sue

BYLINE: By DEBORAH L. JACOBS 

 BODY:
AS if getting laid off wasn't bad enough, a growing number of workers have an extra-tough decision to make on their way out the door: whether to forever give up their right to sue the boss. Those who do can walk away with a sweet deal. Those who don't gamble that they'll be better off in the long run.
Consider the case of Paul C. Bevan, a former marketing director for Honeywell Inc. in Minneapolis, who was replaced by a younger man and laid off in 1992. At the time, Honeywell offered Mr. Bevan $273,000 if he would release the company from any legal claims. Mr. Bevan, who was 52 and had been with the company for 24 years, refused to sign the release. Honeywell then reduced the severance package to about $60,000, he said. 
 Soon after the layoff, Mr. Bevan sued Honeywell, contending age discrimination. His five-year battle ended last summer when the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit upheld a jury verdict in his favor. The award, including interest and legal fees, was more than $900,000, he said. Honeywell declined to comment beyond a statement saying it had a "corporate-wide policy" against discrimination.
In asking for a release, or waiver, companies want to rule out trouble down the line -- discrimination cases based on race, sex or age. A waiver is "almost standard operating procedure whenever severance is given out," said Janice Goodman, an employment lawyer in Manhattan.
Courts have said these waivers are legal as long as they are given voluntarily for "adequate" consideration. That usually means anything more than an employee would otherwise be entitled to, Ms. Goodman said. If the company does not normally give severance pay, which is not required by law, a worker may need to sign the release to get anything at all.
In deciding whether a waiver is valid, the issue is not how much the company will pay but "the circumstances under which the waiver was obtained," Ms. Goodman said. Economic coercion -- withholding severance unless the waiver is signed -- is not illegal, she said, though how far a company can go has yet to be tested.
The key Federal law on waivers is the 1990 Older Workers Benefit Protection Act, which covers people older than 40. It says companies must give workers at least 21 days to decide whether to sign waivers and 45 days if a group of people is being terminated at one time. The waiver must let workers know that they are giving up the right to sue for age discrimination and must say that they have at least seven days after signing to change their minds.
When a release is part of a voluntary buyout or a program offered to a group of employees, the company must give more information, including selection criteria for the program and the "class, unit, or group of individuals covered"; the job titles and ages of the people selected, and the ages of people "in the same job classification or organizational unit" who are not eligible.
Until recently, it was not clear whether workers who sign invalid waivers must return the severance money if they sue. Last month, the Supreme Court said they did not.
That case involved Dolores Oubre, a former scheduler at a nuclear power plant in Killona, La., run by a unit of the Entergy Corporation. After she received a poor performance review, Entergy offered her a choice in early 1995 of trying to improve or resigning and receiving $6,258 in severance pay. Entergy gave her 14 days to make the decision -- a week less than the law requires. Ms. Oubre, then 41, signed the waiver.
When she sued later, contending age discrimination, the company tried to get the case thrown out. Even if the waiver was invalid, it argued, the contract was binding because Ms. Oubre kept the money.
Two lower courts ruled in Entergy's favor, but the Supreme Court reversed the decision on Jan. 26. Ms. Oubre must still prove that she was dismissed because of her age.
While employment lawyers hailed the case as a victory for workers, they called the circumstances unusual. "Don't sign a release with the idea that you're going to be able to disavow it later," advised Wayne N. Outten, a New York lawyer who has helped negotiate thousands of severance agreements. A better course, he said, is to ask for as much time as you need to decide and to talk to a lawyer before giving up any rights.
Before pursuing legal action, of course, a key question is whether you have a good case. No matter how badly employees feel they have been treated, they do not have a claim unless it fits into some legal framework like discrimination, wrongful termination or violation of a law protecting whistle-blowers, said Gary Laturno, a San Diego employment lawyer. Even then, they should not count on hitting the jackpot.
Typically, workers just get back pay -- the salary and benefits they would have earned from the time of dismissal until a court decides the case. If an employee finds another job while pursuing the case, the award is cut by whatever the person has earned at the new job.
HARDER to predict is the effect on an employee's psyche, finances and career should the worker turn down the waiver and proceed with a lawsuit.
Six years after he was dismissed, Mr. Bevan is negotiating an agreement to license his own invention -- a device to create an undulating practice-putting surface for golfers. But he had a tough time finding new employment while his case against Honeywell was pending.
Ultimately, a former colleague helped him land a position in Boston as a branch manager for a company that makes fire alarm and building security systems. He resigned in January to spend more time marketing his invention.
Mr. Bevan said he did not regret suing, but "there's no calculation you could run that would show the return on investment was worthwhile."
Lawyers typically advise clients to try negotiating a better severance package before contemplating legal action. Those with the most bargaining power are high-level, long-term employees with a good case, said Nancy Erika Smith, an employment lawyer in West Orange, N.J. Often the company is willing to improve on its initial offer, she said.
One former vice president at a Midwestern advertising agency negotiated six months' salary and health benefits, instead of the three months of pay that was first offered. Other items that can ease a transition cost a company little, such as outplacement help, favorable references and the right to keep the company car or personal computer or to buy them for a nominal sum.
A lawyer need not handle the negotiations. One marketing executive laid off from a large consumer products company never let on that she had a lawyer coaching her behind the scenes. As the lawyer counseled, she met with a personnel representative, rather than accepting a telephone brush-off. Though she had been with the company less than a year, she persuaded it to pay three-and-a-half months' severance -- a month more than the company had offered.
Even after paying the lawyer, she figured she was $4,000 ahead. And, she said, she learned an important lesson. "Always attempt to negotiate before you accept the first thing they hand you," she said. "You have nothing to lose."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 15; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1002 words

HEADLINE: Anything but Ridicule

BYLINE: By Alan Ryan; Alan Ryan is the author of "John Dewey and the High Tide of American Liberalism."

DATELINE: OXFORD, England

 BODY:
As Prime Minister Tony Blair flew off to Washington to confer with President Clinton, English commentators fussed about the trip. Some worried that Britain would be dragged into an ill-advised war with Iraq. Many more feared that Mr. Blair would be made to look ridiculous by being forced to answer questions about the President and Monica Lewinsky.
After all, Yasir Arafat had recently sat through a news conference in which life and death on the West Bank had taken second place to sex in the Oval Office. Nobody wanted the British Prime Minister to suffer the same fate. 
 But the British need not have worried. Facing a question about the private lives of public figures, Mr. Blair was cool and poised, saying that he had been elected to think about "schools, hospitals, crime, living standards, jobs."
"What is essential is that we focus on the issues we were elected to focus upon," he said, while Mr. Clinton listened appreciatively.
All the same, Americans who feel embarrassed by the obsession with their President's private life might be reassured to know that here in Britain, the personal lives of public officials are still very much on view, even with the Tories out of power.
This week has seen a parliamentary row over Mr. Blair's Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, who fired his secretary last year and admitted that he had planned to replace her with his mistress.
Lord Irvine, the Lord Chancellor and a close friend of the Prime Minister's, has suggested that newspapers be prevented from discussing the extramarital activities of Government ministers.
While legally minded people fretted about "prior restraint," unkind observers noted that Lord Irvine's second wife had formerly been Mrs. Donald Dewar, the wife of a Cabinet colleague.
Whenever a politician's approval ratings lurch up and down and up again, when journalists first puff out their chests and announce in solemn tones that he has finally shown himself unfit to govern and then discover the public is unimpressed -- this is not as peculiarly American as the foreign press pretends.
It was five years ago that the unfortunate David Mellor, the National Heritage Minister in John Major's Conservative Government, lost his post because he had an affair with a young woman who sold her story to the tabloids. She revealed, among other things, that he was particularly attracted to her feet, a detail that particularly delighted the headline writers at the tabloids.
Mr. Mellor was sacked because John Major had nailed his Government's credibility to the defense of family values, and every journalist with blood in his veins took that as an invitation to catch the Tories in flagrante.
Did the public want David Mellor to go? Not in the least; he was and is very likable. But he had become too ridiculous to remain in office. If all we think about when we see a politician is what he does in bed, he is ruined.
This might seem to strike a frivolous note. Shouldn't we take a sterner view of politicians than that? When politicians make mistakes, they can seriously damage our health. It is not clear, however, that we should take so stern a view of their private sins. No one cares whether the chief executive of an automobile company commits adultery or not. So why should we care if the President of the United States does or not?
One answer is that all we want from the auto company is efficient cars at a reasonable price. Its employees may -- within the limits of the law -- do whatever they like on their own time. We might take the same view of our leaders. We want them to give us full employment, low taxes and low inflation. What they do in their spare time is their business.
Yes, that rings hollow. For there is another thing Americans want from the President: a public affirmation of the values by which the United States intends to live.
President Clinton gave precisely such an affirmation three years ago, with his eloquent and powerful response to the Oklahoma City bombing. After the Republican Congressional victories in 1994, he had seemed stricken with doubt and indecision. But his performance in Oklahoma City sharpened his focus and resolve, and his reputation rose rapidly and steadily.
The point is we can't be certain just what parts of a leader's private life hold the key to how he will behave in a political crisis, let alone how he will manage the country from day to day.
Tony Blair, who admires President Clinton so much that he has turned the Labor Party into a slightly less left-wing version of the Democrats, is forever saying to the British people, "Trust me." They do -- but they do it selectively. They trust him not to raise taxes, but they do not trust him to be kind to single mothers and the disabled. They would trust him no more and no less if they discovered he was having problems of the magnitude of President Clinton's.
 The marital problems of Foreign Secretary Robin Cook produced no popular demands for Mr. Cook's resignation. There is, however, near unanimity that it was tacky to tell his wife of 28 years that he was leaving her in the V.I.P. lounge at London's Heathrow Airport. Can the British bear to be represented by somebody tacky? If he doesn't become an international joke, and otherwise does his job properly, the answer is yes.
To some this will suggest that we have lost our moral bearings. If we cannot demand that our leaders be honest, chaste, brave and unselfish, what hope is there for democracy? To others, it will suggest only that we have begun to grow up and come to terms with the fact that politicians are -- at best -- flawed instruments of the public good.
Five hundred years ago, Machiavelli observed that the proper place for saints was in the convent, not the councils of state. The same is true today. We should be ruthless with leaders who weaken national defenses, steal from the public purse or subvert constitutions.
But we should not expect to like what we see when we peer into our rulers' souls.

HEADLINE: European Commission May Revoke Exemption for U.S. Movie Studios

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Europe's love-hate relationship with Hollywood veered back toward hostility last week, when a European Commission antitrust official moved to break up a joint distribution company here owned by three big American movie studios.
The attack infuriated the three studios -- Paramount, owned by Viacom Inc.; MCA, owned by the Seagram Company, and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer-United Artists -- which together account for as much as 20 percent of the box-office sales in Europe. 
 But the move also highlighted an important long-term change that has complicated the long-running European angst about the dominance of American entertainment.
Despite continued resentment in many quarters about the invasion of movies like Disney's "Hunchback of Notre Dame," European demand for Hollywood's output is soaring. Multiscreen suburban movie complexes have become a hit in many countries, and American releases account for as much of three-quarters of their revenues. American books, in translation, dominate the best-seller lists in most countries.
And the expansion of digital television has led to fierce bidding wars for pay-per-view broadcasting rights from American studios.
The trend is not accidental. The underlying direction of policy at the European Commission has moved toward forcing more open competition on every part of the economy -- media included. Torn between promoting national cultures and open markets, the much-maligned "Eurocrats" generally push for the latter. More often than not, American suppliers of entertainment have been big beneficiaries.
But the tensions are real. On Thursday, Europe's Minister of Competition, Karel van Miert, announced that he wanted to revoke an exemption that had been issued to United International Pictures, a European distribution company owned by Paramount, MCA and MGM.
UIP has been operating in Europe since 1989 under an exemption to a European law that prohibits any agreements that "potentially restrict competition."
UIP sells movies from the three studios to theaters around Europe, allowing the studios to save money by sharing the costs of a joint distribution organization. Hollywood's other big studios -- Disney, Warner Brothers and Twentieth Century Fox -- distribute their movies in Europe independently.
Mr. van Miert remained vague about his objections to UIP, but neither he nor other officials in Brussels have argued that the company did anything wrong. Rather, they say that Europe has simply not received much benefit.
A key issue, according to both industry and commission officials, is that UIP is not doing as much to promote European movie producers as they had hoped.
In winning its legal exemption in 1989, UIP agreed to distribute at least some movies from European studios. But officials close to Mr. van Miert said that nonstudio European movies accounted for only 1 percent of all the movies that UIP distributed. By contrast, they said, locally made movies in European countries accounted for 14 percent to 24 percent of box-office sales.
"Recently, we have come to the conclusion that we don't have to tolerate it," Mr. van Miert said on Thursday.
Commission officials quietly rebutted press reports on Friday that UIP was suspected of an anti-competitive practice known as block- booking. The term refers to a practice of forcing theaters to accept unpopular movies as a condition for getting the big hits.
On Friday, however, officials told reporters in Brussels that they had no evidence of block-booking. Rather, they emphasized the fact that UIP had done very little to distribute European movies that did not come from the three studios.
They also argue that the movie-theater industry has become more vibrant in the last several years, as entrepreneurs have built appealing complexes that offer moviegoers a big choice, big screens and big sound. Therefore, they said, the need to give UIP an exemption had diminished.
Brian Reilly, executive vice president of UIP, said his company would fight the decision on the grounds that the company had lived up to its end of the deal. Mr. Reilly said that European inspectors had raided several UIP offices in 1996, looking for evidence of anti-competitive behavior, but had made no accusations. He also said UIP had distributed 227 European movies since 1989, although he did not rebut European complaints that these movies accounted for only a minuscule share of its total box-office revenue.
"We agreed that we would make our distribution organization available for European products, contingent on our commercial judgment," he said. "We feel we have fully met our commitment."
If Mr. van Miert gets his way, the three Hollywood studios will have to set up separate distribution organizations. Mr. Reilly warned that this would greatly increase their costs, ultimately leading to higher ticket prices. UIP will have a chance to rebut Mr. van Miert's objections, but it will have a difficult time prevailing.
Over the longer term, Mr. van Miert's policies have clearly benefited American suppliers of entertainment. A tough-minded and powerful crusader against trade barriers within Europe, he has pushed relentlessly for competition in the growing field of digital television.
In Germany, he has raised objections to a potentially monopolistic alliance between Deutsche Telekom, the telephone and cable company, and the two most powerful media conglomerates, Kirch Group and Bertelsmann A.G.
In Spain, he has forced the Government to retreat from measures aimed at shoring up the power of a Government-backed media consortium at the expense of a competitor controlled by Grupo Prisa and Canal Plus S.A. of France. Those policies kicked off a brutal bidding war for rights from American studios last year that were ultimately sold for hundreds of millions of dollars.
The Brussels-based competition authorities are also carving new inroads in publishing. Several weeks ago, Mr. van Miert formally announced plans to challenge price-fixing practices among German and Austrian book sellers.
The practices have been defended as a protection for small publishers and local culture, because the higher prices theoretically allow bookstores to keep slow-moving titles on their shelves.
But Mr. van Miert is having none of it. If he prevails, and the local publishers are correct about the implications, publishers of John Grisham and Tom Clancy are likely to be among the winners.

HEADLINE: Plea Heeded For Meeting On Black Theater

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
In a provocative speech at a Theater Communications Group's conference at Princeton University in June 1996, August Wilson said that among the 66 regional theaters in the United States only one "can be considered black." He made an impassioned plea for the need to encourage black theater as a separate movement. "It is vibrant," Mr. Wilson, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, said about black theater. "It is vital."
"It just isn't funded," he said.
Mr. Wilson said it was time for black theater artists to come together "to address questions of esthetics and to defend ourselves from the naysayers." He assailed the critic Robert Brustein for his "presumption of inferiority of the work of minority artists." 
 Looking ahead, Mr. Wilson asked for a conference to be held in 1998 to deal with these and related issues and suggested that it take place in the South, which he referred to "as our ancestral homeland." The speech received a standing ovation. On the subject of a conference on black theater, however, there was silence, and when the response came to Mr. Wilson's call, it was not from a Southerner. It was from Dartmouth College.
At the instigation of two Dartmouth professors, Victor Leo Walker 2d and William W. Cook, the college decided to sponsor such a colloquium. After a year of preparation, a weeklong conference on issues confronting black theater in the United States is be held there next month, bringing together many of the most important playwrights, directors and producers in black theater as well as scholars, business executives, lawyers and representatives of foundations. Mr. Wilson is to deliver the keynote address.
In anticipation of the event, Mr. Wilson said, "as black Americans, we want to take an assessment of the state of black theater and lay the foundation for future progress and prosperity." For one thing, he said, "we need to go into communities and strengthen support groups."
After hearing Mr. Wilson's speech in 1996, Mr. Walker, an assistant professor of drama and film studies at Dartmouth, spoke to Mr. Wilson about the possibility of a follow-up meeting. None was immediately forthcoming, although that speech eventually led to a highly publicized debate between Mr. Wilson and Mr. Brustein at Town Hall in Manhattan in January 1997.
Mr. Walker said he felt even more strongly about initiating a conference after the Wilson-Brustein debate. In that encounter, moderated by Anna Deavere Smith, each man in effect accused the other of being elitist. The battle, Mr. Walker said, took the "shotgun approach," throwing many issues into the air, hoping that some would be hit. At Dartmouth, he indicated, the approach would be more specific and structured.
Ntozake Shange, Ed Bullins, Thulani Davis, Woodie King Jr., Ricardo Khan, Robbie McCauley, Clinton Turner Davis and Paul Carter Harrison are among the several dozen artists scheduled to participate. Sessions, closed to the public, will be held from March 2 to 6, to be followed by a one-day public meeting, "African American Theater: The Next Stage."
Panels will discuss economic as well as esthetic issues: audience and community development, fund-raising, marketing, legal and social initiatives and capital campaigns and also the nurturing of playwrights and multicultural aspects of black theater. After the meeting, the organizers plan to publish a book, arrange for future conferences and create an institute in collaboration with the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Darmouth. The conference is supported by the Rockefeller Foundation, Dartmouth and other organizations.
It was also at Mr. Walker's invitation that Mr. Wilson went to Dartmouth to teach playwriting this semester. In addition to his residency, the college offers undergraduates a course in Mr. Wilson's plays ("Ma Rainey's Black Bottom," "Fences" and "The Piano Lesson," among others).
The conference will be at the Dartmouth-run Minary Conference Center in Ashland, N.H. The public session, on March 7, will be held on the Dartmouth campus in Hanover, N.H. Mr. Walker said the Minary Center was in an area that "was a respite for runaway slaves on their way to Canada." He said that "symbolically this really works as a place for our meeting."

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Rose in December

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Domestic orders for machine tools rose in December, wrapping up 1997 with the fifth straight year of positive annual growth, an industry survey showed today.
Orders from American companies for domestic and foreign-produced machine tools jumped 15.1 percent, to an estimated $787.43 million in December, said a joint report from the Association for Manufacturing Technology and the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association. 
 December's gain in orders followed a revised 6.3 percent drop, to $684.09 million, in November.
For all of 1997, estimated orders for tools totaled $8.6 billion, up 24 percent, compared with 1996. December's estimated orders were up 32.6 percent from the $593.72 million estimated in December 1996.

HEADLINE: Microsoft Case May Be Prelude to a Wider Antitrust Battle

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The first round of the Microsoft Corporation's antitrust confrontation with the Government still has months to run, awaiting Federal court decisions. But a second round has already begun -- the discussion, debate and negotiations about whether the Justice Department should file a broader Sherman Act case against Microsoft.
A sweeping case against Microsoft would be a landmark test of how the smokestack-era doctrine of antitrust applies to a high-technology industry. It would also likely be a lengthy, bitter courtroom battle and a step-by-step dissection of the business practices of the software powerhouse that dominates the personal computer industry. 
 Yet comments last week by a senior Justice Department official and the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee suggest that Washington would prefer to avoid a long-running, high-profile Sherman Act case, if possible. Specifically, they talked of agreeing on some ground rules of competition as computing migrates beyond the PC desktop, which Microsoft firmly controls, to the era of the Internet.
The issue, according to policy makers and economists, is to try to insure that Microsoft's near-monopoly of PC operating- system software is not used to exercise what antitrust experts call "chokehold control" over the new markets of Internet software and Internet commerce.
The company's current size, wealth and market share, they emphasize, are not concerns. But the goal of antitrust policy, they add, should be to make sure that the door is open in the Internet markets for the "next Microsoft," a newcomer rising to unseat the industry leaders by dint of business skill, innovation and luck.
Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, the Republican chairman of the Judiciary Committee, warned on Thursday that antitrust scrutiny of Microsoft was preferable to more heavy-handed Government intervention along the lines of an "Internet Commerce Commission."
After his speech before a seminar on antitrust and Microsoft, sponsored by the conservative Progress and Freedom Foundation, Senator Hatch said, "I would suggest to Microsoft and all its competitors that we should be working together to develop a set of antitrust principles for this digital age."
Within the Justice Department, there is a similar sentiment. If Microsoft were willing to agree to "certain principles of openness" a senior Justice Department official said, the accommodation would "go a long way toward getting us off the company's back."
The official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, emphasized that he was not suggesting that Microsoft -- no matter what it did -- could expect to be exempt from continuous antitrust scrutiny. And he said the Justice Department was continuing to assemble evidence that could lead it to file a case under Section 2 of the Sherman Act, which prohibits anticompetitive practices that maintain and extend a monopolist's reach.
Yet the Justice Department official observed that most antitrust investigations tend to combine adversarial relations between the Government and a company along with a "continuing dialogue" between the two sides.
An agreement by Microsoft to discuss ground rules of competition, he said, could be a step toward reopening the "dialogue" element of the Government's dealings with Microsoft. He declined to discuss in detail what areas the Government would want to cover in such principles.
But one area of antitrust concern, he said, would be licensing arrangements and the pricing of deals that Microsoft strikes both with computer companies and with banking, travel and media companies for placement on the front screen of its Windows operating system or its Internet Explorer browser.
The greatest benefits in terms of fostering innovation and competition, he said, would come from light-handed antitrust guidance early on, as Internet commerce is beginning to take off, rather than more Draconian enforcement later.
There are already ways for Government and companies to devise competitive ground rules jointly. The two Federal antitrust agencies, the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission, have issued guidelines in industries, like the health care business, and in fields of activity, like intellectual property.
Yet establishing these guidelines normally requires a lengthy process of public hearings and comment. A quicker way to deal with Microsoft, a senior Justice Department official said, might be to place in a "business review letter" those principles on which the Government and the company have reached agreement. These letters are typically written by the company under investigation in consultation with the Justice Department.
An industry trade group, the Software Publishers Association, weighed in last week with its own set of "competition principles." The trade group published its eight principles of competition after polling its membership and meeting with Joel I. Klein, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division.
Several of the principles are calls for nondiscriminatory licensing practices by an unnamed "owner of a dominant operating system" -- Microsoft, obviously.
A Microsoft spokesman, Greg Shaw, said the Software Publishers Association's principles were "a public relations stunt." The principles, he said, seemed to be mainly the work of some Microsoft rivals who are on the association's board.
But the association is the software industry's largest and oldest trade group, and Microsoft is its biggest single member, paying annual dues of $100,000. "We had no interest in excluding Microsoft and we didn't," said Ken Wasch, president of the association. "Our members think these are important issues."
Microsoft's senior management seems to be open to the notion of renewed talks with the Justice Department, but is wary. "We'd be willing to talk," Nathan Myhrvold, the chief technology officer and a member of the company's executive committee, said on Friday. "But there's a cynical view of the process of dealing with the Government that says throw them a bone and they'll go away. Our concern is that by doing that we would be taking one step down a road which could lead to all kinds of restrictions on our business."
Microsoft now finds itself in court because it chose to fight a seemingly modest curb on its business practices. Last October, the Justice Department sued Microsoft to stop the company from requiring PC makers to install its Internet Explorer browser as a condition of licensing its Windows operating system. The Justice Department contends that practice is a violation of Microsoft's 1995 consent decree, which prohibits tying one product's sale to another's.
Microsoft refused and went to court instead. The company points out that the consent decree allowed it to develop "integrated products." It insists that its Explorer browser is not a separate product but an integrated feature of its Windows operating system.
On Dec. 11, a Federal judge issued a preliminary injunction, ordering Microsoft to offer PC makers the choice of taking Windows without Explorer. Microsoft is appealing the ruling.

HEADLINE: Allan Grant, Farmers' Advocate, 91

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Allan Grant, a California rancher who started as a sharecropper and came to speak for millions of farm families as president of the American Farm Bureau Federation in the 1970's, died on Jan. 27 at Kaweah Delta Hospital in Visalia, Calif., where he made his home. He was 91.
Mr. Grant was president of the federation from 1976 to 1980 after 12 years as head of the California Farm Bureau. The federation has four million members among its 50 state affiliates and one affiliate in Puerto Rico. 
 Founded in 1919, the federation assesses farmers' problems and interests and lobbies for their causes. As president, Mr. Grant often voiced the group's generally conservative views on economic and political matters and gave national news briefings on the outlook for crops and prices.
Mr. Grant was born in Perry, Calif., and studied agricultural economics at Montana State College and the University of California at Los Angeles. He was working in the oil fields around San Diego to earn money for his college tuition when his father died in 1928. He dropped out of college to support his mother and younger siblings.
At age 22, Mr. Grant moved the family from Los Angeles to a farm in Visalia, in the lower San Joaquin Valley, where he leased land and milked cows as a sharecropper. He survived the Depression and a partner who absconded with the proceeds of their first crop.
Mr. Grant acquired about 2,000 acres of irrigated farmland and a herd of 600 dairy cows. He worked on a cattle ranch in Coarsegold, Calif., until he retired in 1985.
Mr. Grant was a vice president of the national farm federation for five years before he was elected president in 1976. He traveled widely to open overseas markets to American farm products and to speak on issues dealing with trade and international relations.
He was a leader of the Future Farmers of America and, in 1980, began raising Belgian draft horses as a hobby.
Mr. Grant's survivors include his wife of 65 years, Irene Chinowith Grant, two daughters, Joyce Greene of Coarsegold, and Margaret Petersen of Visalia; three sons, Murray, Edward and Robert, all of Visalia; 10 grandchildren, and 11 great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: A Look at Religion in China by 3 U.S. Clerics

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Feb. 8

 BODY:
A high-profile delegation of American religious figures began arriving in Beijing today for a three-week tour of China to examine the state of religious freedom here, one of the most volatile human rights issues in American diplomacy.
While it is being described as private, President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China agreed to the mission during their summit meeting in October, and the White House picked the three-man delegation: a prominent rabbi, an evangelical Protestant minister and a Roman Catholic archbishop. 
 The group will meet with officials and religious leaders in Beijing, Shanghai, Nanjing, Chengdu and Hong Kong. It has also been granted rare approval for a visit to Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, the remote mountain region where the Chinese are accused of repressing Buddhist religion and culture.
The Chinese and American Governments say they hope that the unusual dialogue will help defuse what has rapidly emerged as a popular human rights crusade, threatening their efforts to build friendlier political and economic ties.
In the United States, a vocal coalition drawing together evangelical Christians and other religious groups, human rights advocates and supporters of the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, wants stronger measures to combat what it describes as widespread persecution of Christians and Tibetan Buddhists in China.
It charges that China is engaged in a campaign of arrests and harassment intended to stamp out unapproved religious activity by millions of people including Catholics who give allegiance to the Vatican, certain Protestant groups and Buddhists who follow the Dalai Lama.
Legislation pending in Congress that would apply sanctions against countries deemed to engage in religious persecution has received the support of the Republican leadership but is opposed by the Clinton Administration.
The Chinese Government angrily rejects the charges of persecution. It says that some 14 million Protestants and Catholics worship in the state-approved churches and describes leaders of the so-called underground churches as criminal elements out to disrupt the social order.
In Tibet, China says, it acts against those trying to split apart the country.
The first American delegation member to arrive in Beijing today sought to hold down expectations, but he sees the trip as a vital chance to start a dialogue.
"This will be a very modest step, but it's a beginning," said Rabbi Arthur Schneier of Park East Synagogue in Manhattan, president of the Appeal of Conscience Foundation, a New York-based group that promotes religious tolerance around the world. The two other members are Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark, and the Rev. Don Argue, president of the National Association of Evangelicals.
"The fact that we are here shows a certain recognition on the part of the Chinese that this is an issue they have to face," Rabbi Schneier said.
Human rights campaigners generally welcomed the mission as a rare chance to engage the Chinese leadership, but some privately expressed concern that it could be used by China as a propaganda tool and urged the delegation to insist on private meetings with underground church leaders and to press for the release of jailed Christians and Tibetans. Rabbi Schneier said it would be imprudent to divulge the team's plans in advance, but he was confident that it would gain access to a wide range of views from China's Christian, Buddhist, Muslim and Taoist communities.
He said the group planned to issue a preliminary report on its findings in New York on March 5, when it will provide more information about its procedures and meetings.
The final itinerary and formal list of meetings are to be worked out with Chinese officials on Tuesday. Most of the officially scheduled meetings are likely to be with officials of Government-approved "patriotic" churches. The delegation's host is a Government group that will accompany it around the country, and all of its activities are certain to be intensely monitored by security agencies.
In its quest for dialogue, the group will confront a sharp difference in perspectives about the meaning of religious freedom. In a statement issued in October, China boasted of the country's diversity of religions and noted the recent surge in the number of Protestants and Catholics inside the official churches. It acknowledged that religion had been violently suppressed during the Cultural Revolution of 1966-76 but said the Government had restored religious freedom, which is guaranteed in the Constitution.
But the statement also said that "religion should be adapted to the society in which it is prevalent."
In China, still firmly governed by the Communist Party, the Government does not tolerate any organizations that give allegiance to outside authorities. So its official Catholic church, for example, explicitly rejects the idea -- central to Catholic teaching elsewhere -- that the Pope is the supreme leader of the church and has sole right, for example, to appoint bishops and cardinals.
In Tibet, too, China is combating the notion of a non-state allegiance. It has belatedly begun to support aspects of Tibetan culture but aims to wrench Buddhists away from their traditional leader, the Dalai Lama, who is described as an enemy of the country. The Government's October statement said that "no one in China is punished because of his or her religious belief." Human rights advocates paint a different picture, of repression that if anything may be rising.
In late 1993, Chinese officials stated that no "underground" Catholic priests or bishops were in so-called re-education camps or prison, said John Kamm, an American businessman and human rights campaigner. Currently, he said, several dozen Catholic leaders are incarcerated and efforts to stamp out church activities are constant.
"The situation for Catholics is as serious as it's been since the late 1970's," when the new era of economic reforms began in China, Mr. Kamm said.
The delegation members have said they will not conduct news conferences during their tour. China, which restricts travel by foreign reporters, has said it will not allow any to accompany the group to Tibet.
