HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Winter Shuffle: Who Went Where?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The hot topic of conversation heading into spring training a year ago was the economic binge of the Florida Marlins, who committed $89 million to six free agents in an effort to become a contender and lure fans back to their ball park. As the beginning of spring training loomed this past weekend, the Marlins were again a hot topic of conversation.
Baseball people, in fact, have not stopped talking about the Marlins, who last October won the World Series, then four days later began playing another sport -- demolition derby. 
 The Montreal Expos won no championships last season, but they were the Marlins' fiercest competition this winter in the race to see which team could downsize itself fastest and most severely.
Now comes the time for the Marlins and the Expos to see what they have left. It is also time for the Arizona Diamondbacks and the Tampa Bay Devil Rays to see what they have wrought. Baseball's 29th and 30th teams, the Diamondbacks and the Devil Rays have spent the way the Marlins did last winter, but neither expects to contend for a spot in the World Series this year. They just hope to be competitive.
"We're in a division with some pretty high payrolls; that's not going to make it easy," Larry Rothschild, manager of the American League East Devil Rays, said yesterday. Rothschild, who will send his pitchers and catchers onto the field for their first workout next Sunday, is one of two new managers who, as Jim Leyland's coaches, were part of the Marlins' wild experience last year. He was their pitching coach, and Jerry Manuel, the new manager of the Chicago White Sox, was their bench coach.
"It's still a pretty good team," Rothschild said of the Marlins' skeleton. "The pitching obviously will be the question mark. They still have a pretty good team on the field. They still have a pretty good lineup and they have one of the top managers in the game. I can't count them short."
Twelve members of the championship team have departed. Kevin Brown, the Marlins' No. 1 starting pitcher, will have his spring training this year with San Diego, beginning Saturday. Al Leiter, another of their starters, will be with the Mets, and Robb Nen, their closer, with San Francisco. Moises Alou, the Marlins' erstwhile left fielder, will be with Houston, and center fielder Devon White with Arizona.
The Marlins aren't finished. Sometime during spring training they could complete the transformation of their outfield by trading right fielder Gary Sheffield, maybe to the Mets.
The Expos shed four position players and one pitcher. The pitcher, Pedro Martinez, just happened to be the best in the National League last season and will start this year in Boston as the highest-paid player in baseball history. First baseman David Segui is with Seattle, second baseman Mike Lansing with Colorado, left fielder Henry Rodriguez with the Chicago Cubs and catcher Darrin Fletcher with Toronto.
The San Francisco Giants are another team that has lost some name players, all as free agents. Wilson Alvarez and Roberto Hernandez, two pitchers the Giants rented from the White Sox for two months, are with Rothschild in Tampa Bay; Rod Beck, their closer, moved to the Cubs after the Giants obtained Nen from the Marlins, and Jose Vizcaino is now the Los Angeles shortstop.
The Cleveland Indians weren't looking to downsize, but they nevertheless engineered their second major shuffle in two off seasons. Before last season, the Indians acquired third baseman Matt Williams and traded Kenny Lofton for Marquis Grissom and David Justice. Now they have shipped Williams to Arizona for another third baseman, Travis Fryman; sent Grissom to the National League Milwaukee Brewers for pitching help and brought back Lofton to play center field. They also, in effect, swapped starting pitchers, Orel Hershiser (now with the Giants) for Dwight Gooden (now not with the Yankees).
Williams represents a major part of the expenditure the Diamondbacks have made, committing $113 million to him, shortstop Jay Bell and pitchers Andy Benes and Willie Blair.
The Devil Rays have committed $78 million to six players, including Alvarez, Hernandez, Fred McGriff and Paul Sorrento.
The Braves traded McGriff, then snatched first baseman Andres Galarraga from the Rockies, from whom they also grabbed shortstop Walt Weiss, whose signing prompted Jeff Blauser to go to the Cubs.
Closers were on the move, too. Besides Beck, Nen and Hernandez, Randy Myers moved from Baltimore to Toronto, Dennis Eckersley from St. Louis to Boston and Jeff Brantley from Cincinnati to St. Louis.
For roster shuffles, though, the Yankees have probably come closest to the Marlins in numbers. The Yankees didn't downsize; they trimmed some decaying wood. Gooden has moved to Cleveland, Kenny Rogers to Oakland, Wade Boggs to Tampa Bay, Cecil Fielder to Anaheim, Charlie Hayes and Rey Sanchez to San Francisco, Mike Stanley and Pat Kelly to Toronto.
The Yankees have added two strong hitters, second baseman Chuck Knoblauch and designated hitter Chili Davis, and a light-hitting third baseman, Scott Brosius.
Their chief division rivals, the Orioles, have added a veteran hitter, Joe Carter, and a veteran pitcher, Doug Drabek.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Schools Face Tough Choice About Repairs

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
LATELY, it seems, hardly a day goes by -- O.K., maybe a week -- without some fresh disaster befalling a city school.
The brick facade of a Brooklyn high school collapses, crashing through a protective shed. Carbon monoxide seeps from the furnace of an elementary school in Queens, sickening dozens of students. A cinder block topples off a Brooklyn elementary school, killing a teen-age girl. 
 In one sense, the incidents are unrelated -- a set of freak accidents bunched together in time. But in another sense, they are very much connected. The city schools not only appear to be, but are collapsing.
Three years ago, a commission created by the Schools Chancellor issued a report on the physical condition of the city schools and predicted just the sort of calamities that have become almost commonplace in the last few weeks.
In a letter accompanying the report, the commission's chairman, Harold O. Levy, warned that the schools were "on the verge of a serious calamity" and credited "simple dumb luck" for the fact that there hadn't been more fatalities.
The commission's central finding was that while serious management problems persisted at the Board of Education, they were not the main cause of the schools' wretched condition. Rather, the falling roofs and crumbling masonry were the direct result of years and years of insufficient spending on routine repairs.
The funds devoted to maintaining the city's schools, the commission stated, were "grossly and devastatingly inadequate."
When the commission issued its report, almost no one questioned its findings. In fact, officials at the Board of Education praised the report for the clarity of its message.
Yet in the three years since, there has been almost no change in policy. Indeed, by some measures, the school system has reduced its spending on maintenance, adding more buildings without increasing its repair budget commensurately.
According to figures from the Mayor's Management Report, school maintenance spending per square foot over the last three years is, when adjusted for inflation, exactly equal to the average of the previous five.
And according to the calculations of the Independent Budget Office, the figure has actually been falling in recent years, to $3.34 per square foot last year from $3.64 in 1995.
Because of the complex way city schools are financed, the decision to spend -- or not to spend -- on maintenance is divided a half-dozen ways. Not only is the Board of Education responsible, but also the Mayor, the City Council, the Governor and both houses of the State Legislature.
 ASKED about maintenance spending for city schools, the chairman of the Assembly Education Committee, Steven Sanders, conceded that the recommendations of the Levy Commission had been largely ignored. He added, however, that the Assembly's top goal for the current session was to direct more money to school repairs, and he blamed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for not making the issue a priority for the city.
"When the Mayor wants to make his point known, he's extremely effective," Mr. Sanders said. "I defy people to find three quotes from the Mayor that talk about the desperate needs of the infrastructure."
For its part, the Giuliani administration pronounced itself blameless. The Mayor, according to his press secretary, Colleen Roche, does not have any control over how the Board of Education allocates its resources. Furthermore, Ms. Roche went on to note, "city tax-level spending on the schools is higher now than five years ago."
Finally, officials at the Board of Education said they simply had not had enough money to do any better, even though the board had asked for additional funds from both the city and state.
"Asking isn't necessarily getting," said the board's chief financial officer, Beverly Donohue.
Ms. Donohue went on to say that when money is "that tight," the Board puts a priority on instruction rather than upkeep for buildings. Which is, of course, precisely the sort of calculation, repeated over the decades, that explains the dangerous condition of the city's schools.

HEADLINE: Canadian Indians Win a Ruling Vindicating Their Oral History

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: KISPIOX, British Columbia, Feb. 3

 BODY:
In the early time, long ago, an Indian maiden was taken into the sky. When she came back to the land, the man who took her turned into a grizzly bear. Her three brothers searched for her but found the bear first and killed it without realizing that it was their sister's husband. They brought the skin to where the river calls back the salmon every year. The Gitxsan people have been in Kispiox ever since.
That, says a Gitxsan elder, Alvin Weget, is the history of his people and their relationship to this breathtaking land of sky-high mountains. It is preserved on a towering cedar totem pole and in stories that Gitxsan elders first told hundreds of years ago. 
 And according to a recent ruling by the Supreme Court of Canada, that story is now legally binding evidence that can be used, along with other histories, to support Gitxsan claims to as much as 22,000 square miles of British Columbia's remote interior. Claims by other Indian groups cover all of the province's nearly 600,000 square miles.
By essentially validating Indian claims to land even where no treaties or titles exist, the ruling -- in a case started by the Gitxsan (pronounced GIT-san) and their neighbors, the Wetsuweten (pronounced WET-soo-wet-en) -- may redefine how government deals with Indians across Canada.
With other recent actions, including the Canadian Government's historic apology to native peoples for 150 years of paternalistic and sometimes racist treatment, the court's ruling seems to reflect a sharp shift in attitudes. It is driven as much by politics and a muscle-flexing court as by statistics indicating that Canada could be sitting on a demographic time bomb.
By any measure, the country's 1.3 million indigenous people -- about 5 percent of the population -- are much poorer, sicker and socially troubled than non-natives. They are also, on the whole, much younger, and their population is growing twice as fast.
"Nobody can look at the reality facing aboriginal people in Canada and not feel that something has to be done to put things back in balance," said Indian Affairs Minister Jane Stewart. "The status quo is not acceptable."
Ms. Stewart said she had a much better relationship than her predecessors with Indian leaders, making compromise possible. She also cited public opinion polls indicating that Canadians think Indians have gotten a raw deal and want something done quickly to help them.
But while such attitudes dominate in eastern cities, here in the west, where there are more indigenous people and the impact of land claims and self-government initiatives have immediate impact, things look different.
"Supreme Surrender" is the title of a recent article that sums up western attitudes about the Supreme Court ruling, handed down on Dec. 11, in the magazine The Western Report.
Mike Scott, an opposition Member of Parliament with the conservative Reform Party from British Columbia, said, "This whole thing is foolish, ill advised and downright irresponsible." He accused the Liberal Government of Prime Minister Jean Chretien of taking politically correct positions "without the foggiest notion of what this entails."
Like many others here, Mr. Scott is worried that the court's decision undermines British Columbia's control over the 95 percent of the province that is publicly owned. The justices basically rejected the province's long-held position that Indian claims to the land were extinguished when British Columbia became a province in 1871.
They also fear that uncertainty over who legally controls the land will undermine land-use decisions and threaten British Columbia's timber and mining industries.
In the six weeks since the ruling, industry leaders say, no logging contracts have been revoked, but there is a ground swell of uncertainty and fear about the impact of the ruling.
"What was uncertain before," Mr. Scott said, "becomes disastrous now."
Already, other native groups across Canada have interrupted treaty negotiations to consider how the ruling affects them. Last weekend, Indian leaders from British Columbia met with federal and provincial leaders and demanded a 60-day moratorium on all timber cutting and mining permits to give them time to apply the court ruling.
The Gitsxan here argued that as protectors of the large territory over which they have historically ranged, they should have the right not only to use the land in traditional ways like hunting and fishing, but also to take part in decisions on granting timber licenses and mining concessions and any other way the land is used.
Some 5,000 Gitxsan now live on scattered reserve land that totals less than 40 square miles. With unemployment among them approaching 90 percent, they also want to use the territory as a resource base.
They expect to receive royalties or compensation on timber, mineral and other resources they allow to be taken from here. They say they are willing to share those resources with the 20,000 non-natives who live in the territory.
The 3,500 Wetsuweten live just south of the Gitxsan on reserve land that is even smaller and more spread out.
Treaty negotiations have been going on throughout Canada for much of the last 30 years, but the Gitsxan case was an important exception to most treaty negotiations. While 46 other Indian groups in British Columbia focused on the provincial government's treaty process, Gitxsan and Wetsuweten leaders refused to accept ownership of a part of traditional lands and monetary compensation for an agreement to surrender claim to the rest.
"We were not interested in that," said Don Ryan, chief negotiator of the Gitxsan. Along with the Wetsuweten, the Gitsxan claimed what amounts to co-ownership with the province of a vast area of mountain range, salmon streams and timberland.
The case began in the early 1980's, and the provincial courts ruled against the Indians. The provincial Chief Justice, Allen McEachern, infuriated them by concluding that the oral histories presented in court by the elders were too contradictory to stand as evidence.
When the case was appealed to the Supreme Court, the Gitxsan and Wetsuweten separated their claims. The province was confident that it would win. In hearing the case last June, the Supreme Court did not allow the elders to recite their songs and histories in the courtroom. But after reviewing the testimony of the earlier trial, the justices brushed aside longstanding rules of evidence, deciding that uncorroborated oral histories have the same weight as documentary evidence.
"The law of evidence must be adapted in order that this type of evidence can be accommodated and placed on an equal footing with the types of historical evidence the courts are familiar with," the justices ruled.
Herb George, who headed the legal team for the Wetsuweten, said Indian strategy had fundamentally changed when the case went before the high court. Instead of claiming ownership in the traditional fee-simple way that most Canadians own their homes, native claim was defined as a kind of overlay on Government sovereignty.
"If you put one hand out and that represents the underlying title of the crown, and then put your other hand on top of it, that is the aborignal claim," Mr. George explained. "In order for crown to express itself, it will have to go through us."
The top court overruled the lower court but stopped short of granting absolute title and self-government to the Indians. Either a new trial or a new round of negotiations is needed to resolve the issue.
On Jan. 31 the Gitxsan people gathered here in Kispiox to celebrate the ruling with dance, song and a feast of a type that had been outlawed until 1951. They gathered in the community center here and listened once again to the elders retelling how their leaders got the white people to recognize their laws.
"What evidence did we have to show them this land was ours?" asked Neil Sterritt Sr., addressing the group in what may someday be another oral history. "There are the names of the territory, the names of the streams, the names of the mountain peaks. This took thousands and thousands of years. These are our boundaries. You could not fake them."
Led by Mr. Sterritt's son, Neil Jr., the Gitxsan have meticulously recorded the ancient tales that told of great birds leading the people to new settlement as the big ice of the glaciers receded. They wrote out the history of how the enraged giant grizzly destroyed the founding village of Temlaham by thrashing in the river and sending up a huge foaming wave that swept everything away.
In that instance, they even brought in geologists and botanists to search for historic concurrence. They drilled deep core samples and found evidence that a monumental mud slide leveled the area about 3,500 years ago, placing the event within the time frame of Gitsxan habitation.
The Supreme Court's acceptance of the oral histories was a bold act of judicial activism in a country accustomed to seeing its Parliament, not its top court, effect such legal changes. The justices encouraged the provincial government and the Gitxsan to settle the issue through negotiation, but Mr. Ryan, the Gitxsan negotiatior, said he doubted that the province would act unless the courts forced it to do so.
Whether they return to court or not, the Gitxsan see the ruling as recognition of their history, validation of their laws and acknowledgement of their ancient way of life.
This is not the first time two so very different cultures with foreign concepts of time and history have met in this place. After deciphering the totem pole that relates the story of Kispiox, Mr. Weget, the tribal elder, accompanied visitors to the village cemetery. There he pointed out a marble headstone he discovered years ago, almost completely buried in dirt and debris.
It is for a Chief Alexander Kit-Lu-Dalthque. The stone and its base bear no dates. But they were clearly carved by non-native craftsmen. And the eulogy, too, has unmistakably come from a non-Gitxsan source, lost in early time: "His end was peace," read the words carved in stone.
"His ancestors were the discoverers of Kispiox," says the stone, which then embraces an imprecise view of history more suited to a totem pole by adding, "hundreds of years ago."

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: THE OVERVIEW;
U.S. WILL NOT ASK TO USE SAUDI BASES FOR A RAID ON IRAQ

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 8

 BODY:
With Saudi Arabia showing deep reluctance to support a military strike on Iraq, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said today that he would not seek permission to launch American fighters and bombers from Saudi territory.
Mr. Cohen's decision not to ask for the use of more than 100 American aircraft now based in Saudi Arabia -- half of them combat jets -- allows the United States to avoid the political embarrassment of having a request turned down by a key ally. 
 The Saudis' stance, though, undercuts the Clinton Administration's efforts to build political support for a punitive attack in the confrontation over United Nations inspections of Iraq's chemical and biological weapons programs.
Mr. Cohen said just last week that he expected "full cooperation" from allies in the Persian Gulf. Of America's European allies, only Britain has so far pledged to join an attack.
As he arrived here tonight to begin a tour of Persian Gulf states, Mr. Cohen said the commander of American forces in the region, Gen. Anthony C. Zinni of the Marines, had concluded that a "very substantial" attack could still be carried out even without receiving approval to use the aircraft based in Saudi Arabia.
"It's not my intent to make such a request," Mr. Cohen said in an interview with reporters en route to Jidda, "because we don't think it's necessary."
Whatever the necessity, however, a senior aide traveling with Mr. Cohen said the United States had concluded that Saudi Arabia would say no to any request to launch combat jets from its territory.
Saudi Arabia is one of the United States' closest Arab allies and a major regional power. During the Persian Gulf war, Saudi Arabia provided a crucial base for the 500,000 American and allied troops that ultimately routed Iraqi forces occupying Kuwait in 1991.
But without the violent occupation of another Arab state as justification for an attack, and with many Arabs sympathetic to the plight of Iraqis after seven years of economic sanctions, Saudi Arabia has found the idea of another round of strikes on Iraq unacceptable.
The developments added significance to Mr. Cohen's order, signed on Saturday, sending 42 more aircraft to the Persian Gulf. That brings the total in the region to well above 300. Most of the new aircraft are going to Kuwait and Bahrain, two gulf countries that have signaled a willingness to allow an attack from their territory.
The United States will send six more F-117 "stealth" fighters to the region, doubling the number based there since the crisis with Iraq flared again last fall. Another B-1 will join a pair of the heavy bombers in Bahrain. Mr. Cohen also sent six more B-52's to Diego Garcia, a British island in the Indian Ocean that has a major American base, raising to 14 the total number of B-52's there.
All of those -- along with cruise missiles and fighters already in Kuwait and Bahrain, as well as those aboard American aircraft carriers now plying the Persian Gulf -- would be even more essential to any attack.
Mr. Cohen also left open the possibility that some American aircraft based at Prince Sultan Air Base southeast of the Saudi capital, Riyadh, could provide support for fighters launched from Kuwait, Bahrain and the carriers. Those aircraft could include Awacs surveillance and communication jets and tankers for mid-air refueling.
Another official traveling in Mr. Cohen's party said those requests remained under discussion. The senior defense official said it was likely that Saudi Arabia would allow American bombers based elsewhere to fly over Saudi airspace, though that was not yet settled.
Mr. Cohen also noted that Saudi Arabia would continue to allow American and a few British and French jets to patrol the "no flight" zone over southern Iraq. "We do expect support in the region itself, and we would hope the Saudis would continue to be as helpful as they have been," he said.
But even as Mr. Cohen arrived here for talks with King Fahd and other leaders, the Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, declared the kingdom's strong opposition to an attack by the United States and Britain.
"We do not favor striking Iraq as a people and as a nation," the Prince was widely quoted as saying in Saudi news reports today.
Mr. Cohen said the remarks did not signal a widening split between the United States and Saudi Arabia. He noted that Prince Sultan also called on Iraq to comply with United Nations resolutions providing for weapons inspections and expressed support for a diplomatic resolution.
"I think most people think a military option is not the preferable option," he said. "We have said that ourselves."
Administration officials said today that President Clinton called King Fahd on Saturday, and that the two leaders spoke for seven minutes. In that conversation, officials said, the President did not ask for the use of Saudi bases to launch attacks against Iraq, but Mr. Clinton did stress the "urgency of the situation."
Mr. Cohen arrived in Saudi Arabia after spending the weekend in Munich, Germany, attending an annual conference on European security matters. The conference was overshadowed by the looming conflict with Iraq. Earlier today, Mr. Cohen largely departed from a prepared speech on the future of NATO to make an impassioned case against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
"Let me say to all of our friends who are here, especially our Russian friends," Mr. Cohen said, alluding to Russia's efforts to forge a diplomatic solution to the confrontation with Iraq, "If Saddam Hussein has nothing to hide, he has nothing to fear."
Mr. Cohen also held talks with Israel's Minister of Defense, Yitzhak Mordechai, who flew to Munich specifically for the meeting, which was not previously publicized. The two men met for more than an hour aboard Mr. Cohen's plane, an E-4B command aircraft, as it sat on the runway at Munich's airport.
Mr. Cohen expressed strong support for Israel and pledged to review its requests for additional materiel to defend itself from a chemical or biological attack by Iraq.
In an interview last week, Mr. Cohen urged Israel to refrain from retaliating in the event of an attack, including one like Iraq's missile strikes during the Gulf war. Today, his tone shifted significantly.
"Israel obviously has the right of self-defense and will exercise that right of self-defense as they see fit," he said.
The Pentagon's military strategists have drafted a series of plans for bombing campaigns against Iraq, including some that assumed that Saudi Arabia would not give permission to use its territory, officials have said. The targets evidently include bases belonging to Iraq's powerful Republican Guard, military command centers and suspected weapons factories or stockpiles.
Even without the use of the Saudi bases, according to officials at the Pentagon, the United States, with Britain, can still launch a substantial strike from the other bases in the region, as well as the aircraft carriers plying the Persian Gulf.
"The loss of those resources would be felt," a senior defense official said last week, "but that does not in any way mean the objective could not be met."
There are 50 United States combat aircraft at bases in Saudi Arabia enforcing the "no flight" zone in Iraq. Those planes are flown by pilots who have great familiarity with the terrain and possible targets in Iraq. But Pentagon planners could still call on 250 other American combat aircraft in the region.
The United States also has two aircraft carriers in the Gulf, the George Washington and the Independence. A third carrier, the Nimitz, left the gulf today. Mr. Cohen announced on Saturday that he would order the Nimitz, which arrived in the gulf last October, to return to the United States before March 1, as scheduled.

HEADLINE: Indians' New Money Buys Lobbying Power

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Five short years ago, a lobbying excursion to Congress for the Oneida Indians of central New York went something like this: Tribal officials would pile into an old car, endure the eight-hour drive to Washington, sleep on a friend's floor and dine on peanut butter sandwiches, all for the chance to catch some Congressional aide on the fly.
How quaintly remote all that now seems to the Oneidas who flew into Washington last week, stayed four nights in a first-class hotel, co-sponsored a splashy reception for two dozen members of Congress and brought along two lobbyists, a tax lawyer and a publicist to their meetings on the Hill. 
 "We're a bit more sophisticated these days," said Keller George, a member of the Oneidas' ruling council.
A bit more wealthy, too.
Flush with huge gambling profits, tribes like the Oneidas have undergone political makeovers in Washington, where they are using high-priced lobbyists, savvy public relations firms and big campaign contributions to win influence, make friends and crush opponents.
Last week, the Oneidas were one of nearly two dozen tribes from along the Eastern Seaboard and as far west as Texas who flew to Washington for a week of lobbying and political power building. As a sign of their influence, their advocacy association, the United South and Eastern Tribes, drew not only members of Congress to their events, but also the Interior Secretary, Bruce Babbitt, and Attorney General Janet Reno, who electrified the crowd by saying she opposed taxing Indian casinos.
Indians, of course, have been coming to Washington for as long as it has existed, to talk over treaty rights and other issues. And since the early 1990's at least, tribes have been using newfound gambling wealth to expand their political muscle.
But, concerned that momentum is building behind a wide range of Republican bills they consider anti-Indian, tribal leaders have been stoking up their lobbying operations earlier and more forcefully this year than in the past, Congressional officials and tribal leaders say.
"There are more harmful bills out there," said Charles Hobbs, a partner in the lobbying firm of Hobbs, Straus, Dean & Walker, which represents several Eastern tribes.
Chief among their concerns are bills that would authorize the Federal Government to tax profits from casinos, enable states to block new Indian casinos, allow citizens to sue Indian tribes and make it easier for local governments to collect sales taxes from Indian businesses that sell to non-Indians.
In a sign of their growing sophistication, Indians are also weighing in on issues that seem, on the surface, unrelated to tribal affairs. For instance, many tribes are opposing portions of a proposed national tobacco litigation settlement because it might authorize government agencies to regulate Indian tobacco shops -- a violation of their sovereignty, tribes say.
A look inside the United South and Eastern Tribes, whose members include the Mashantucket Pequots and Mohegan Indians of Connecticut and the Seneca Indians and St. Regis Mohawks of New York, shows the changing face of Indian lobbying in Washington.
Ten years ago, only 5 of the group's 23 tribes had Washington lobbyists, but by last year 14 did, from the Seminoles in Florida to the Wampanoags in Massachusetts. And while few tribes could afford major campaign contributions a few years ago, the Pequots, Mohegans and Oneidas -- who all run casinos -- have contributed a total of more than $800,000 to state and Federal candidates since 1994, according to public records.
"The sad fact of life throughout the United States is that having money, or being perceived as having money, does seem to give people more of a voice," said Jayne Fawcett, vice chairwoman of the Mohegan Tribe in Uncasville, Conn.
The Pequots, who run the largest casino in the nation, have also opened a Washington office with full-time staff. And the Oneidas have not only retained law, lobbying and public relations firms in Washington, but also hired a former top Commerce Department official to run their communications operation in New York.
Some Congressional officials contend that the slickness of Indian lobbying is creating a political backlash. And a Justice Department inquiry into whether Mr. Babbitt denied a gambling permit to one Wisconsin tribe because of contributions from a rival tribe has cast shadows over Indian political activity here.
"A lot of their political capital stems from being poor tribes that have been disenfranchised and beat up for 300 years," said John Albaugh, an aide to Representative Ernest J. Istook, Republican of Oklahoma. "Then they hire the biggest firms in town and hold fancy events, and that cuts against their message."
Mr. Hobbs agreed, saying, "Indians have always gotten an extra measure of sympathy from people in Congress." But that factor often disappears, he said, "when a Robert Strauss or someone like that shows up."
For that reason, lobbyists urge their clients to plead their cases face to face with Congressmen. So Mr. George, dressed in a blue jean shirt and alligator boots, his hair pulled taut into a ponytail, did almost all the talking when he led a delegation of Oneida leaders into meetings on Capitol Hill last Thursday.
In session after session, Mr. George told of the dire economic consequences Indians would face if the tax bills were enacted. He offered gifts of fragrant sweetgrass. And he urged an aide to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, to persuade Gov. George E. Pataki to settle an Oneida land dispute.
Throughout the meetings, the Oneidas' battery of lawyers and publicists remained silent. Their responsibility will be to block the secret deals and catch the bad amendments after the Oneidas have left town.
"I don't fault our opponents for strong lobbying -- it's in their business interests," said Ray Halbritter, the Oneida Nation representative, an elected official. "But we have to look out for ours, too."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
Arab Nations Send Cautious Message to U.S.
With Saudi Arabia showing deep reluctance to support a military strike against Iraq, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said that he would not seek permission to launch American fighters and bombers from Saudi territory. A1
 
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright portrayed her recent visit to the Middle East as a success, but messages from top Arab officials are heavy with suggestions that the renewed use of force against Iraq could set off more turmoil in a volatile region. A6 

Native Canadians Win Ruling
A recent ruling by the Supreme Court of Canada declared that the legends of the Gitxsan people in Kispiox, British Columbia, are legally binding evidence that can be used to support Gitxsan claims to as much as 22,000 square miles of British Columbia's remote interior. By essentially validating Indian claims to land even where treaties or titles do not exist, the ruling may redefine how the Government deals with the 1.3 million indigenous people in Canada. A1
 
Leaders Start China Tour
A high-profile delegation of American religious leaders began arriving in Beijing for a three-week tour of China to examine the state of religious freedom, one of the most volatile human rights issues in American diplomacy. A3
 
New Political Plan for Ireland
For the first time since the current peace effort began, a new political structure for Northern Ireland has begun to emerge in talks between leaders of the Protestant majority and the Roman Catholic minority. The plan under discussion would give the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republic more influence on the British province, but would allow no changes to be made without the approval of the province's Protestant majority. A4
 
Cover-Up Denied in Italy Crash
The crew of the American jet that sheared ski-lift cables in northern Italy last week issued a message of sympathy to the families of the victims, and United States military officials denied Italian charges that a delay in handing over the jet's mission recorder was part of an attempted cover-up. The accident killed 20 cable car passengers. Questions about the whereabouts of the plane's mission recorder led to accusations by Italian officials of possible tampering with evidence. A5
 
Backing Away From the Dollar
Southeast Asian leaders, hoping to reduce their reliance on the American dollar and shore up their economies, are rallying behind a proposal to trade goods in local currencies instead of dollars. The dollar, used for most regional trade, has become costly for Southeast Asian countries that have seen their currencies plunge. But experts dismissed the proposal as quixotic, and how such a system would function is unclear. A9
 
NATIONAL A10-15
 
White House Steps Up Campaign Against Starr
The White House broadened its attack on Kenneth W. Starr, calling him "corrupt" and demanding an independent investigation of alleged leaks from his office. Officials in Mr. Starr's office said he had begun his own inquiry into whether his office was leaking to the press. Meantime, a new witness emerged who, lawyers said, told investigators that Monica S. Lewinsky confided in her that she had had an extended affair with President Clinton. A1
 
Springing from unnamed sources, leaks of information about President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky have started a very public brawl among not only hotheaded partisans, but also normally tight-lipped, mild-mannered lawyers. The leaks -- and subsequent fingerpointing and name-calling -- are being picked apart on talk shows and around dinner tables, with ever more fevered theories of Machiavellian strategy being spun to explain who is spreading the information, and why. A15
 
If there is one constant to the difficulties that have rattled through President Clinton's White House these past six years, it is Bruce R. Lindsey, perhaps the closest of Mr. Clinton advisers. He is once again in the middle of a storm -- subpoenaed to testify in the Lewinsky case and helping to direct the White House's daily political and legal response to the investigation. Mr. Lindsey talks often about escaping his existence. But he keeps plodding loyally along to help his friend of 30 years. A15
 
Battle Over Lawyers' Fees
Calling the proposed fees for lawyers in Texas' settlement with the tobacco industry "outrageous," Gov. George W. Bush has gone to Federal court to block the $2.3 billion payment to the roughly 150 lawyers who assisted the state in the tobacco lawsuit. The fight in Texas, and a similar one in Florida, could be dwarfed by the battle that would occur if Congress approved the proposed $368.5 billion national settlement with the tobacco industry. A1
 
G.O.P. Fights Harder on Census
House Republicans, once content with threats to withhold money from the Census Bureau or to challenge the constitutionality of the new methods, are drawing up plans to oversee the census more tightly than any Congress in memory. The Republican moves are part of a continuing fight over the proposed statistical sampling methodology for the 2000 census. House Republican leaders say it is unconstitutional and subject to political manipulation by the Clinton Administration. A11
 
H.I.V. Disclosure Low
Four of every 10 people infected with H.I.V. failed to inform their sex partners about their condition, and nearly two-thirds of those did not always use a condom, according to a survey to be released today. Most of the people surveyed had low incomes and were high school dropouts; many were also drug users. But researchers believe that the withholding of information about H.I.V. infection is widespread. A10
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
Troubles Mounting For Labor Coalition
Prosecutors are investigating 7 of 56 locals of District Council 37, a coalition representing 120,000 New York City workers, and a well-known president of one of the locals has been suspended, plunging the coalition into what some labor leaders are calling its worst crisis ever. The problems are an embarrassing blow to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. A1
 
Partnership to Open Clinics

HEADLINE: Man Attacks One Officer and Shoots Another, Police Say

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 8

 BODY:
A 23-year-old man who was apparently angry because the Newark police had confiscated his car for having stolen license plates walked calmly into a Jersey City police station early today, attacked a desk officer, grabbed the desk lieutenant's gun and shot him twice, seriously wounding him, the police said.
The suspect, William Marable, was arrested after being shot in the ribs, but not badly hurt, by a third officer who ran into the station when he heard gunfire. 
 The wounded lieutenant, Patrick Robinson, was listed in guarded condition at Jersey City Medical Center after surgery to remove about half a foot of his small intestine. Mr. Marable, who was in stable condition at the same hospital, is being charged with attempted murder.
The attack prompted an outcry from Lieutenant Robinson's union because, unlike many modern police headquarters that wall the police off from civilians with buzzer-operated security doors and bulletproof partitions, Jersey City's prewar police stations are wide open to the public.
Mr. Marable, the police said, simply walked in the front door of the West District station, walked around the four-foot-high police desk, which is not protected by a gate, and assaulted Officer Joseph Kelly, the desk assistant.
There was also a 1997 warrant out for Mr. Marable's arrest for failure to pay child support, leading the Jersey City authorities to wonder why the Newark police had released him after arresting him on the license plate charge on Thursday.
Mr. Marable, whose police record includes convictions for drug charges and for falsely incriminating another, lives five blocks from the West District station in the city's depressed Bergen-Lafayette section. Sometime after midnight today, his father said, Mr. Marable left the house, after complaining to a friend about how the Newark police had taken his car.
At 2:04 A.M., according to police reports, he walked into the police station and, apparently ignoring a coffee-stained sign that says "No One Permitted Behind Desk Without Permission of Desk Supervisor," knocked down Officer Kelly.
When Lieutenant Robinson, a 20-year veteran of the force, came to his colleague's aid, Mr. Marable knocked him down, too, and took his service weapon, a 9-millimeter Smith & Wesson, said the Police Director, Michael F. Moriarty. He said both officers are nearly six feet tall. The warrant for Mr. Marable lists him as 5 feet 7 inches tall and weighing 150 pounds, but his father, William Cook, described him as closer to six feet tall and powerfully built.
Mr. Moriarty said that there were 14 bullets in Lieutenant Robinson's gun, and that Mr. Marable fired 12 of them, striking the lieutenant in the thigh and stomach. The noise drew Sgt. Ed Carrittini, who from his car had watched Mr. Marable enter the building. Sergeant Carrittini fired twice at Mr. Marable, hitting him in the chest, the police said.
Lieut. Ron Buonocore, the president of the Jersey City Police Superior Officers Association, said that doctors and nurses at the hospital heard Mr. Marable bragging that he had got even with the police. His father, Mr. Cook, did not rule out the possibility.
"I know he was angry," Mr. Cook said. "Maybe he got revenge."
Mr. Cook, standing at the windowless front door of the faded white row house on Summit Avenue where he and his son live, said that Mr. Marable was "a good kid" but that he had been in and out of jail and was usually unemployed.
When told that Lieutenant Robinson was expected to recover, Mr. Cook said, "That's good. At least they ain't got death on him yet. At least he ain't killed anyone yet."
Last night the police in Newark and Jersey City were trying to figure out why Mr. Marable was not held in Newark on the child support warrant, which was issued in Jersey City. The police are supposed to run a warrant check on anyone they arrest, but Robert Martin the Deputy Police Chief in Jersey City, said it was conceivable that the warrant had not been entered into the state database, or that officers in Newark were not able to confirm that the warrant was still active when they arrested Mr. Marable.
Today's attack marked the first time in memory that a Jersey City officer had been shot inside a precinct house, but Mr. Buonocore said that given the design of the station it was only a matter of time before something like that happened.
"Members have been complaining for years that there's no security," he said.
Mr. Moriarty said that four months ago, the department began planning to buy and install surveillance cameras and intercom buzzers at all four stations, at a cost of about $40,000. He said the shooting would probably speed up the procurement process.
Mr. Moriarty said that while the officers' safety was a priority, it had to be balanced with community relations.
"There's a tradition in Jersey City that people have access to the Police Department," he said. "We don't want to give the impression that we're trying to keep people away. If nobody can come into the precinct, or if people say they got turned away because the guy didn't like the way they looked or the way they sounded, people are going to complain."
But while the police, unlike many store owners, are armed and carry the authority of law enforcement, a veteran tour commander at the West District, Lieut. Charles Winterhalter, said he sometimes felt vulnerable. He stood behind the desk at the busiest police station in the city, one of the busiest in the state, 10 feet from a double door, the panes of which have been replaced by aluminum panels painted black.
"At least when you get dispatched to a shooting or a homicide you know what you're getting into," he said. "Here they walk in and they're on top of you, and you have no idea what they're going to do."

HEADLINE: Reclaiming 'Day' and 'Night,' Memories in Marble

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
In 1968, Robert A. Roe saved the "Day."
And the "Night."
These two graceful allegorical statues, wrested from the facade of Pennsylvania Station, had been carted out of Manhattan and dumped into a trackside landfill in Secaucus, N.J. 
 There, "Day" was photographed by Eddie Hausner of The New York Times. He depicted a large fragment of the marble maiden -- with her gentle face and silken robes, sunflower garland and bayberry wreath -- upside down in a jumbled wasteland as a lone train crossed the bleak horizon.
"I knew I made a nice picture but that was about the extent of it," Mr. Hausner said.
Actually, what he made was probably the most evocative single image of the demolition of Pennsylvania Station.
"It grabbed you," recalled Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York. "You thought: 'What have we done? Has the city been sacked?' "
The picture in The Times grabbed Mr. Roe, who was then the New Jersey Commissioner of Conservation and Economic Development. (He later served in the United States House of Representatives.) Mr. Roe dispatched a rescue crew. "We decided to salvage them because they were of great historical interest and value," he said.
The remnants of the statues were taken to Ringwood State Park in northern Passaic County, where they have been stored ever since. Now -- shades of Ellis Island! -- New York would like one of them back.
But it will have to persuade New Jersey Transit, which has acquired the statues with a view to installing them at the Broad Street station in Newark.
The Pennsylvania Station Redevelopment Corporation, a New York agency, proposes sharing the costs of shipping, restoring and duplicating the statues, so that each state would wind up having an original of one statue, and a replica of the other.
New York's pair would be part of the new Pennsylvania Station that the corporation is planning within the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue. "These statues are an irreplaceable physical tie to the late, great Pennsylvania Station," said Alexandros E. Washburn, the president of the corporation, in a letter to New Jersey Transit. "Finally, the mute stones speak."
A spokeswoman for New Jersey Transit said on Tuesday that the railroad was "trying to work out something" with New York officials.
The figures were the work of Adolph A. Weinman, who may be best known for the gilded "Civic Fame" atop the Municipal Building in lower Manhattan.
Pennsylvania Station had four pairs of the "Day" and "Night" figures flanking large clocks on each facade. One "Night" is now at the Brooklyn Museum. A "Day" and a "Night" are in Kansas City, Mo. David D. Morrison, a railroad historian, does not believe that the Ringwood "Day" is the one pictured in The Times, based on its condition, although he said it may have been salvaged from the same field of debris.
The impending move was greeted ambivalently by Elbertus Prol, the curator of Ringwood Manor in the state park for 31 years.
"I'm going to miss them, yes," he said. "But they're going to be preserved in a better setting."

The Pennsylvania Station figure was later saved. (Eddie Hausner/The New York Times)(pg. B1); This statue of "Day," possibly the same one photographed in a landfill in 1968, is now at Ringwood State Park in New Jersey. There were four "Day" statues and four "Night" statues at Pennsylvania Station. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)(pg. B6)

HEADLINE: Fat Fees in Tobacco Deals Signal New Foe for States: The Lawyers

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
At first blush, it sounds like a standard contingency-fee agreement -- even generous to the client, by trial lawyers' standards. The lawyers who took the case fronted the initial costs, agreed not to take a penny if the client did not collect, and asked for only 15 percent if there was a settlement.
But when the client is the state of Texas, and the state's settlement with the tobacco industry is $15.3 billion, the result is not cheerful payment of the lawyers' bill, which comes to $2.3 billion (plus expenses, some lawyers argue). It is a Texas-sized war. 
 Calling the proposed fees "outrageous," Gov. George W. Bush has gone to Federal court to block the payment to the roughly 150 lawyers who assisted Texas in the tobacco lawsuit, which was settled last month. In return, the state's Attorney General, Dan Morales, the chief architect of the settlement, who believes that Governor Bush's move could undermine the accord, accused him of having "chosen to wrap himself in a tobacco leaf" and said the Governor was pandering for campaign contributions from big tobacco in a future run for the White House.
The fight here mirrors one in Florida, where some lawyers are trying to collect up to 25 percent of that state's $11.3 billion settlement with the tobacco industry for health-related damages caused by smoking. That battle has the added twist of lawyers fighting among themselves over the share of any proceeds, but for now, a state judge has blocked some lawyers' attempts to collect fees by filing liens on the tobacco companies' payments to the state.
The Florida judge, Harold J. Cohen, of the Circuit Court in West Palm Beach, ruled late last year that the lawyers may well be entitled to hundreds of millions of dollars for their work. But in a ruling that basically tore up the stipulated 25 percent, he wrote: "2.87 billion dollars simply shocks the conscience of the court. It is per se unreasonable."
The proposed fees in Texas and Florida appear to be the two largest payments to lawyers in the history of American litigation. But as gargantuan as the fight over them may seem now, it may well be dwarfed by the one that would occur if Congress approves a $368.5 billion national settlement with the tobacco industry, which in most respects would supersede the agreements here and those expected in three dozen other states that have pending legal action against the tobacco companies.
Even without such a national deal in hand, several members of Congress have offered legislation that would cap the amounts that would be paid to the hundreds of private lawyers who assisted on that agreement, which was announced last spring but has yet to be acted on. A bill in the House would set the fees at no more than $150 an hour, plus expenses, while one in the Senate would put the amount at $250 an hour.
Here in the second-largest state, there are enough subtexts in the fee battle to occupy an entire semester's study of Texas Politics 101.
Trial lawyers here have long been major contributors to the Democratic Party and have fought Mr. Bush, a Republican, over tort-reform legislation that would cap award payments in civil trials and limit what Mr. Bush calls "frivolous lawsuits."
The Governor is running for re-election, and it seems hard to believe that he has chosen the wrong side of a major political issue by arguing to Texans that a bunch of trial lawyers do not deserve $2.3 billion in fees. In his filing to Judge David Folsom of Federal District Court in Texarkana, Mr. Bush said he did not want to do anything to reduce the overall size of the settlement: he wanted more of the money to go to health-care programs and less to lawyers.
Nor is he alone among Texas politicians. A bipartisan group of seven lawmakers filed a similar petition to the judge, arguing that the fees are "excessive and unconscionable."
Nonetheless, Mr. Bush's strategy is not without risk. Mr. Morales says the action directly threatens to undermine the settlement, which contains a provision that it can be terminated if the courts or lawmakers change it in any major "material respect." The Attorney General said Mr. Bush was doing the bidding of the tobacco companies by filing the equivalent of a legal bombshell that could destroy the agreement.
"Today's filing is about one thing and one thing only," Mr. Morales said at a news conference in Austin just after the Governor acted: "A Republican Presidential campaign and political contributions from big tobacco. Our state's historic victory over big tobacco is placed in serious jeopardy. Governor Bush, shame on you. The children of Texas will never forgive you for this."
Mr. Bush's spokeswoman, Karen Hughes, said the Attorney General was engaging in "scurrilous personal attacks" and that he was "trying to defend the indefensible." She said that the Governor was only seeking to sever the issue of fees from all other aspects of the settlement.
Mr. Morales, a popular Democrat who has declined to run for re-election this year but is still seen as a possible future candidate for higher statewide office, has clearly chosen to align himself with the lawyers. As the Democrats, who once dominated Texas politically, struggle to fight back the Republican surge of recent years, the lawyers' industry is expected to continue to be a major financial backer of the party.
The Attorney General said his office had made an up-front agreement on fees with the private lawyers two years ago and should honor the pact.
Clearly raising the image of an Old West duel, Mr. Morales said he wanted to meet with the Governor "any place, any time" to settle their differences -- with a public debate, not a shootout, he added -- over the fee issue. Mr. Bush declined, saying the matter should be resolved in court.
For its part, the tobacco industry stoutly denies that it carries any secret agenda of trying to scuttle the Texas agreement, under which the state is to get $1.2 billion for health programs this year and a series of other payments stretched out over at least the next 15 years.
"We are not looking to blow up the deal and consider the case done," Dan Webb, a lawyer who represents Philip Morris, said last week.
"If the state of Texas wants to give all their money to lawyers or all the money to sick smokers, they can do it," Mr. Webb told The Dallas Morning News. "The tobacco companies don't have a dog in this fight."
Last month, Mr. Bush speculated aloud that the fees the lawyers were demanding here could average roughly $450,000 an hour, though Mr. Morales called that a "patently silly estimate." The 150 or so lawyers involved in a major way in the case have not provided a precise estimate yet of exactly how much time they put into the case, but many have pointed out that they also owe a small fortune in payments to doctors, other health experts, economists, professors and other consultants they had hired in preparation for the case. (Some of the lawyers say those are expenses that are separate from the legal fees.)
Some lawyers have made it clear that they would be willing to negotiate much-reduced fees: a spokesman for the lawyers in Texas said they would be willing to donate more than $400 million to a private foundation for health care. But others insist that the arrangement is defensible, and point out that other states have initiated fee agreements of 25 percent or even 33 1/3 percent for tobacco litigation.
First, they say, $2.3 billion sounds like more than it really is, since that is an amount to be paid out over several years, not in present-day dollars. Second, they argue, as in all contingency arrangements, the lawyers took an enormous risk in taking on a case that was by no means certain to be settled. And third, they say, Mr. Morales made what should be considered a binding agreement.
The fight over the fees is not the only litigation likely to be spawned by the $15.3 billion agreement. While the money has already been earmarked for health programs and hospitals, many public officials have demanded more say in precisely how the money is spent.
"It is ironic," said Judge Lee Jackson of Dallas County, who joined in a motion to change some of the spending provisions in the deal, "that a tobacco settlement would contain a secret budget deal that is reminiscent of agreements made in the days of smoke-filled rooms."

HEADLINE: Pessimism Retains Grip on Appalachian Poor

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: BOONEVILLE, Ky.

 BODY:
There is an area of Booneville that some residents call Ho Chi Minh City for its third world appearance. It is not large, just a few winding gravel roads. But many of the houses look like shanties, heated with wood or coal. Children walk around with dirty bare feet. Many people lack telephones and cars.
In many respects, this little corner of Appalachia looks much as it did 30 years ago, when President Lyndon B. Johnson declared a war on poverty, taking special aim at the rural decay in places like Owsley County, here in eastern Kentucky, and other distressed areas in the 399 counties of 13 states that make up Appalachia. 
 Federal and state agencies have plowed billions of dollars into Appalachia through economic development programs, highway construction and job-creation initiatives to help residents overcome the economic and psychological isolation caused by poverty and the rugged terrain.
But a tour of Booneville offers ample evidence that money and countless programs have had only marginal effects on breaking a cycle of poverty and despair that continues throughout many parts of Appalachia. And conditions could grow worse before they improve.
With state welfare regulations forcing recipients to find work and with the Federal Government reviewing the eligibility of children who receive disability benefits, many Owsley County residents could lose vital monthly checks that they have relied on for years. More than half of the people in the county who receive those benefits are children.
Viewing those prospects, some residents sound much like people who have criticized entitlement programs for stagnating inner cities.
"The war on poverty was the worst thing that ever happened to Appalachia," said Denise Hoffman, 46, who runs a small farm here with her husband, Neil. "It gave people a way to get by without having to do any work."
By many measures, Appalachia remains mired in poverty. In about one-quarter of the highland region's counties, according to data from the 1990 census, 25 percent or more of residents live below the poverty level as defined by the Federal Government. That rate is nearly double the national average.
Owsley County, with a population of 5,400, is one of the most distressed areas. To many residents, the booming national economy is something they hear about only on television.
More than 46 percent live in poverty, as defined by the Government. The median household income of $8,595 is one of the lowest in Appalachia. Almost half the adults are unemployed. About two-thirds of the people in the county receive Federal assistance, 30 percent of county families do not have telephones, and 20 percent do not have cars.
More than half the adult population is illiterate.
But perhaps most critical of all, with the coal industry long gone as a major employer and job creation minimal and sporadic, feelings of hopelessness have become so deeply entrenched that many residents have long forsaken any expectation of bettering themselves.
Even a generous new program to encourage savings is struggling to win participants. Through a foundation grant to finance a $6-to-$1 match, residents can deposit up to $15 a month for two years, a total of $360, and receive back $2,520. The program began in May to encourage low-income people to set aside money for home improvements, a new business or school.
Eight people are participating.
"The overriding theory of the program works against the mentality that is deeply set within people who live in poverty," said the program administrator, Jennifer Hart. "They don't think they have a future. If they did, they would think about it and delay instant gratification. But they have no reason to. And they can't. They can only think about how they are going to feed the children this week and pay the rent this month."
Even many of the 70 seniors at Owsley County High School this year sense the inevitability of spending their lives in poverty, unchanged from their parents' situations.
The Hoffmans' 17-year-old daughter, Megan, a top student and an athlete who has been accepted to four state colleges, thinks of her classmates with chagrin.
"Many of them think things are never going to get any better," she said. "It's pretty sad. Kids feel, 'I don't think I can make a difference.' They don't seem to want to change or care."
When the senior class voted on the message to print on their T-shirts this year, an annual custom, they chose: "I came. I slept. I graduated." Megan said fewer than 25 percent plan to attend college.
As elsewhere in Appalachia, the feelings of hopelessness prevail despite energetic efforts by Government and private groups like the Mountain Association for Community Economic Development, a 21-year-old organization in Berea that helps community groups in 49 counties around the state.
In Owsley it provides a ray of hope through self-help programs like job-training classes, courses on starting a business and agencies that make low-interest loans. It also aids in recruiting companies into the area, a mighty challenge in Booneville, with its remote location and lack of services. The town has two restaurants, three groceries and one dentist. And while it has three doctors the nearest hospital is an hour away.
To attack the worst of rural poverty, the association created "action teams" six years ago for the most distressed counties, Owsley and Letcher. In each, officials work closely with local leaders to convince residents that they can lead more productive lives.
The efforts take many forms. In Booneville, the team helped bring Image Entry, a data-entry company that created 58 jobs, onto a site that local leaders hope will become an industrial park. Team members helped start associations for goat breeders and vegetable growers, to increase their profits. The team also helped set up a secondhand shop that employs welfare recipients so that they can fulfill new state regulations that require them to find a job in two years or lose benefits. Next to the shop is a credit union that offers low-interest loans and a generous matched-saving program.
The state welfare agency has set up a pilot program for recipients that teaches "job readiness skills," including how to write a resume and how to fill out a job application.
Yet every initiative pits the action team and Government agencies against an intractable pessimism built on decades of depressed conditions that are visible everywhere: piles of garbage heaped into creeks and ravines because people cannot afford the $12 monthly fee for trash removal; landscapes of rusting cars, some from the 1950's, and the crumbling shell of the Seale theater, which last showed a movie, "Silver Bullet," in 1985.
But many residents say the prevailing attitude in the county, particularly among those receiving state and Federal entitlement benefits, is that no amount of help and instruction is going to make a difference. According to the most recent state statistics, 14.3 percent of Owsley residents receive welfare benefits, 20 percent receive benefits through the Federal assistance program for disabled people known as Supplemental Security Income and almost half receive food stamps.
Mr. Hoffman, 47, a member of the action team, grew almost angry, talking about the conditions in much of Appalachia. "Poverty is not about money," he said. "It's in the mind. It's a way of life. Once you're in that cycle you think you can't break out of it. I don't know why people think that way, but they become a prisoner of it. It took us three generations to get into this mess, and it's going to take us three generations to get out of it."
Members of the team say many parents urge their children to try to go to special education classes at school as a way to prove that they are eligible for disability benefits.
"That shows how creative people are when there are no jobs," said Jeanne Gage, the director of the sustainable communities initiative for the Mountain Association. "You learn how to work the system."
But as the system is changing, that could have a devastating effect on Owsley County without more jobs.
Pam Barrett, 32, a divorced mother of a 17-year-old daughter and two sons, 11 and 10, is beginning to feel the pinch. Living with her 38-year-old former husband, who receives $438 a month in disability benefits for bad nerves and a spine injury, she began working 20 hours a week at the secondhand shop two months ago. She plans to use some of the money for her daughter, Jennifer, who expects to receive an athletic scholarship and start college in the fall.
"She has the chance I passed up to have three young'uns," Ms. Barrett said. "I quit school in the eighth grade to get married. I was 15. He was 21. I've regretted it ever since. And young'uns having babies is going on right today. But I tell you what, you learn from your mistakes."
Farmers like the Hoffmans, who rely on tobacco as their leading cash crop, are enduring another anxiety, waiting to see how the litigation between cigarette companies and Federal and state governments might affect small growers.
Action team members and government officials working to turn around the fortunes of Owsley County all say their efforts are paying off, even against an enormous tide of negativism that now touches some of those who are succeeding.
Megan Hoffman said, "I have really enjoyed growing up here." But asked whether she planned to return after college, she said: "No. There is nothing here. There is nothing to come back to."
The president of the Mountain Association, Don Harker, said that attitude would be difficult to change any time soon.
"We have an immense amount of work to do to bring up the prosperity levels of Appalachia," Mr. Harker said. "To give people hope, we have to change the whole dynamic. To give people a reason to believe things can be different than they are, we have to change their expectations.
"I know we can do it," he said. "But I don't think it will be done in my lifetime."

HEADLINE: Armenia's Turmoil

 BODY:
The resignation of Armenia's president, Levon Ter-Petrossian, earlier this month was a disturbing development for peace and ethnic harmony in the Caucasus. Largely Christian Armenia is at war with its larger and richer Muslim neighbor, Azerbaijan, over Nagorno-Karabakh, an enclave in Azerbaijan populated by Armenians, who are seeking independence. In September, Mr. Ter-Petrossian, under pressure from the United States, France and Russia, announced his support for a peace plan that contained necessary compromises. The compromises enraged hard-liners in his Government and parliamentary coalition, who forced him to resign.
Mr. Ter-Petrossian was already unpopular, largely due to suspicions that he won the 1996 election through fraud. But his peace plan, seen by many Armenians as a sellout, is the only realistic solution to the Nagorno-Karabakh war, which began in 1988 after the enclave demanded Armenian rule and has killed 25,000 people, mostly civilians. It has sabotaged Armenia's economy and threatens the stability of the oil- and gas-rich Caspian Sea region. Mr. Ter-Petrossian's ouster increases chances that a cease-fire that has held since 1994 will be broken. 
 His resignation also formalizes the increasing grip on power of an unsavory band of military and security officials. Their troops beat demonstrators protesting election fraud, and some have ties to a group that has attacked religious minorities.
The sponsors of the negotiations, most importantly Moscow, must scramble to keep the peace effort from collapse. They must persuade Armenia's new leaders that the agreement, which would result in some form of autonomy but not independence for Nagorno-Karabakh, is the only chance to achieve the stability and peace their country needs.
International groups must mobilize now to supervise new elections scheduled for March 16, as another ballot clouded by fraud would harm Armenia's teetering democracy. But even a clean election is unlikely to choose a president willing to make the compromises necessary for peace.

HEADLINE: House Republicans Plan to Keep a Tight Rein on 2000 Census

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Republicans in Congress are preparing to renew their fight to prevent the Census Bureau from using a new method to count the nation's population in 2000.
House Republicans, once content with threats to withhold money from the Census Bureau or to challenge the constitutionality of the new method, are now drawing up plans to oversee the census more tightly than any Congress in memory. 
 "We must have a huge say in the planning, preparation and implementation of the 2000 Census," said Representative Dan Miller, the Florida Republican who is heads a House subcommittee that oversees the Census Bureau.
Last week, House leaders granted Mr. Miller's subcommittee a $1.1 million budget to oversee preparations for the next census. The money, which comes from a special account established by House Republican leaders for investigations, is about 10 times more than what was allocated to the House subcommittee that oversaw preparations for the 1990 census. House leaders have yet to say precisely how they will supervise the census.
The Republican moves are part of an ongoing fight over the proposed statistical sampling methodology for the 2000 Census. The technique is already used to measure things like the nation's unemployment rate.
For the 2000 Census, the bureau plans to estimate the number of people living in a given census tract -- a neighborhood of about 1,700 households -- by visiting a sample of those homes in which residents do not return their mail-in census forms or do not answer the knock at the door when visited by census takers. In addition, after the census is completed, the bureau plans to have census takers visit 750,000 of the country's estimated 119 million addresses and use that sample to determine the accuracy of the overall count.
Census officials have said sampling is the only way to avoid the problems of the 1990 Census, which was the most expensive in history but missed more than 10 million people, many of them minority residents of inner-city neighborhoods.
Though the method has been sanctioned by scientific panels, Republican leaders in the House say it is unconstitutional and subject to manipulation by the Clinton Administration. Supporters of sampling say they suspect that Republican opposition stems from a fear that counting more minorities, who tend to vote Democratic, would result in a redrawing of Congressional district lines that would benefit Democrats.
To counter the charge that that the Administration could, through the use of sampling, manipulate the census, some members of Congress are pushing the Clinton Administration to appoint a Republican, Barbara Everitt Bryant, as the new director of the Census Bureau. The former bureau director, Martha Farnsworth Riche, resigned last month in the face of mounting Republican opposition to the use of sampling.
Ms. Bryant, a proponent of sampling, was the Census Bureau director during the Bush Administration.
The possibility of Ms. Bryant's appointment places Republican opponents of sampling in a political quandary. As a former census director, she has the professional credentials. And, as a Republican, she could conceivably be trusted to resist any attempts by the Clinton Administration to manipulate the census figures for partisan gain.
"She is a professional and not a politician," said Representative Christopher Shays, a Connecticut Republican who has defied his party's leadership by supporting sampling.

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
Backer of U.S. Heliport Wins Vote in Japan

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 8

 BODY:
A backer of a proposed floating United States heliport off the coast of Okinawa narrowly won a mayoral election today, providing a boost to supporters of an American military presence on the southern Japanese island.
The winning candidate, Takeo Kishimoto, who was endorsed by Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, told voters in the city of Nago that the heliport would help the depressed local economy. Mr. Kishimoto won 16,253 votes -- about 1,150 more than his main opponent, Yoshikazu Tamaki, who argued the base would increase noise and crime. 
 The election, with turnout at 82 percent, was held two days after the Governor of Okinawa, Masahide Ota, announced that he would not support the central Government's efforts to build the floating platform.
Governor Ota noted that in a non-binding referendum in December, 54 percent of Nago voters rejected the proposed heliport. Mr. Kishimoto's victory is expected to bolster the central Government's campaign to persuade the Governor to support the heliport. Mr. Ota's approval is required for the base.
The heliport project resulted from a 1996 United States-Japan agreement, under which Washington agreed to close the Futenma Air Station in five to seven years on condition that an alternative heliport be built somewhere in Okinawa prefecture. Two-thirds of the 47,000 American troops stationed in Japan are concentrated on Okinawa, about 1,000 miles southwest of Tokyo.
Longstanding grass-roots opposition to the military presence in Japan exploded in 1995 after three American servicemen raped a 12-year-old girl in Okinawa.

HEADLINE: Don't Let Russia Derail NATO Expansion

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Howard Baker Jr., Sam Nunn, Brent Scowcroft and Alton Frye (Op-Ed, Feb. 4) take the issue of expansion of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization too seriously. NATO expansion is not a threat to Western security. Only Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary are likely to be admitted in the next several years. The Russians have accepted, however reluctantly, this degree of enlargement. 
 Second, full Russian cooperation with the United States can no longer be achieved or even expected. Russia is seeking a larger role in international politics by pursuing its own national interests as its post-Communist elites see them. Part of this is convincing Americans that NATO expansion is a danger. The article also suggests permanent second-class -- and in effect non-European -- status for all the countries of East Central Europe (and Russia).
Do the writers have the right to say who is European and who is not? And who are they to tell the unemployment-ridden Western Europeans that they ought to admit more states now to the European Union?
 
KARL W. RYAVEC
Pelham, Mass., Feb. 5, 1998
 
The writer is a professor of political science, University of Massachusetts at Amherst.

HEADLINE: Don't Let Russia Derail NATO Expansion;
Marshall Plan Model

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"NATO: A Debate Recast" (Op-Ed, Feb. 4) raises serious reservations about the expansion of the alliance to include Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. Howard Baker Jr., Sam Nunn, Brent Scowcroft and Alton Frye conclude that European Union expansion should precede NATO expansion. 
 Their reservations are reinforced when you consider the costs of expansion: $35 billion over 10 years. Adding other Central and Eastern European countries would double the cost. Rearming the former Warsaw Pact countries would add little to their security or the security of NATO members. The last things these countries need are the advanced fighter jets and military infrastructure required by NATO membership.
This level of financing could be used to establish a new Marshall Plan that could help turn around their economies.
 
MICHAEL D. INTRILIGATOR
Los Angeles, Feb. 4, 1998
 
The writer is a professor of economics, political science and policy studies, University of California at Los Angeles.
