HEADLINE: N.B.A. ALL-STAR GAME: NOTEBOOK;
Jordan Is Still Firmly In His Coach's Corner

BYLINE: By STEVE POPPER 

 BODY:
Michael Jordan had arrived at Madison Square Garden yesterday, still sniffling, but he was seated comfortably in the Knicks' locker room. The National Basketball Association could breathe a sigh of relief that Jordan was suiting up for what could be his final All-Star Game appearance, but he did nothing to alleviate the Bulls' fears that their golden goose is leaving after this season.
Jordan has said that if Phil Jackson is not back as the coach, he will not be back as a player. And if Jackson does not return, Jordan will put the blame squarely on Jerry Reinsdorf, the team owner, and Jerry Krause, the general manager. 
 "I think it's more or less personalities," Jordan said.
"It certainly can't be because of his job and what he's done with his players and the respect that he has won with the players," Jordan said of Jackson. "His success as a coach is certainly impeccable."
Asked if he truly believed that this would be his last go-round, he said: "Yes, I do. I haven't seen any light on the other side of the tunnel at all."
While Jordan and the Bulls' success has turned the N.B.A. into a worldwide enterprise, he said that he believed that greed and control were at issue.
"It's more control than anything," Jordan said. "Maybe it's not the way they want it to be. From an economic standpoint, I don't think they're making as much as they used to."
But even subtracting Jordan's $31.8 million salary, as well as the contracts of Jackson and Scottie Pippen, the Bulls do not figure to have their logo confused with a dollar sign anymore.
"That's a gamble they're willing to take," Jordan said. "You and I understand that. I think it's more a personality issue. They're willing to take the risk."
Asked if he might have a role in the league after he retired, he replied: "I'm going to be a fan from afar, watching the game. I'm pretty sure I'll still have some contact because of my business with the shoe industry. I'll come down to the United Center and visit."
With his problems with Bulls management and the expected departure of those in the organization he holds dear, Jordan was not about to profess just whom he would be a fan of.
"I don't know yet," he said. "We'll have to see."
 
Multimillionaires' Locker
 Michael Jordan did not know that the locker he had taken at the Garden belonged to Patrick Ewing.
Told whose spot he was using, Jordan expressed a bit of empathy for the Knicks center who missed a chance to play in front of the hometown fans when he dislocated a bone and tore ligaments in his right wrist in December.
"He's here in spirit," Jordan said. "I respect Patrick so much. Fortunately, I got his locker. That's pretty neat. I always wanted to stand in his shoes. I've never been over here. I wondered what it looked like."
When someone joked that you have to earn at least $20 million to use that locker, Jordan deadpanned, "Yeah, that's why I'm here."
 
Williams, a Nonbeliever
 Despite Jordan's insistence that this was his final season, not everyone believed him.
"Michael will be here again next year and win the m.v.p. again," the Nets' Jayson Williams said. "I don't know why Mike needs so much drama in his life."
 
Passing the Torch
 While younger All-Stars have been inundated with questions about who is Jordan's heir apparent, he is not bothered by talk of his demise and the prospect of handing the torch to Kobe Bryant or Grant Hill.
"I think it's no different than when I came in the league," Jordan said. "It's just a standard of measurement in terms of competitors.
"They did it with me and Dr. J," he said, referring to Julius Erving. "It doesn't faze me. But it puts pressure on certain people to live up to it."

HEADLINE: Researchers Paint New Portrait of an Ancient People

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
AS the last of the great civilizations of antiquity to be discovered, the Indus culture of the third millennium B.C. has long suffered in comparison with its more illustrious contemporaries to the west. Its baked-brick cities, without splendid palaces and unadorned by images of mighty rulers and triumphant battles, might evoke wonder but not the awe of archeologists whose eyes had gazed upon the pyramids and temples of Egypt or the royal cemeteries of Mesopotamia.
Even the timing of its discovery, in the early 1920's, militated against a proper appreciation of the Indus civilization on its own terms. At the same time, Howard Carter was opening the tomb of the young pharaoh Tutankhamen and seeing "everywhere the glint of gold." And Leonard Woolley was excavating graves at Ur, revealing the art, technology and wealth of the Sumerians on the plain of the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers in what is now Iraq. 
 Nothing so dazzling greeted John Marshall, the British director general of the Archeological Survey of India, who brought to light the large cities of Harappa and Mohenjo-daro in the fertile Indus River valley. They were among the world's largest cities (rivaled only by Uruk in Mesopotamia), serving as centers of commerce for a civilization extending over the region of present-day Pakistan and western India. This was an area twice as large as that occupied by either the Egyptians or Sumerians.
Now, renewed excavations and a re-examination of artifacts have awakened scholarly interest in everything about the Indus civilization: the sources of its economic strength and cultural cohesion, the puzzle of its undeciphered writing, the reasons for its rise in 2600 B.C. and decline around 1900 B.C. Many early assumptions and theories have been abandoned or revised. More than 1,500 sites of Indus settlements have been identified. But mysteries persist.
The new research has inspired an exhibition of Indus pottery and figurines, bangles and beads, which opens tomorrow at the Asia Society in New York City. The curator, Dr. Jonathan Mark Kenoyer of the University of Wisconsin, has described current knowledge of the culture in the current issue of Archaeology magazine and in a new book, "Ancient Cities of the Indus Valley Civilization," published by Oxford University Press.
The Indus cities represented the beginning of urbanism in the Indian subcontinent. The people lived in large cities with thick brick walls and gateways to protect them and control trade. The cities were served by numerous water wells, bathing quarters and an extensive system of waste-water drains. The elites seemed to shun ostentation, apparently doing without elaborate palaces or temples. The view of this as a largely unmilitary culture is fostered by the absence of any iconography of battle or of spears and other obvious instruments of warfare.
The Indus culture, Dr. Kenoyer wrote, "was quite different from other early civilizations."
In an article in the current issue of The Journal of World Prehistory, another leading archeologist in the field, Dr. Gregory L. Possehl of the University of Pennsylvania, described how theories about the Indus culture by earlier scholars have been swept aside, but have yet to be replaced by a new consensus.
According to the original view, the Indus people were austere, peaceful, urban, merchant burghers, a kind of ancient version of the Hanseatic mercantile culture of northern Europe. When the British archeologist Mortimer Wheeler excavated more intensively in the valley after World War II, a new interpretation emerged: this was a state ruled by priest-kings, its wealth based on agriculture and trade, a dull and regimented society that bore a strong likeness with Mesopotamia. This view also has been largely rejected.
"You catch us at a moment of change and re-interpretation," Dr. Possehl said in an interview at the University Museum of Archeology and Anthropology in Philadelphia.
Before him was a table laid with Indus artifacts: assorted pottery with fish-scale designs, woodland scenes and peacocks; a seal bearing the impression of a unicorn; a clay rattle and a toy cart also made of clay, and several small figurines, including one of a potbellied man.
Dr. Possehl stood there pondering a question: Why is it taking so long to come up with new interpretations explaining the Indus success?
"We have a stubborn problem; call it a double-whammy problem," Dr. Possehl said, finally. "So much archeological reconstruction of a civilization depends on an interplay of physical remains and written records. Forget about Indus writing. We can't decipher it and, besides, we have found no inscriptions of more than 26 characters, so we are left with no long narratives. Also, the physical remains, the archeological expressions of the Indus people, don't look like anything we are familiar with -- no palaces or monuments or temples."
Dr. Possehl, who has excavated Indus cities since the 1960's and written several books on the culture, also lamented the apparently simple Indus burial practices, which deprive archeologists of what is usually a most revealing lode of cultural information.
Unlike the elites of Egypt and Mesopotamia, the Indus people sent their dead to the afterworld unaccompanied by jewels, furniture and weapons. "That's an attitude," he said. "Stuff is kept in circulation with living people."
Excavations at Harappa, Dr. Kenoyer said, indicated that some people were buried in wooden coffins with pottery vessels that may have been filled with food. But having found so few cemeteries, archeologists suspect that burial was not the rule; perhaps most bodies were cremated or thrown into rivers.
Simple burials seem to fit the one persistent image of Indus society, which is that of a practical people without centralized rulers or kings but with wide-ranging economic interests. Somehow they introduced millet cultivation from Africa. Mesopotamian cuneiform tablets record the presence of Indus merchants and ships there during the reign of Sargon the Great, founder of the Akkadian kingdom, around 2300 B.C. The texts mention such trade goods as hardwoods, tin or lead, copper, gold, silver shell, pearls and ivory.
In other excavations, archeologists have found distinctive Indus cubical weights, made of chert or agate and used for measuring goods before a transaction, at many sites of Arabian Sea ports. These weights have also turned up at all Indus settlements. However, the large number of them recovered, along with small copper scale pans, near Harappa's main gate has led Dr. Kenoyer to suspect that the weights were not used primarily for trading but for assessing taxes on goods being brought into or taken out of the cities.
Even if the cities reveal no monumental traces of strong rulers, all around is indirect evidence of some kind of organizing influence. Who oversaw foreign commerce by sea and regulated the system of weights? How to explain the apparently common religion, uniform pottery and coherent Indus style of artifacts over a period of 700 years, spanning nearly 30 generations?
"We have the peculiar expression of an ancient sociocultural complexity without the ostentations of ideology or evidence of a focused leadership, like a king or queen," Dr. Possehl said. "There's no real model in history or ethnography that suggests that somewhere else there was a civilization like this one."
The Indus cities themselves attest to the presence, if not the identity, of some powerful guiding hand in the culture.
Dr. Michael Jansen, an archeologist at the University of Aachen in Germany, calls Mohenjo-daro "a founder city." That is, like Alexandria, the Egyptian city ordered built by Alexander the Great, Mohenjo-daro bears all the signs of a city that was willed into existence by some powerful person or group of people. The streets were straight, laid out on a north-south and east-west grid. Houses of brick on top of stone foundations seem to have been built to standard designs. Nearly all of them were connected to a city-wide drainage system, and each block had one or more water wells.
The most imposing part of Mohenjo-daro was the Mound of the Great Bath, originally thought of as a citadel. Built on a high mound of dirt and brick rising from the flood plain, this upper city covered an area about 600 feet by 1,200 feet. Its largest building is sometimes described as a warehouse for grain and other agriculture products, though some archeologists think it was more likely a residence or meeting hall for powerful merchant families. The bathhouse itself included a sunken courtyard lined with closely fitted bricks for a watertight pool, which was surrounded by colonnaded halls.
"This is the only piece of architecture we have that is reasonably convincing as something to do with ritual," Dr. Possehl said. "It's not your Y.M.C.A., but a place where some select part of the population came to do their ritual ablutions."
Although the rise of Indus urbanism is usually dated at 2600 B.C., most archeologists characterize the transition as a gradual phenomenon. For several centuries, people throughout the region developed new technologies like wheel-thrown pottery and copper metallurgy.
They began carving seals on ivory and terra cotta and decorating pottery with graffiti, the beginning of the culture's writing. Perhaps of special importance was the expansion of long-distance trading networks.
All these are considered factors in what appears to have been a population explosion around 2600. Recent radiocarbon dating indicates that the number of settlements in the region more than doubled at the time, and the first large cities came into being.
The civilization, however it was tied together, began unraveling in the early second millennium B.C. The end is usually dated at 1900 B.C.
As for the causes, archeologists cite new research that rules out invasion by Indo-Aryan hordes from the north. That was the earliest hypothesis advanced by Mortimer Wheeler. But the Rig Veda, the liturgical writings of the nomadic Aryans, was not composed until about 1000 B.C., making it unlikely that these people were in the Indus region at the time of the collapse. Besides, the historical validity of the Rig Veda has not been established.
In his book, Dr. Kenoyer wrote: "We now believe that there was no outright invasion. The decline of the Indus cities was the result of complex factors. Overextended economic and political networks, the drying up of major rivers as well as the rise of new religious communities all contributed in some way to the creation of a new social order."
Calling what happened a collapse may be overstating the situation, archeologists said. True, Mohenjo-daro was suddenly abandoned, probably because the Indus River changed course, and when a parallel stream, the Saraswati or Ghaggar-Hakra river, dried up, the effect must have been devastating over a wide area. But Harappa continued to exist after 1900 B.C., though with a greatly diminished population. Other cities suffered sharp declines.
In the end, the civilization did not so much collapse as disintegrate or de-urbanize, for reasons that may not be fully known until the Indus script can be deciphered. Then the civilization faded into the background and became truly "lost" until the buried stones and bricks of it cities were uncovered.
It was one of the few "pure archeological discoveries," Dr. Possehl said. "Egypt, we knew from the Bible, and Ur, also. There was Chinese literature with references to ancestral cultures. But there had been no suggestion in any literature before of the Indus civilization."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Remembering David Schramm, Gentle Giant of Cosmology

BYLINE: By DENNIS OVERBYE 

 BODY:
THE first thing you needed to know about David Schramm was that he wouldn't hurt you -- not unless you got in his way on a racquetball court or a wrestling mat or unless he had cajoled you onto some mountain with no way down. Not unless you took issue with his classic computations on how the elements were formed in the thermonuclear furnace of the Big Bang at the beginning of the universe, in which latter case he would form a posse from his mafia of astrophysical confederates and perform the intellectual equivalent of beating you to death with a baseball bat.
At 6 feet 4 inches and 230 pounds, his red-topped head cocked bemusedly in his soft chuckle, David Schramm, cosmologist, the Louis Block Distinguished Service Professor in the Physical Sciences and vice president for research of the University of Chicago, indefatigable champion of the Big Bang theory of the universe, one-time Olympic wrestling hopeful and sole proprietor of Big Bang Aviation, was impossible to ignore, especially when he indulged his characteristic habit of lifting his thick arms, as during the heat of argument, as if to squeeze your head. 
 Cosmologists certainly could not ignore him. "I always considered him to be the leader of our field, the one who organized the most conferences, chaired the most committees, acted as chief spokesperson to the world and kept us all in touch with one another," said the cosmologist Dr. Alan Guth of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
When Dr. Schramm, 52, plowed his twin-engine Cessna into a Colorado wheat field a week before Christmas and died, cosmologists and astronomers could not believe he was gone. It was as if a mountain had suddenly and inexplicably disappeared from the landscape.
Rock stars die in plane crashes. Astronomers are supposed to die in bed, sunken by the gravity of a lifetime of solemn thoughts and shy nighttime excursions into the depths of the cosmos, wreathed in a nebulosity of eminence. In the world of the universe, however, Dr. Schramm was a rock star, and at the end of January, his colleagues, students, friends, and old wrestling opponents gathered in Chicago to give him the academic equivalent of a star's send-off highlighted by a nonsectarian memorial service in the University of Chicago's Rockefeller Memorial Chapel.
"Death and tragedy strike those who lead passionate lives," Jeff Jewel, one of Dr. Schramm's graduate students, told a gathering of his students. Others described him as a gentle giant, a larger-than-life adventurer who played hard at both science and life, and whose energy and optimism inspired those around him to be better than they were.
Around Chicago they called him Schrambo for his physical audacity and feats, but his real daring had been mental, prodding his colleagues and the rest of the scientific world, especially particle physicists, to take seriously the implications of the Big Bang. His life, in fact, was a parable on the often underestimated and mistrusted role of personality and passion in science.
The history of astronomy and cosmology is littered with tales of great thinkers who lost their nerve when confronted with the wilder consequences of their abstract reasoning. Albert Einstein inserted an extra term, the so-called cosmological constant, into his solutions of general relativity in 1917 to make the universe stand still -- and thus missed the chance to predict that the universe was expanding.
George Gamow and his colleagues later envisioned the beginning of the universe as a thermonuclear fireball, but did not try to persuade radio astronomers to search for the leftover radiation; the famous cosmic background radiation was discovered by accident 20 years later.
Lack of nerve was never Dr. Schramm's problem.
"He went through life as if every door was open to him," said Dr. Gerald Wasserburg, who ran the Caltech "Lunatic Asylum," where the Moon rocks were analyzed and where as a graduate student Dr. Schramm began applying the lessons of a youth lived on the wrestling mat to science.
When Dr. Schramm picked a particularly risky and contentious topic for his doctoral thesis, Dr. Wasserburg tried to advise caution. Dr. Schramm responded with an explanation of "jugular science," Dr. Wasserburg recalled in Chicago.
Play to win, Dr. Schramm said, always play to win.
For Dr. Schramm, the Big Bang itself would be the ultimate wrestling mat. By the time he came of age, in the early 1970's, scientists were still having trouble taking the beginning of the universe seriously. Cosmologists haunted lonely dark telescope domes hoping to discern the fate of the universe in the flights of the galaxies. Particle physicists sought to discover the fundamental forces and constituents of nature by banging elementary particles together at greater and greater energies in bigger and bigger underground particle accelerators.
In the eyes of Dr. Schramm and a few other brave souls, the Big Bang was the natural meeting place for those disparate fields. "The Big Bang is the poor man's particle accelerator," Dr. Yakov Zeldovich, the Russian theorist, often said, and Dr. Schramm adopted the phrase as his mantra.
Dr. Schramm did not invent the calculations that married inner space and outer space, but he was willing to bet the fate of the universe on them. Combined with measurements of cosmic deuterium, a heavy form of hydrogen, they indicated that ordinary matter could supply the gravitational oomph to reverse the present universal expansion.
Those results were a cornerstone for a famous 1974 paper "An Unbound Universe?" Dr. Schramm and three other young astronomers, Dr. Beatrice Tinsley, Dr. James Gott and Dr. Jim Gunn, argued from a variety of lines of evidence that the universe would expand forever. That paper heralded a rude generational shift in cosmology. None of the authors were over 40.
They were relieved a year later when Dr. Allan Sandage of the Mount Wilson Observatory also concluded after 20 years of classical observations that the universe would expand forever.
In 1976 Dr. Schramm, Dr. Gunn and Dr. Gary Steigmans made the audacious suggestion that these calculations could be used to answer a fundamental question in particle physics: how many families of elementary particles are there? At the time, generations of elementary particles were proliferating seemingly without limit, as accelerators got bigger and bigger, but Dr. Schramm and his friends predicted that there could be no more than seven such generations in the end. At the time, the suggestion was viewed with skepticism by particle physicists.
"People still wanted to hear about it, but they thought it was amusing," he recalled. "Their tone was sort of 'Why don't you come and entertain us?' Heh, heh, heh."
Play to win. But observational techniques improved and by the late 1980's Dr. Schramm and his co-authors were beginning to look pretty good. Cosmological estimates of the number of particle families shrank toward four and and then three. Dr. Schramm began telling people that he and his two co-authors had been nominated for the Nobel Prize.
In the meantime, Dr. Schramm had built an empire on the Big Bang and the cosmology-particle physics connection at the University of Chicago. He and Dr. Leon Lederman convinced NASA to set up an astrophysics group at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, where it could act as a "border patrol" between inner and outer space. It was famously quick to strike back when the Big Bang calculations, which had emerged as one of the pillars of Big Bang cosmology, were attacked. "People are always trying to shoot us down," Dr. Schramm explained cheerily. "So far we're still afloat."
A skit last Christmas put on by the Chicago physics students showed how it worked. In a takeoff of the scene from "The Untouchables," in which Robert de Niro, playing Al Capone, fondles a baseball bat while giving a soliloquy on teamwork and then suddenly bashes in the head of a betrayer, a student playing Dr. Schramm took a foam bat and pretended to beat another astrophysicist who had challenged the Big Bang model. Play to win.
Under the umbrella of his gregarious personality, a new style of astrophysics grew in Chicago -- brash, irreverent and fun-loving. Food fights and ski trips were regular features of the scientific life. On a 1976 visit to the Aspen Center for Physics, a longtime summer outpost for Caltech physicists, Dr. Schramm saw the mountains for the first time and fell in love, bought a house and helped transform Aspen into the summer and winter camp of cosmologists.
Always on the lookout for new talent and ideas, Dr. Schramm expanded his influence far beyond Chicago. When Dr. Guth, a young particle physicist at M.I.T., came up with an elegant new theory called inflation, which resolved many longstanding paradoxes about the universe by presuming that it had undergone a kind of quantum burp very early in time, Dr. Schramm took him under his wing and promoted the theory -- and its maker -- as if it were his own. He became a statesman of science. He was appointed vice president for research of the University of Chicago and headed an important committee of the National Academy of Sciences on the future of physics. It was suddenly easy to imagine him as a future Presidential science adviser.
Dr. Schramm's life style, meanwhile, was becoming the stuff of legend. His apartment took up the entire wing on the 52d floor of a luxury lakeshore condominium and featured a flying-saucer-like view of the Second City. He drove around in a red Porsche with license plates that read "Big Bang," and worked out on the wrestling mat with members of the Chicago Bears football team until his knees would not take it anymore. Fulfilling an old dream of his father's, Dr. Schramm bought an airplane and incorporated it under the name of Big Bang Aviation. He often flew it to conferences.
He climbed mountains on every continent but Antarctica, including McKinley, where he sat through a whiteout for four days waiting to help lug a dead body from a crevasse, and tumbled down the steep headwall of Tuckerman's Ravine on Mount Washington. He turned down an invitation to join an Everest expedition, but liked to point out that the peak of Ecuador's Chimborazo, which he had attained, was farther from the center of the earth than the top of Everest, due to the earth's equatorial bulge. Coming down Switzerland's notorious Eiger, Dr. Schramm fell, almost dragging his partner and himself off a cliff. "You should have seen the look on your face when I came past," he said when they had stopped sliding.
Such exploits earned Dr. Schramm the nickname "Schrambo." Chicago writers fawned over his "cosmic giggle."
In 1989, physicists at the Stanford Linear Accelerator in California and the European Center for Nuclear Research in Geneva held competing news conferences to announce that experiments had concluded that there were only three families of elementary particles. Dr. Schramm flew to the European center, known as CERN, for the announcement. But now there would be no Nobel, since it is not awarded posthumously.
On the evening of Dec. 19, Dr. Schramm was flying from Chicago to Aspen for the holidays and a series of annual winter physics conferences. He had climbed to 5,000 feet after a refueling stop in Denver when he radioed that his plane was stalling. Dr. Schramm turned around and headed for a field, no doubt expecting to walk away chuckling from yet another scrape. Play to win.
As word spread of the accident, many astronomers expressed disbelief that a man so often described as a force of nature could be gone.
"All I can say is that David was larger than life in many ways," said Dr. Stephen W. Hawking, the British physicist, who was a longtime friend.
At the official memorial in Chicago, Dr. Schramm's old crony, Dr. Lederman, imagined him in heaven in a "terrific argument with God about what happened before the Big Bang." God, he said, was wearing glasses for protection.
The day after the official memorial, a few dozen of Dr. Schramm's former and current students, gathered in a small seminar room for an informal remembrance of their own. Laughter broke out frequently.
"He had this ability to convince otherwise sane people to do these things," said Dr. Joshua Frieman, a former student who is now the leader of the Fermilab cosmology group. "He personified greatness, but it was not a selfish greatness. It radiated outward. In his presence you felt that could be better than you were."
If there was a sliver of light in the gloomy weeks that followed Dr. Schramm's death, it came during the American Astronomical Society meeting in January, where there was big news from God's particle accelerator about the fate of the universe, a favorite subject of Dr. Schramm. Two teams of astronomers using distant supernova explosions as beacons to chart the flow of the universe had concluded that the universal expansion had not slowed and never would; the universe would expand forever.
Moreover, their data suggested that the expansion of the universe was actually speeding up, apparently under the influence of some mysterious cosmic repulsion. Among themselves, astronomers were beginning to talk about having finally detected Einstein's old discredited cosmological constant.
On the last day of the meeting, Dr. Michael Turner, one of Dr. Schramm's oldest friends, flew in to arrange an impromptu memorial session for Dr. Schramm. Afterward, he stood in front of a chart that displayed the new data. "It would be a magical discovery," he said. "What it means is that there is some form of energy we don't understand. And the astronomers discovered it first."
He paused and nodded. "Dave would have liked that."
High on Mount Olympus, a smile broke through the clouds.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Black Success vs. Black Despair

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
As President Clinton's "national conversation" on race moves haltingly around the country, Henry Louis Gates Jr. comes forward with a call for a conversation about class.
In "The Two Nations of Black America," Mr. Gates, who is the DuBois Professor of the Humanities at Harvard University, draws a picture of growing black success along with deepening black despair. He argues in this thoughtful edition of "Frontline" that black professionals and entrepreneurs now have more in common with their white colleagues and peers than with the brothers and sisters they have left behind in the inner cities. 
 He begins a short but incisive history with his own upbringing in the working-class town of Piedmont, W.Va. An early beneficiary of affirmative action, Mr. Gates was admitted to Yale University in 1969 with 95 other selected men and women who amounted to an advance guard of America's black elite. There he found himself involved with the Black Panthers in shutting down the campus for a couple of weeks.
But he was put off by the Panthers' ideological mix of nationalism and Marxism and, perhaps more, by their tough style. As he says tonight: "The truth was, the Panthers scared us to death. They seemed like the thought police in blackface, as offensive as other bullies." He and most other students turned back to their studies. Instead of battling the school, they hit the books.
The legacy of those early achievers has been built on; there are many more black youths in America's best colleges, many more black men and women in prestigious positions and high-paid jobs. For them the promise of America has been real. But the gap within black America, Mr. Gates emphasizes, has widened, exemplified in Washington, with its black moneyed class on one side and poverty and crime on the other.
Older actors in the civil rights movement like Julian Bond, Angela Davis and Eldridge and Kathleen Cleaver give their historical perspectives, but the program's focus is on the current stark divide. Mr. Gates describes his feelings about ghetto gangs in language not often heard from black intellectuals: "I find it hard to concede that these young hoodlums are part of the same community I belong to." He says that "gangsta culture" makes him want to holler, "Since when does being black mean embracing the worst of what we can be?"
William Julius Wilson, the Harvard economist who heads the national conversation on race, sees little hope for change in what Mr. Gates calls dysfunctional behavior until opportunities open up to the underclass. The two agree with the Rev. Jesse Jackson on the need for the kind of interracial coalition that inspired the March on Washington 30 years ago.
But Mr. Gates is not optimistic. "Today," he reports, "one-third of all black Americans working full time live beneath the poverty line. Hope for a future has practically disappeared from the inner city." And he concludes, "I'm worried that the two nations within the black community are permanent."
 
FRONTLINE
The Two Nations of Black America
PBS, tonight
(Channel 13, New York, at 9)

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 733 words

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
It's Good for You

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
It was interesting to be in Prague watching on CNN as the U.S. Congress gave President Clinton a standing ovation for his call to expand NATO to Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. It was interesting because Mr. Clinton couldn't get a similar standing ovation for that proposal from the Czech Parliament.
Yes, after months of the Czech Government bombarding the public here with propaganda about why they have to join NATO, polls still show that only 54 percent of Czechs favor the idea. So just remember this equation: two-thirds of the U.S. Senate is going to be asked to ratify a NATO expansion that will ultimately cost U.S. taxpayers billions of dollars, but only half the Czech people being expanded to support the idea. . . . Hello? 
 Czech advocates of NATO have had to resort to evoking the "Red scare." You can't find a picture of former Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev anywhere in Russia today. But his face was recently plastered up in Prague, above the sarcastic words, "Thank you for freely deciding not to join NATO." The campaign was meant to shock Czechs into joining the alliance.
Indeed, to the extent that there is support here for NATO membership, it is for all the reasons the Clinton team says NATO expansion is not about. The Clintonites insist it is not an anti-Russian move, but Czechs say if it is not anti-Russian what use could NATO expansion be? "It is highly confusing to Czech people," said the Czech polling analyst Jan Hartl from the Stem agency. "They say, 'We want NATO against Russia, and if it's not against Russia, who needs it?' "
Those Czechs who remain indifferent to NATO membership fall into several camps. Many simply see no threat, so no reason. Some older Czechs are more afraid of Germany than Russia. Many younger people are deeply skeptical of spending money on the Czech military, which did not defend the country from the Nazis in 1938, from the Communists in 1948 or from the Soviets in 1968.
To break down this skepticism, Jiri Bis, head of the Impact ad agency in Prague, has been running a privately financed, pro-NATO campaign, often using sports heros and movie stars to sell NATO expansion as though it were deodorant. It's the Czech equivalent of "Hi, I'm Michael Jordan and I'm here to talk to you about NATO. . . . Hi, I'm Cindy Crawford and I'm here to talk to you about the Eastern Front." He's also tried to make NATO fun. On Christmas Eve they gave out 100 fresh carp to the first 100 people who showed up in Prague's main square wearing pro-NATO ribbons. They also gave away Polish dumplings, Hungarian goulash and Czech beer to honor the three would-be NATO members. There has also been an effort to underscore that joining NATO "is a way for Czechs to rejoin Europe, which we were separated from by the cold war," said Mr. Bis.
But even those Czechs who see NATO membership as a bridge to Western Europe would really prefer to join the European Union first, but the E.U. has been dragging its feet because it does not want Eastern European workers or farm products. When asked in a Stem poll what was more important, E.U. membership or NATO, 44 percent of Czechs said they preferred E.U. membership and 13 percent said NATO.
So far cost of membership has not been an issue, because no one really knows how much is involved. But it will be high. This is a country that traded its only advanced fighter jets, 10 MIG-29's, to Poland for helicopters because it could not afford to maintain the planes. Says Miroslav Vacek, a former Czech Defense Minister and leader of the Communist Party here, "For the NATO alliance the Czech Army cannot mean anything in its present condition, and I doubt we will have the economic growth in the coming years to pay for the upgrades."
And if NATO expansion has to be paid for with reduced health care, social care and education, he added, it is going to lose a lot of support. When the Czech Parliament's Foreign Relations Committee began debating ratification of NATO membership the other day, only 6 out of the 18 members of the committee showed up.
So get this: The Clinton team is begging Czechs to take something -- NATO expansion -- that is for their own protection, and yet barely half feel they want it, need it or are ready to pay much for it. But never mind, the Clintonites intend to plow ahead with expansion anyway. Who says American foreign policy can't be funny?

HEADLINE: Study Questions The Usual View Of Downsizing

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Month after month, the Labor Department reports the creation of hundreds of thousands of new jobs. The latest report showed that 358,000 were added in January, even as the economy showed signs of weakening.
Where are all these jobs? While low-wage work is one source, a new study finds that well-paid middle managers and other upper-level office workers are being hired in big numbers. 
 The study, to be made public today, challenges two widely held views about the work force. One is that corporate downsizing has decimated middle-level management. Downsizing has indeed been widespread, but hiring has outpaced the layoffs, the study found. The other challenge is to the concept that corporate America is starved for people highly skilled in technology. The real draw for the college graduate is an upper-level office job, not a job that requires education in science and technology. That specialty work does not pay as well.
Thirty-seven percent of all the jobs created since 1989 have been for "business professionals and managers," the study said. That was up from 20 percent of the new jobs in the 1970's. These are the middle-level executives, the bankers, accountants, brokers, sales account representatives, insurance agents, advertising and public relations specialists, financial officers, analysts, buyers, personnel managers and data processors who occupy America's ubiquitous office towers. Their annual pay averaged a healthy $46,000 in the mid-1990's.
"The decision structure in a global economy demands these people," said Steven Rose, senior economist at the Educational Testing Service, and a co-author of the study. "It takes less and less to produce a product or service, but more and more to promote it, manage the process, customize it, make it consumer friendly, deal with style and convenience. No firm feels it can cut back without losing market share."
The Educational Testing Service prepares and administers the SAT and other college entrance exams, and draws its revenue from the fees paid by students who take these tests. The new study's message, not surprisingly, is that college graduates populate the new professional and managerial class and, thus, get the highest-paying jobs, without high-technology knowledge. Indeed, these jobs place a premium on tasks that a generation ago often did not require a college education, Mr. Rose and his co-author acknowledge.
"Our study raises basic questions about what these people need to know to do their jobs," said Anthony P. Carnevale, the co-author and a vice president at Educational Testing Service. "A case can be made for a liberal arts education, with its emphasis on analysis and problem solving, although companies seem to prefer people who have taken business courses. The curriculum issue is naturally of great concern to us, and we don't have answers."
This study, as do most that try to explain labor force dynamics, relies on Labor Department data. What sets it apart is the decision to rearrange workers into the authors' own set of occupations and functions. The goal was to more accurately reflect reality, but some labor economists said the study's classifications were arbitrary and subjective.
"The tremendously positive spin on this office-economy stuff is unwarranted and inappropriate," said Lawrence Mishel, chief economist at the Economic Policy Institute.
Front-office managers at a steel mill, or a computer manufacturer, or a restaurant chain, for example, are included in the new category of business professionals and managers. But supervisors on the factory floor -- probably earning less -- are excluded, as are managers of McDonald's restaurants. Such distinctions are not made by the Labor Department, although in Mr. Rose's view they reflect valid divisions.
Similarly, the study distinguishes between a sales representative who handles a corporate account and a sales clerk in a store. The former is in the manager category, while the latter is not. An executive secretary and an office administrator are also included, but not a file clerk or a mail room manager. Accountants, insurance agents and brokers qualify as office professionals, but not most engineers, scientists, architects, computer system analysts and technicians. Unless they have shifted to the office environment, they are classified as production people.
From all the tabulation, these findings emerge:
*Of the 69 million new jobs created from 1959 through 1995, the last year in the study, 34 million, or 49 percent, fell into the new business professional and manager class. The category reached a high for a single decade of 39 percent in the 1980's, as the global economy took shape, and edged down slightly, to 37 percent, in the 1990's.
*Average wages, which had risen through the 1980's for managers and professionals, fell slightly in the 1990's, Mr. Rose said. Wages were a casualty of the downsizing in management ranks. "Corporations tried to cut costs, but they also needed these people, and they ended up hiring more managers and professionals than they fired," he said.
*Among prime-age workers, 30 to 59 years old, the new office sector accounted for 41 percent of all employment, up from 30 percent in 1959. In addition, business professionals and managers pocketed half of the earnings of all workers, excluding those earning more than $200,000 a year. Their average pay in 1995 was "47 percent more than the average earnings of workers in all the other sectors," the study said.
For Mr. Rose, a prominent labor economist, the study is an important explanation of the sources of wage inequality. It challenges the view that workers can close the wage gap through training in technology, math and science.
But even before its formal release, the study drew criticism from labor economists familiar with its contents. Some, like Frank Levy of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, note that other studies have already spotted "the accelerated growth of managers, administrators and sales occupations." Census Bureau data do show that the ratio of managers to production workers has risen over the last three decades.
Alan Krueger of Princeton contends that the study fails to take into account the increasing level of skill needed to make efficient use of office computers. And Peter Gottschalk of Boston University said the classification procedure used by Mr. Rose and Mr. Carnevale was too arbitrary and subjective.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Most Gauges Fall on the 2d-Slowest Trading Day of 1998

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mostly lower yesterday in the second-slowest trading day so far this year, reflecting a dearth of economic data and corporate earnings reports that made investors reluctant to buy without a clearer sense of the market's next move.
Investors were also wary of driving stock prices much higher, analysts said, after the strong gains and heavy trading volume of the previous week, when the Standard & Poor's 500 index hit four new closing highs. 
 Last week's gains reflected a growing belief that corporate earnings would not be hurt much by the economic problems in Asia as well as expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise short-term interest rates anytime soon.
"It was such a big week last week and people are trying to figure out which way this thing is going to go," said Alan Bond, chief investment officer of Bond Procope Capital Management in New York.
After gaining more than 282 points, or 3.6 percent last week, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 8,180.52, down 8.97 points, coming back after an intraday decline of more than 47 points. American Express, Chevron and Hewlett-Packard led the blue-chip index lower.
Even with the slight loss yesterday, the Dow average is only 78.79 points below its all-time high of 8,259.31.
The S.& P. 500 index dipped 1.72 points, or less than two-tenths of a percent, to 1,010.74. The S.& P. rose 3.3 percent last week.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index fell 3.92 points, to 1,690.43, as well-known technology shares, including Intel, Cisco, Microsoft and Sun Microsystems, declined. Based on the strength of other technology companies like Oracle, the Nasdaq composite had climbed 4.6 percent last week.
Bucking the trend, the Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks rose 1.78 points, to 447.28, after rising 3.6 percent last week.
As evidence of yesterday's limited trading activity, volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 542.5 million shares, falling off last week's pace, which was marked by four days in which more than 690 million shares changed hands. It was also the lowest daily trading volume since 367 million shares were traded on Jan. 2.
"This is part of the normal digestion when you have a big up week," said Andrew Brooks, vice president in charge of equity trading at T. Rowe Price Associates. "Last week caught a lot of people by surprise," Mr. Brooks said, pointing to the strong upward moves in the major market indexes.
And after last week's strong gains, investors were wary of quickly pushing the Dow to a new high, said Ken Ducey, director of trading at BT Brokerage in New York.
Without any major barometers to signal market direction, investors were left to ponder the uncertainties in the market, which include the outlook for corporate earnings in the first quarter, the implications of the reported White House scandal and the rising possibility of a military confrontation with Iraq.
"People are waiting for these things to fall into place," Mr. Ducey said, adding that "nobody's rushing in to buy stocks and nobody's rushing in to sell."
Skittish investors, who decided not to buy stocks earlier this year, have missed a strong move in the market, said Arthur Hogan, a senior trader at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter.
As a result, they might decide to wait until the market sells off a bit, hoping to pick up stocks at lower prices. Or, if the market continues to move higher, investors might be pulled in by fear that they may continue to miss future gains, he said.
One sign of investor uncertainty about the stock market could be the record amount of cash that has been flowing into money market mutual funds, Mr. Hogan said. Approximately $11.4 billion flowed into money market funds during the week ended Feb. 4, said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services in Arcata, Calif.
Since the beginning of the year, money market funds' assets have increased by about 4 percent, to $1.99 trillion, the highest amount ever, Mr. Adler said.
"There are a lot of investors on the sidelines with a wait-and-see attitude," Mr. Hogan said of the cash buildup in money market funds.

HEADLINE: Newark Shows Increased Revenue

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Mayor Sharpe James said today that increased revenue from operations by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey here, as well as improved property tax collections, would net the city about $25 million more than expected this year and would allow the hiring of 300 police officers and a 5 percent cut in the local tax rate.
 The Mayor's election year announcement came today as he released his $517 million budget proposal, down from $546 million last year. Mr. James said the revenue windfall also allowed him to propose a cut in municipal water rates. 
 The bulk of the new revenue -- $18 million -- came from the Port Authority operations. With an improved national and state economy, there was growth at Newark International Airport that translated into more flights and more landing fees, increasing the agency's annual payment to the city under a net lease agreement.
The improved economy also increased property tax payments to 86 percent of the rolls, from 82 percent. All of these factors combined with what Mr. James termed the city's "fiscally conservative policies" to produce "one of the best budgets we have crafted in years."
The budget must now be debated and voted on by the nine-member City Council. which includes the Mayor's two opponents in this May's election.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Drop as Traders Await 3 Days of Auctions

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices ended lower yesterday, weakened by selling ahead of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auction of $35 billion in new debt this week.
The 30-year bond fell 12/32, to a price of 102 18/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.94 percent from 5.92 percent on Friday. 
 With no economic news to influence the market, traders focused on the impending auctions.
Prices often weaken around the time of an auction as securities firms seek to cause yields to rise by selling bonds in an effort to attract investor interest. That can help insure quick distribution of the new debt they buy from the Treasury and resell to investors. The firms try to avoid amassing big supplies of new Treasury debt, leaving them exposed to a potential decline in the market.
Some of the weakness in the market yesterday may have reflected fear that prices would decline after the refunding is completed. Kim Rupert, an economist with Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, said Treasury bonds had fallen after every February refunding auction this decade, except for 1993 and 1995.
The Treasury will auction $13 billion of new three-year notes today, followed by $12 billion of 10-year notes tomorrow and $10 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday. In when-issued trading late in the day, the three-year note to be sold today was offered at a price to yield 5.43 percent, up 3 basis points from Friday, while the 10-year was offered at a price to yield 5.61 percent, up 4 basis points, and the 30-year bond at 5.95 percent, up 2 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Yesterday the Government held its regular weekly sale of three- and six-month bills and had good investor demand. Analysts said the number of bids compared with the total amount of the auction, known as the bid-to-cover ratio, improved over other recent sales, with the three-month issue getting a solid 5.96-to-1 ratio and the six-month maturity, 5.07 to 1.
Besides the auctions this week, market participants will be looking for further signs of an economic slowing when the Government releases its January retail sales report on Thursday. The last retail sales report showed a gain of seven-tenths of a percent over all and two-tenths of a percent without autos. For this report the consensus is for a gain of three-tenths of a percent over all and five-tenths, excluding autos.

HEADLINE: U.S. Jewish Group Sets Up Office In Berlin as Sentinel Against Bias

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Reflecting a gradual resurgence of Jewish life in Germany, the American Jewish Committee opened a permanent office in Berlin today at a site once owned by a Jewish family that fled the Nazis.
The inauguration drew high-level German officials together with United States and Israeli diplomats to ceremonies including the nailing of a mezuza to the door of offices in the building that stands in Berlin's Mitte District, close to both the ruined center of Hitler's Reich and the construction sites that have come to symbolize the emerging new capital of a reunified Germany. 
 The building is also close to the proposed site for a German national memorial to the Holocaust -- a project still surrounded by debate.
David A. Harris, the executive director of the American Jewish Committee, said, "We never expected the kind of fascination that has surrounded the opening of this office."
The remark, made in an interview, reflected the complex emotions felt by Germans seeking what Mr. Harris called Jewish "validation" of their efforts to come to terms with the Nazi past. But, he said, the point of the office was not -- as he put it -- to tell Germans that they had been "koshered" by the presence of an American Jewish organization. Rather, he said, the committee, which was founded in 1906 to fight anti-Semitism, saw itself as "another ally, supporter and watchdog" against any future "German fear that the demons will again come out of the closet, that with the fading of memory such a thing could occur."
Of particular concern to the organization is a surge of neo-Nazism in the economically depressed former East Germany, Mr. Harris said. Other officials of the group said a principal task was to promote a greater understanding of modern Germany among American Jews.
"American Jews' perceptions of Germany remain split and not very positive," Eugene DeBow, the director of the new office, said recently. The office, in the former East Berlin, is on a site once owned by the Mosse family, a prominent Jewish family in prewar Berlin. The family won back title to the land after reunification.
The site was sold to a German developer, and the architect who drew up the plans for a new building was Hans Strauch of Boston, Mass., the nephew of George Mosse, a historian who fled Berlin in 1939. The developer agreed to give the American Jewish Committee rent-free space for 10 years, Mr. Harris said.
Since the fall of the Iron Curtain in Europe, Germany's Jewish population has more than doubled, from 29,000 a decade ago to an estimated 70,000. The increase is ascribed to the arrival of tens of thousands of Jews from the former Soviet Union who, under German law, have automatic residence rights in Germany.
"There is a chance that this Jewish life can once again become an integral part of German culture and society," President Roman Herzog said at an official ceremony marking the inauguration.
The inauguration was accompanied by another undercurrent. The American Jewish Committee reportedly angered Chancellor Helmut Kohl last May by publicizing Bonn's refusal to pay compensation to Holocaust survivors in Eastern Europe. The dispute was finally resolved last month when Germany agreed to set up a $110 million fund for some 18,000 Eastern European Jewish survivors.
Mr. Kohl was invited to the ceremonies but declined, citing scheduling problems, and did not send a representative, American Jewish officials said. The absence of a representative was initially seen as a slight, the officials said. But it emerged later that Mr. Kohl had sent a message to the committee president welcoming the group to Berlin, German officials said.

HEADLINE: Craze for Beanie Babies Helped Surge in '97 Toy Sales

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Those pint-sized bean bag characters, stuffed animals that gyrate and giggle and key chains that youngsters nurture like pets helped push toy sales up nearly 8 percent last year, double what the industry and analysts were expecting.
"We had a very good year in the toy industry with Sing and Snore Ernie, Star Wars, Barbie, Beanie Babies and Tamagotchis and other virtual pets driving market sales up to the double-digit numbers at various times throughout the year," Gary Baughman, chairman of the Toy Manufacturers of America, said yesterday during an industry address to open the 95th annual American International Toy Fair in New York. 
 Retail sales increased 7.8 percent last year, to $22.5 billion, while manufacturers' unit sales rose 5.6 percent. Including video games, total industry shipments grew 6.9 percent, in units, or 14.3 percent, in dollars. The healthy economy, licensing arrangements tied to hit movies like the re-release of the "Star Wars" trilogy and strong consumer confidence contributed to the growth.
As the Toy Fair was getting under way, Hasbro Inc., the industry giant, announced an acquisition that is intended to capitalize on the growth of electronic toys. Hasbro said it was acquiring Tiger Electronics Inc., the privately held maker of the popular virtual toys known as Giga Pets, for $335 million. Tiger said the sale would accelerate the international growth of its toys.
As for the overall toy business, "it was a surprisingly robust year," said Frank Reysen Jr., editor of Playthings, a trade publication. "I don't think anybody would have foreseen an 8 percent growth."
A number of factors contributed to the increase. For one, toy companies have been aggressively marketing products throughout the year to be less dependent on consumers' often finicky shopping moods during the all-important fourth quarter. While Christmas sales still account for half of the industry's annual revenues, that is a decrease from as much as 70 percent in previous years. Products based on popular summer movies have helped, as has the Beanie Baby craze, which had youngsters scrambling year round to collect the latest of the little stuffed characters as they hit the market.
A wider range of popular playthings last year than in previous years also helped the industry, making manufacturers and retailers less reliant on a few hot items that they could not keep in stock. And manufacturers are clearly looking to once again capitalize on the success of many of those items this year.
Visitors would be hard pressed to walk through a showroom at the fair this week and not find some doll or creature giggling or snoring. The hope, of course, is to come up with the next Tickle Me Elmo, as Mattel's Tyco Preschool division did when it duplicated that toy's success in 1996 with Sing & Snore Ernie last year.
Tyco Preschool is showing off several new Ernie pals this year, including the Sesame Street Walk & Talk Assortment. The $29.99 characters, including Elmo, Big Bird and Cookie Monster, walk and talk when their sneakers are pressed.
There are also plenty of new virtual pets this year, intended to relegate last year's models to the back of the toy chest. They include new ones from Tiger called Giga Pets Plus, which enable owners to take care of up to eight characters, and Giga Farm, which enables youngsters to raise an assortment of farm animals and also requires them to virtually raise crops for the animals to eat.
The popularity of virtual pets is responsible for one huge theme at this year's Toy Fair. Everyone, it seems, is making dolls that require the same nurturing that is necessary to care for the electronic pets. One is Takin Care of Baby, created by Toyriffic L.L.C., which may well be the next best thing to having a baby brother or sister.
Once its internal clock is set, the doll cries spontaneously up to 20 times a day. It also "wakes up" every morning at 7:30 demanding to be fed, played with or given medicine, and responds by saying "I love you, Mommy."
"I called my sister who has a 3-year-old and said, 'I don't know how you do it,' " said Neil C. Wasserman, who used $20,000 of his savings to create the doll. "I wanted to throw the thing out the window."
Computer-programmed playmates are a big trend this year, as well, playing off of a hit from last year, Actimates Barney from Microsoft. Mattel is coming out with My Interactive Pooh, a computerized stuffed bear. Using CD-ROM, parents can program the toy to repeat a child's name, hair color, age or birthday as well as to sing and tell stories. The bear can then be disconnected from the computer and will interact with the child for up to 20 minutes. Pooh's companionship will not come cheap, though. The bear sells at retail for $100.
Not surprisingly, most companies at the fair are offering beanie-something. Tyco has Sesame Street Beans and Hasbro has Star War Buddies bean bag toys. In all, Hasbro is introducing more than 100 new "Star Wars" toys, including collectible figurines and toy vehicles.
As usual, Barbie provided a few surprises, including a new career. She has joined the W.N.B.A. and now wears official league gear. W.N.B.A. Barbie, which sells for $20, comes with a basketball rim and net and a ball that magnetically attaches to her, enabling her to shoot.
With so many potential big sellers again this year, the toy manufacturers' association is cautiously optimistic about the prospects for another successful year. It conservatively forecast a 4 percent sales gain for this year but also acknowledged that toy companies still faced some challenges.
Fluctuations in the Asian economies could affect the industry, for instance. While weaknesses in the Asian currencies could push production costs lower this year, retail sales could suffer as well.
In the United States, meanwhile, toy makers are finding it more difficult to market effectively to children. The growth of cable television, -- with such networks as Nickelodeon, WB Network and UPN -- is making it harder to find mass audiences of youths to advertise to.
Over all, though, the industry should have another strong year, according to Mr. Baughman, the toy group chairman, who is also chief executive of Fisher-Price Inc. "We're coming off a healthy year in the toy industry that should create momentum for 1998," he said.

HEADLINE: Black-White Economic Gap Is Narrowing, White House Says

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
After two decades without progress in narrowing the economic gap between black and white Americans, the nation shows tentative signs that economic inequality between the races has been reduced in the last few years, the Clinton Administration said today.
Much of the improvement was linked by Administration economists to the economic expansion that began seven years ago and continues to rumble on. Unlike the boom of the mid-1980's, when much of the gain went to people at the top of the income scale, the current upturn has not added to overall economic inequality, they said. 
 Choosing selectively among a broad range of statistics, the Administration said the signs of renewed progress in narrowing the gap between the races included a rise in the median income of black families since 1993 that was larger than the increase for non-Hispanic white families, record high income for black families in 1996 and a drop in the poverty rate for black families to a record low.
"Such developments raise hope for renewed and sustained progress toward economic equality," said Janet L. Yellen, the chairman of the White House's Council of Economic Advisers.
Administration officials said they did not want to overstate the progress or minimize the economic gulf that continues to divide the races. Their findings were contained in the annual Economic Report of the President, which the White House submitted to Congress today.
The report said that income gaps between black and white families remain as large as they were three decades ago and that the median wealth of white families may be as much as 10 times that of black and Hispanic families. And while there has been some narrowing of differences in educational attainment, which speaks for longer term gains, there were growing gaps in social indicators of economic success like the proportion of families headed by single women -- 14 percent among white families last year compared to 47 percent among black families.
"Substantial disparities in economic status across racial and ethnic groups persist," Ms. Yellen said.
Private economists said the Administration's conclusions were generally in line with their own. But they said it was important to distinguish between the benefits to non-white families from the current low unemployment rate and robust economic growth, which could prove transitory when the economy next turns down, and the much slower progress in addressing the underlying social and historical causes of inequality.
"If all we're seeing is labor market improvement, that could go away the next time the Midwest goes into recession and all the good jobs go away again," said Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, the research organization.
The Administration's report also said the nation has made some progress in reducing poverty among children in recent years. The combination of the strong economy and Government programs like the earned-income tax credit, the report said, helped push the poverty rate among children down to 20.5 percent in 1996 from 22.7 percent in 1993, following a relatively steady rise that started in 1969.
"Despite these improvements, far too many children remain economically vulnerable," Ms. Yellen said.
The report said the nation's overall economic condition was the best it had been in a generation, with few problems on the horizon and little risk that even the financial turmoil in Asia will derail the expansion.
In its discussion of racial inequality, the Administration said that income differences between white and non-white Americans narrowed substantially in the decade after the Civil Rights Act of 1964, but then expanded again or held steady for much of the next 20 years.
In the last few years, though, black families have closed some of the gap with their white counterparts in terms of inflation-adjusted income. Median family incomes for blacks increased 13.4 percent between 1993 and 1996, to $26,500, while median family income among non-Hispanic whites increased 5 percent, to $47,100, the report said. Median incomes for Hispanic families have been declining over the past several decades due to an influx of immigrants with little education, but have turned up slightly in the last few years and stood at $26,200 in 1996.
Family incomes tend to be driven in part by the strength of the economy. Administration officials said the narrowing of the income gap, and the general reduction in inequality during the current expansion, might also have been helped by an increase in the minimum wage and by the growing numbers of racial minorities who are completing high school. The gap between high-school completion rates for white students and black students, for example, has narrowed to seven percentage points in 1996 from 20 points in 1967.
Broader measures of economic well-being, like household wealth, represent longer-term trends. By one of two surveys used by the Government to measure household wealth, the median net worth of white households in 1993 was $47,740, more than 10 times greater than that of black or Hispanic households. A similar survey in 1995 found median net worth was $73,900 for non-Hispanic white households and $16,500 for all other households. As of the 1993 survey, 95 percent of black households reported owning no stocks, compared to 75 percent of white households.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

America Online Shares Rise On Higher Internet Fees
America Online shares rose more than 12 percent to an all-time high after the company broke from its standard $19.95 price of unlimited Internet access, raising the fee to $21.95 for its 11 million members -- half of the home Internet market in the United States. The shares surged $11.9375, to $110.4375.
The on-line service provider also promoted to a new No. 2 position, Robert W. Pittman, the former MTV founder recruited to help the company last year. In a further move welcomed by investors, America Online cut half the jobs left at Compuserve, the rival it bought last week. D2. 

G.M. to Buy 10 Percent of Shares
General Motors announced an unexpectedly large buyback of its stock, extending efforts made by the company over the last year to raise the price. The $4 billion repurchase amounts to about 10 percent of G.M.'s outstanding shares. G.M. shares rose nearly 4 percent, to $62.9375. D2.
 
Dow Jones Posts Big Loss
Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, reported a loss of $889.3 million, mostly because of a write-off connected to the reorganization of its financial data business, Dow Jones Markets. The company is also said to have received an offer of $500 million for Dow Jones Markets from Bridge News. Other offers are said to be lower. D6.
 
CVS to Buy Michigan Chain
CVS agreed to buy Arbor Drugs, a big Michigan drugstore chain, for $1.48 billion in stock. The acquisition would make CVS the biggest drugstore chain in the country. D2.
 
Time Warner Sells Six Flags
Premier Parks will buy the Six Flags theme-park chain from Time Warner and its partner, Boston Ventures, for $965 million. Premier will leapfrog from No. 5 to No. 2 in the theme-park business, behind Walt Disney. D6.
 
Stocks Finish Mostly Lower
Stocks ended mostly lower yesterday in the second-slowest trading day of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average, which gained 282 points last week, closed down 8.97 points, to 8,180.52. D8.
 
South Korea's Next Problem
While South Korean banks' renegotiation of short-term debts to foreign banks eased some concerns, a messier problem may be unpaid loans local companies owe Korean banks. Dozens of debtors are collapsing. A1.
 
Big Merger in Water Business
United States Filter will buy Culligan Water Technologies for $1.5 billion in stock, combining a leading industrial-water systems provider with one of the best known names in residential water. D2.
 
Insurers Seek Truck Changes
An insurers group urged auto makers to redesign sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, after concluding the vehicles increased the risk of death for other drivers while providing little if any additional protection for their own occupants. A1.
 
Economists Seek Euro Delay
Criticizing what they called ill preparations for the euro, 155 prominent German economists pleaded for a delay in Europe's single currency, scheduled to make its debut in less than a year. It was the broadest and most credible objection yet to the monetary union plans, but is not expected to result in a postponement. D4.
 
Ex-Fox Executive Joins Henson
Margaret Loesch, formerly vice chairwoman of Fox Kids Worldwide, was named president of Jim Henson Television. D6.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Every Sled Dog Has Its Day

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

DATELINE: NAGANO, Japan

 BODY:
IF you can dream up something semi-athletically peculiar to do on ice, snow or on the side of a glacier, Juan Antonio Samaranch has an Olympic medal in his bag for you.
Like Bill Clinton with the economy, Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, says that one of his remaining missions before his term expires in 2001 is to continue to grow the Winter Games. More sports. More athletes. More sponsors. More mind-altering traffic jams on slippery mountain roads. 
 More women.
"The Olympic movement is determined to make its contribution so that the 21st century marks the beginning of a new era for women in world sport," Samaranch declared late last week. "Any new sport wishing to be included in the Olympic program must comprise the women's events."
There is no place, he insisted, for old-school sexism within the Olympic Movement. But if you can find a way to keep the layers of clothing and body fat off the little pixies, the figure skaters and gymnasts have demonstrated that their movement will be enhanced, as will the Movement's television ratings and its bloated revenue stream.
Bikini bobsled, guaranteed, would rate right up there with the Super Bowl. And as many journalists here have been complaining about the dearth of transcendent news at these Olympics compared with Lillehammer's four years ago, someone may want to introduce Tonya Harding to Latrell Sprewell before Salt Lake City in 2002.
What a pairs team for a sport whose every event goes to arbitration.
Curling and snowboarding are the newest medal sports at the Nagano Games. The inclusion of the former supports my point that no activity that defies comprehension is beyond consideration, while the latter emphasizes how the Olympics, the true global sports league, is determined to incorporate Generation X before ESPN and its Extreme (or X) Games becomes the unofficial Olympics R Us.
Look, then, for future Olympic takeouts from the following Winter X menu: ice climbing, snow mountain bike racing, skier X, snowmobile snocross and a yet-to-be titled competition in which young men and women with too much hair spray sit stiffly on a snowbank and make wisecracks while delivering the scores.
Just kidding on that last one, though it is interesting to note that Samaranch did not totally dismiss the question of dog sled races, which has everyone in Greenland pumped and Alaska talking secession from the United States. (Note to my wife: Call the trainer. I am reserving a space in the 2002 athletes' kennel for the puppy right away.)
"It's not easy to find new sports for the Winter Olympics, but we have room," Samaranch concluded in his news conference last week.
Dear Mr. Movement and Shaker: All it takes is a little imagination. You, for instance, summarily rejected an earnest Japanese reporter's suggestion that sumo wrestling be added to the hopelessly overcrowded Summer Games. "My answer is no," Samaranch said. "It is a sport practiced in very few countries."
Here, then, some thoughts on how to grow the Winter Games:
Sumo speed skating. Now that women are being treated as team-sports equals in hockey, basketball, soccer, etc., isn't it time for the Olympics to stop discriminating against the unhealthy? This competition would require gorging, not training, along with a small ponytail. The United States, homeland of junk food, could be an immediate medal power.
Monkey moguls. The obsession with those friendly little critters at the hot springs here has got me thinking. Put the monkeys on skis and let 'em rip. With the dogs, the monkeys, perhaps a wide selection of marine life captured in the popular and Olympic-deserving sport of ice fishing, I'm thinking about a family-friendly zoo and aquarium that would be built in host Olympic cities with precious tax dollars.
Cell phone cross-country. Forget the Olympic rings; the most prominent rings in Nagano are coming from the tiny telephones in everyone's pockets. Beepers are out of control. Everybody's E-mailing the world here at the On Line Olympics. Photographers with laptops are sending pictures from the tops of mountains. Meanwhile, those poor cross-country saps are out in the woods for hours with no one to talk to. Give them a cell phone and Geraldo's number.
American football: Paul Tagliabue, you owe me for this. But why not one more Dream Team? "The rule is that all winter sports must be on snow and ice," Samaranch argued. To which I say: has this man ever heard of the Ice Bowl?

GRAPHIC: Photo: All he needs is skates. (Barton Silverman)
