HEADLINE: Film's Rising Star: New York;
Independent Movies Spur the City's Celluloid Success

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Larry Meistrich is not central casting's idea of a movie mogul. He wears torn jeans to the office. His two huge dogs -- both half chow-chow, half Samoyed, found abandoned on a film set -- wander around his lower Manhattan office, lapping water from a giant silver bowl and nuzzling up to visitors.
But Mr. Meistrich, who is all of 31, produced the 1996 hit film "Sling Blade," and that has given his independent film company, the Shooting Gallery, a name and a reputation, not to mention a fortune. Last month, Mr. Meistrich decided to flex some of that newfound muscle. With little fanfare, he announced that he would build the biggest movie sound stage in the world in an old industrial park in Harrison, N.J., just outside Newark. 
 "We want the same toys Los Angeles has," Mr. Meistrich said.
Being an independent filmmaker in New York, unless you were Woody Allen or Martin Scorsese or Spike Lee, used to mean three things: obscurity, poverty and an attitude that turned the first two traits into badges of artistic integrity. No more. An explosion of movies and television shows being filmed in the region in the last few years, and the heightened visibility of an edgy, urban movie-making style long associated with the New York film world, has changed the scene. New York is hot. New York filmmakers are hot.
"New York has become a nurturing, sexy, cutting-edge environment for independent filmmakers," said Terry Casaletta, the associate eastern executive director of the Director's Guild of America. "It's apparent by the level of increased production in New York that the rest of the film industry has come to the same conclusion."
The forces behind the city's rediscovery are intertwined, like subplots in a film noir. The number of locally produced films has grown, and Hollywood producers and directors have, at the same time, decided to make more movies here. But Hollywood has also embraced some of the ideas and rhythms that film scholars say have long characterized New York independent film, and that in turn has led to even greater expansion, as Hollywood tries to capture or tame whatever it is that New York has got.
The results are stark: New York City, New York State and New Jersey all set records in 1997 for the volume of productions and the amount of money the film industry spent locally. Spending on movie, television and other such productions rose to $2.37 billion in the city last year from $2.23 billion in 1996, according to figures released last week by the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, making the film industry the fastest job growth sector in the city's economy.
And while not even Mr. Meistrich is predicting a return of New York as the industry's capital, as it was early in the century when Thomas A. Edison and his imitators were cranking out slice-of-life films like "Central Park" and "At the Foot of the Flatiron," the new growth is raising questions. Is New York doomed -- as it seems to be on days like today when all eyes are on Los Angeles and the Academy Award nominations -- to live at the whim of Hollywood's casting call? Is there a middle way between aloof independence and mainstream market success?
"The pioneers of the independent film business were working outside the Hollywood system," said Daniel Victor, the president of Boneyard Entertainment, a Manhattan company born two years ago to finance and produce independent movies. "The Shooting Gallery is a pioneer in terms of where they'd like to take the independent film business from here."
Mr. Victor, a former entertainment lawyer, made his first film investment in "Sling Blade" and got a return on his money of more than 300 percent. He is now preparing a $15 million fund to back films mostly costing $3 million or less.
What that kind of money creates, when added to the mix of bigger budget Hollywood films like "Meet Joe Black," "Ransom" and the new "Godzilla," which were all filmed at least partly in New York, is demand.
Throughout the region, film and television crews have swarmed into armories and warehouses, creating sound stages in places that were not built for the purpose. The Park Slope Armory in Brooklyn had three movies filmed in succession last year. Some places have taken on a air of semi-permanence, with one film crew in some cases passing on its equipment to the crew of the next film coming in.
Talk of expanded capacity is everywhere as well. Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens, where the television show "Cosby" is filmed, is considering adding on. Sonalysts Studio in Waterford, Conn., where Steven Spielberg filmed many of the interior scenes for "Amistad," is also planning major growth. A company in New Jersey founded by a line producer from "Saturday Night Live" and a businesswoman from Franklin Lakes, N.J., said last week that they were entering the fray with plans to open a 30,000-square-foot sound stage complex in Paterson, N.J.
"There's no question that if we build them, they will be filled," said Patricia Reed Scott, the New York City's Commissioner of Film, Theater and Broadcasting. "We want to build on the extraordinary numbers we're doing so that the critical mass goes larger."
But there are also plenty of worriers. Independent filmmakers say that while all the new attention has made financing movies easier than ever, the unique flavor of New York filmmaking could easily get lost in all the new opportunities and pressures.
"Basically what's happening is that Hollywood is trying to co-opt the entire independent film world," said Ira Deutchman, a partner at Redeemable Features, a three-year-old independent production company in Manhattan that is probably best known for the film "Kiss Me Guido," released last year. "There was a time when a low-budget film could go in, and if it made a million in the box office, it was perceived of as a success. These days, a million is a failure -- they keep raising the bar."
Most film scholars trace the tradition of the New York independent film to people like John Cassavetes, the actor and director who honed his skills in New York in live television in the 1950's. His first feature film, "Shadows," in 1960, with its grainy texture and jumpy scene cuts, was embraced by a generation of New York filmmakers as a blueprint.
"There's a certain pace that was carried from the hectic quality of live TV into the rhythms of New York City movies," said Annette Insdorf, director of undergraduate film studies at Columbia University. "And there's a greater overlap between the concerns and style of European films and New York independent movies than between New York independent movies and Hollywood."
Recent New York films like "All Over Me," directed by a Columbia film school graduate, Alex Sichel; "The Daytrippers," directed by Greg Mottola, also from Columbia's film school, and "New Jersey Drive," directed by Nick Gomez, all include the city or the region as a prominent feature, almost a character. Other locally based filmmakers, like Joel and Ethan Coen, carry the banner of New York edginess, film experts say, whether they shoot in the city or in the snowy northern plains, as in the Coens' 1996 movie, "Fargo."
Some local industry executives say the greatest danger is that New York will start to believe its own mystique. "This is not 'Field of Dreams,' " said Hal Rosenbluth, the president of Kaufman Astoria Studios. "There is nothing that says, 'If you build it, they will come.' "
Mr. Rosenbluth said the central fact of the industry is that Los Angeles leads. New York has improved as a place to live and work, and the local film production unions have become more accommodating than they were a few years ago, Mr. Rosenbluth said. Those changes have given New York star appeal, he said, but not real power to influence its fate.
While there are more television series, like "Spin City," starring Michael J. Fox, "Oz," an HBO series, and "Law and Order," being produced in New York, there are even more, like "Seinfeld" and "Friends," that are set in a fictional New York, imagined from a sound stage in California. And the region's film facilities, Mr. Rosenbluth said, are like hotels -- if Hollywood does not check in, there is simply not enough local business to make for success.
"I'm dependent on Warner Brothers and Paramount and Sony and Fox, and I have to wait for them to say, 'Let's do a project and let's do it in New York,' " he said. "I can't influence that decision other than to say, 'I'm here.' "
Officials at the Shooting Gallery said that plans for the New Jersey project would proceed with the market's needs in mind. The overarching goal, said David C. Tuttle, the company's senior executive vice president for operations, is to allow for flexibility of uses -- smaller, intimate spaces for shooting commercials, or large stages for film and television, or some combination.
The capstone, a 106,000- to 110,000-square-foot sound stage that would edge out the 105,000-square-foot sound stage at England's Pinewood Studios as the world's largest, would require a separate building and would not come until the second phase of construction, Mr. Tuttle said. He said that $100 million in venture capital money had been committed, but that plans and estimates were still being drawn up to calculate how much each phase might cost.
Such ambition has been seen before. Under a headline that read, "Movies Come East from California," The Wall Street Journal noted an expansion of studio space and film industry investment and predicted that the tide of motion picture production heading west for California had turned.
"It is safe to say," The Journal article said, "that in the future the bulk of production will be done within easy reach of Manhattan."
That article was published in 1924.
 
Big City as Stage: Best Shooting Sites
 
For New York City location managers, whose job it is to find interesting places to film, the city has an endless variety of architecture and atmosphere, but also a collection of stupefying logistical problems. Following is a sampling of typical New York shots and where film crews go to get them.
 
WHAT THE SCRIPT CALLS FOR -- Grit, decay, the urban wasteland.
THE REALITY -- "It's not as easy as you'd think," said Tom Whalen, a location manager on several films, including "Kids." "There's not that much of it left."
THE LOCATIONS -- The Brooklyn waterfront, especially in Williamsburg and Greenpoint; under any East River bridge; parts of northern Long Island City and sections of the South Bronx and Staten Island.
THE SHOTS -- "Donnie Brasco," with Al Pacino and Johnny Depp, shot in Williamsburg and on the Staten Island waterfront; the coming "Frogs for Snakes," starring Barbara Hershey, recently shot along Elton and Westchester Avenues in the Bronx; "Cop Land," with scenes shot under the Queensboro Bridge.

WHAT THE SCRIPT CALLS FOR -- An alley (with rats if possible).
THE REALITY -- Location managers say this is also a surprisingly tough chore. "Many of these scripts are written in Los Angeles, where there are alleys everywhere," said Nathan Gendzier, a freelance location manager. "Manhattan has about seven good ones."
THE LOCATIONS -- Staple Street in TriBeCa; Minetta Street in Greenwich Village; Cortlandt Alley in Chinatown; Ryders Alley in the financial district; side streets in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.
THE SHOTS -- "Little Odessa," shot in Brighton Beach, with Tim Roth as an unhappy Russian; "State of Grace," starring Sean Penn, shot on Staple Street.
WHAT THE SCRIPT CALLS FOR -- Landmarks.
THE REALITY -- "Filmmakers from out of town like to have a skyscraper in the shot to convince people that they were actually there," said Joseph Zolfo, a location manager. "New York types actually try to avoid it."
THE LOCATIONS -- The Empire State Building, the World Trade Center, the Brooklyn Bridge.
THE SHOTS -- The 1976 remake of "King Kong," in which the big ape climbed the World Trade Center; "Godzilla," in which the Empire State Building is sliced in half by the big lizard's tail; the Guggenheim Museum, which is scaled by a fugitive alien in "Men in Black."

WHAT THE SCRIPT CALLS FOR -- Vintage New York.
THE REALITY -- Period pieces require some ingenuity. "If you point the camera up and avoid the street level, a lot of the city's buildings can look old," said Andy Clark, a location manager who worked on "I Shot Andy Warhol."
THE LOCATIONS -- The National Arts Club and the Players Club, both on Gramercy Park, for interiors. For exteriors, Sylvan Terrace, off Jumel Terrace in upper Manhattan; St. Luke's Place and other streets in Greenwich Village; parts of Park Slope, Brooklyn (minus the street signs).
THE SHOTS -- "The Age of Innocence," a drama set in the 1870's with scenes shot in the National Arts Club; "Ship of Fools," a 1930's comedy, starring Stanley Tucci and Isabella Rossellini, with shots in the theater district and on a Hudson River pier.

HEADLINE: Whitman Plans Her Biggest Spending Rise

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
With New Jersey's coffers overflowing with extra tax revenue from the economic boom, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will recommend raising spending by about $1 billion in her new state budget, the largest increase since she took office four years ago, top aides to the Governor said today.
Mrs. Whitman is not expected to propose any major tax cuts when she outlines her spending plan to the State Legislature on Tuesday, the aides said. But they said that she would propose giving $75 million more to cities and towns to help them keep property taxes down. 
 She will also propose eliminating the sales tax on long-distance telephone calls made within the state, which would save taxpayers $24 million annually, and she will recommend putting $650 million aside in the state's rainy-day fund.
After cutting taxes and striving to hold down state spending, Mrs. Whitman will make a significant departure in the proposed $17.9 billion budget by increasing spending, primarily for public schools and state colleges and universities. Total spending in her new budget is about 5.4 percent more than in this year's budget.
Assemblyman Richard H. Bagger, chairman of the Assembly's Budget Committee, praised the Governor for proposing more spending for public schools and higher education, and for setting part of the surplus aside in the rainy-day fund. He said that he did not think that Mrs. Whitman should follow the lead of Republican governors in New York and Connecticut and give part of the budget surplus back to taxpayers.
"Been there, done that," said Mr. Bagger, a Republican from Westfield. "We've cut taxes 17 times." He added, "Perhaps the fact that we cut taxes early on has helped the economic recovery in New Jersey be so strong."
In her plan, Mrs. Whitman recommends a $540 million increase for public schools, including $50 million for school construction. State aid for state colleges and universities would rise by $61 million, but state officials said that future increases would depend on whether colleges and universities meet certain performance standards, like graduation rates.
Mrs. Whitman is also expected to propose spending $50 million for a new program to help preserve farmland and other open space. Other spending increases include $29 million for New Jersey Transit to avoid a commuter ticket price increase this year and $15 million to build bicycle paths throughout the state. The Governor is also expected to announce a $25 million spending increase for a program to help revive urban neighborhoods.
"It is a good-news budget," John Farmer, the Governor's chief counsel, said, "because it strikes the proper balance between spending on school programs, like school construction, and exercising the kind of fiscal restraint that has characterized this administration."
Senior administration officials announced on Friday that tax revenues would be $609 million higher than they had expected for the current fiscal year that ends on June 30. They estimated that tax revenue would be $710 million higher in the new fiscal year, presenting Mrs. Whitman with the difficult choice of spending more or giving some of the budget surplus back to taxpayers.
Today, administration officials said the higher tax revenues were offset by some unexpected expenses, such as overtime costs in the state prison system. The state is expecting a $1.021 billion surplus in this fiscal year.
State Treasurer James A. DiEleuterio Jr. said that the surplus, combined with the extra tax revenues in the new fiscal year, persuaded Mrs. Whitman to increase spending in some areas and set aside $650 million in the state's rainy-day fund. The state usually budgets about $550 million annually for the fund, he said.
Almost $6 billion, a third of the state budget, is intended for public schools. Urban school districts would receive almost half of all state aid for public schools.
Of the $540 million overall increase in state aid for public schools, about $343 million would cover local pension costs and Social Security payments for teachers. State spending would rise by $35 million for urban schools and $165 million for suburban districts.
The Governor's proposed budget does not include an extra $312 million for urban schools that a judge, appointed by the State Supreme Court, said last month was necessary to further correct inequities between the state's poorest and wealthiest school districts. The court must now decide whether to force the state to spend the money.
Mr. Farmer, the chief counsel, said the administration did not budget the extra money because officials did not think the court would require the state to spend $312 million on top of the money it is already spending this year in response to an order from the State Supreme Court. Last year, the court ordered the state to increase spending for urban schools by $246 million.
Democrats said the Governor's proposed budget did not include enough relief for property-tax payers. "If we've really heard the message of last November, we simply can't go to the people with this paltry amount of new property tax relief," said State Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr., a Democrat from Hoboken who is the assistant minority leader.
Steven H. Hochman, senior vice president of state ratings at Moody's Investors Service, said the Governor's spending plan did not include risky budget maneuvers -- like relying too much on one-shot revenue sources -- that concerned bond rating analysts in the past.

INTERNATIONAL A3-8
 
Israel Rabbinate Rejects Proposal on Conversion
Israel's Chief Rabbinate categorically ruled out any cooperation with non-Orthodox sects of Judaism. Reform and Conservative leaders in the United States and Israel announced that they would resume legal and political battles for recognition. A1 

Jewish Office Opens in Berlin
The American Jewish Committee opened what it called the first permanent office of its kind in Berlin. High-level German officials and diplomats from the United States and Israel attended the dedication ceremony. Officials of the American Jewish Committee said that the presence of the office would guard against the rise of neo-Nazism in the former East Germany. A6
 
More U.S. Soldiers to Gulf
The Pentagon said it was sending up to 3,000 more American soldiers to Kuwait. A senior military official said the Pentagon planned to use the new troops to bolster Kuwait's defenses against possible retaliation by Iraqi forces. A8
 
Secretary General Kofi Annan canceled a trip to the Middle East in order to remain at United Nations headquarters to help work toward a diplomatic end to the confrontation with Iraq. A8
 
The Palestinian Authority sent out scores of policemen to prevent marchers supporting Saddam Hussein from clashing with Israeli troops in the West Bank. A8
 
Lobbying for NATO Expansion
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright began the Administration's final push for Senate approval of NATO expansion, as President Clinton prepared to submit documents for expansion to the Senate for ratification. The Senate is expected to vote in March to approve the addition of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic to NATO. Ms. Albright warned senators not to complicate the effort with a delay in any second round of expansion. A4
 
Guatemala to Heighten Security
The Interior Minister of Guatemala announced plans to double the number of police officers assigned to some rural provinces in the aftermath of the rape and robbery of a group of American students. The extra security is meant to combat highly organized armed bandits who operate on many of Guatemala's rural highways. The problem came under international scrutiny after bandits hijacked the group's bus on a major highway in daylight. (Reuters)
 
Italian Freed by Kidnappers
Sardinian kidnappers freed a northern Italian businessman after cutting off part of both his ears during his nearly eight months in captivity, police officials said. News reports said all or part of a $5.5 million ransom might have been paid for the release of the man, Giuseppe Soffiantini. The case was one of a series that has caused debate over an Italian law prohibiting families from negotiating with kidnappers or paying ransom without the permission of a prosecutor. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A10-19
 
Lewinsky Is Summoned To Testify at Grand Jury
Government prosecutors have summoned Monica S. Lewinsky to appear before a Federal grand jury on Thursday, a significant escalation of the battle over Ms. Lewinsky's testimony now that immunity talks have broken down. A1
 
President Clinton's lawyer filed a formal complaint in Federal District Court, apparently accusing the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, of disclosing secret grand jury information about the President. A19
 
House Republicans have quietly begun to prepare for possible impeachment action, as expectations grow that the independent counsel would be more likely to refer any presidential wrongdoing he discovered to Congress rather than to a criminal proceeding. A17
 
Babbitt Inquiry Is Pressed
Top Justice Department officials have formally recommended that Attorney General Janet Reno seek an independent counsel to investigate Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's role in a decision to block an Indian casino project in Wisconsin, law enforcement officials said. A1
 
Vehicle Redesigns Are Urged
The auto insurance industry urged auto makers to redesign sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, after concluding that these vehicles increased the risk of death for other road users while providing little if any additional protection for their own occupants. A1
 
Overhauling Social Security
President Clinton began a yearlong effort to persuade both major political parties to deal with Social Security's problems. A16
 
New Citizenship Process
Officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service unveiled a plan to impose tighter control on the process of obtaining United States citizenship. A15
 
Gap Between Races Narrowing
The Clinton Administration said that after two decades without progress in narrowing the economic gap between black and white Americans, the nation had recently shown tentative signs that the economic inequality between the races had been reduced. A16
 
Bills to Ban Cloning
The Senate will consider bills to ban the cloning of human beings. A16
 
Sergeant Major's Court-Martial
Opening statements were made in the court-martial of Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, once the Army's highest-ranking enlisted soldier. Sergeant Major McKinney faces 19 charges of sexual misconduct and coercion, leveled by six women. A10
 
A Respite Between Storms
Brilliant blue skies gave Californians a chance to dry out, offering a respite from Pacific storms that have battered the coast like artillery barrages. But another storm was expected to hit today. A10

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 185 words

HEADLINE: School-to-Work Programs Set Students Back;
Learning in Context

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Lynne Cheney (Op-Ed, Feb. 3) seems to be unaware of the increasing amount of national research on school-to-work programs, much of it financed by private foundations that see these efforts as promising ways to eradicate the "floundering" stage between school and work. 
 Moreover, connecting young people to the world of work is not the only goal: contrary to Ms. Cheney's assertion, there is research that suggests that learning in context can strengthen understanding and improve retention of academic subject matter.
School-to-work programs don't call for eighth graders to choose careers but career majors, which are broadly defined occupational areas. These programs don't direct job choices but instead provide information about job possibilities, give students exposure to different occupations and workplaces, and help them create ties with adults from whom they can learn about specific jobs and working in general.
 
KATHERINE HUGHES
New York, Feb. 4, 1998
 
The writer is senior research associate, Institute on Education and the Economy, Columbia University.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (70%);

HEADLINE: If NATO Doesn't Grow

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Contrary to the suggestion of some Feb. 9 letters, membership in the European Union should indeed precede any expansion of NATO. But that does not seem to be in the cards for three reasons. First, Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic are major agricultural producers. Their entry would complicate inter-E.U. agricultural controversies. 
 Second, the European Union is about to go to a single currency, which will require budgetary restrictions and austerity and the setting of exchange rates; the still frail economies of these countries would not be up to that.
Finally, cheap exports and expensive imports are already a barrier to the reforms and reconstruction of their industries and infrastructure that all three countries need badly. Forcing them to spend on weaponry would foreclose the prospect of a better life for their long-suffering peoples.
 
JOHN E. ULLMANN
Hempstead, N.Y., Feb. 9, 1998

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- The St. Louis Phoenix;
From Its Heartland Hub, T.W.A. Is Rising, but Wall St. Has Some Doubts

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
Last summer, Wall Street feared Trans World Airlines was headed for yet another emergency landing in bankruptcy court -- its third since 1992.
Speculation about bankruptcy has evaporated, though, as T.W.A. scored impressive gains in efficiency and pulled off a string of refinancing deals that raised nearly $225 million. Memories of the still-unexplained explosion of Flight 800 off Long Island in 1996 have faded. And after T.W.A. reported third-quarter earnings that were the best since 1989, its stock soared more than 60 percent, and several analysts added it to their buy lists. On Monday, the shares were unchanged at $11.5625. 
 But don't mistake Wall Street's relief for long-term optimism. The company is expected to report a fourth-quarter loss this month. Moreover, it will end 1997 -- a year in which other airlines rode the strong economy and low fuel prices to record profits -- deeply in the red. T.W.A. can survive, but will it prosper?
"We still have to prove we can make money," acknowledged Gerald L. Gitner, the lanky, balding 52-year-old Texan who has led the recovery since being named chairman and chief executive late in 1996.
To gain financial altitude, T.W.A. will have to confound the industry experts. Once the nation's biggest airline, it is now No. 7, just ahead of Southwest. The common wisdom is that there is no such thing as a lucrative niche for a relatively small carrier like T.W.A. that is saddled with entrenched unions and the hub-and-spoke structure of the industry giants. And in an industry where there is constant talk of mergers and of deals like last month's alliance of Continental and Northwest, T.W.A.'s name is usually among the last mentioned.
Indeed, most analysts and airline industry insiders see T.W.A.'s recent rebound as little more than the latest evidence that it is almost impossible to kill an established airline when the economy is growing. One industry joke, both a comment on T.W.A.'s prospects and a backhanded compliment to its survival skills, has it that the airline business in the year 2025 will consist of three prospering giants created through mergers "and financially strapped T.W.A."
T.W.A., not surprisingly, has a rosier vision, based on two core assumptions about the nature of the airline business. The first is that the worst battles of the industry's civil war following its deregulation in 1978 are history, leaving T.W.A. and other established airlines organized around impregnable hubs. "There's not a whole lot anybody can do to compete but get a lot better where they are," said Michael Palumbo, T.W.A.'s chief financial officer.
The second assumption is that T.W.A. is strategically blessed with its major St. Louis hub here in the heart of the nation and a strong presence at New York's chief international gateway, Kennedy International Airport. Profits will roll in, T.W.A. believes, if T.W.A. can beat other airlines at the fundamentals such as on-time service, getting the right-size planes for each route and marketing plans that reward frequent, full-fare passengers.
Put it together, and you end up early in the next century with a flourishing airline, according to Mr. Palumbo. Revenues might be about $4 billion, not much larger than today and just a fourth the size of the giants like United Airlines. But if everything goes right, profit margins could top the industry, Mr. Palumbo said.
Even after T.W.A.'s impressive strides the last year, such a rewarding scenario seems far-fetched. But, a gradual return to solid profitability at least seems possible.
T.W.A.'s most startling gains have been in on-time service. After starting 1997 as the worst performer among the nation's 10 biggest airlines, it vaulted to first by summer. Though bad weather, wildcat strikes and a breakdown in the Federal air-traffic-control computer covering St.Louis knocked it back into the pack the final two months of the year, it continued to outshine its own recent past, completing every scheduled flight on six days of November, for example, compared with none for all of 1996.
"It's so basic," said William Compton, a longtime T.W.A. pilot whom Mr. Gitner put in charge of operations and recently promoted to president. "As soon as the on-time figures began shooting up last February, so did all our measures of customer satisfaction."
One key to both more timely service and cutting costs was replacing wide-body Boeing 747's and Lockheed L1011's with new 757's and a mixture of new and almost-new MD-80's, which have less than half the capacity. T.W.A. is also phasing out its aging 727's.
With fewer seats to sell, T.W.A. has experienced a 10 percent drop in operating revenue. But operating profit in the third quarter jumped to $63.8 million from $26 million a year earlier, and the company is projecting a sharp narrowing of its loss during this year's slow winter period to $50 million from $150 million last year. This is because the new planes are fuller and more efficient, requiring smaller crews and less fuel and maintenance.
The average age of T.W.A.'s fleet has dropped from over 19 years to just over 16. That is far from the best in an industry that averages 13 years -- but it is no longer the worst. Getting rid of the widebodies saves $20 million in annual training costs. It also cuts T.W.A.'s vulnerability to higher fuel prices: each 1-cent increase now adds $7.1 million to the airline's annual fuel bill, down from $8.4 million before.
T.W.A. is also rebounding on the marketing front. It recently became the first airline to deploy a computer program tracking how much customers spend with the company as well as how many miles they fly. That data have given it a tool to track -- and reward -- full-fare business customers who fly frequently but rarely on long hauls.
The carrier has also renovated lounges for its frequent and full-fare fliers here and in New York and recently expanded its first-class seating and upgrade programs as a further inducement.
Analysts give Mr. Gitner's team high marks for these and other improvements. So why is there so much skepticism that they can build on such successes to the point that T.W.A. can sail above the turbul when the next downturn hits? After all, Continental Airlines, which has also been through two bankruptcies since deregulation, now has a $1 billion cash hoard, and Northwest Airlines, which narrowly averted bankruptcy in 1994, is flying high.
One problem is that not many people outside the company buy T.W.A.'s assumption that there is a host of unexploited benefits from its particular route structure. T.W.A. already accounts for more than 60 percent of the traffic originating at St. Louis's Lambert Field. Southwest, which cannot be beat on budget prices, holds much of the rest.
St. Louis businesses are already pulling out all stops to support T.W.A. Each spring in recent years, Civic Progress, which brings together the local business community, has organized a drive in which companies like Monsanto and Anheuser-Busch buy tens of millions of dollars worth of tickets in advance to help the airline stay aloft until the summer season.
The leaves T.W.A. extremely dependent on getting more customers flying between other cities to come through St. Louis, especially those with no direct flight options. T.W.A. calls it the Portland, Ore., to Jacksonville, Fla., market. But such "transhub" customers already account for two-thirds of T.W.A.'s business at Lambert, more than any other airline has running through a major hub.
St. Louis's central location makes the potential transhub market worth tens of billions of dollars, but T.W.A. acknowledges that does not reflect Lambert's current physical limitations. It is already the fifth-busiest airport in the nation despite being reduced to one runway whenweather is bad. A planned additional runway will not be ready before 2003 at the earliest.
T.W.A.'s second hub, at Kennedy Airport, is no help. It is a reminder of the glory days when the T.W.A. of Charles Lindbergh and Howard Hughes was rivaled only by Pan Am as an internationally renown symbol of American aviation. But after Carl C. Icahn, the Wall Street financier who took control of the airline in 1985, sold the valuable London routes to American Airlines in 1991, Kennedy and the routes feeding international traffic into it became money losers.
Mr. Icahn was forced out after T.W.A. went bankrupt in 1992, but efforts to return T.W.A.'s Kennedy operations to profitability have not worked. T.W.A. can claim it flies to more American cities from Kennedy than any does other airline, but most business travelers heading to or from New York prefer La Guardia or Newark. That is why Continental's heavy investment in expanding its Newark hub has contributed so much to that airline's rebirth.
"T.W.A.'s board thinks their problem is that people avoid them, but I believe people don't even think about them," said Glenn D. Engel, an airline industry analyst for Goldman, Sachs. "Outside of St. Louis, they are a nonentity."
Beyond such fundamental strategic problems, T.W.A. also faces tough labor negotiations this year, and the continuing challenge of keeping up with wealthier rivals when it comes to investing in new technology and renewing its fleet.
Ultimately, analysts say, T.W.A.'s best hope is to attract bigger and healthier airlines as marketing partners so that it can link its routes, schedules, frequent-flier programs, clubs and other attractions to theirs. T.W.A., said Samuel Buttrick, who follows the industry for Paine Webber, "has to become part of a true network."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 12, 1998, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Tuesday comparing the operating results of Trans World Airlines with those of other airlines carried an erroneous label for 1997 results. They were for the 12 months ended in September, not for the first 9 months of the year. T.W.A., for example, had an operating loss of $30 million for the first 9 months, but a loss of $263 million for the year.

HEADLINE: Beyond Rancor, Brecht Remounts His Pedestal;
Playwright Is an Icon Again as Many Forgive His Marxist Politics

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Feb. 10

 BODY:
When Bertolt Brecht returned here in 1948 from wartime exile in the United States, the legendary German playwright and stage director chose to live and work in East Berlin. He was not, in fact, a card-carrying Communist, but he described himself as Marxist. And after his death in 1956 at the age of 58, his Berliner Ensemble theater company remained East Germany's principal cultural ambassador. With the unification of Germany in 1990, Brecht's name seemed irrevocably linked to a repressive regime and a failed ideology.
Yet today, the 100th anniversary of his birth on Feb. 10, 1898, Brecht is being celebrated throughout Germany on a scale suggesting that his politics have already been forgiven. In addition to a speech honoring him by President Roman Herzog of Germany today at the Berlin Academy of Arts, Brecht's birthplace in Augsburg has been turned into a museum, while his last residence in Berlin at Chausseestrasse 125 now contains his archives. Stamps have been issued, tours organized, a dozen new books on Brecht published and, across the country, his plays are being performed, accompanied by lectures, workshops and exhibitions. 
 At the ornate 19th-century Am Schiffbauerdamm Theater, home to the Berliner Ensemble since 1954, five Brecht plays are currently in repertory, including Robert Wilson's production of "Flight Over the Ocean," the American director's first venture into Brecht. On Monday night, the countdown to Brecht's birthday was accompanied by a lively concert of his songs, leading off with "The Ballad of Mack the Knife." Tonight, a performance of his 1930 play, "The Measures Taken," was followed by "Germany Nine-Zero," a film of Jean-Luc Godard, the most Brechtian of movie directors.
Outside Germany, the return of Brecht is occurring more slowly, with many theater directors still put off by both his politics and his often pessimistic plays. New productions are nonetheless being presented, not only of the best-known plays written after he fled Hitler's Germany in 1933, like "Mother Courage and Her Children," "The Life of Galileo," "The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui" and "The Caucasian Chalk Circle," but also of earlier works, among them "The Threepenny Opera" and "The Rise and Fall of Mahagonny," both with music by Kurt Weill. If Brecht has not been forgotten, then, which Brecht is being remembered? At different times during -- and after -- his life, he was variously considered European theater's most important playwright, director and theorist. Yet in all three categories his views often changed, suggesting he was more empirical than dogmatic. Today, Germany has placed him alongside Schiller as an icon, but what is his relevance to theater?
Certainly his plays continue to be performed and studied, with his midlife works considered by some experts among the best epic plays written in Europe since the 17th century, although at least three of his mistresses probably deserved to share credit for them.
Brecht's stagecraft, which challenged Stanislavsky's realism by provoking what Brecht called an "alienation effect" to remind audiences they were in a theater watching a re-enactment, is also present in modern theater, opera, cinema and even advertising, albeit at times absorbed to the point that its provenance is not always apparent.
But what clearly fell out of fashion in the Reaganite and Thatcherite 1980's was Brecht's strong commitment to what he called "epic theater," to making audiences think before feeling, to the idea, in the words of the British playwright David Hare, "that plays have to be defined by people's social class and by power relationships and not simply by psychology." Or as Sir Richard Eyre, until recently artistic director of the Royal National Theater in London, put it: "He taught people that they could take the theater seriously and that theater was a medium to talk about serious things."
Brecht's influence on British theater from the mid-1950's to the mid-1970's was enormous, first through the impact of the Berliner Ensemble's early visits to London on theater technique, then through the way British directors came to interpret Shakespeare and other classics as sociopolitical dramas.
"Brecht is the key figure of our time, and all theater work today at some point starts or returns to his statements and achievement," the British director Peter Brook wrote in 1969. Mr. Hare, who has translated and adapted both "Mother Courage" and "The Life of Galileo," said, "Only when his influence as a director began to wane did we begin to rediscover his plays."
 
Topical in France As Jobs Dry Up
While Brecht has now joined the classical repertory in Britain and elsewhere, rising unemployment and social disenchantment have made him more topical in France and Germany.
"In the 1960's, many French directors were politically engaged Brechtians, but they fell out of favor," said Stuart Seide, an American director who teaches at the National Conservatory of Dramatic Art in Paris. "But now the young are interested in a different Brecht, the early Brecht, the poetic Brecht, the Brecht before Marxism, the Brecht who had not found himself, who found the world to be a confusing place."
Stephane Braunschweig, a 33-year-old French director whose production of Brecht's "In the Jungle of the Cities" is drawing young audiences at the Theatre de la Colline in Paris, said he chose this early work because "it speaks more directly to my generation." And he added: "People have an image of Brecht as serious and didactic theater, but his early work was pulsating, nervous, irreflexive, dynamic, almost surreal at times. I too want audiences to take a position, to react, to fight, so in this sense Brecht is natural material."
Holge Teschke, 39, the resident dramaturge at the Berliner Ensemble, noted a similar phenomenon in Germany. "Young directors are doing early plays like 'St. Joan of the Stockyards,' which in the 1920's dealt with unemployment and the social crisis," he said. "These plays interest young directors more than the classics." Among these young directors is Brecht's own granddaughter, Johanna Schall.
Still, if Brecht wrote plays for all occasions, this also reflected the changing circumstances of his turbulent life. He came of age during World War I and wrote his first play, "Baal," in a Germany humbled by defeat and a Europe convulsed by the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Empire and the rise of Soviet Communism. Brecht himself, as if reflecting this confusion, was a leftist anarchist: his early plays in Munich, with audiences encouraged to become involved, often set off near-riots.
In 1924, he moved to Berlin, and it was there in 1928 that he enjoyed his first triumph -- and financial success -- with "The Threepenny Opera," based on John Gay's 18th-century "The Beggar's Opera." It was also with this production that he first earned a reputation for sharing neither earnings nor credit with his collaborators. According to John Fuegi, a professor of comparative literature at the University of Maryland and author of "Brecht and Company: Sex, Politics and the Making of the Modern Drama" (Grove Press, 1994), Brecht's mistress and assistant, Elizabeth Hauptmann, translated and adapted most of "The Threepenny Opera."
In 1933, with Brecht long viewed as both Communist and "degenerate" by the Nazis, he fled to Denmark with his wife, the actress Helene Weigel, their two children, and Hauptmann. In 1939, as war approached, they moved hurriedly to Sweden and eventually to Finland. During these years he wrote his best-known works, the so-called chronicle plays, in these cases, Mr. Fuegi said, with considerable assistance from two other mistresses, Margarete Steffin and Ruth Berlau.
Finally, in June 1941, after crossing the Soviet Union (and choosing not to stay there), Brecht took his family by boat from Vladivostok to Los Angeles, where he lived until 1947. His time in the United States did not win him over to capitalism. His efforts to write for Hollywood and Broadway failed, and only in 1947 was he able to present "The Life of Galileo" onstage, with Charles Laughton in the lead role. Finally, under intense surveillance by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and interrogation by the House Committee on Un-American Activities, he returned to Europe.
Before accepting an invitation to work in the Soviet-run section of Berlin, he tried unsuccessfully to find a permanent theater in Zurich and Vienna. But the offer of the Am Schiffbauerdam Theater, scene of his triumphant "Threepenny Opera" in 1928, was hard to resist. It would be used, he said, "for the scientific manufacture of scandal."
As it happens, the East German authorities never fully trusted him, and he was not assigned the theater until 1954. But by then he had created the Berliner Ensemble and had made his mark in postwar European theater with his stunning production of "Mother Courage," with Weigel in the main role.
After Brecht's death, the Berliner Ensemble continued to prosper under Weigel's direction until her death in 1971. But by the mid-1970's, the company was being suffocated by East Germany's cultural bureaucracy. And by the time the Berlin wall came down in 1989, it was a shadow of its former self.
Since then, it has been liberated from Government meddling, although not from politics, with a succession of directors fighting their personal and ideological battles onstage. Indeed, if the 32-member ensemble is working well this year, it may be because it has no permanent director. In the view of many European theater experts, the effort to make Brecht relevant today has been complicated by his heirs, notably his daughter, Barbara Brecht Schall, who insists on approving all translations of Brecht's plays and, in the case of the Berliner Ensemble, even on authorizing the director and principal cast members.
"It's easier to do something fresh with Brecht in Namibia than in Berlin or Paris," Mr. Teschke said.
 
'Absurd Policing Of Translations'
"One of the reasons Brecht is not performed more is this absurd policing of translations," argued Sir Richard Eyre, who nonetheless presented seven Brecht productions during his time at the National Theater. Mr. Hare, though, said he saw signs of flexibility. "There was a time of almost monarchical obeisance that one had to pay to the great man. But since the fall of the wall, there has been an easing up, a recognition that Brecht has to live."
In that sense, then, his place in 21st-century theater may be assured less by this month's homages than by the fact that young European directors are now choosing to present his early plays. "I think the later pieces are a bit intimidating because there is such tradition and orthodoxy," Mr. Braunschweig said. "Perhaps we have to pass through the early pieces to cast fresh light on the later pieces."

HEADLINE: 'Titanic' Leads the Oscar List With 'L.A.' and 'Good Will'

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Gloria Stuart was asleep at her home in West Los Angeles when her visiting daughter and son-in-law woke her up and began jumping up and down to tell her she had just been nominated for an Academy Award for her supporting role in "Titanic." Ms. Stuart, 87, said later, "All these years -- I've been waiting for this a long, long time."
Gus Van Sant, who was nominated as best director for "Good Will Hunting," said his parents cried when he called them with the news. And Robert Forster, who has struggled for years as an actor, heard from some unlikely callers that he had been nominated for an Oscar for Quentin Tarantino's "Jackie Brown." 
 "In rapid order, Quentin called, my two ex-wives called, my daughter and son called, even my old agent called," said Mr. Forster.
It was that kind of morning in Hollywood.
As expected, "Titanic," the James Cameron romantic epic that seems destined to break box office records around the world, was nominated for 14 Academy Awards, including best picture, actress and director. The only other film to earn 14 nominations was "All About Eve," released in 1950.
Two other films, "L.A. Confidential" and "Good Will Hunting," received nine nominations each, including best picture. The other films nominated for best picture were "As Good as It Gets," and "The Full Monty."
Uberto Pasolini, the producer of "The Full Monty," the comedy-drama about a group of unemployed men in northern England, said he was "flabbergasted" at the best-film nomination, which was a relative surprise to the film industry. Mr. Pasolini said that the movie, which cost only $3 million and has grossed nearly $200 million around the world, resonated with filmgoers because it dealt with characters and issues that were instantly recognizable.
"I thought this was the year of the big film, like 'Titanic,' " said Mr. Pasolini. "They decided to squeeze a small Cinderella in there."
What was unexpected in the 70th annual Academy Award nominations, announced before dawn in Los Angeles, was the decision by the Director's Branch of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science to pass over Steven Spielberg, who did not receive a best director's nod for "Amistad." The film was also ignored in the best-picture category.
The well-reviewed "Ice Storm" did not receive any nominations.
At the same time, the directors ignored James L. Brooks, whose film "As Good as It Gets" received seven nominations, including best picture, best actor (Jack Nicholson), best actress (Helen Hunt) and best supporting actor (Greg Kinnear). Mr. Brooks was nominated, though, for best original screenplay for the film, which he wrote with Mark Andrus.
Also nominated for best original screenplay was Woody Allen for "Deconstructing Harry." It was Mr. Allen's 13th writing nomination, breaking Billy Wilder's record of 12.
Instead of Mr. Spielberg and Mr. Brooks were two surprise directorial choices: Atom Egoyan, for "The Sweet Hereafter," a critically acclaimed but not widely seen drama about sorrow and forgiveness, and Peter Cattaneo, for "The Full Monty." The other directors nominated were Mr. Cameron, Mr. Van Sant and Curtis Hanson for "L.A. Confidential."
Mr. Hanson was in a friend's apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan when he saw the news of his nomination on television. "I was on the 17th floor and could have stepped out the window and still been this high," said Ms. Hanson, whose film is being re-released by Warner Brothers after grossing only $41.6 million, which was not bad for a period drama about the Los Angeles police in the 1950's but a disappointment given its dazzling reviews.
A total of 5,371 academy members selected the candidates in 24 categories. The Oscars are to be presented on March 23.
While independent films were well represented in last year's Oscar nominations, this year's marked the return of major studios like Paramount, 20th Century Fox, Warner Brothers and Sony. The list included comebacks for several prominent performers of the 1960's and 70's. These included Julie Christie, 56, nominated for her role as a faded actress in a troubled marriage in "Afterglow." Ms. Christie, who won an Oscar for the 1965 film "Darling," is competing in the best-actress category with Kate Winslet in "Titanic," Helen Hunt in "As Good as It Gets," Helena Bonham Carter in "The Wings of the Dove" and Judi Dench in "Mrs. Brown."
Ms. Dench said in London that she was sitting in the cafeteria at the BBC, where she is rehearsing a television role, when the news of her nomination came by phone. "It was terribly glamorous," she said with a laugh. "It was a truly terrible lunch, and I celebrated by cracking open a bottle of water."
Ms. Hunt, speaking from her car phone in Los Angeles, said it was a "dizzying compliment" to be compared to an actress like Ms. Dench, one of Britain's most honored stars. "If I see 'Mrs. Brown' one more time, the tape will break down," said Ms. Hunt.
Another comeback was made by Peter Fonda, who rose to fame in 1969 with "Easy Rider" and was nominated for best actor for his role as a beekeeper in "Ulee's Gold." Mr. Fonda said from Toronto, where he is making a television film: "I'm just a lucky actor to be working. An actor takes so much rejection. Rejection after rejection. To have this moment of acceptance is wonderful."
Mr. Fonda has formidable competition, including Mr. Nicholson, whose 11th acting nomination sets a record. The other actors nominated are Dustin Hoffman in "Wag the Dog," Robert Duvall in "The Apostle" and Matt Damon in "Good Will Hunting."
Mr. Damon, who was also nominated with Ben Affleck for their screenplay "Good Will Hunting," said that his sudden stardom has left him overwhelmed. "It's been going by a little too fast," he said. "It's hard to take control over it. I've got to sit back and gauge where my life is. I feel like I'm missing an anchor."
Mr. Damon said he did not expect to win the acting award. "Did you see 'The Apostle'?" he asked. "All I want to do is six next to Robert Duvall."
Another comeback was that of Burt Reynolds, who turns 62 on Wednesday. He was nominated for best supporting actor for his role as a pornographic filmmaker in "Boogie Nights." The other supporting actors nominated are Mr. Forster, Anthony Hopkins in "Amistad," Greg Kinnear in "As Good as it Gets," and Robin Williams in "Good Will Hunting."'
As for the supporting-actress category, Ms. Stuart faces Joan Cusack in "In and Out," Kim Basinger in "L.A. Confidential," Minnie Driver in "Good Will Hunting" and Julianne Moore in "Boogie Nights."
Ms. Moore said she was nursing her 2-month-old son, Caleb, when the Oscar nominations were announced on television this morning in Los Angeles.
"I was pretending nothing was going on, with the lights off, when my boyfriend came into the bedroom and said, 'Congratulations,' " she said. "And then the phone rang, and it was my Dad in Maryland."
Ms. Moore said that the impact of the nomination had still not sunk in. "I'm still in my ratty running clothes and taking care of the baby," she said. "Nothing feels different. Yet."
Mr. Williams heard the news of his nomination on a film set in Asheville, N.C. "Someone shouted out, 'Mazel tov!' " he said. "These are not words you hear in North Carolina."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Taking Pulse of the President's Pulse-Takers

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
FOR weeks, President Clinton has seemed like a stunt flier defying gravity. Why are his approval ratings soaring in the face of allegations that he had sex with a former White House intern? Could he still crash and burn? Public Lives put these questions to Mr. Clinton's very busy pollsters, Mark Penn and Doug Schoen, two New Yorkers who got their start in the early years of Mayor Edward I. Koch.
The pollsters responded, at first, with the not-astonishing view that the public is happy with the President because he made good on his promises to stoke the economy and bring down crime. 
 Here are some of their less predictable comments:
*Party lines are crucial. "There are three things going on," Mr. Penn said. "Democrats feel that their party is under assault by a partisan investigation, which is why fund-raising is going up. Conservative Republicans see this as a confirmation of their hatred for Clinton. And independents have reviewed his job performance, and see that he's kept his commitments. Their approval of him has gone up significantly."
*Even though polls show that a majority of Americans approve of the President's job performance, and a majority think the allegations are true, it does not automatically mean the country accepts the allegations of an affair. Mr. Penn agreed with his college friend E. J. Dionne of The Washington Post, who wrote recently that there are two distinct majorities -- those who approve of the President, and those who think he had a sexual relationship with Ms. Lewinsky. The two majorities do not overlap that much. Polls show that most people who approve of the President do not think he had the affair, or do not know. Only 25 percent, Mr. Dionne said, think Mr. Clinton had the affair and still approve of his job performance. "That's an accurate point," Mr. Penn said.
Does that mean that Mr. Clinton might be in serious trouble if more damaging allegations come out?
"That's true of anybody, at any time," Mr. Penn said.
Mr. Penn and Mr. Schoen have been polling for the President since before the 1996 election, when the former White House consigliere, Dick Morris, brought in Mr. Schoen, his old friend from Upper West Side Democratic politics. A year later Mr. Schoen brought in his partner, Mr. Penn, to Mr. Morris's initial dismay. There were many fights (Mr. Morris threw a fit when Mr. Penn took over a White House closet as an office), but when the dust settled, Mr. Morris was out and Penn, Schoen & Berland Associates were in as the President's pollsters -- Mr. Schoen in New York to manage clients like AT&T that pay the bills, and Mr. Penn in Washington to take care of the President.
MR. PENN is now closer to Mr. Clinton than Mr. Schoen is, but Mr. Schoen contends there are no hard feelings.
"This is a long-term professional investment," he said. "It's not a short-term 'How close can we get to Bill Clinton, Al Gore, whoever?' "
Mr. Schoen, who talked in smooth paragraphs over lunch at the Lobster Club on the Upper East Side, said the 1996 Clinton campaign still owes the pollsters $1.6 million. Mr. Penn talked at Dock's Oyster Bar in midtown, in fitful starts and stops.
Mr. Schoen, 46, is the duo's lean and intense Mr. Outside, described by friends as a classic political operator with overlapping agendas who assumes that everyone else has them, too. He still insists that a question he was asked during an interview for a Rhodes Scholarship -- "Do you write poetry?" -- was a trick designed to make him hold forth on his other achievements. Mr. Schoen responded instead with an unembellished "no," and is convinced that it cost him the Rhodes.
"I couldn't spin the answer to that question in the way I've tried to instruct my clients to answer similarly difficult questions," he said.
Mr. Penn, 44, is in contrast the shy, sleepy bear who avoids the press, loses his cellular phone and wakes up when the talk turns to numbers. In the 1996 election, he pushed Mr. Clinton to take credit for the prospering economy. He polls for the President two to four times a month, but more often around big events. This year Mr. Penn threw some scandal-related questions into the polling he usually does at the time of the State of the Union address. Mr. Penn will not discuss his questions but did say, "There is nothing more deeply rooted in the American psyche than keeping the Government out of investigating these types of matters."
Mr. Penn, the son of a kosher poultry-plant owner, grew up in Riverdale in the Bronx. Mr. Schoen, the son of a corporate lawyer, grew up on the Upper East Side. Their partnership was born at the Horace Mann School, where the 5-foot 8-inch Mr. Schoen played football and the 6-foot 1-inch Mr. Penn was editor of the school paper, The Record. Mr. Penn conducted his first poll, about the liberal civil rights views of the Horace Mann faculty, when he was in ninth grade.
The two were at Harvard together, then polled for Mr. Koch, Gov. Hugh L. Carey and national elections in South American countries. They have, however, turned down dictatorships.
"If people feel that they're going to get shot based on how they express an opinion," Mr. Penn said, "you don't get a reliable poll."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Mark Penn, above, and Doug Schoen take public opinion polls for President Clinton. Mr. Penn indicated that Mr. Clinton might be in trouble if more damaging allegations come out. "That's true of anybody, at any time," he said. (Photographs by Librado Romero/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
I.M.F. Concedes Its Conditions for Thailand Were Too Austere

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 10

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund has conceded that conditions it imposed on Thailand as part of a multibillion-dollar bailout package have proved too austere, clearing a path for the Thai Government to increase spending substantially.
Acknowledging that economic growth and tax revenue have fallen far below levels predicted only several months ago, the I.M.F. has agreed to allow Thailand to run a budget deficit instead of posting a sizable surplus, said Hubert Neiss, director of the fund's Asia Pacific department. 
 "There is a need for flexibility on the spending target," Mr. Neiss said in an interview today. "Especially to the extent that there is a need for spending on social programs, this program is not hard and fast."
Mr. Neiss, who is visiting Bangkok this week for a formal assessment of the country's progress under I.M.F. care, said details of increased spending would await the completion of the Government budget, expected later this month.
The revised budget target, while not unexpected, would appear to vindicate some critics of I.M.F. bailout programs for troubled Asian countries. Several critics have argued that when the fund prescribed austerity for Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia last year, it tried to cure the wrong ill.
Those countries, the argument goes, do not have spendthrift governments, but rather huge private-sector debt problems. Sharp austerity adds to economic pain without solving the debt problem, the critics say.
Indeed, when the I.M.F. came to Thailand's rescue in August, the fund's experts predicted a relatively mild economic slowdown. They imposed belt-tightening measures to restrict Government spending and ordered that interest rates rise to high levels -- they are now close to 25 percent -- to help curtail excessive lending and force companies to clear their books of bad debt.
The forecast proved far too optimistic. The Thai baht lost half its value against the United States dollar. The country by most accounts has slipped into a recession, and some economists see the economy shrinking by 5 percent this year. One million people are expected to lose their jobs, doubling the unemployment rate.
Mr. Neiss acknowledged that the fund underestimated the ferocity of the Asian contagion and its impact on Thailand. But he says austerity was nonetheless needed, as Thailand showed classic symptoms of government mismanagement when it first applied for I.M.F. help last August.
Belt-tightening was necessary to curb excessive credit expansion, a gaping current account deficit and wasteful infrastructure spending, Mr. Neiss said. It is because of the sharper-than-expected recession and Thailand's success in meeting most early I.M.F. targets -- its balance of trade in particular has shown rapid improvement -- that the fund now advises looser restrictions on the budget, he said.
"Thailand is on the path to recovery, although not perhaps as fast as we had hoped," Mr. Neiss said. "This Government has given people confidence that it will stay the course."
Despite the mild criticism of the I.M.F. program here, Thai officials have taken pains to show their solidarity with the fund's program, fearing that they might otherwise jeopardize improving financial market sentiment.
Still, Pisit Leeahtam, the Deputy Finance Minister, said the Government felt strongly that it needed more spending power. It has cut its budget several times already to account for revenue shortfalls, and the new budget is already bare bones, he said. Most new spending would be used to help the jobless and support education, he added.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Up 115 As It Reaches Newest High

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market soared again yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to its first record high in six months.
The gains continued a rally that began earlier this month when stock markets around the world surged on optimism that the economic crisis in Asia was easing. Wall Street strategists are calling it a "sigh of relief" rally, a sense that the Asian crisis might not be as fierce a threat to American corporate profits as once was believed. 
 "There's a recognition that some of the earlier fears about Asia were unwarranted," said Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The fact is that U.S. companies in aggregate will not see a big negative impact."
Many other strategists, however, warn that the Asian turmoil has not really diminished -- it has only receded from the front pages -- and that it could reappear in the form of lower first-quarter profits. But in the meantime, investors around the world are celebrating the less visible threat by buying up shares of companies that had been beaten down in recent months.
Yesterday, strong earnings reports by Goodyear Tire and Time Warner rallied the market early. And the heavy buying sent the Dow up 115.09 points, or 1.41 percent, to 8,295.61. In the last two weeks, the Dow -- the most widely followed stock index -- has risen nearly 5 percent, managing to eclipse its old record of 8,259.31, set on Aug. 6.
More remarkable, though, is the gain since Oct. 27, when the Dow fell 554 points to slip as low as 7,161.15. While many investors panicked, those who bought stocks around that time, following a pattern seen throughout this bull market of buying on dips in prices, have pocketed big gains.
Indeed, many of nation's biggest and best-known companies -- even those with considerable interests in Asia -- have rallied sharply in recent months. The so-called Nifty Fifty, which includes companies like Coca-Cola, DuPont and Phillip Morris, is up 30 percent in the last 12 months.
Yesterday, investors were bidding fiercely for such blue-chip stocks, helping send the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- which reached the 1,000-point level for the first time last week -- up 8.27 points, to 1,019.01. The Nasdaq composite index rose 18.61 points, or 1.1 percent, yesterday to 1,709.04, leaving the technology-heavy indicator just 2 percent from its all-time high.
Much of the buying interest is being focused on big-name stocks, but in recent days the bidding has broadened to smaller-company issues. And the pace of the activity picked up, too, yesterday. More than 647 million shares traded hands on the Big Board yesterday, about average for this year, but well above the pace of just a few months ago. In 1997, for instance, about 525 million shares traded each day on the Big Board.
Technology stocks are among the big winners this year. Shares of Intel and Microsoft, which trade on the Nasdaq stock market, continue to soar. Microsoft, now valued at more than $192 billion, reached an all-time high yesterday. Meanwhile, the Pacific Stock Exchange Technology Index is up 11.6 percent this year.
The bond market has held up well, too, in part because investors expect that the Asian crisis, even if it is easing, will help keep inflation in check despite an economy that continues to plow ahead.
In addition, a rise in worker productivity is helping hold costs down. Yesterday, bond prices rose, sending yields lower, after the Government reported that productivity increased much more than expected in the fourth quarter and rose by 1.7 percent for all of 1997. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.92 percent, from 5.94 percent on Monday.
The stock market rally in recent weeks has come despite what some see as a lackluster earnings season. With more than 80 percent of the companies in the S.& P. 500 reporting, earnings for the most recent quarter are up about 7.9 percent from a year earlier, a solid gain, but down significantly from the double-digit pace of earlier quarters, according to I.B.E.S. International, a firm that tracks corporate earnings.
"When we look back it's not a strong quarter at all," said Joseph Abbott, a research manager at I.B.E.S., noting that many analysts are cutting their projections for the first quarter of 1998. "They continue to come down, and the question is: Where does it stop?"
Mr. Abbott said that as recently as a month ago, Wall Street analysts had been projecting profit growth of about 9.4 percent for S.& P. 500 companies in the first quarter of 1998. That figure has dropped as low as 5.3 percent in recent days.
Elizabeth J. Mackay, chief investment strategist at Bear, Stearns, says that not much has changed since October, and that the crisis in Asia still looms large. "I'm not sure Asia's over with," she said. "I'm not even sure the impact on earnings has begun."
Ms. Cohen at Goldman Sachs, however, says that many investors are simply coming to the conclusion that the American economy is "hot stuff." She likens the economy here to a "supertanker," slow and purposeful, and hard to knock off course.
That may be why about nine stocks rose for every five stocks that fell on the Big Board yesterday.
Joseph Yurman, a managing director at BancAmerica Robertson Stephens, was on the trading floor yesterday and he likened the frenzy to the investors' dream of owning a piece of corporate America and watching the price appreciate.
"Everyone's chasing the same rainbow," he said. "We're all trying to buy the big names."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
From Mutual Funds to Raising Funds

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
The bull market on Wall Street has produced a windfall for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which received its first round of contributions this week from employees of Bear, Stearns & Company and Salomon Smith Barney, two of the nine investment banks and brokerage houses that participate in the fund's annual appeal.
As of Monday, $58,000 had been raised among 322 employees at the two firms, and much of that total will be matched by corporate grants. 
 Christian Hensley, 23, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney who helps coordinate the Wall Street campaign, said he expected this winter's yield to surpass that of previous drives, especially as donations from the seven other firms are gathered in the coming weeks.
"This is an extremely strong beginning to what we hope will be record-breaking numbers," Mr. Hensley said.
If so, they will be icing on the cake for the fund, which is enjoying its most successful campaign since it was established 86 years ago to help the city's poor, hungry and dispossessed. As of yesterday, $5,260,745 had been received from contributors, about $692,000 more than at this time last year. On Feb. 3, the tally of donations broke the record of $5,083,551 collected in the 1991-92 drive.
When this year's appeal ends, on Feb. 28, the money will be distributed among seven of the city's most prominent charities. And because The Times pays the fund's administrative costs, every dollar is spent on direct services, from feeding homeless children to keeping elderly renters in their homes.
Many contributors this year said they were moved by the realization that not everyone has benefited from New York City's healthy economy. Although the city's 8.7 percent unemployment rate is the lowest in years, it is still far higher than the national average of 4.7 percent. At least two million New Yorkers still live below the Federal poverty level, and their numbers are expected to grow as welfare benefits shrink over the next few years.
"The fact remains that if you're at the bottom of the barrel, not much prosperity is trickling down," said Herman Weingarten, 74, a retired teacher from the Upper West Side who sent the fund $25 for the seventh straight year. Mr. Weingarten said he was particularly worried about unskilled immigrants who arrive in New York without the ability to speak English.
"Like my own parents, who came to this country penniless," he said, "I know that many new arrivals need a little push before they can support themselves and their families."
Those who work with New York's most impoverished residents say that the need for assistance continues to outstrip available resources, especially after last year's welfare cuts, which removed thousands of legal immigrants from the food stamp program.
"For a city that is supposedly flush with prosperity, there is still too much deprivation and suffering out there," said Megan E. McLaughlin, executive director of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of the charities that benefit from the fund. "From where I sit, things look rather grim."
As in years past, the Wall Street campaign was led by a dozen young analysts who collected money for the fund in addition to working 80-hour weeks.
Sebastian Stubbe, 25, a third-year analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said that raising money for the fund was easier than he anticipated. "What I've learned is that people aren't stingy," he said. "They just don't have a conduit in which to be charitable. Present them the opportunity and they give."
This year the average donation from Wall Street has been $179. The largest came from James Valentine, 32, an equity researcher at Salomon who gave $10,000.
"The great thing about the fund is that we don't have to do any arm-twisting," said Aarti Chawla, 25, a second-year analyst at Salomon. "Everyone seems to know it's a good cause, so it's just about catching people who have very busy lives."

HEADLINE: Chrysler Is in the Market for Acquisitions

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 10

 BODY:
The chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, Robert J. Eaton, said this week that his company, the third-largest United States auto maker, was interested in buying all or part of another car company as it tries to increase international sales.
Talking to reporters before speaking at the Economic Club of Detroit, Mr. Eaton said: "Obviously, we're looking around. And if the right thing materializes, we'll be a player." 
 He told analysts last month that he expected some consolidation among auto makers in the first half of the year. Sales by the North American auto industry are expected to remain steady, prompting Chrysler to join its rivals General Motors and Ford in trying to improve sales abroad, analysts said.
Mr. Eaton said Chrysler might expand in Europe, where it has the smallest operations of Detroit's Big Three. While he would not say whether the company was in acquisition talks, he did mention Latin America as a region where Chrysler is putting emphasis.

HEADLINE: Productivity Jumps In 4th Quarter

 BODY:
Rapid economic growth at the end of 1997 was accompanied by sharp gains in worker productivity, the Labor Department reported yesterday. The index of nonfarm productivity rose at a 2 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, faster than analysts had expected, reflecting a surge in output of goods and services that far outpaced increases in wages and hours worked.

HEADLINE: Utility Agrees to Settlement in Bias Lawsuits

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 10

 BODY:
The Detroit Edison Company, the largest utility in Michigan, agreed today to pay as much as $65 million to settle accusations that it engaged in race, sex and age discrimination against 3,500 current and former employees.
Under the agreement, an arbitrator will decide on the overall amount that Detroit Edison must pay -- anywhere from $17.5 million to $65 million. Then, a committee made up of some of the plaintiffs, Detroit Edison executives and members of the Council of Baptist Pastors of Detroit will determine how much each employee will get. 
 The lawsuits were filed beginning in 1993, after Detroit Edison cut its work force of 11,000 to 8,400. Employees contended that the utility singled out women, members of minority groups and older workers. They enlisted the help of the Council of Baptist Pastors, which threatened economic sanctions.
