HEADLINE: Clinton Is Reported Set to Propose Rise in the Minimum Wage

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
President Clinton plans to propose increasing the minimum wage by $1 an hour over the next two years, Democrats say, an initiative that sets up the possibility of an election-year battle with Republicans.
After several weeks of negotiations, White House officials and Democratic leaders in Congress agreed today to work together to pass legislation raising the minimum wage in two 50-cent steps, to $6.15 an hour, people involved in the talks said. 
 A number of Democrats in Congress, including Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, had been pressing for an increase of $1.50 an hour over three years and a provision for further increases, indexed to inflation, after that. Administration officials, who supported a much smaller increase, ultimately agreed to $1 an hour over two years as a compromise, negotiators said.
Mr. Clinton could announce the plan as early as Thursday, when he goes to Capitol Hill to meet with Congressional Democrats about their agenda for the year, Democratic officials said. But these officials also said that the Administration was still consulting tonight with members of Congress over some details, including the precise timing of the increases, and that it was possible the formal announcement would be delayed.
Congress last passed an increase in the minimum wage in mid-1996, raising it 90 cents in two steps, to $5.15 an hour. The second step took effect last Sept. 1, when the minimum wage went up 40 cents an hour.
A new increase would affect about 12 million workers. For someone being paid the minimum for a 40-hour workweek, 52 weeks a year, the proposed increase would mean a raise before taxes of $2,080, to $12,792.
Influential Republican constituencies, especially small-business owners, have long opposed minimum-wage increases, saying the added costs force them to lay off workers, postpone hiring or even go out of business.
The Republican leadership in Congress was initially opposed to the minimum-wage increase in 1996, but reversed course in the face of strong public support for it.
Republicans have not taken a formal position on the issue this year. And although there is strong opposition among many conservatives to any increase, it is unclear how the party will respond to the Democratic initiative with the midterm Congressional elections looming and the economy booming.
Democrats said they would be happy to make their initiative an issue in the elections if the Republicans opposed it.
Congressional Democrats and White House officials said they were confident that the initiative would win considerable bipartisan support, in part because the job losses direly predicted by opponents of the last increase had failed to materialize. The Democrats said there was a very good case for raising the minimum wage at a time of strong business profits and low inflation.
"This is an effort to insure that as the recovery goes forward, people at the low end of the income scale will share in the benefits," a senior Administration official said tonight.
Unemployment currently stands at 4.7 percent, near a quarter-century low, and the strong economy is forcing many employers to offer higher starting pay to attract the workers they need. As a result, employers in a number of industries that have traditionally paid minimum wage, like fast-food restaurants, are already raising wages above the minimum.
The White House initially considered proposing a minimum-wage rise as an element of Mr. Clinton's State of the Union Message last month, but held off after a number of Congressional Democrats had asked the Administration to consider a larger increase.
Mr. Kennedy, Mr. Bonior and other Democrats had initially asked for an increase of $2.10 an hour over five years, to $7.25 an hour, and then an annual adjustment for inflation. They later scaled their proposal back to 50 cents an hour in each of the next three years, followed by an annual inflation adjustment.
Mr. Kennedy has argued that for the minimum wage to have the purchasing power it had in 1968, it would have to rise to $7.33 an hour. In the last 30 years, "the purchasing power of the minimum wage has gone down by 30 percent," he said in a speech in December, adding that the current annual pay of a full-time worker earning the minimum would leave a family of three $2,600 below the poverty level. "No one who works for a living should have to live in poverty," he said.
Mr. Kennedy and Mr. Bonior met earlier this month with their party's leaders in Congress, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, and a delegation from the White House, including Erskine B. Bowles, the chief of staff; John D. Podesta, deputy chief of staff, and Gene Sperling, the economic policy adviser.
They tentatively agreed to drop the proposal to index the minimum wage to inflation, and agreed as well to scale back the increase to $1 over two years, participants said.
Administration officials said that because the $1-an-hour increase over two years was roughly in line with the increase enacted in 1996, it would be harder for opponents to argue that it would kill jobs or damage the economy.

HEADLINE: Time for a Fuel Tax;
New Urban Coalition

 BODY:

To the Editor:
We agree that President Clinton must focus on transportation aid programs if the United States is to have a full urban agenda (editorial, Feb. 5). But transportation programs are not enough. There are other Federal (and state) policies that benefit new suburban developments at the expense of hard-pressed inner cities and older suburbs. Tax policies subsidize the development of housing subdivisions at the exurban fringe, and Federal regulations make reusing urban land prohibitively expensive. 
 These discriminatory policies, along with the fact that many older suburbs face inner-city problems (concentrated poverty, high unemployment, failing schools) but lack the tax revenue to combat them, are a powerful impetus for new metropolitan political coalitions. The coalitions would include the constituencies of central cities and older suburbs as well as others that lose from suburban sprawl, like environmentalists and rural advocates. We cannot save the cities without looking beyond their borders.
 
BRUCE KATZ
Dir., Center on Urban & Metropolitan
Policy, Brookings Institution
Washington, Feb. 6, 1998

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Japan's Trade Surplus Continues to Grow

BYLINE: Agence France-Presse 

 BODY:
Japan's current account surplus surged 59.8 percent in 1997, the first time in four years that it has grown, the Finance Ministry said yesterday. The surplus, measuring the flow of goods and services as well as monetary transfers, hit $92.6 billion in 1997. The surplus in trade alone expanded 35.5 percent, with exports growing 13.7 percent and imports rising 7.9 percent. 
 In December, the current account surplus jumped 57.4 percent from a year earlier, to $10.5 billion, rising for a ninth straight month. The trade surplus alone rose 35.7 percent, with exports up 12.2 percent and imports up 4.1 percent. The ministry said strong demand for Japanese goods in Europe and the United States offset sluggishness in Asia.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Opponent Challenges Newark Mayor's Report

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
In a speech rebutting Mayor Sharpe James's glowing State of the City address, a political opponent on the City Council yesterday attacked the Mayor's claim to have created 25,000 jobs in the past year and the rosy picture he painted of the city's future even as unemployment continues to soar.
Councilwoman Mildred Crump, who is running against Mr. James in the May nonpartisan election, said that the city's unemployment rate stood at 14 percent. She challenged the Mayor to explain what kind of jobs were created and who got them. She said his 25-page address, delivered two weeks ago, devoted just one paragraph to education, and she criticized him for failing to cooperate with officials of Newark's state-run school district. 
 Pamela Goldstein, a spokeswoman for Mr. James, listed Continental Airlines and Prudential Insurance among several local employers that had recently increased hiring. She also said that Mayor James worked frequently with the Newark Board of Education, including running an after-school recreation program.

HEADLINE: Argentina's Values

 BODY:

To the Editor:
As an Argentine living in the United States, I was somewhat disappointed by your article "Argentine Economy Reborn but Still Ailing" (front page, Feb. 6). What Argentines fear is not globalization itself, but the Americanization of our culture. We have strong ties with Europe, as our social structure indicates. Universal health care provided by the state, free public universities, legal protection from layoffs, and six-month maternity leaves are just some of the social rights that have protected us from becoming a selfish society. 
 Unlike Americans, we strongly value solidarity and do not praise success as our utmost goal. Efficiency belongs to inanimate objects. Free time is still highly cherished, and being busy is something that people are not proud of. Unfortunately, these are the values that we are losing.
 
FEDERICO GRAYEB
Oklahoma City, Feb. 6, 1998

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Investors Step Up Purchases Of Stock and Bond Funds

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Investors stepped up their purchases of shares of stock and bond mutual funds in January, compared with December. But while bond funds took in more money than in any month for more than four years, cash flows to stock funds failed to measure up to the levels reached in January of the previous two years.
According to estimates released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute, a fund trade group, stock funds continued to receive a majority of the new cash that went into long-term mutual funds, garnering an estimated $18.5 billion in net investments last month. 
 That topped December's cash flow of $16.8 billion but fell below the extraordinary flows of January 1997, when stock funds added a record $29 billion, and January 1996, when they added $28 billion.
Prior to 1996, however, stock funds had never taken in as much as $18.5 billion in a single month. Therefore, last month's take can be measured as slow only in relation to the very strong totals of the previous two years.
Bond funds, meanwhile, took in an estimated $11.5 billion in January, up from $5.6 billion in December and $3.6 billion in January 1997. Last month was the strongest month for bond funds since August 1993, when they added $12.7 billion.
The January bond fund purchases came close to the $12.6 billion that the funds added for all of 1996. That year followed two years in which more money flowed out of the funds than came in.
The cash flow figures released yesterday represent estimates of new investments minus the amounts that are pulled out of funds; final figures will be released near the end of the month.
The rapid purchases of bond funds follow three years of extraordinary stock-fund gains; those gains attracted more than half a trillion dollars in new stock-fund investments.
Now, analysts say, investors are seeking to buy a bit more safety, perhaps in the expectation that such strong gains in stocks cannot continue. Evidence that investors are simply reallocating their mutual fund investments can be found in the fact that the $30 billion that flowed into long-term mutual funds in January -- that is, into stock and bond funds combined -- is only about 10 percent below the totals in January of each of the last two years.
Also spurring cash flows to bond funds in recent months has been talk of the possibility of deflation, brought on by the economic problems in Asia, said James Paulsen, chief investment officer at Norwest Investment Management in Minneapolis.
"Government bonds are absolutely the best thing to own in a deflationary environment," Mr. Paulsen said. "And we're already seeing deflation in several areas, like unit labor costs, new auto prices and the cost of alcoholic beverages."
In addition, over the last three months, the average corporate and government bond fund gained about as much as the average stock fund, according to Lipper Analytical Services.
The yield on 30-year Treasuries, which declines as the price of the bonds rise, has been falling for nearly a year. In August 1993, the last time sales of bond mutual funds were as high as they were last month, interest rates had been declining for about three years. Within six months, long-term rates headed sharply higher after the Federal Reserve began to raise short-term rates.

HEADLINE: A Place for Part-Time Students

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's attack on the City University of New York has prompted debate about the system's mission and how best to deliver remedial courses that more than 8 in 10 students require. The debate is timely and important. But so far it has overlooked the merits of revising the state student-aid formula, which has failed to keep up with changes in student demographics.
Over the last 20 years, colleges all over the country have seen a large rise in part-time and non-traditional enrollment, as younger students work to meet soaring tuition costs and older workers return to college to retool for the changing labor market. The trend is especially pronounced at CUNY, where 70 percent of students attend school part time at some point. These students, mostly poor and many of them single women with children, must work to support their families and to earn money for tuition. 
 Full-time students can take advantage of the state Tuition Assistance Program, which provides $615 million a year statewide and covers more than 80 percent of tuition for the poorest students. But part-timers are covered by a less generous program that furnishes only up to a third of tuition costs and has only $15 million to spend. That is unfortunate, given that a third of the state's 770,000 students attend part time. With education so important to the state's economy, it is time for an aid formula that encourages part-timers to complete their degrees instead of punishing them for trying.

HEADLINE: Brazil Congress Votes to Scale Down Social Security Benefits

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Winding down a special session of Congress marked by political horse-trading inside and labor protests outside, lawmakers have approved bills to strip down social security benefits and job protections.
The measures are the cornerstone of the Government's four-year plan to stabilize the economy. 
 The social security changes, sought by President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, passed Congress late Wednesday, by 346 votes to 151, with the winning margin 38 votes more than necessary for a constitutional amendment. And on Tuesday the Senate approved civil service changes that loosen job protections that public workers have long had.
Congress also approved a bill against money-laundering, and at noon today, once the social security vote was in his pocket, the President signed an environmental crimes law, vetoing some of its toughest provisions. The provisions were opposed by members of Congress close to industrial and rural interests.
Riordan Roett, a specialist on Latin America at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies in Washington, said the votes would lift the confidence of international investors. The Government has been pushing through the structural changes to distance itself from the tumult in Asian markets. But he noted that further votes lie ahead before the bills take effect.
In the social security system, the minimum age for retirement is being raised to 60 years from 50 for men who have contributed to the system for 35 years, and to 55 for women who have contributed for 30 years.
The maximum pension for private sector employees is $1,080 a month, but for public workers the maximum jumps to $11,256 a month, corresponding to the top salary of a Supreme Court minister.
Divisive parts of the social security bill were put off for a vote early in March, after which the entire bill will return to the lower house for a second approval.
Under the civil service amendment, public employees for the first time could be dismissed for incompetence or because spending on salaries exceeds 60 percent of a state's total budget. The change is subject to enabling legislation outlining the criteria for dismissing employees.
The Government estimates that the reforms will save Brazil $10 billion a year and, more important, lessen future strains on the social security system.
But the changes set off bitter protests among workers. Scattered work stoppages were reported, and protesting workers and pensioners threw counterfeit bills at lawmakers disembarking at the Brasilia airport for the vote.
Vicente Paulo da Silva, president of the country's most powerful labor union, the 19-million-members Central Labor Union, said the reforms would penalize the most vulnerable, least-educated workers. "The rich man's son will retire with fewer years of work," Mr. da Silva said.
In signing the environmental protection law, the President vetoed seven key articles. One banned setting fires without taking precautions to keep them from burning out of control, while another removed the automatic liability of companies to clean up their environmental damage and compensate victims. Companies will be held responsible only if the Government can prove the damage was intentional.
Mr. Roett of Johns Hopkins said the financial reforms were important "for the long-term health of the Brazilian economy, but they don't address the outstanding issue of inequality, especially in income."

HEADLINE: U S West Media Reduces Loss

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ENGLEWOOD, Colo., Feb. 12

 BODY:
U S West Media Group said today that it had pared its fourth-quarter loss on higher revenue from its United States cable-television, high-speed data and cellular phone businesses.
The company, the media unit of U S West Inc., said its loss narrowed to $133 million, or 24 cents a diluted share, from $174 million, or 30 cents, a year earlier. Per-share results matched the average estimate of nine analysts polled by I.B.E.S. International Inc. 
 The loss included a pretax noncash charge of $200 million that has been set aside to cover costs arising from Asian economic problems and a pretax gain of $313 million on the sale of assets.
Revenue rose 5.3 percent, to $1.29 billion from $1.22 billion, helped by the growth of its high-speed data services. The company almost doubled its number of data customers to 23,000, from 13,000 at the end of the third quarter, while the number of United States cable subscribers was unchanged in the same period.
Shares of U S West Media Group were up 56.25 cents, to $30.50.
Cash flow, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, rose 16 percent, to $453 million.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Sees Asian Crisis Moving World to Western Capitalism

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told a Senate panel today that one of the most fundamental effects of the Asian crisis was a worldwide move toward "the Western form of free market capitalism," instead of the competing Asian approach that only a few years ago looked like an attractive model for nations around the world.
"What has happened here is a very dramatic event towards a consensus of the type of market system which we have in this country," Mr. Greenspan said before the Senate Foreign Relations committee. 
 In the last year there have been a number of triumphal declarations of America's economic success from members of the Clinton Administration. But rarely have they come from the cautious chairman of the Fed. Today the argument fit neatly with Mr. Greenspan's agenda: to overcome broad resistance in Congress to $18 billion in new support for the International Monetary Fund as it attempts to stabilize Asia's markets and others around the world.
Mr. Greenspan's appearance, alongside Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, was part of an intense effort by the Administration to get the I.M.F. financing pushed through quickly, with few strings attached. During the hearing, Mr. Rubin pledged to "sit down with the I.M.F." and press for broad reforms in the institution -- something a growing chorus of lawmakers is insisting upon -- though he stopped well short of promising actual changes. The United States is the largest contributor to the fund, but it only provides 18 percent of its financing and has a commensurate vote in its operations.
A few days ago, Administration officials believed they would win a relatively quick approval for additional funds for the I.M.F., despite a struggle in the House. Now they are not so optimistic. Republican leaders have once again suggested the funds could be tied to an amendment that denies funds to any organization abroad that provides or counsels on abortions. That amendment killed a $3.5 billion contribution to the I.M.F. at the end of last year's Congressional session. This year the Administration is seeking those funds and an additional $14.5 billion increase in the American contribution to the I.M.F. -- though the money is lent to the fund rather than actually spent.
Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Rubin are pressing for quick action because the Administration fears the closer it gets to Congressional elections the more difficult it will be to get House members to vote for what is clearly an unpopular cause in many parts of the country. They are also fearful that continued social unrest in Indonesia, where the I.M.F. is currently involved in its most difficult economic rescue effort, could kill the entire American contribution.
"A few pictures of troops putting down riots, and opponents of this will say the I.M.F. is helping along the cause of authoritarianism," one Administration official said recently.
The chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican, hinted at that argument today as he jousted with Mr. Rubin.
"There is no getting around the fact that I.M.F. intervention has so often meant the bailing out of negligent bankers and corrupt or incompetent governments," Mr. Helms said.
Mr. Rubin, Mr. Greenspan and Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, argued today that the I.M.F. had succeeded in using its bailouts to force nations to open their markets and transform their economies -- a step, they suggested, toward more democratic government.
In the last decade or so, Mr. Greenspan said, the nation has observed "a consensus towards the, for want of a better term, the Western form of free-market capitalism as the model which should govern how each individual country should run its economy."
"We saw the breakdown of the Berlin wall in 1989, he added, "and the massive shift away from central planning towards free market capitalist types of structures. Concurrent to that was the really quite dramatic, very strong growth in what appeared to be a competing capitalist-type system in Asia. And as a consequence of that, you had developments of types of structures which I believe at the end of the day were faulty, but you could not demonstrate that so long as growth was going at 10 percent a year."

HEADLINE: U.S. and I.B.M. Join Forces to Develop Fastest Computer

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
The Department of Energy yesterday raised the stakes in the international race to build the world's fastest supercomputer when it announced that it had signed an $85 million contract with the International Business Machines Corporation to build a machine capable of 10 trillion calculations a second.
I.B.M. said that its machine, designed on the technology that enabled the Deep Blue supercomputer to beat the chess grandmaster Garry Kasparov last year, would be ready by 2000. 
 If it meets its goal of 10 "teraflops," or 10 trillion mathematical operations a second, it will be the world's fastest computer, combining the processing power of 8,000 of I.B.M.'s most powerful microprocessor chips.
"To put this into context," Secretary of Energy Federico F. Pena said, "we will be able to do in less than a day all of the calculations that were performed at the weapons laboratories in the first 50 years of the nuclear weapons program."
But for all that, I.B.M.'s speed record could be fleeting.
The Japanese Government has also embarked on an aggressive supercomputer development program whose goal is a 32-teraflop machine to be constructed by the NEC Corporation and installed by 2002.
The United States Government program, financed by the Energy Department, is known as the Advanced Strategic Computing Initiative. Computer scientists said it had had a striking impact in the international computing world, touching off a new race for global supercomputing supremacy.
"Our program has inspired other organizations and other governments to look hard in this area," said Randy Christensen, deputy program manager for the Advanced Strategic Computing Initiative at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories. "We're pushing the envelope."
Computer scientists said there were crucial differences in the goals of the American and Japanese programs.
The United States program, begun in 1996, is aimed at designing a new class of computers capable of simulating nuclear weapon explosions. They are a fundamental component of the Energy Department's Scientific Stockpile Stewardship Program, which is intended to maintain the nuclear weapons arsenal without physical testing of the bombs.
The Japanese are embarking on an Earth Simulator Program to help scientists model global climate conditions, earthquakes and other natural phenomena.
The Energy Department's program is planning five generations of supercomputers intended to scale up from 1 to 100 teraflops by 2005. In addition to Lawrence Livermore, both Sandia National Laboratories and Los Alamos National Laboratories have received awards from the agency to have purchase supercomputers from Silicon Graphics Inc., the Intel Corporation and the Sun Microsystems Corporation.
The two competing national programs will also match two fundamentally different computer architectures against each other, and scientists said that the competing designs were both still unproved at multi-teraflop speeds.
"The drama here is that the two programs pit I.B.M. against NEC, said Larry Smarr, director of the National Center for Supercomputing Applications, in Champaign-Urbana, Ill. "In a sense this is untried territory."
The Department of Energy is betting that I.B.M., Silicon Graphics and Intel will be able to solve thorny problems in scaling machines from hundreds to thousands of microprocessors. As scientific challenges like modeling storms are broken up into parts to be solved simultaneously on thousands of microprocessors, bottlenecks emerge based on huge amounts of data that need to be shuttled back and forth at great speed inside the computers.
Livermore researchers said they had not yet proved that the systems would accurately model weapons explosions, but they said they were confident that they could refine their software codes to run on the new superfast machines.
Even so, Mr. Christensen, a veteran physicist who has long been involved in the weapons simulation program, acknowledged: "This is hard, and it's not a lock. We don't have a 100 percent guarantee."
The risk that the United States runs is that the more traditional computers favored by the Japanese may be easier to program and may come closer to reaching peak speeds on real problems.
But United States industry analysts said that massively parallel processing, or M.P.P., computers have been making large strides in recent years. In 1997, commercial M.P.P. machines for the first time surpassed the sales of the traditional high-performance computers based on what is known as vector architecture for the way they arrange problems, said Chris Willard, research director at the International Data Corporation in Mountain View, Calif.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Up Just 0.1% As Cars Slump

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
A slump in auto sales offset a surge at department stores last month, holding retail spending over all to a tepid increase of one-tenth of a percent, a report by the Commerce Department showed today.
The rise in retail spending, to a seasonally adjusted $214.8 billion, followed a three-tenths of a percent gain in December and an advance of one-tenth of a percent in November, the department said. Both earlier months had previously been reported as stronger. 
 The report suggested that consumers began pulling back a bit late in 1997 after spending strongly through much of the year.
"We are talking about a consumer who has not been a pacesetter these last several months," said Robert Dederick, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "The consumer hasn't been on a tear since the third quarter."
Still, there is little evidence the retreat is anything more than a natural slowdown, he said. Asia's widely reported financial problems may have unsettled the American stock market for a time, but they have not discouraged consumers, who are enjoying solid income growth and a plentiful supply of jobs.
In another indication of the strong demand for workers, the Labor Department said today that new claims for unemployment benefits edged down to 303,000 last week from 305,000 the week before. A four-week moving average of claims dipped to a three-and-a-half-month low.
The retail sales mix in January largely reversed the December pattern, when sales at many stores were weaker than expected but auto makers enjoyed a big gain.
In January, discounts drew shoppers back to department stores, where sales rose 1.6 percent, the biggest gain in 13 months. Clothing shops posted an increase of seven-tenths of a percent, the best in five months. But auto sales fell 1.1 percent.
"When consumers buy cars, they tend to throttle back on other purchases," said Paul Boltz, an economist at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. "They don't buy a car and a new stereo and two new suits. It's too much."
Excluding the volatile auto category, sales rose five-tenths of a percent in January after declining one-tenth of a percent in both December and November. It was the best showing since July.
Also contributing to the January advance were sales at building supply and hardware stores, up 1 percent, and furniture stores, up three-tenths of a percent. Both were helped by robust home sales.

HEADLINE: Low Rates Spur Surge in Home Buying and Refinancing

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
Interest rates have fallen to a four-year low in recent weeks, causing a surge of home buying and mortgage refinancings that has created a windfall for consumers, lenders and real estate agents in the New York metro politan region.
"I am probably getting 50 percent more phone calls than a year ago," said Ellen Bitton, president of the Park Avenue Mortgage Group in Manhattan. 
 As of Wednesday, the average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was 7.1 percent, with 1.31 points, according to HSH Associates, a mortgage analyst in Butler, N.J. -- slightly above the 6.83 percent of Oct. 15, 1993. A point is a fee paid at closing that is equal to 1 percent of the loan. The average adjustable rate was 5.59 percent, with 1.35 points, up from a low of 4.15 percent on Oct. 29, 1993.
"Our phone volume has increased by 500 to 600 percent, and this is the third time something like this has happened in the 90's," said Bruce R. Lublin, president of the Homerica Mortgage Corporation in Harrison, N.Y.
The lower interest rates have made buying a home more attractive and fueled business at real estate brokerages.
"It has led more people to put their homes on the market and make the move to a more desirable neighborhood," said John Dibs, the owner of RE/MAX Liberty, a real estate broker in Ozone Park, Queens. "At the same time, more purchasers have entered the home buying market to take advantage of the low interest rates. Over all, I'm currently experiencing an increase in purchasing activity and inventory."
In 1992 and 1993, 30-year fixed-rate mortgages dipped below 7 percent for the first time in more than a quarter-century and some adjustable-rate mortgages had initial rates as low as 3 percent. Then, like now, more than 70 percent of all new mortgages were refinancings.
Christopher Ryan, a Danbury, Conn., firefighter, and his wife, Donna, who operates a day-care center at their home in nearby Sherman, Conn., recently refinanced their mortgage after watching their one-year adjustable-rate mortgage jump to 8.5 percent, swelling their monthly payment by $400 above what it was in 1995. So in January, they refinanced to a mortgage that is fixed for seven years and adjusts annually after that; it has a lower rate, 7 percent, than their old loan and saves them $125 a month.
"We could have gotten down to 6.5 percent," Mr. Ryan said. "But I jumped the gun and locked in about two days before the big rate drop."
On Wednesday, People's Bank in Bridgeport, Conn., received 75 refinancing applications; the norm is 30.
"Volume has risen dramatically during the first six weeks of 1998 compared to the first six weeks of 1997, more than tripled, and the weather has been about the same, so the increase is not weather-driven," said Dorothea Brennan, a bank spokeswoman.
Mortgage brokers' business has jumped so much that they are writing about as many loans as are banks. It has not always been that way. Before the early 90's, few people used mortgage brokers, intermediaries who find loans for borrowers and help them with the applications but do not make loans themselves. The industry was small and, to some degree, had a slightly shady reputation. Instead, borrowers usually, almost reflexively, shopped for rates at local lenders.
The National Association of Mortgage Brokers, a trade organization, said that the percentage of home mortgage applications written by brokers increased to 52 percent last year, from 20 percent in 1987. Most of them are refinancing loans.
"Seventy-five percent of my business is currently devoted to mortgage refinancing," said Neil Bader, chief executive of the Skyscraper Mortgage Company in Manhattan. "It is double what it was at this time last year."
Most of the recent refinancing activity has been into 30-year fixed-rate loans. Rates on one-year adjustable mortgages have not fallen so sharply. Indeed, many homeowners who took them out in recent years have found that they are paying higher rates than they would for a 30-year fixed-rate loan.
The savings on mortgages can be substantial when rates decline. Circumstances have outdated the old formula for practical refinancing of "2-2-2," meaning borrowers had been in a home at least two years, intended to stay at least two more years and refinanced at a rate at least two percentage points lower than their current mortgage rate.
When is the rate difference wide enough? Many mortgage brokers believe that a drop in rates of even half a percentage point can justify refinancing, if the fees of the loan are wrapped into the loan or are paid by the broker. Such loans are sometimes called "zero-cost" refinancings; in exchange for about three-eighths of a percentage point in the rate, all other fees are paid.
The savings can be substantial, however, even when rates drop just a little. Consider a homeowner with an existing mortgage of $200,000, and a mortgage rate of 7.25 percent. The monthly payment is $1,364. At a refinanced rate of 7 percent, just a quarter-percent lower, the monthly payment would be $1,330, a savings of $34 per month.
Robert Gold, a lawyer and real estate developer who lives in Greenwich Village in Manhattan, recently refinanced the mortgage on his one-bedroom co-op apartment using a mortgage broker.
By refinancing from a 7.25 percent one-year adjustable-rate mortgage into a 7.125 percent mortgage that has a fixed rate for 10 years, Mr. Gold could take out $35,000 in equity from his home and only bump up his payments by about $100 a month.
"It's wonderful to be able to get the appreciation out of an apartment after eight years," he said, "and be able to lock in a very comfortable rate for a 10-year period."

HEADLINE: Hispanic Births in U.S. Reach Record High

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
The number of babies being born to Hispanic women in the United States has reached a record high, increasing to 18 percent of the total number of births, according to a new Federal report released today.
The study by the National Center for Health Statistics indicated that 679,768 babies were born to Hispanic women in 1995, the latest year for which complete data are available. That figure is up from 532,249 Hispanic-origin births in 1989, when 14 percent of all babies born in the United States had Hispanic mothers. 
 Hispanic residents make up 10.3 percent of the nation's population.
The fertility rate among Hispanic women varies greatly among nationalities, according to the study, which is the Government's most comprehensive look at Hispanic births to date.
The report also indicates that much of the increase in Hispanic-origin births is the result of high fertility rates among Mexican-Americans, particularly recent immigrants. About 70 percent of the babies born to Hispanic women in 1995 -- up from 61 percent in 1989 -- were born to women of Mexican heritage, the report said.
The study also estimated that Mexican-American women would average 3.32 births over their lifetimes, compared, for example, with 1.7 births for Cuban-American women and 2.2 births for Puerto Rican women, birth rates that are comparable to those of black and non-Hispanic white women.
The study provides further evidence that people of Mexican heritage have an increasing demographic significance in American society. The study's findings strongly imply that, as a result of high levels of immigration and a high birth rate, people of Mexican heritage are poised to become a major economic, political and cultural force in the coming decades.
"Their birth rates have been increasing while other groups have been stable or have declined," said Stephanie J. Ventura, a demographer in the National Center for Health Statistics. "It's not like the Cubans, who have low fertility and no growth from the outside."
The report also notes that as the Hispanic birth rate continues to rise, the birth rates of whites and blacks have declined. As a result, even if immigration is curbed, the Hispanic proportion of the American population will continue to grow.
The report, entitled "Births of Hispanic Origin, 1989-95," is compiled from birth records supplied by each state. The National Center for Health Statistics publishes a final report about 18 months after the close of a particular calendar year.
The reason for the delay is that hospitals and other birthing centers must first transmit their records to state health departments, and those departments must then send the records on to the health statistics center.
The report also noted a sharp increase in births among Hispanic teen-age girls from 1989 to 1995. Indeed, the study determined that in recent years, the birth rate for Hispanic teen-agers has exceeded that of black teen-agers.
The study said there were 106.7 births per 1,000 Hispanic teen-age girls in 1995, compared with 100.8 in 1989. In the same period, the birth rate among black teen-age girls dropped to 74.5 births per 1,000 teen-age girls, from 84.8.
But the study noted that Hispanic teen-age girls who give birth were more likely than the black teen-age girls to be married.
The study also highlighted some positive trends in Hispanic fertility. It noted, for example, that the number of Hispanic women who began prenatal care in the first trimester of their pregnancies rose by 19 percent from 1989 to 1995.

HEADLINE: Indonesian Rupiah Again Falls Sharply

BYLINE: Agence France-Presse 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Friday, Feb. 13

 BODY:
The Indonesian rupiah dropped sharply today for the first time this week, hurt by worries over possible changes in Indonesia's banking system and growing political tension in the country.
The currency fell more than 15 percent in Asian dealings to a rate of 9,100 to the dollar. 
 Traders said the decline reflected opposition by the International Monetary Fund and the United States to President Suharto's proposal to tie the rupiah's value to the dollar. Such a change would require Indonesia's central bank to hold enough dollars to repurchase rupiah to keep the exchange rate stable, which I.M.F. officials have said is unrealistic for the economically distressed country.
Fear of civil unrest in Indonesia also hurt the rupiah. Food riots have broken out in Jakarta, the capital, and other areas, in recent weeks.

HEADLINE: California Governor's Race: A New Height in Spending

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Politics has never been a cheap sport in California, home to a dozen media markets stretching over a span equal to the distance from New Jersey to Georgia and to a diffuse and desultory political culture where paid television commercials are king.
But as the 1998 gubernatorial race begins here in earnest this month, the state of so many firsts seems poised to set yet another record, for the most expensive state election campaign in American history. And in no small measure that is the work of one man, a demibillionaire Democratic businessman named Al Checchi (pronounced CHECK-ee), who is running for office for the first time. 
 Mr. Checchi, a 49-year-old investor who has been involved with companies from Marriott to Walt Disney and was until last year the co-chairman of Northwest Airlines, has come from nowhere to virtually dominate the Democratic field at the moment. Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, whose husband is a onetime partner of Mr. Checchi and himself a multimillionaire, chose not to run for governor last month -- though she led in all the polls -- because she confessed dreading the prospect that Mr. Checchi would spend millions of dollars attacking her in a primary.
Leon E. Panetta, a member of Congress from Monterey for eight terms who went on to serve as President Clinton's budget director and White House chief of staff, concluded last week that he could not possibly raise enough money to compete. Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis, who has spent years planning a gubernatorial bid and amassing a war chest of more than $4 million, now finds Mr. Checchi nipping at his heels in public opinion polls.
The only other Democrat who decided she could afford to join the fray by the filing deadline last week was Representative Jane Harman, who represents a coastal district on the south edges of Los Angeles and whose husband has a fortune akin to Mr. Checchi's.
On the Republican side, the conservative State Attorney General, Dan Lungren, faces only token opposition for his party's nomination to succeed Gov. Pete Wilson, who must leave after two terms. But a combination of concerns among moderate Republicans that Mr. Lungren's strong anti-abortion stance and Mr. Checchi's deep pockets might hurt Mr. Lungren's chances led the popular Republican mayor of Los Angeles, Richard J. Riordan, himself worth well over $100 million, to flirt briefly but intensely last week with the notion of running for governor.
"What can I say?" said Herbert E. Alexander, a professor of political science at the University of Southern California and a longtime expert on campaign finance. "Money is an important element in politics, and it certainly gives an advantage to a person such as Checchi. There's a lot of money going in this race."
Wealthy candidates who finance part or all of their own campaigns are nothing new in American politics, from the Kennedys to Ross Perot and former Representative Michael Huffington of California, who spent close to $30 million of his family's fortune in an almost successful effort to unseat Senator Feinstein in 1994. That was the all-time record for spending for an individual in a Senate race and together with the $13 million Ms. Feinstein spent, the all-time record for collective spending in a Senate race.
Mr. Wilson and his 1994 Democratic gubernatorial opponent, Kathleen Brown, together spent even more than that, an all-time record of nearly $50 million.
But Mr. Checchi, who is worth more than $500 million, has the capacity to cause both those records to be broken. To boost his name recognition among voters, Mr. Checchi began advertising on television last November for the June primary, the earliest of any candidate in California history. By Dec. 31, he had spent $7.25 million on the race, and he acknowledged today that he had probably already broken the record state primary spending level of $9 million set by Ms. Brown in her campaign for governor.
Mr. Chechhi, whose adversaries refer to him with a mixture of scorn and envy as "Al Checkbook," makes no apologies for his wealth, or his decision to spend it on a campaign. He dismisses as "nonsense" any suggestion that his entry into the race deterred other candidates, or limited voters' choices.
"What my spending has done is allow the public to have another choice," Mr. Checchi told a group of reporters over breakfast this morning. "No amount of money is going to get people who want to do something to do something they don't want to do. You can't buy votes, you can only disseminate information."
In fact, in politics, getting out the message is often the biggest battle, and Mr. Checchi's wealth has already given him a major leg up. He has hired experienced campaign consultants and run advertisements that portray him as the self-made grandson of immigrant grocers and that show him walking the beach with his attractive family, advocating tougher educational standards and the imposition of the death penalty for serial rapists and repeat child molesters. His wife, Kathy, who speaks fluent Spanish, has appeared in Spanish-language advertisements aimed at the growing Hispanic electorate.
Acknowledging his electoral inexperience, Mr. Checchi spent months last year crisscrossing the state and listening to the concerns of various groups before speaking out on the issues. He showed up at the State Democratic Convention in Sacramento last spring to make the rounds, but declined an invitation to address the delegates, insisting he was not yet qualified.
He is considerably more confident now, jousting aggressively this morning with veteran political reporters over everything from his wealth to his failure to vote in four elections since 1993, including the 1994 governor's race.
This morning, Mr. Checchi also tossed out two new popular proposals in this state where automobiles are ubiquitous and managed health care plans are widespread: He called for a 10 percent cut in auto insurance premiums and a "Patients' Bill of Rights," for members of health maintenance organizations and other managed care plans.
Paradoxically, some political experts say, it was a recent state effort to sharply limit campaign contributions and spending that contributed to Mr. Checchi's current dominance. Proposition 208, passed by voters in 1996, limited contributions to candidates for statewide office to $500 per donor, or $1,000 if candidates agreed to spending caps, and under the law, candidates for office this year could not even begin raising new money until last summer, though they could use money raised before the new law took effect.
That left Mr. Panetta, who was waiting to see what Ms. Feinstein did in any case, unable to start raising money to catch up with Mr. Davis's war chest, let alone Mr. Checchi's potential. A Federal judge last month struck down the contribution limits as unconstitutionally harsh, but by then it was too late. "Proposition 208 was a drastic measure that has been knocked down," Professor Alexander said. "Now the floodgates are open and it'll probably be an arms race."
Steve Merksamer, a Sacramento lawyer and Republican who was chief of staff to former Gov. George Deukmejian, said that most wealthy aspiring politicians in the past, from John F. Kennedy to Ms. Harman, started out running for lower offices like Congress before presuming to take on leadership of the nation's most populous state and the world's seventh-largest economy.
"As a general proposition, I think it perverts the Democratic process," Mr. Merksamer said. "There's nothing wrong with people of all walks of life, including wealthy people, entering the political fray.
"What's changed," he added, "is that you have candidates that have never been involved in appointed or elected office, who haven't participated in the difficult tasks and give and take of making public policy, and think that by virtue of the fact that they have either inherited or made a lot of money that they are instantaneously qualified for holding high political office."

HEADLINE: Democrats Rally as President Unveils Agenda for Campaign

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
They stepped up, woman after woman, to praise the President. A black business executive. A white woman looking toward retirement. A 21-year-old college student, not much younger than Monica S. Lewinsky.
"Six years ago, I was filled with apprehension and fear about my economic well-being and my retirement security," one of them, Judy Lee, said today at a Democratic rally in a Senate auditorium. But she prospered under the Clinton economy. "I'm back," she said. "I'm hopeful again. And I now plan to retire when and if I want to." 
 Then Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri lauded his rival Vice President Al Gore for working "so hard and so effectively." Mr. Gore called Mr. Gephardt, his expected Democratic challenger in 2000, a "a great leader."
Basking in Democratic unity that has so often eluded him in better times, President Clinton rolled out a campaign agenda today for the November mid-term elections built on the traditional Democratic touchstones of strengthening Social Security, improving health care, expanding Medicare, hiring teachers and increasing the minimum wage by $1 over two years.
"If it doesn't happen this year, we owe it to the American people to make sure it was not our fault," Mr. Clinton said, urging Democrats to work with Republicans to pass as many of the agenda items into law as possible.
It was Mr. Clinton's first appearance on Capitol Hill since the night of the State of the Union Message. And Democrats put aside their feuds, ignored the White House crisis over the President's relationship with Ms. Lewinsky, a former White House intern, and gamely stood by Mr. Clinton's side, aware that their fate in the mid-term election may be inextricably linked to his.
Mr. Gore contrasted the Democratic unity with Republican squabbling over tax cuts, health care and the propose tobacco settlement.
"The Republican Party is in so much disarray today," the Vice President said, "that the right hand doesn't know what the far right hand is doing."
Though Congressional Democrats have assembled similar campaign platforms in the past, this was the first time that Mr. Clinton, too, had embraced the identical agenda.
The Democrats have built this platform on their traditional areas of strength, putting Social Security front and center as an issue that can draw the elderly and the baby boom generation. Mr. Clinton staked out the issue in his State of the Union Message when he called for any government surpluses to be saved for Social Security.
For the first time, too, Mr. Clinton endorsed a specific proposal to raise the $5.15-an-hour minimum wage.
The other cornerstones of the Democratic program are health care issues, the regulation of health maintenance organization managed care and the expansion of Medicare so uninsured people nearing retirement age can buy into the program.
It was significant that the Democrats featured three women to talk about these issues. Women are now some of the most faithful Democratic voters and many of the agenda items are designed to have a particular appeal to them.
Mr. Clinton thanked the three for "reminding us why we're here."
In his only oblique reference to the scandals consuming his White House, he said: "I'm not exactly a Washington person, you know. I just sort of showed up here a few years ago for work. And sometime I really get lonesome for why I came here."

HEADLINE: Amsterdam News' New Generation;
Owner's Daughter Tries to Rebuild Famous Paper for Blacks

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Leonard Davis sells papers in Harlem, but his opinions are free. Ask him what he thinks of The New York Amsterdam News, one of a half dozen black newspapers neatly displayed on his newsstand, and he will offer several earfuls. The paper, he said, has become "bourgeois" -- too much news about social goings-on, too little about issues -- over the last half-decade.
"You get off the first two or three pages, and there's really nothing there," he said, as a customer nodded vigorously in agreement. 
 This does not mean Mr. Davis has no interest in news on black life, from a black perspective: he is an avid reader of several other black papers, and thinks general market papers like The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post "slant" their coverage of black issues unfavorably. Whether the issue is the allegations of a police attack on Abner Louima or even a black view on Bill Clinton's troubles, Mr. Davis says black newspapers are almost as necessary today as when the first one was founded 170 years ago.
Finding the magic formula that will bring Mr. Davis back to The Amsterdam News, and take new readers with him, is Elinor R. Tatum's challenge. In December, she became editor in chief and publisher of The Amsterdam News, the city's oldest, best-known black paper, replacing in name, if not yet entirely in fact, her father, Wilbert A. Tatum, who owns the paper. Mr. Tatum, 65, has had health problems, from heart bypass surgery and prostate cancer to neurological damage from injuries in a fall.
"It's time," he said about his daughter's anointment.
Ms. Tatum, who is 27, has her work cut out for her. The 89-year-old Amsterdam News is profitable, and it remains a Harlem institution, its imprimatur still coveted by many politicians. But the city's media market is more competitive than ever, and its black population larger and more diverse than ever. No single paper may be capable of serving that population, but some critics, including several journalists, say The Amsterdam News has not done enough to reflect the changing face of the New York region.
There is no question that its readership is withering. The New York metropolitan region has a black population of more than 2 million, but the paper's circulation has dropped to 25,962, according to the most recent figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulations, down from 36,242 in 1987 and 58,905 in 1977. (Other black weeklies, like The New New York Beacon and The New York Voice, claim larger circulations, but they are not audited by the bureau, which is considered the industry standard.)
The paper's reputation, once illustrious, has fallen as well. E. R. Shipp, the Daily News columnist, recently included The Amsterdam News in a description of the country's black papers as "ghost shadows," offering "embarrassingly inept and irrelevant journalism."
Under Ms. Tatum's leadership, there has so far been no perceptible change in the paper's tone or content. As a defamation suit against Tawana Brawley's advisers proceeds in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., for instance, the paper is trying again to prove -- as it did a decade ago -- that Ms. Brawley was raped, despite a grand jury finding to the contrary. The paper has also devoted front-page space to articles from The Tribune-Review, an extremely conservative paper in the Pittsburgh area owned by Richard Mellon Scaife, alleging that the Government has covered up evidence that the death of Commerce Secretary Ron Brown was a homicide, not an accident.
"I don't want to make any bold changes," Ms. Tatum said in the paper's time-worn offices on Frederick Douglass Boulevard. "I want to do it slowly, correctly. I have to defer to him because he has the experience," she said of her father, who will, for now, continue to write editorials and have a say in the paper's content.
How The Amsterdam News fares under a new generation of leadership may be a bellwether for the nation's several hundred black papers. Dorothy R. Leavell, the president of the National Newspaper Publishers' Association, an organization of black newspaper publishers, said at least 12 of the association's 215 publishers had died last year. At those papers and others with aging leadership, succession is a pressing question. So is keeping readers and, especially, generating advertising. "We are at a crossroads," Ms. Leavell said.
All the black papers face fierce competition these days from everything from television to black-oriented Web sites.
The competition is especially thick in New York, but The Amsterdam News seems ill equipped for combat. It has only one staff reporter. It culls the rest of its content from freelancers, reprints from other papers and press releases. The office has only one computer and, unlike The New York Beacon, The Daily Challenge and other black papers, no Web site.
Nor does the paper have a Brooklyn office, although the borough now rivals Harlem as a center for the city's black population. While the paper reprints some stories and press releases about Africa and the Caribbean, it gives minimal coverage to immigrants from those areas living in the city.
Wilbert Tatum responded to criticisms of his paper by pointing to the growth in competition, as well as his paper's unionized status, alone among New York's black papers. "People say, 'What have you done?' " he said. "We're alive -- that's what the hell we've done."
Control of the paper has been firmly in Mr. Tatum's grasp since he became editor and took majority control in 1983.
"To a large extent, The Amsterdam News has become Bill Tatum," said Ken Smikle, who worked at the paper in the 1970's and is now president of Target Market News, a publication based in Chicago that covers the black media and consumer market. "The paper's personality has sort of merged with his own, for good or for bad."
That personality combines expressions of Southern sweetness, moral outrage and fiery melodrama. The paper is much the same. It features "small town in a metropolis" coverage of Harlem's galas and the region's black residents' achievements, coupled with an abundance of stories about police brutality, redlining and other manifestations of racism and discrimination.
There is also breathless, opinionated and sometimes outrageous coverage of racially polarized stories like the Brawley case -- a "certain amount of conspiracy thinking," said Dr. Roscoe Brown Jr., a professor at the City University Graduate Center.
Among those who work at or watch black newspapers, there is heated debate over whether they should be painting a more nuanced picture of black life and leadership. The Tatums -- and their counterparts at The New York Beacon and The New York Voice -- say that while mainstream papers show the negative, they exist to show the good.
To show black life, period, was the central reason black papers were founded. Segregation gave the papers a captive audience, as black readers turned to their own publications to find a favorable chronicle of their existence and follow the progress of their quest for civil rights.
But starting in the 1950's, integration and the civil rights movement sapped much of the black papers' vigor as they lost readers, journalists and advertisers to general-market papers and later to black-oriented magazines and radio stations.
Elinor Tatum also attributed her paper's drop in circulation to a more recent decision to cut back the print run in light of rising costs and distribution problems.
Joel Dreyfuss, a senior editor at Fortune magazine, said he sympathized with the difficulty of obtaining financial resources for a black publication: he recently spent over a year unsuccessfully trying to raise $8 million to start a new national black weekly. "The perception that blacks want first-class, high-quality news is still lagging," he said, adding that some black publishers seemed to share that perception -- including Mr. Tatum.
"It's an issue of quality," Mr. Dreyfuss said of The Amsterdam News. "They haven't put in the resources to demand better journalism." By focusing too narrowly on racial grievances, he said, the paper failed to capture the complexity of black life and politics in the 1990's.
The paper makes money, though, according to the Tatums, and Mr. Smikle argued that Mr. Tatum's "fiery, aggressive, outspoken political focus" was one reason why. "Shy of that," he said, "The Amsterdam News could just be swallowed up by all the other media outlets in the city."
As an editor, Mr. Tatum was never accused of being a shrinking violet. He won renown and rebuke over the years for running 104 consecutive front-page editorials calling for Edward I. Koch's resignation -- the culmination of a long-running feud between the two men -- and for printing the name of the jogger who was gang-raped in Central Park in 1989. After the Crown Heights riots, Mr. Tatum ran a headline, "Many Blacks, No Jews Arrested." That and some pieces in the paper drew accusations of anti-Semitism, which Mr. Tatum angrily denied.
He speaks with pride of his own integrated private life; he regularly mixes with whites and is married to a Jewish woman, the former Susan Kohn, who fled Czechoslovakia at the beginning of the Holocaust.
Elinor Tatum is a practicing Jew as well. "My identity is both black and Jewish, and very proud of both," Ms. Tatum said, adding that she thought it would not affect what she did at the paper.
Over time, she said, she will upgrade the paper technologically and recruit young reporters. She also hopes to beef up the arts coverage to lure young readers, she said, noting that the paper's Arts and Entertainment editor has been there for 52 years. The paper has already hired a new assistant to the publisher, Robert E. Seixas, who is 25 and, like Ms. Tatum, attended New York University's journalism program.
Ms. Tatum, who was raised on the Lower East Side, lives there in a building owned by her father and around the corner from her parents' home. An only child, Ms. Tatum said she had a "privileged upbringing, but not sheltered," noting that she grew up on a block with a homeless men's shelter. She attended the private Dwight School, then on the East Side, where her passion was theater, not journalism.
She graduated from St. Lawrence University in upstate New York, working her way up to editor at large of the campus paper. She started work at The Amsterdam News in 1994.
She appears poised and at ease with political notables like David N. Dinkins or the Rev. Al Sharpton. But in her comments about the paper, she seemed to feel the weight of history and high expectations on her shoulders.
"The paper is basically being handed to me by my father," she said. "I've got to keep it going for the next generation."

Over the last five years or so, a host of new small publications, often put out by just a few people using increasingly affordable technology, have joined the mix of black newspapers in New York City. Below is a sampling:
 
The Black Star News Founded 1997
Publisher: Milton G. Allimadi
Circulation: Monthly. Last issue sold out a 20,000 print run.
The scoop: The Ugandan-born Mr. Allimadi, a graduate of Columbia University School of Journalism and a former deputy editor at The City Sun, got the money to start his paper from Bill and Camille Cosby.
His monthly covers everything from the African continent to health care to the history of black hair and has a literary feel. Eventually, he would like to make the paper a weekly.
 
The KIP Business Report Founded 1997
Publisher: Lloyd C. Grant
Circulation: Aimed at 25,000 black business owners and professionals in New York and New Jersey, as well as policy makers.
The scoop: Middle income blacks, Mr. Grant observed, tend to fly beneath the radar of the major media and above that of the local black press. Co-founded by Cynthia Y. Franklin, its editor, The Report tries to provide an extended business grapevine and monitor the economy from a black perspective.
 
The New York World Founded 1993
Publisher: Franklin Solis
Circulation: Monthly; 35,000 copies distributed free in Brooklyn and downtown Manhattan.
The scoop: Mr. Solis, a former advertising salesman, started this paper, initially called The Brooklyn Advocate, because there was no free black or Latino publication in Brooklyn at the time. To keep his paper true to the grass roots, he said, he accepts advertising only from local businesses. He covers local people and events.
 
Our Time Press Founded 1995
Publisher: David Mark Greaves and Bernice Elizabeth Green
Circulation: Monthly; 25,000 distributed free in Brooklyn, Harlem and lower Manhattan.
The scoop: He left his job as a project manager for a moving company; she left hers in media relations at CBS. We felt there was a lot of information the African-American community wasn't getting, Mr. Greaves said. The couple operates off a computer and out of a Clinton Hill storefront, covering issues from multilateral trade agreements to local black history.
(pg. B10)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
CITING ASIAN CRISIS, LAM RESEARCH ANNOUNCES JOB CUTS

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
The Lam Research Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 700 jobs, or 14 percent of its work force, in a reorganization the company attributed to Asia's financial crisis. Lam, a maker of equipment for manufacturing computer chips, said it expected lower prospects for orders and revenue from its Asian customers. Lam Research said it would take a third-quarter pretax charge of $80 million to $85 million because of the reorganization, which also includes closing plants and writing down the value of certain assets. Lam Research, based in Fremont, Calif., had revenues of $582 million in the six months ended Dec. 31. Lam announced the cuts after its stock gained $2.125, to $28.4375.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
I.B.M. Sells Another Site

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The International Business Machines Corporation is nearing the end of a major sale of its real estate holdings that it began four years ago.
In recent years, I.B.M. has disposed of more than 14 million square feet of office, warehouse and industrial space across the country, according to real estate executives. The latest sale came earlier this week in Endicott, N.Y., the town where I.B.M. got its start about 80 years ago. 
 The company sold its 127-acre Glendale Technology Park to the Glencott Realty Corporation, a Manhattan investment company, for $6.5 million. The one-million-square-foot site, which once housed I.B.M.'s software development laboratory, had been on the market for three years in an area that is only beginning to recover from the recession. About 40 percent of the 17 buildings in the $100 million complex are occupied by several state agencies, and the companies Telespectrum and Nationwide Credit. I.B.M., however, still has a major presence in the area.
"Glendale Technology Park is truly a diamond in the rough," said Lawrence J. Bijou, a director at Cushman & Wakefield, who represented the buyer. "This is a Class A facility in a tertiary market that is rebounding nicely."
Robert A. Mead, a real estate consultant, represented I.B.M. in the sale.
James Ruderman, a spokesman for I.B.M., said that the Glendale campus was the last major parcel in the country that it had put up for sale. The remaining sites are small and scattered across the country.
Also this week, I.B.M. sold its 257-acre Ulster Business Complex to the investor Alan Ginsberg for more than $20 million. It has also sold a 3 million square foot complex in Boca Raton, Fla., and a 200-acre complex in Franklin Lakes, N.J., that had been closed in 1993. CHARLES V. BAGLI

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Another Day, Another High; Dow and S.&P. Climb Again

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average rebounded from an early drop to reach its third consecutive new high yesterday as investors discounted unsettling news from Asia.
Mirroring the trend of weaker equity markets in Asia and Europe, stocks opened lower on Wall Street, with the Dow falling as much as 76.23 points before climbing in late afternoon trading. 
 Casting a pall on this week's rally were fears of growing political protests in Indonesia over its economic crisis and fears that the United States might not support the Indonesian Government's plan to impose monetary controls.
Those concerns pushed Indonesia's benchmark equity index down 9.3 percent yesterday, and stock markets in Hong Kong, Singapore, New Zealand, Malaysia, South Korea, Thailand and the Philippines each lost more than 1 percent.
While American stocks have been gaining in recent days -- with both the Dow average and the Standard & Poor's 500 index posting new highs on the belief that Asia's impact on corporate earnings has been limited, -- the early selloff "tells you the focus is still on Asia," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.
"From time to time, it starts to look like all the pieces in Asia are going to come apart," Mr. Johnson said. "If you ask me what the stock market is going to do tomorrow, I'd ask you how many people are going to be marching in the streets of Indonesia or in the streets of Malaysia."
As evidence of investor concerns, stocks of multinational corporations like AT&T, Walt Disney, Merck, General Electric and Coca-Cola, which have also been some of the Dow's better performers this year, were lower in early trading.
However, comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin yesterday seemed to allay some investor concerns, analysts said. In comments to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, both called on Congress to support the United States commitment to contribute to the International Monetary Fund's bailouts of the faltering Asian economies.
Traders and analysts said those remarks as well as the economic fundamentals of this country, including low inflation, low unemployment and moderate economic growth, pulled investors back into the market.
"Once it stabilized, after the first people stuck their foot in the water, it was just everybody in the pool," said Michael W. Clark, a managing director and head of United States equity trading at Credit Suisse First Boston in New York.
In pushing the Dow to another record close, investors ignored reports that President Clinton plans to call for a $1 increase over two years in the minimum wage, bringing it to $6.15 by 1999, said Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company. In previous remarks, Mr. Greenspan had warned that rising wage pressures could aggravate inflation and hurt the economy.
The Dow finished at 8,369.60, up 55.05 points. Over the last 14 trading days, the Dow average has risen 668.86 points, or 8.7 percent.
The S.& P. 500 also reached its seventh new high in the last nine trading days, closing at 1,024.14, up 4.13 points. The Nasdaq composite index, heavily weighted with technology shares that had fallen early in the day, finished up 5.79 points, to 1,714,34. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled more than 611 million shares.
Some investors were perplexed by the market's turnaround.
"I was surprised at the strength of the market," said Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer and chief executive of New Amsterdam Partners, a New York-based investment management firm. Since she is only forecasting that the stock market will increase about 10 percent this year, Ms. Clayman said that since the Dow has already risen more than 5 percent in 1998, she anticipates a modest retreat.
However, New Amsterdam, which has become more domestically focused since late last summer, was employing a well-tested investor strategy of buying on the dips yesterday, Ms. Clayman said.

HEADLINE: December Business Inventories Grew 0.4%

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Stockpiles of unsold goods accumulated steadily on store shelves in December, the Commerce Department said today in a report that may foreshadow slower economic growth in 1998.
 Total business inventories increased four-tenths of a percent in December to a seasonally adjusted $1.048 trillion -- the 18th consecutive month without a decline -- after gaining a revised three-tenths of a percent in November. 
 Analysts said much of the inventory buildup had been in response to brisk demand so the December report was not worrisome. But there have been signs that consumers may be curbing their spending pace.
 Lynn Reaser, an economist at Nationsbank in Jacksonville, Fla., said the relatively weak retail sales of the last three months, as reported by the Government on Thursday, may lead to an adjustment as companies restrain production to avoid an excessive buildup of unsold goods.
It remains unclear whether consumer spending, which accounts for the bulk of economic activity, is about to slow significantly. But a new consumer confidence survey distributed today showed growing optimism about the economy's future. The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index, based on survey results, rose to a record 110.1 in February from 106.6 in January.
 A Labor Department report today showed a 1.3 percent drop in import prices in January, more than twice the six-tenths of a percent fall in export prices. Imported oil fell 9.9 percent -- the biggest price drop since December 1993 -- a restraint on consumer prices since industry is highly dependent upon foreign oil.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices End Higher in a Shortened Session

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended higher in a shortened session yesterday, drawing foreign investors after stock prices slumped in Asia.
Gains in bonds were limited, however, by a survey showing that consumers were more upbeat and likely to spend more, reviving concerns about a pickup in inflation. 
 The University of Michigan's preliminary index of consumer sentiment rose to a record 110.1 in February, from 106.6 in January, traders said. (The survey is released only to subscribers.)
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose a quarter-point, to 103 30/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.84 percent, from 5.86 percent on Thursday. The Treasury market closed early yesterday, at 2 P.M., and will be closed on Monday in observance of Presidents' Day.
While some investors were buying yesterday because of the weakness in Asian markets, others were booking profits on the upticks in price.
A report on business inventories in December gave the market some comfort since it suggested that growth the next quarter might be reduced as companies cut back production to get rid of some of their inventory accumulation of goods, said Anthony Chan, chief economist for Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio.
Next week, the market will focus on producer prices and housing starts on Wednesday and December trade data on Thursday.
