HEADLINE: I.M.F. Opposing Indonesia's Plan For Currency

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund tried today to veto Indonesia's plan for changing how it values its beleaguered currency, setting up a showdown with President Suharto that could have profound implications for the world's fourth-most-populous nation.
The fund, which has promised $43 billion in assistance to help the country recover from the financial instability that has swept Asia, said Indonesia was not ready to adopt the high-risk, high-reward recovery strategy for its currency that Mr. Suharto had settled upon in recent weeks. 
 "We are of the strong view that this moment has not yet come in Indonesia," Michel Camdessus, the fund's managing director, said in response to a question from the audience after a speech here.
Mr. Camdessus did not say how the fund would respond if Mr. Suharto went ahead with his plan, which would lock the Indonesian currency's value to that of the dollar under a mechanism known as a currency board.
If successful, the move would greatly strengthen the currency and help Indonesian industrialists, not least among them members of Mr. Suharto's family, who have long used their connections to amass great wealth and who have been influential proponents of the strategy. If it failed, it could leave Indonesia's foreign currency reserves depleted and its economy in an even steeper downward spiral.
The I.M.F. is scheduled to disburse another $3 billion to Indonesia next month, but must review Mr. Suharto's economic management and give it a passing grade before doing so. While the fund has temporarily cut off aid to other nations that have failed to live up to bailout agreements, including Russia, Mr. Camdessus would have to consider the risks to financial markets throughout Asia and around the world if he were to move against Indonesia.
Mr. Suharto met in Jakarta today with Steven Hanke, an economist from Johns Hopkins University who has been a leading advocate of adopting a currency board. Mr. Hanke said after the meeting that the Indonesian leader was committed to going ahead with the plan and would continue to discuss it with the fund.
One day after Mr. Suharto ordered the military to take "stern action" to deal with his opponents, there were reports today of rioting in at least eight towns by residents angry about rapidly rising prices for many basic goods. Although there has been sporadic unrest for a month because of the economic crisis, there are few signs that the 76-year-old Mr. Suharto is losing his grip on power after 32 years in office.
Officials from the I.M.F. and their counterparts at the World Bank and in the Clinton Administration have been raising doubts about Mr. Suharto's emerging strategy in recent days, and the fund dispatched an envoy from Washington this week to tell the Indonesian leader of its concerns.
Today, Mr. Camdessus turned up the pressure, leaving no question that the fund was strongly opposed to Mr. Suharto's plan and would work to stop it.
Mr. Camdessus said adoption of a currency board, which has proved successful in Hong Kong, Argentina and other economies, might one day be appropriate in Indonesia. But he said that if Indonesia adopted a currency board now, it might well fail, risking deeper economic and political turmoil.
Mr. Suharto's Government, Mr. Camdessus said, has not yet done enough to strengthen the banking system, deal with foreign debts and bolster the nation's foreign currency reserves -- all steps that economists say are necessary before Indonesia can cope with the short-term economic strains that Mr. Suharto's approach would entail.
Mr. Camdessus emphasized twice that his statement represented the unanimous view of the I.M.F. executive board, which is dominated by the United States and the other big industrial democracies.
Mr. Camdessus, however, did not address what American and international officials have acknowledged to be another of their primary concerns: that Mr. Suharto's backing of the plan may be driven in part by his family's desire to minimize its financial losses from the instability sweeping the country.
Two of Mr. Suharto's children reportedly helped Mr. Hanke win access to the Indonesian leader to convince him of the merits of the currency board. Like other business owners who have debts in dollars and large holdings of the Indonesian currency, the rupiah, they would benefit greatly from the plan.
Under the plan, the rupiah's value would be pegged at around 5,500 to the dollar, significantly stronger than its recent rate. Today, the rupiah settled at 8,200 to the dollar, down 11 percent from where it traded on Thursday.
Under a currency board, the Government would effectively give up control of monetary policy. The Government would pledge to do whatever was necessary to maintain the exchange rate at its fixed level, primarily by using its foreign currency reserves to purchase rupiah and by allowing interest rates to rise.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F. chief, said Indonesia's rescue plan was premature. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Havana Journal;
Remember the Maine? Cubans See an American Plot Continuing to This Day

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
The old monument still towers over the Malecon, Havana's tattered seafront promenade, but it has been stripped of most of its original busts and plaques, including the eagle that once crowned it. Clearly, even after 100 years, remembering the Maine has a different meaning in Cuba than in the United States.
"To the victims of the Maine, who were sacrificed to imperialist greed in its fervor to seize control of the island of Cuba," reads an inscription at the base of the memorial. 
 Only two rusted cannon and a weathered tablet listing the 267 American sailors who died in the still-unexplained sinking of the battleship remain intact at the site.
As generations of schoolchildren in the United States, Cuba and Spain have been taught, the Maine blew up in Havana on Feb. 15, 1898, leading to a four-month war that freed Cuba from Spanish rule and made Puerto Rico an American possession.
Now, with the centennial of that war looming, Cuba has embarked on a campaign to selectively revive memories of the conflict as a tool to be used, scholars and diplomats say, in disputes with the United States and Spain.
The Cuban Government's position is perhaps most succinctly conveyed in the title of a new book, written by a prominent Cuban historian, about to be published here: " '98 -- The War That Does Not Cease."
From President Fidel Castro on down, officials are seizing every opportunity to portray the conflict as the beginning of a century of American hostility and avarice toward Cuba and to minimize the United States role in what is known here as the Spanish-Cuban War or the Second War of Independence.
Mr. Castro set the tone in welcoming remarks to Pope John Paul II on Jan. 21 that attacked the United States as well as Spain. Cuba, he maintained, "had to fight alone for its independence," and in doing so fell victim to "a veritable holocaust" at the hands of Spanish colonial oppressors.
"Today," Mr. Castro continued, "genocide is again being attempted when some try to subdue this people, which refuses to accept the dictates and rule of the mightiest economic, political and military power in history, by means of hunger, illness and total suffocation."
Subsequent comments made clear that he was referring to the 37-year American economic embargo of Cuba, especially the 1996 Helms-Burton Act tightening such sanctions.
A week later, on the 145th anniversary of the birth of Jose Marti, Cuba's national hero, Mr. Castro's brother Raul, the country's Defense Minister, lashed out even more strongly. In a speech in Santiago, where much of the war was fought, he announced plans to put up new monuments to the rebel Mambi army "that the Yankees refused to let enter" Santiago and to the victims of the Spanish, whose toll he put at 300,000.
In an interview at Jose Marti National Library here, Eliades Acosta Matos, who is director of the institution and author of the forthcoming book on the war, offered the standard Cuban interpretation of the sinking of the Maine: that the United States itself probably did it. The same "powerful economic interests" that had an interest in doing so, he argued, may also have been involved in a conspiracy that may have been responsible for the assassinations of Presidents Lincoln, Garfield and McKinley.
Dr. Acosta said a series of conferences and discussions of the war would be held here throughout 1998, along with expositions of documents and photographs from the period. Such commemorations, he said, are a matter of "historical justice" and of reminding Cubans how their national identity was forged.
"Everyone wants to forget, but 1898 is still alive and relevant, and we ought to be able to bury it," he said. "A century later, the main actors in the war still have important differences. Relations with the United States and Spain are not normal, and Cuba is still defending itself from nearly 100 years of blockade and disrespect for its liberty and right to self-determination."
But Jaime Suchlicki, author of "Cuba: From Columbus to Castro and Beyond," an English-language history widely used in the United States, takes another view. He notes that before Mr. Castro seized power in 1959, most Cubans were taught that "Cuba became independent as a result of U.S. help" and that there was no knowing "how long it would have taken Cubans to defeat the Spaniards had the Americans not come in."
As for the sinking of the Maine, "conventional historiography taught that either the explosion was an accident or that Cubans did it themselves to provoke American intervention," added Dr. Suchlicki, who is a professor of history at the University of Miami. "Accusing the U.S. of blowing up the Maine is just a way of linking the war to all of the propaganda that blames the U.S. for Cuba's current problems."
It was gratitude for the United States role in the struggle for independence that led Cubans to build the monument to the Maine, which was dedicated in 1925, damaged by a hurricane a year later and subsequently restored. But in May 1961, just days after the Bay of Pigs invasion, a crowd assembled at the site to hold an anti-American rally and to watch as a crane toppled "the eagle of imperialism" from its pedestal atop a pair of 40-foot columns.
Today, the shattered remains of the eagle's wings and body lie in a heap at a downtown museum. There, groups of visiting schoolchildren are taught that the American intervention "sought to invalidate 30 years of immense pain and glorious battles," according to the museum display that the sinking of the Maine was merely "a pretext for the U.S. to participate in the Spanish-Cuban War."
The head of the eagle was rescued by Cubans sympathetic to the United States and turned over to the Swiss Embassy, which handled American interests in Cuba after diplomatic relations were broken in 1960. It is now mounted on a wall in a snack bar at the American Interests Section, Washington's quasi-embassy here, awaiting better relations between the countries.
"A lot of Cubans say they look forward to the day that the head and the body of the eagle will be reunited," said Michael Kozak, the senior American diplomat here, who has a copy of the intact eagle on display in the garden of his official residence.
At San Juan Hill in Santiago, where Theodore Roosevelt led the famous charge against Spanish troops that eventually propelled him into the White House, the authorities have taken a different approach.
At the top, there are monuments to Cuban combatants and even one honoring "the Spanish soldier, who knew how to die heroically in the performance of his duty," but nothing commemorating what Roosevelt called "the great day of my life."
"This park has been all but forgotten," said its unofficial caretaker, Eliezer Jorge Montelier, 21. Anything that once acknowledged Roosevelt's feat "has been removed," he added, though a pit for Cuban soldiers has been dug at the summit in recent years, "in case of an enemy invasion."
But Santiago is eager to attract tourists, and so there are plans to restore the original English-language plaques at San Juan Hill and open a historical museum near Siboney Beach, where 15,000 American troops landed in June 1898. With a centennial conference on the war to be held in Santiago in late June and early July, Dr. Acosta promised that the treatment given the American role in those events would be evenhanded.
"Americans died for the freedom of Cuba, and that should be recognized," he said. "But others wanted to annex Cuba, and that should be criticized. If relations with the United States improve, all these things can be re-examined more fairly."

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: THE RUSSIANS;
Russia's Stake In Iraq Bolsters Anti-War Cry

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Seven years ago, the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, begrudgingly blessed the American-led campaign to evict Iraqi forces from Kuwait.
But now President Boris N. Yeltsin and his top aides have led the opposition to American military action against Iraq. 
 From Moscow's political and business elite to the people on the street, most Russians oppose an American air strike to punish Saddam Hussein's Government for thumbing its nose at United Nations inspectors.
Russia's opposition stems from a potent combination of foreign policy and commercial interests. In one example of the economic stakes, Lukoil, Russia's premier oil company, has signed a $3.8 billion agreement to develop Iraq's Qurna oil field once economic sanctions are removed.
But the Russian stance is also a matter of national psychology.
Russians know the United States won the cold war. But many still find it hard to accept that the United States has the power, the will and the resources to launch a military campaign in the face of determined Russian opposition.
"What gives the United States the right to attack Iraq without other nations' permission?" said an aide to a Russian bank president.
It is a message that ripples through an array of new public opinion surveys here. Russian polls show that many Russians think that United States has recklessly picked a fight with its old nemesis and is arrogantly throwing its weight around. Even American polls here chronicle a tidal wave of popular Russian opposition. A survey by the United States Information Agency shows that most Russians do not want Iraq to have chemical and biological weapons.
Still, 8 of 10 people in Moscow and in St. Petersburg, a liberal stronghold, oppose "all military action needed to eliminate Iraq's chemical and biological weapons and its capability to produce them," the survey shows. And that opposition comes from Russians who are generally more sympathetic to Western views, the agency notes.
None of this means that Russia wants to forge an military alliance with Iraq or renew cold war hostilities with the United States. There is no serious talk of providing military assistance to Baghdad.
Americans officials were disturbed when United Nations inspectors found a document indicating that Russian specialists and Iraqi officials were discussing the sale of equipment that could be used as part of a biological warfare program.
But they say Russia has a generally satisfactory record of observing the economic sanctions against Iraq. Nor is the Yeltsin Government threatening to openly flout the sanctions if American force is used.
Russian experts say American bombing will make it more difficult to win approval of the Start 2 treaty in Russia's Parliament. But the Russian military is unlikely to withdraw its support for the accord, if only because Russia's nuclear force is shrinking with age and the treaty would reduce American strategic weapons.
Still, there is no doubt that American and Russian interests seriously diverge.
Russia's foreign policy team, headed by Yevgeny Primakov, a former spymaster, has enjoyed close ties with Baghdad since Soviet days and it sees the crisis as a way to regain influence in the Middle East.
Russian oil barons are eager to dispel the threat of war and see economic sanctions lifted so they can do business in Iraq. Lukoil is eager to get started on its 23-year agreement to develop oil fields in Iraq.
"We will be ready to start practical work two months after the embargo is lifted and to bring in equipment and people," said Dmitry Dolgov, Lukoil's spokesman.
The Russian Government also hopes that Iraq will be able to repay billions of dollars it owes for weapons supplied by the Soviet Union if and when sanctions are lifted.
"Russia has an economic interest in restoring ties with Iraq, and Russian businessmen are prepared to work with their Iraqi colleagues," Gennady Seleznyov, the Communist speaker of the Parliament, said last year.
That was underscored when the head of the Volgograd Tractor Plant proudly announced today that the company had concluded a $5 million agreement to sell Iraq 250 tractors. Although this deal was approved under the terms of the United Nations relief program, it is the kind of trade the cash-strapped Russians would like to see expand.
There is also the matter of hurt pride. Its not that Russians love Saddam Hussein. But they have a hard time accepting that Moscow is only marginally relevant to Washington's geopolitical calculations.
The public's anxiety over Russia's decline as a world power was papered over to an extent during the debate over NATO expansion. Russia and NATO worked out an accord that gives Moscow a voice, but not a veto, on alliance decisions.
But there is no easy way to smooth over the current dispute. Taking center stage, Mr. Primakov staked Russian prestige on a diplomatic settlement that would stop American bombs from falling on Iraq. And now the diplomacy appears to be collapsing and both Iraq and the United States seem determined to fight.
Add to that the generally nationalist tone of the Russian press, which has shown American aircraft carriers steaming toward the Persian Gulf even as the Russian military remains a picture of decay and weakness.
A banner headline in Izvestia this week reported that an American air strike could unleash a deadly cloud of chemical gas throughout the Middle East, based on analyses by the Government weather forecasting service.
And last week, radio talk shows here were abuzz over reports of an American plan to hit Iraq's weapons sites with tactical nuclear weapons.
"Most of those polled are just afraid of a war and as usual do not understand quite clearly what is going on," said Yuri A. Levada, the head of the respected polling company, Vtsiom.
With the possibility of American military action drawing closer, Mr. Primakov today made a bid for more time. After meeting here with the American Secretary of Defense, William S. Cohen, Mr. Primakov urged Kofi Annan, Secretary General of the United Nations, to go to Baghdad to discuss a possible political settlement.
But not even Russia's media held out much hope for a diplomatic breakthrough on Iraq -- or an upturn in American-Russian relations.
The independent NTV television network dutifully reported tonight that Mr. Cohen and Mr. Primakov appeared pleased after their meeting.
But then the network added sarcastically: "Maybe Mr. Cohen was satisfied with the results or maybe he was simply glad to leave the country before a spell of cold weather came."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1213 words

HEADLINE: AUTO UNION BACKS TENTATIVE ACCORD WITH CATERPILLAR

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Feb. 13

 BODY:
In a reflection of the labor troubles faced by America's traditional, smoke-stack worker unions, leaders of the United Automobile Workers today endorsed a proposed contract with Caterpillar to end the longest labor dispute of the decade.
The deal, which includes a two-tier wage scale and drops the unfair-labor-practice charges against Caterpillar, is not much better than the one the union rejected more than two years ago. 
 The agreement stands in stark contrast to the triumph scored last summer by United Parcel Service strikers.
It also comes at a time when American unions are pushing hard to demonstrate a renewed vitality in a prosperous economy and have had some significant victories.
The success of U.P.S., most experts say, illustrates the differences between the industrial and service sector.
A factory, with its stockpile of machines awaiting shipment, feels little pain at the beginning of a strike, said Michael Belzer, a labor scholar at the University of Michigan. A company like U.P.S., on the other hand, had no time to waste. If packages were not delivered in a timely manner, it could devastate the company -- which had a significant impact in its negotiating stance with its union.
"Some days you win, some days you lose, and some days you just get rained out," Mr. Belzer said. "For labor, this day was clearly a loss."
The battle with Caterpillar was truly lost more than two years ago, Mr. Belzer said, when the U.A.W. folded its tent in December 1995, after a 17-month strike and told its workers to return to their jobs. Indeed, thousands had already done so, crossing picket lines in defiance of union leadership.
"A generation or two ago, it would have been inconceivable to see workers at Caterpillar cross the lines," Mr. Belzer said. "And that really weakened them."
Caterpillar also had a much easier time finding replacement workers, in part, because it employed 13,000 workers -- compared with the 185,000 workers at U.P.S. In addition, since the factory workers are better paid -- the average worker at Caterpillar earns about $18 an hour -- it was easier for the company to find replacements.
Without any international cooperation among unions, Caterpillar workers outside the United States went right on producing heavy machinery, working overtime to increase the output.
In its domestic factories, the company used modern, computer-based production lines to stay in operation. Non-union workers, including secretaries and bookkeepers, performed the manufacturing tasks with the assistance of union members who crossed the picket lines and an ample and seemingly endless supply of replacement workers.
In fact, even with most of its veteran and highly skilled factory workers on strike, this major manufacturer of complicated machinery was not only able to continue making its products but to also earn record profits of $1.67 billion in 1997.
The deal, worked out with Federal mediators in Chicago in a marathon bargaining session, would allow some workers who had been discharged for union activities to return to work. The accord would also count time spent on strike in calculating retirement benefits. But under the proposed two-tiered wage, new workers would be paid a lower hourly rate than the prevailing wage of existing employees.
The contract, which would run for six years, rather than the typical three, also calls for the union to re-admit members who crossed the picket lines to return to their jobs.
And despite the weakened contract analysts noted the importance of securing a contract at all. Workers had been without a contract since 1991, and many believed that Caterpillar had hoped to be free of the union.
In announcing the tentative agreement, Caterpillar's vice-president, Wayne Zimmerman, said the company was "very, very happy and satisfied."
But the union's vice-president, Richard Schoemaker, did not shower the accord with praise, saying only that he believed the rank-and-file would endorse it.
The deal is expected to go to a vote of union members on the weekend of Feb. 21.
Inside the factory gates in Peoria, there was plenty of anxious talk among workers about the accord. After the three o'clock whistle, as workers poured out of the plant, some of them were simply shaking their head with disgust.
"Everybody in the shop is disappointed," said one worker, who would not give his name. "They weren't all that surprised, but they were hoping for more."
After the farm crisis of the 1980's, which severely hurt Caterpillar and other makers of big equipment, the company took a tough, uncompromising stance with the union in the early 90's.
Caterpillar brought the union to its knees in 1992, successfully ending a strike after threatening to hire replacement workers.
Two years later, with no progress on a contract, the union went on strike again, alleging unfair labor practices. This time, the company did hire replacement workers during the 17-month walk-out that ended in December when union leaders told workers to return to their jobs.
The company, saying it would not discharge any replacement workers, did not initially have jobs for all union members, saying that some would have to wait for openings. By now, all of those union members have been given the chance to return to work.
But the cases of more than 100 other Caterpillar workers -- people discharged for union activities -- have not been resolved. The union contends that these workers were illegally terminated.
George Boze, a vice-president at local 974 here, said one union worker was discharged when he ordered a man who crossed a picket line to leave his daughter's wedding reception.
But there were also allegations of cars being damaged and workers being harassed by union members.
According to the proposed agreement, the company would immediately rehire some of these workers. The cases of the others would go to Federal arbitration.
"At this point, nobody knows who might get called back," said Mr. Boze. "There's no list of names yet."
 For all its negotiating successes, Caterpillar has much fence-mending to do with its work force, if friendly labor relations are a goal, as the company has insisted.
Among rank-and-file workers at Caterpillar, there is profound resentment toward the company.
There is also plenty of hostility remaining toward the replacement workers hired during the strike, as well as the workers who crossed the picket lines.
Euel Smith, an inspections worker who crossed the picket line in 1994, said the feelings had "mellowed quite a bit" but would never heal.
Mr. Smith, 52, started working at the factory at age 19, and many of the faces here are familiar to him. But friendships soured, he said, when he crossed the picket line.
"If we're doing something at work, they'll talk to me about business," Mr. Smith said. "But once we're outside the job, a lot of them will just turn and look the other way."
Some workers clearly do not believe the company is paying its fair share.
"If the vote was based on the 20 people I talked to tonight, I'd say 98 percent are going to vote against this thing," said Fay Vogelsang, 48, a union member who has worked at Caterpillar for 23 years. "I feel like we're selling Manhattan for a necklace of beads."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Not-So-Honest Abe

BYLINE: By Gabor Boritt; Gabor Boritt's latest books are "The Gettysburg Nobody Knows" and "Of the People, by the People, for the People and Other Quotations From Abraham Lincoln." He teaches history at Gettysburg College.

 BODY:

HONOR'S VOICE
 The Transformation
 of Abraham Lincoln.
 By Douglas L. Wilson.
 383 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $30. 
 We think we know him. But what do we really know, especially about the private man whom we all suspect to be somehow crucially tied to the public one? "Historians are forever doomed to ignorance about the early life of Abraham Lincoln," began "The Last Best Hope of Earth" (1993), a brief volume that summed up more than 20 years of learning about Lincoln by the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Mark E. Neely Jr. Now comes Douglas L. Wilson with "Honor's Voice," a solid new portrait of the private Lincoln between the ages of 22 and 33, during the years 1831-42, that puts him in a strikingly fresh light.
The book starts not from the President's legendary greatness but from his actual beginnings. Wilson, the Saunders Director of the International Center for Jefferson Studies at Monticello, focuses with careful intensity on otherwise antiquarian oral reminiscences that help illuminate Lincoln's rise. Wilson tells a story about a search for identity and self-definition, and follows Lincoln's very exacting road of self-education, his finding of a vocation in law and politics, and the partial resolution of his painfully difficult relations with women.
The evolution of his religious outlook might illustrate his education. Raised a Baptist, Lincoln never outgrew a sense of fatalism, even "a nameless sense of . . . doom." But he had the strength to go against the grain, and he quickly found the skeptics. He read in Thomas Paine about "a young woman engaged to be married, and while under this engagement she is, to speak plain language, debauched by a ghost": it is the story of the Virgin Mary.
The law student, while teaching himself the rules of evidence, wrote two manuscripts of religious skepticism, long lost but also long remembered by his contemporaries. According to John T. Stuart, his first law partner, Lincoln "went further against Christian beliefs . . . than any man I ever heard." As he advanced in politics, Lincoln muted his heathenish talk, but even during this early period he learned to present himself, when necessary, "as an unfortunate victim of unbelief." A hypocrite? Wilson's readers can decide; but Lincoln was certainly someone with a sense of self-preservation. And someone at this time a very long way from the Second Inaugural.
In politics and law Lincoln rose from successful frontier fighter to peacemaker who fought with words. At times the words were not honest, and relied on smear and innuendo. Yet Lincoln carried a "compulsion" to help the helpless, and learned, to quote the Shakespeare he had come to love, that the best of men "have pow'r to hurt and will do none."
His most troublesome problem was women. The young man who had lost his mother at the age of 9 always felt awkward around them -- except for older women. He loved Ann Rutledge, she died and he fell apart. Friends and, in time, work helped Lincoln back from a perhaps suicidal mental breakdown. The depth of his grief suggests to Wilson that Ann's death challenged the core of his being. His central goal in life, his wish to rise, "to shape and even to control events," now seemed "nothing but foolish vanity."
Ambivalence characterized his later courtships and various marriage proposals. A possible reason for this, at least for a period of time, may have been a fear of syphilis -- not an unknown disease in his world. Wilson does not credit stories of Lincoln's possible love children but notes two episodes with prostitutes. If once or twice, why not more often? His longtime law partner, William H. Herndon, thought that "Lincoln had a strong if not a terrible passion for women: he could hardly keep his hands off." Nor would he get married until he was 33.
As Lincoln the outsider learned to be an insider, deep anxieties beset him about his ability to make a living, about success in law, about polite society. His journey led him from country to village to town, where he found the exciting, highborn Mary Todd. A superficial courtship was followed by a commitment to marry. In a brief diversion, he became smitten by another woman, but Mary did not let go. As his brother-in-law put it, "Lincoln in his conflicts of duty-honor and his love went as crazy as a Loon." In time he recovered the ability to rule himself, strengthening his self-respect by getting married. Love, Wilson suggests, seems to have had "very little to do with it."
Lincoln's road, therefore, was both harder and "swampier" than legend -- or scholars -- have allowed: the difficulties and temptations wider, the fears and depressions deeper. By 34 he appeared to have overcome his troubles, but not many signs of future greatness had yet turned up.
After 130-some years of Lincoln appraisals, how can a scholar, especially one as extraordinarily careful and fair as Wilson, create a startlingly new Lincoln? Wilson's achievement stems in part from the respect the culture has acquired for oral history (which often gives voice to the voiceless) and from his having put together, with his colleague Rodney O. Davis, the Szold Professor of History at Knox College, the definitive edition of the reminiscences of about 250 people who knew Lincoln: "Herndon's Informants: Letters, Interviews, and Statements About Abraham Lincoln" (1998). The two men have also been assembling, but have not yet published, the similarly massive recollections of Herndon himself -- the person who knew Lincoln better than anyone but Mary Todd. Historians have long used these oft-conflicting, difficult-to-read manuscripts, but Wilson's familiarity with them is unsurpassed.
The bulk of the reminiscences collected by Herndon were from 1865-66 and, as Wilson explains, emphasize the "honorable, or at least unobjectionable." But "Honor's voice," as Wilson calls them, "can tell us a great deal, and sometimes tells us much more than it intended."
This book establishes Wilson as the leading historian of the young and private Lincoln. Still, others sifting through the same sources may reach somewhat different conclusions, or take matters further. Consider the story about Lincoln's visiting a prostitute and, after undressing, realizing that he is $2 short of the needed $5 fee. He is offered credit but he departs, leaving the woman astonished at his integrity. Wilson knows that this sounds like "a deliberate parody of the Honest Abe Lincoln legend," yet he accepts it. But might not a less cautious biographer venture an additional step, teasing out of this story and other evidence the possibility of a homosexual young man, even if observers and participants failed to speak of such?
Focusing on the private Lincoln while mostly ignoring the public one can obscure the private, too. For example, to prevent a quorum at a session of the Illinois State Legislature in 1840, Representative Lincoln jumped out of a window of the building where the members were meeting. Wilson sees this as a sign of private distress. That the leap was intended to influence important financial legislation during a debilitating economic depression is largely lost. Biographers, then, will have to use "Honor's Voice" with both admiration and a critical eye.
IT is profitable to divide the Lincoln literature roughly into two schools: "Lincoln the man" and "Lincoln the god." Both have their uses. Wilson's book, with its understated, even prose, falls plainly into the first camp, and it makes a fine counterpoint to Garry Wills's "Lincoln at Gettysburg," with its portrait of a President who "remade America" with a brief speech. Had Wilson claimed to be showing all of Lincoln, he might be criticized for missing some of the elements that make his subject great. As it is, he makes a very important start toward a new understanding of the greatest of Americans.
Writing about Lincoln is not something to be brushed off as simply a scholarly exercise. In our multicultural age, he remains a man of world-historic significance, the very symbol of what is best about the United States. During the Iranian revolution, a reporter saw a big painted slogan in Teheran: "Government of the people, by the people, for the people." During Jiang Zemin's recent visit to the United States, the Chinese President conjured up Lincoln's memory. So has Pope John Paul II. When Colin Powell announced his refusal to run for the Presidency, he held up but one name. The Lincoln scholar's responsibilities are large. "Honor's Voice" gives Americans reason to be grateful that the field continues to attract students of ability and integrity.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 36; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 867 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber

 BODY:

A RIVER LOST: The Life and Death of the Columbia
By Blaine Harden. Norton, $13.
An author who grew up in the shadow of the Grand Coulee Dam chronicles the passage of the Columbia from a swift-moving, salmon-filled waterway to a polluted series of brackish lakes. He "has written a hard-nosed, clear-eyed, tough-minded dispatch," Hal Espen said here in 1996. The many lives that were shaped by these once-rushing waters are the theme of RIVER OF THE WEST: Stories From the Columbia, by Robert Clark (Picador USA, $15). In 1995 one critic called the book "an original and vibrant account."
 
FLYING HOME: And Other Stories
By Ralph Ellison.
Edited by John F. Callahan.Vintage International, $12.
This posthumous collection, which includes six previously unpublished works, captures Ellison's youthful voice and many of the themes he would expand on in his novel, "Invisible Man." All written between 1937 and 1954, the stories reflect the dislocation of black Americans and the cruelties, large and small, they were expected to endure. In one, a young white boy, a visitor in town, relates what it was like to watch a lynching; in another, a Tuskegee airman has the misfortune to crash his plane in Alabama. "The least of these stories are distinctive, the best are gripping and two are genuinely terrifying," our reviewer, Gary Giddins, wrote last year.
 
FRAGMENTS: Memories of a Wartime Childhood
By Binjamin Wilkomirski.
Translated by Carol Brown Janeway. Schocken, $11.
The author, a Jew born in Latvia, was a toddler when he saw his father murdered. He relates his story from the perspective of his childhood self, who neither knew the reason for the barbarity surrounding him at Auschwitz nor understood when it had actually ended. This "extraordinary memoir . . . recalls the Holocaust with the powerful immediacy of innocence," Julie Salamon said in these pages in 1997. PLAYING FOR TIME, by Fania Fenelon with Marcelle Routier, translated by Judith Landry (Syracuse University, $17.95), also evokes daily life in the death camps. Fenelon, a half-Jewish Parisian, was spared only because she could sing with the Auschwitz orchestra. Her memoir, now restored to print, "is particularly well told, with a minimum of self-pity," Raymond A. Sokolov wrote in the Book Review in 1977. The fate of survivors is explored in A HOLE IN THE HEART OF THE WORLD: The Jewish Experience in Eastern Europe After World War II, by Jonathan Kaufman (Penguin, $13.95). Chronicling the lives of five families, the author shows how they endured in the divided world of postwar Europe. His work is "profoundly chilling," one critic said last year.
 
TALKING IN BED
By Antonya Nelson. Scribner Paperback, $11.
Evan Cole, a psychologist, and Paddy Limbach, a roofer, meet at the hospital where their fathers are dying. But their awkward friendship threatens the stability of both their lives, as Evan's wife becomes drawn to Paddy. This novel is an "affecting and rewarding meditation on the confounding unpredictability of love," Stephen McCauley wrote in these pages in 1996.
 
EUROPE: A History
By Norman Davies. Harper Perennial, $24.
Concentrating on political events and his own specialty, Eastern Europe, the author gives a highly idiosyncratic view of a continent. Although in 1996 our reviewer, Theodore K. Rabb, criticized the book for historical mistakes, he praised its "telling insights, apt quotations and excellent quick overviews."
 
THE ERROR OF OUR WAYS
By David Carkeet. Owl/Holt, $13.
It's not surprising that a linguist by training should write a novel about communication. In this book, two men, a well-off entrepreneur and an unemployed linguist, negotiate the tough terrains of middle age and threatened marriages. Carkeet is "both an acute social observer and an engaging stylist," Margalit Fox wrote in the Book Review last year.
 
THE CONCERT
By Ismail Kadare. Translated from the French
of Jusuf Vrioni by Barbara Bray. Arcade, $14.95.
The author writes of his native Albania, which in this novel is undergoing its rupture with China in the 1970's. He portrays the tiny Communist nation as so isolated that it is devoid of all perspective, a situation ripe for both comedy and tragedy. "Kadare takes the reader completely inside the Albanian universe," Robert D. Kaplan said here in 1994. The same publisher has reissued Kadare's earlier novel THE PALACE OF DREAMS, also translated from the French of Jusuf Vrioni by Barbara Bray ($12.95). His subject is again totalitarianism, but the setting is the fictional United Ottoman States, where his protagonist, a bureaucratic functionary, works in an office whose purpose is to analyze dreams. The novel is "small, clever and all the more disturbing for its elegance and refinement," David R. Slavitt wrote in these pages in 1993.
 
MONKEY KING
By Patricia Chao. Harper Flamingo, $13.
The heroine of this first novel, Sally Wang, is struggling to come to terms with her father's sexual abuse, a painful childhood memory that her Chinese-American upbringing has encouraged her to bury and ignore. Last year our reviewer, Philip Gambone, called the book "a considerable achievement." Laurel Graeber

SECTION: Section 6; Page 20; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3033 words

HEADLINE: Fleeced

BYLINE: By Hal Espen; Hal Espen is features editor of Outside magazine.

 BODY:
Just one word: fleece.
In this American winter of our anxious contentment, fleece is, as style scouts like to say, everywhere. Unlike "plastics," that singular specter of conformity and inauthenticity that Dustin Hoffman was confronted with three decades ago in "The Graduate," fleece in our time enjoys a fuzzy, warm, unironic kind of ubiquity. Yet like plastic, fleece is a wholly synthetic product, derived from the Uberstaple of late-20th-century life: crude oil. It is, in fact, pure polyester, the stuff of hideous 70's shirts and disco tailoring -- but polyester technologically refined and reconfigured so that its organic-seeming secondary characteristics and narrative connotations have become dominant. The art historian Anne Hollander has written that fashion mutates to match "the shifty character of what looks right" at a given moment; in these first chilly months of 1998, the right uniform for both comfort and violent change in the weather is fleece. 
 A longtime fundamental of outdoor-sports product lines, fleece has lately proliferated on the streets, in department stores, in Old Navy television commercials, in baby carriages and in beds. Vogue assures us that models can't live without Patagonia's fleece vest. In L.L. Bean's Christmas catalogue this year, fleece was the unrivaled star attraction, featured on the front and back covers and highlighted in the first 14 pages; more than 170 fleece items were available. Over on Seventh Avenue, Tommy Hilfiger and Polo by Ralph Lauren offer fleece designs; Donna Karan is selling a $300 fleece robe and a $170 fleece unitard, while Nicole Miller has made dresses and skirts of fleece. In London, the street-fashion crowd has adopted fleece wear from labels like Red or Dead. Up on the slopes, wilderness skiers can pull on a Lowe Alpine Aleutian Check Hoody; snowboarders have their own subcultural choices in fleece garments, like Ned Limbo Ph.D. Beatmock shirts and hats by Rasta Imposta, Head Shreds and Chapeau de FUNK. On screen and off, Samuel L. Jackson's version of dapper owes a certain jaunty something to his plush Kangol berets.
By far the most culturally resonant version of fleece is the nonspecialized "technical" sportswear that ranges from L.L. Bean's and Lands' End's high-volume lines to more hard-core outdoor-endeavor brands like the North Face, Marmot and Mountain Hardwear. The aura of these premium lines has benefited both from constant innovation in fleece design and from waves of marketing that extols the fabric's empowering qualities. Like jungle khaki before it, fleece has become associated with athleticism and risk-taking in exotic and remote wilderness areas, and in the process, an androgynous fashionable archetype has emerged: the trekker.
More glamorous, versatile and daring than the trudging backpacker of old, the trekker roars across Southwestern landscapes in sport-utility-vehicle commercials and embraces exhaustion and annihilation in the Himalayas. He or she wages the moral equivalent of war against faceless natural enemies: cold, ice, altitude, exposure and frigid water. A new genre of death-haunted quest literature has arisen, most visibly in the best-selling nonfiction books of Jon Krakauer ("Into the Wild" and "Into Thin Air") and Sebastian Junger ("The Perfect Storm") and in the novels of Charles Frazier ("Cold Mountain") and David Guterson ("Snow Falling on Cedars"). In some sense, the incessant concern with the weather effects of El Nino and even the public's response to the movie "Titanic," with its images of insidious death through loss of body heat, fits in with this theme. It may be true, as is often said these days, that Americans are a little lost without a powerful threat to face -- international Communism, economic recession. Lacking any other nemesis, we seem to be mesmerized by hypothermia.
Given our suddenly urgent preoccupation with maintaining our core body temperature, the near-universal deployment of fleece makes perfect sense. Still, none of this happened overnight; the biography of fleece spans two decades, and it's a story with a history, a catechism, several heroes and ethical lessons. Follow the fuzz, and the charisma of those enveloping swaths of polyester proves to be an extraordinary creation.
For breaches, sweaters, shirts and caps, the answer is wool. Thus declared Yvon Chouinard in his classic 1978 book, "Climbing Ice." Chouinard, then renowned primarily as a pioneering extreme mountaineer and as a small-scale manufacturer of climbing equipment, was about to transform his obscure line of Patagonia clothing into a stupendous retail and catalogue sales success story, but the future was only dimly discernible. In the late 70's, the mantra technical had barely begun to be applied to apparel. Garments made with W.L. Gore's first generation of breathable, water-resistant Gore-Tex, which was introduced in 1976, tended to be flawed and unreliable. And fast-drying polypropylene underwear was a much-derided novelty item notorious for its tendency to retain, distill and broadcast body odor.
Cotton for comfort, wool for insulation and nylon to repel moisture were the chief options available to growing hordes of wilderness athletes who were discovering that sodden clothing could transform an outing into a miserable and even dangerous affair. (The 70's adventurer also relied on the bulbous, puffy goose-down parka, which had its own problems both as a fashion statement and as a reliable garment in inclement conditions.) Of course, earlier generations of explorers and adventurers had somehow managed to conquer mountains and survive the back-of-beyond without space-age clothing, but as the recreation boom took off, the stoical tolerance of discomfort began to seem a little stupid -- and an obsessive attention to gear became half the fun. By the mid-80's, improved versions of Gore-Tex became tremendously popular, inspiring endless debate over the art and science of wicking moisture away from the skin.
A few years earlier, Patagonia, based in Ventura, Calif., had introduced what it would later describe as its "infamously homely yet unforgettable" pile jacket -- a synthetic fleece garment that, it insisted in one of its patented authenticity-by-association gambits, was modeled on jackets used by North Sea fishermen. Its successor, called a bunting jacket, became the company's first runaway best seller in the early 80's. But the fateful date for fleece came in the spring of 1985, when Patagonia launched its Synchilla-fabric line of jackets, the first recognizably modern, fuzzy-smooth fleece outerwear.
The Synchilla jacket had supposedly been tested for an entire globe-trotting year. The catalogue rhapsodized about the garment's grand tour with prose that Patagonia (and J. Peterman) copywriters have honed to the verge of self-parody: We took it on a 40-day kayaking trip to South America, used it all fall fly-fishing in Wyoming and Montana and then took it on a trip to Nepal -- where every day for 21 days we put on our jackets in the morning, wrapped them around our waists at midday and used them as pillows at night. We even washed them in a yak-watering bucket with cheap Chinese lye soap so strong it faded the freckles on our hands. Along with an itinerary, Synchilla came with a set of scientific-sounding attributes: the fleece was light (nine ounces per square yard), did not stretch out of shape and absorbed very little water. Soon Synchilla Snap-T's with Patagonia's horizontal Andean ridgeline logo on the left breast became a status symbol for outdoor types of all persuasions.
Backed by Yvon Chouinard's reputation for insisting on fanatical quality control and for possessing an exquisite, almost tortured corporate conscience, technical fleece was accepted as the real thing. For polyester, which had so ignominiously fallen from favor at the end of the preceding decade, being embraced by the environmental purists and gnarly role models who bought Patagonia was the beginning of a triumphant comeback.
In Lawrence, Mass., the executives at Malden Mills watched the spread of Synchilla with growing intentness. After all, Malden and Patagonia had collaborated on the design of Synchilla, and Malden manufactured Synchilla and virtually all of the high-end fleece being sold through outdoor specialty catalogues and stores across the country. The company also made "lots of crummy fleece," as one Malden executive admits now, but it began to see that its fortune lay not in remaining merely a faithful supplier to brands like Patagonia but also in establishing its own brand as the quality standard.
Malden Mills Industries, which is privately held, was founded in 1906 by Henry Feuerstein, an Orthodox Jew from Hungary who had won and lost a fortune in the New York City garment business before trying his luck in Massachusetts. Malden became a leading manufacturer of furniture upholstery, fake fur and commodity fleece for the bunting trade.
Under the founder's grandson, Aaron Feuerstein, the company had declined to abandon Lawrence when almost all of the fabric mills left in search of cheap nonunion labor in the South and abroad beginning in the 50's. But Malden had suffered a serious scare in 1981, when its overreliance on fake fur forced it to declare bankruptcy under Chapter 11 and reorganize its business. Through his alliance with Patagonia and other up-and-coming outdoor-equipment brands, Feuerstein saw a way to escape the capriciousness and low margins of the wholesale-commodity business. Malden would eventually pour more than $100 million of research-and-development funds into devising better and more kinds of synthetic fleece than anyone had ever dreamed of and would become to fleece what Levi Strauss was to denim.
After first establishing its fleece in the 80's under the brand name Polarfleece, among others, Malden relaunched its high-performance fabric as Polartec in early 1991. The new name explicitly echoed the notion of technical clothing, and its new mountain-range logo seemed to be a conscious homage to Patagonia's. Malden's ambitions had grown far beyond the idea of providing only insulation. It began manufacturing fleece suitable for every layer of clothing, from underwear, socks, hats and gloves to sweaters, jackets and pants, both as inner layers and outerwear. It added four-way stretch and laminated breathable windproof and water-resistant membranes inside its two-layer fleece.
The range of garments reflects Malden's obsessiveness about fleece, as do its patents and trade secrets. Close attention is paid to variations in the polyester filament yarns it uses: tenacity, lubricity and colorfastness are crucial characteristics. Next, in order for polyester to become fleece, its knit design must incorporate a surface covered with tiny loops. The truly cunning stage of making fleece is the final one -- the finishing -- in which thousands of tiny needles grab and pull out the loops before shearing trims the fleece to a velourlike smoothness or a peltlike pile. The resulting products range from lightweight next-to-the-skin fleece ($4.50 a yard wholesale) to warm-water wet suits ($25 a yard). Basic Polartec 200 midweight fleece wholesales for $7 to $8 a yard; the price will increase four times or more by the time the material reaches the consumer in a finished garment.
Taking another cue from Patagonia and its rivals, Malden has been fond of featuring trekking and adventure-travel archetypes in its Polartec advertising: Inuits, Himalayan yak herders and Scottish Highlands climbers. But the product's slogan, The Climate Control Fabric, was more essential to the company's purpose, which has been to spread the gospel of layering, moisture management and personal shelter beyond the inner circle of outdoor athletes to the mass of consumers. Remember the 80-20 rule, Tom Mendl, a product manager at Malden Mills, says. Eighty percent of the people who purchase premium outdoor clothing don't buy it for the use it was intended. They're out there walking the dog in cold weather, and that's it.
They're in a celebratory mood up at Malden Mills these days, and it's not just because they expect to sell $500 million worth of fleece and other fabrics this year. In more ways than one, the success of fleece has been a vindication for Aaron Feuerstein, the company's white-haired, 72-year-old C.E.O. It gave him the confidence to rebuild after a fire destroyed three buildings and 600,000 square feet of manufacturing space at Malden's Lawrence headquarters just before Christmas 1995, and it gave him the means to stand in front of his workers three days after the fire and tell them he was keeping them on the payroll and covering their health benefits while the rebuilding went forward. Everyone wept, including the television news crews. Utilizing equipment salvaged from the fire, some fleece production resumed within a week.
It was perhaps the closest thing to a real-world It's a Wonderful Life in the annals of American business, especially when people learned that Malden paid its workers -- a polyglot group representing 52 nationalities, including many first-generation Dominican and Puerto Rican immigrants -- a living wage far above the industry standard. Feuerstein became a national hero; he sat with President Clinton's family and heard himself extolled in the 1996 State of the Union speech. Last September, he dedicated a gleaming, airy new computerized fleece-manufacturing facility.
Feuerstein can recite yards of Shakespeare and Shelley as sonorously as he can praise his fleece. It's a fabulous fiber, almost miraculous, he declares. Very lightweight, comfortable and useful, exceptionally warm, and yet it has all the esthetics of the most expensive natural-fiber fabrics. Malden fleece comes in more than 100 styles, nearly 5,000 colors and 1,000 patterns. Feuerstein will tell you that the branding of Polartec has been so successful that even Patagonia and his old partner there, Yvon Chouinard, will begin using the Polartec label on new fabrics. (Although Malden and Patagonia continue to have a close, friendly relationship, it must be a little bittersweet for the Californians to acknowledge the ascendance of their formerly silent manufacturing partners, who are also suppliers to Patatgonia's competitors.) Nike has switched largely to Polartec for its outdoor fleece apparel.
Malden is targeting anyone who works and plays outdoors. Talks are under way with the U.S. military (the Green Berets are already using a very technical version of Polartec's Power Stretch line, and Polartec is standard-issue wear for American troops stationed in Bosnia), with the Postal Service and with utility companies around the country. The company is going after the golf-apparel business in a big way. And more and more, fleece is making its way to the indigenous people whose way of life contributed so much tribal mystique to fleece: Sherpa guides are well stocked with Polartec hats and sweaters; so are Indians in the Andes and natives in the Arctic regions.
Meanwhile, Malden's success has inspired counterfeiters to sew bogus Polartec labels into inferior fleece garments and to attach phony hang-tags. Nothing makes a Malden product manager sound more aggrieved than a discussion of the idea that cheap fleece -- which tends to mat, pill, shed and deteriorate prematurely -- can easily be confused with bombproof Polarfleece and Polartec. Consumer trust is particularly vital in the burgeoning children's market.
And, of course, Malden can still claim 90 percent of the market in its bedrock business of making technical clothing for outdoor sports. Malden makes most of the fleece that Marmot Mountain Ltd. in Santa Rosa, Calif., sells. Everyone wants something technical, but they also want to look old school, like the guides and mountain climbers in vintage photographs, reports Daniel Bohlman, a 23-year-old former professional mountain biker who works in customer service for Marmot. Fleece with a pile texture," he says, "has distinct technical advantages, but it's also part of the retro resurgence. And customers love fleece with embroidered ribbon work. If it looks remotely tribal or ethnic, it adds to the fleece. And I can try to sell them on the E.C.O. line of fleece" -- the acronym stands for Environmentally Correct Origins -- "made from recycled plastic soda bottles, but all they want is technical.
Real mountain climbers still wear fleece, even as the mortal risks they take become more routine and less sacramental. The gear and the clothing have become so sophisticated that if you employ good judgment, climbing is relatively safe, even though there's clearly always going to be objective danger up there, like a cornice falling on top of you, says Kim Gattone, a Santa Fe-based climber who wore lots of fleece on her way to the top of Tibet's 26,900-foot Cho Oyu last fall. But it just doesn't compare to what the old explorers went through. All you have to do is read about them and what they were using, and you say, 'Oh, my God.'
Fleece, then, is on the verge of taking over the entire world; Aaron Feuerstein's eyes light up when he talks about the potential of fleece catching on in China. The only question that remains, as Malden races toward a future in which it becomes a billion-dollar company and as everyone you know eventually turns up wrapped in a colorful, nappy cocoon, is this: What is to become of that precious, perishable nimbus of authenticity that still hovers around fleece?
Probably something akin to the dilution of meaning that has befallen other formerly potent fashion sheaths in the aftermath of relentless exposure -- coverings like denim for the counterculture, leather for various demimondes and even shamelessly unveiled human skin itself. Eventual obsolescence is the inescapable and melancholy fate of the authenticity that mass marketers have attached to fleece. To be sure, fleece is an ingenious and beneficial technological invention, but one day soon we'll recognize it as fake in every way and we'll be a little bit ashamed of what we once felt about it, if we think about it at all.

HEADLINE: Whatever Happened To Politics?

 BODY:
Your series "Whatever Happened to Politics?" (Jan. 25) addresses an important issue -- but not a new one. Two hundred years ago, the French intellectual Madame de Stael described her country in terms that apply equally well to the United States today. France, she wrote, was dominated by "a mass of complacent men concerned only with their personal affairs," desiring nothing but "material comfort and tranquillity." The French believed that "things will go better if the government does not act. Far from calling for its assistance, people regard it as an obstacle." 
 Indifference to politics was hardly a sign of national decline. After 1799, when de Stael wrote, France enjoyed more than a century of economic growth and artistic creativity. With luck, the apolitical United States will do equally well in the next hundred years.
 
Pepe Karmel
New York

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Reviving Long Beach Takes Another Step Forward

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

DATELINE: LONG BEACH

 BODY:
IN recent years, this seaside city once the playground of the wealthy, then a dumping ground for the elderly poor and the mentally ill -- has made a remarkable comeback.
Smart new high-rise oceanfront buildings like the Avalon Towers rental and the Sea Pointe Towers condominium have supplanted most of the single-room-occupancy rooming houses and the seedy nursing homes that had taken root here in the 60's and 70's. 
 Stores have a 95 percent occupancy rate, according to Stanley Fleishman, chairman of the local Chamber of Commerce, and boutiques are opening. And young families attracted by the Atlantic Ocean beaches and the 53-minute commute by train to Manhattan are moving here.
But city officials want more. They want Long Beach, which has three-and-a-half miles of ocean with a boardwalk, to have hotel, conference and catering facilities that can attract business and leisure visitors for extended stays.
"Long Beach is the only resort community without a hotel room, and the only waterfront community without a waterfront restaurant," said City Manager Edwin L. Eaton.
Two years ago, city officials placed a moratorium on development of several vacant oceanfront parcels along a three-block stretch extending from National to Long Beach Boulevards.
Then the city selected the largest parcel, 6.1 acres bounded by Riverside and Long Beach Boulevards and East Broadway and the boardwalk, as the site for hotel development. Under the plan, the city is to assemble the property, which has six separate owners, through condemnation if need be and turn it over to a developer. The developer must compensate the city for acquisition costs, including legal fees, and must build a hotel complex.
Earlier this month the City Council moved a step closer to that goal by selecting the Parkoff Organization of Great Neck as the developer. Parkoff has proposed a 218-room hotel with a spa, banquet and conference facilities, restaurants and stores and an open-air amphitheater.
Under the terms of the Feb. 3 Council resolution, Parkoff has six months to find the money to pay for the property and to find a hotel operator. It has an additional six months to find construction financing for the $50 million project.
The company is a real estate investment group that owns and manages apartment houses and retail space in New York City and on Long Island.
"We're tremendously excited because this development will become a magnet for those people who now come here to walk along the boardwalk and then get in their cars and go somewhere else," said Michael G. Zapson, the City Council president. "We also think this is a very low-density use of this site."
STILL unresolved is the price of the site, but A. Richard Parkoff, the president of the Great Neck company, said he was able to submit his proposal because in a condemnation "there are rules and laws as to how property is valued."
"We have done our due diligence and already anticipate what the value is going to be, so we're not working in the blind," he said.
The 6.1-acre property, dubbed a "superblock" because of its size, has 700 feet of frontage on the boardwalk. The city owns Shore Road, which crosses the property, but it will be demapped. The largest landowner is the Haberman Group of Manhattan, which controls 2.7 acres; under the zoning, it has the right to build two 10-story buildings, each with 110 apartments. In 1986, investors paid $6.7 million for the same parcel, but lost it through foreclosure. Haberman subsequently acquired the property for $1.2 million, according to city officials. Owners of the smaller parcels can only build one- and two-family houses.
Purchase prices will be negotiated based on appraisals, and any disputes will be settled in court. But a challenge to the city's power to condemn appears to be unlikely.
"The eminent domain law specifies that if there is a public purpose, the municipality can condemn," said Joel K. Asarch, the city's Corporation Counsel. And in a community without hotel accommodations and catering facilities, a hotel is a public purpose, he said. Jacob Haberman of the Haberman Group, who is a lawyer, agreed that the city would be within its rights.
The resolve to acquire the superblock and see it developed for a hotel complex grew out of three public hearings in 1995 and last year, which indicated most local residents preferred hotel development to more condominiums, Mr. Eaton said.
"People saw what we saw, that here was one of the last big oceanfront parcels, so let's make it the definitive Long Beach project rather than condominium towers that don't offer anything that we don't already have," he said.
But the city first commissioned a study to see if a hotel was feasible, he added, because "we didn't want to be part of a failure."
The study, prepared by the Mineola office of Hospitality Valuation Services International and completed a year ago, concluded that a hotel would be economically viable and last year the city issued a request for proposals.
The City Council chose the Parkoff Organization over the two other contenders, the Haberman Group and Nathan L. Serota & Sons of Valley Stream, because Parkoff gave the city more of the elements it wanted, including more restaurant facilities, a complete spa and a 400-seat amphitheater, Mr. Eaton said.
THE superblock has a long history. At one time it was the site of the Long Beach Hotel, built in 1880. The rambling 900-foot-long, 150-foot wide three-story structure burned down in 1907, the same year William H. Reynolds, a State Senator turned real estate entrepreneur, began selling house lots with the promise that Long Beach would become a French Riviera on the Atlantic Ocean.
For many years, the city was an elegant summer resort, attracting the well-to-do until jet travel to Europe and improved road access to the Hamptons drew vacationers away.
"We're going to build a nice hotel that will be a place where you can have a bar mitzvah or a wedding, where you have a spa, where you can stay for the weekend or for the summer and where we can bring in professional volleyball teams," said Mr. Parkoff. "I have concepts in my mind that will keep this hotel filled."
As now visualized, the complex, whose architect is Breger Terjesen Associates in Manhattan, will have a 10-story hotel with a 100-seat restaurant, with additional outdoor dining on terraces occupying the top floor.
The main lobby entrance on East Broadway will have a two-and-a-half story high atrium, with 15,000 square feet of retail space on the ground level, and 14,000 square feet of conference and office space on the upper level. A 40,000-square-foot banquet hall with seating for 600 will adjoin the lobby.
The hotel's other amenities will include a 30,000-square-foot, two-story spa with an indoor pool and an indoor volleyball court. An Olympic-size outdoor pool, which the lobby will overlook, will be flanked by additional shops. The hotel will also have three outdoor tennis courts that can be covered during the winter.
The lobby level will also have a two-story restaurant with seating for 250 not counting outdoor dining. Strollers on the boardwalk will have direct access to the hotel.
Some of the 218 hotel rooms will be equipped with kitchens, and can be combined to become two- and three-bedroom suites. All will have views of either the ocean or of Reynolds Channel which borders Long Beach on the north, and all will have balconies.
The buildings will be Art Deco in style, and in pastel colors, said James O. Bermel, the project architect.
Flanking the hotel will be an octagonal amphitheater suitable for outdoor concerts and other functions. Parkoff has also proposed a five-story, 100-unit residence with two- and three-bedroom apartments for people in their sixties and older who want hotel services, including meals. The entire hotel complex will have parking for 600 cars.
Although some elements of the plan can change -- for example, a multi-plex movie theater could replace the assisted living residence -- construction of the hotel, restaurants and catering facilities are not negotiable, Mr. Eaton said. Use restrictions will be incorporated in the deed Parkoff receives from the city.
Mr. Parkoff said he would be working with an investment banking firm to put the construction financing together.
Once the financing is in place, a builder will be selected. "I am not a builder, but neither is Donald Trump," Mr. Parkoff noted. "I am the creator of the project and I will orchestrate the necessary parts to bring this about."

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1547 words

HEADLINE: For a Growing Region, a 'Nassau Hub'

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
A NAME not yet coined may one day describe the 2.9 square miles of central Nassau County that planners and government officials call the Nassau Hub.
The name would designate a hybrid place that was neither urban nor traditionally suburban, but rather an integrated yet decentralized low to midrise supercenter of stores, offices, industries, museums, campuses, government offices, stadiums and theaters, laced with green spaces and abundant parking. 
 It would be a city that was not a city, a "there" in a wealthy suburban county that lacks a core and hungers for a stronger identity and an attraction to draw people from Nassau and beyond.
For such a place to exist, the planners and many officials agree, a major new transit system, financed with hundreds of millions of Federal dollars and supported by local subsidies, would have to relieve severe congestion and move people from point to point.
Sounding a warning heard for years, the planners and officials said that unless the traffic problems were solved soon the hub would sprawl out of control and strangle, a victim of its successes and broken spokes.
The latest attempt to address the problem is a $200,000 six-month study paid by the county and the Town of Hempstead. The Long Island Regional Planning Board, the Nassau County Planning Department, the Regional Plan Association and the Laboratory for Urban and Suburban Studies at the New York Institute of Technology carried out the work.
Without choosing a favorite, the study offers three alternatives. They are an elevated "people mover," larger elevated trolleylike cars that run on tires and a ground-level light-rail system with elevated sections over roadways and a connection to the Long Island Rail Road.
The study also looks at additional bus service as an immediate way to reduce congestion. The existing bus services are underused, suffer from congestion and run at a deficit, requiring multimillion-dollar subsidies from the county.
The hub, the largest employment and shopping area on Long Island, includes the former Mitchel Field, Roosevelt Field, the former Roosevelt Raceway and surrounding areas. The Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum, the Roosevelt Field mall, other major stores, office complexes, warehouses and Hofstra University and Nassau County Community College are in the zone. The executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, Lee E. Koppelman, said Federal support would be needed for the transit options.
"Mass transit at the hub has now become essential," Mr. Koppelman said. "Just with the documented growth that could take place, the existing job base in the hub of 44,000 will increase to 60,000. With that kind of increase there will be a lot more traffic."
County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, who has called the proper development of the hub "the linchpin of Nassau County's future economic vitality and identity," has proposed building a sports complex near the coliseum for the Islanders and other franchises, to be ready in 2001.
Mr. Gulotta is also proposing additional hotel rooms, converting the coliseum to a convention center and developing a museum area that would include the Cradle of Aviation Museum. That plan would draw even more traffic. A redevelopment of the former raceway also adds to the glut.
The executive director of the Regional Plan Association, Robert D. Yaro, said the projected development in the hub was crucially important.
"The place is strangling in traffic already, and there is four million feet of commercial space already out the door and permitted," Mr. Yaro said. "This study suggests the benefits if that four million square feet is organized differently."
Scattered "single-use destinations surrounded by a sea of parking" would make any transit system ineffective, Mr. Yaro said. What is needed, he suggested, were mixed-use centers where transit stations were close to entrances and convenient to multiple destinations.
The study is candid about the intractable nature of the traffic problems, saying: "It must be stressed that mass transit solutions will help reduce existing automobile congestion. But since the additional growth anticipated in the hub will inescapably generate more overall movements to, from and within the hub area automobile usage will continue to grow."
"The vast oceans of parking lots at Roosevelt Field is one of the principal resources of the hub," Mr. Yaro said.
The Meadowbrook State Parkway is the lone limited-access road with exits to the hub area. Hempstead Turnpike, Stewart Avenue and Old Country Road, all east-west thoroughfares, are heavily used and frequently congested.
"You've got to do something, and it's very clear there just isn't any potential for widening parkways," Mr. Yaro said. "Everything that can be done to the roads has been done. So you have to get creative."
Mr. Yaro said a transit system that provided even marginal reductions in car trips to or within the hub would significantly lessen traffic. "The difference between highway gridlock and free-moving traffic is the last 5 to 8 percent of cars," he said.
Any effort to control development in the hub to create mixed-use centers would require extraordinary cooperation among developers, prospective tenants and government officials. Most of the area is in Hempstead.
Mr. Yaro said that would be a challenge, but "a lot less of a challenge than fixing the congestion in this area if it keeps building out the way it has."
"What we have now is a whole that is less than the sum of its parts," he said. "The idea is to reverse that. It's absolutely essential for the economy of Nassau County and Long Island that we get this right."
What happens at the hub, he added, could become a model for development in Hauppauge and Melville, two future hubs, and for other parts of the country.
Light-rail connections from the L.I.R.R., possibly from a new station, would require support from the rail line and its parent, and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
Seventeen light-rail systems operate in the United States. Proposed extensions and new systems in 29 cities would add 800 miles of light-rail track in the next several years.
Last week the Government approved using money from a passenger ticket tax to build a light-rail link from the L.I.R.R. at Jamaica Station to Kennedy International Airport. The $1.5 billion project would be partly financed by the $3 Passenger Facility Charge that is added to tickets for flights at Kennedy.
The Nassau study does not have proposals for taxes or fees to finance the transit systems. It estimates costs that range up to hundreds of million dollars for plans like full and partial loops through the hub.
The death this month of State Senator Norman J. Levy of Merrick, the influential chairman of the Senate Transportation Committee, means the loss of a forceful promoter of suburban mass transportation in Albany.
In addition to light-rail, the study also outlines options that would accommodate greater sprawl and address the deep-seated reluctance of drivers to abandon their cars.
"Our assumption is that people are not going to mend their ways," said Paul Koch, co-director of the Laboratory for Urban and Suburban Studies at the New York Institute of Technology. "Developers are going to keep on developing in the way they are used to."
To overcome resistance to mass transit and the problem delivering passengers to widely separated hub locations, Mr. Koch said, a people mover that is in use in one of the suburbs of Chicago held promise.
"A people mover can get into tight areas, it can go all around the place," Mr. Koch said. "Our concept is that you have a very small unobtrusive system that can duplicate a lot of the perceived advantages of the automobile."
Such people movers have automated electric cars that seat four passengers. They run on rubber tires along elevated pathways. A central computer route cars to selected destinations. Cars would run separately, not in trains.
The system, called Personal Rapid Transit, or PRT, tries to duplicate automobile travel. Passengers would never have to ride with strangers. They would control their destinations, and there are no schedules.
"There are a lot of cars waiting at the station," Mr. Koch said. "One is waiting for you, and when you get in it knows your destination."
The third option, the elevated trolleylike car on rubber tires, would be propelled by a set of wheels in the runway that would contact a fin extending from the car. Mr. Koch said rubber tires were a preferred over rails because they were quieter.
Some people have suggested that drivers in the hub had to accept that the time they spent in traffic was part of any hub visit, just as they would accept delays in going to a large amusement park or sports stadium.
The co-director of the laboratory, Michele Bertomen, has suggested that if drivers adjusted to congestion and delays in areas like the hub, that would have humanizing aspects.
"We forget that often a slower life is a more civilized one," Ms. Bertomen wrote in an article in Newsday. "In a time when road rage makes national headlines, it may be psychologically necessary to catch a glimpse of a car, with an identifiable person inside, once or twice a day."
