SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 4; Column 4; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1063 words

HEADLINE: When Households Included Slaves

BYLINE: By NANCY NEWILL DONIGER 

 BODY:
AT a time when the White House is urging Americans to engage in a candid conversation on race relations, and the General Assembly in Hartford has enacted legislation requiring school districts to report annually on their efforts to reduce racial, ethnic and economic isolation, Connecticut educators say the dialogue is already well underway.
"The dialogue is going on. I meet people in the state who are genuinely interested in the issue," said Daniel Cruson, the town historian in Newtown and a history teacher at Joel Barlow High School in Redding who has written a book about slavery in rural Connecticut. Surprisingly, he said, many people were unaware that slavery existed in Connecticut. 
 Gwen Parks, a chairwoman of the Newtown High School History Department, said she sees the release of Steven Spielberg's film, "Amistad," about the 1839 mutiny of Africans aboard a ship of that name, the ensuing trial in New Haven and an 1841 Supreme Court ruling that the Africans were free men, as a powerful catalyst for increased interest in black history.
Historical societies, libraries, schools and universities across the state are giving workshops on the Amistad and other intriguing facets of black history, Ms. Parks said.
Gloria Williams, who teaches a graduate course in cultural diversity at the University of New Haven, said that while she was born and raised in the New Haven area, she had never heard of the Amistad case while she was growing up.
"I feel cheated," she said. "There are so many things that happened right here in Connecticut I never heard about." Ms. Williams said she would now like to see the heightened interest in black history lead to greater communications among people of other ethnic groups.
Jackee Bryant, a self-described history buff and chairman of an annual African-American Day parade in Hartford since 1994, said: "With all the years the Amistad story has existed, it amazes me that people are just now becoming aware of it."
Mr. Cruson attributes the general lack of awareness that slavery existed in Connecticut to the low number of slaves in the state. Slaveholding households in the state typically had only one or two. Little record of their lives remains outside emancipation documents and some records of births, deaths, marriages and church membership.
"From the 1780's, state residents came to realize that slavery was not right," Mr. Cruson said. The majority of slaves in the state were emancipated between 1780 and 1813, following the Revolutionary War. Legislative efforts to abolish slavery began in 1784. In 1790 the first year a national census was taken, Connecticut slaves numbered 2,759, and the free black population stood at 2,801. The number of slaves declined to 310 by 1810, 97 by 1820 and just 17 by 1840.
Laws were intended to ease the institution of slavery out of existence, without violating the property rights of owners or resulting in freed blacks becoming a burden on the towns.
Some of the freed blacks acquired houses and property, although their net worth was a fraction of that of their white neighbors, based on probate records studied by Mr. Cruson. Their low numbers, and the disapproval associated with inter-racial marriage, resulted in isolation and population decline of blacks in rural areas, which persists to the present day, he said.
Free blacks tended to move to the cities in search of social and economic opportunities. Blacks from the South also migrated to the cities, planting the roots of urban isolation that forms the basis of the recent Sheff v. O'Neill lawsuit, he noted.
That complaint by 17 Hartford-area school children alleges this isolation has resulted in their being denied access to the equal education guaranteed under the state constitution. In its defense, the state argued that the segregation was not intentional, but the state Supreme Court last year ordered the legislature to enact an integration plan, without specifying the details or appropriating funds.
Gov. John G. Rowland appointed a diversity panel that made a slate of recommendations, including public funding for early school education and the formation of more charter schools.
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Mr. Rowland's predecessor, had ordered each of Connecticut's 169 municipalities to form a diversity committee and develop voluntary proposals to reduce racial isolation. While the voluntary plans were accepted by the state's cities, they were defeated by the majority of towns.
Ms. Williams and Ms. Parks would like to see the voluntary proposals, which include recommendations to build more magnet schools, encourage cooperative programs between the cities and suburbs, and recruit more African-American teachers in suburban schools, taken down from the shelf, dusted off and given renewed consideration.
Gloria Rodriguez is assistant principal in charge of English and history at Wilbur Cross High School in New Haven, the school with what may be the most ethnically and economically diverse population in the state. The school offers black history, a Latino Caribbean course and "literature outside the canon" of traditional high schools, Ms. Rodriguez said.
She, too, would like to see more urban and suburban exchanges and dialogue. "It's really important for people to come together and talk about problems and solutions," she said.
Ms. Parks is the principal writer of a resource guide on African-American history by the state's Department of Education in accordance with legislation making African-American, Puerto Rican and Native American history as well as the great famine in Ireland part of the core curriculum taught in Connecticut public schools.
Members of Delta Sigma Theta, an international African-American sorority, hope to make the guide readily accessible for teachers of every grade level, Ms. Parks said.
The General Assembly in 1995 authorized the development of what is being called a freedom trail, with more than 60 historical sites including several in Farmington, considered the Grand Central Terminal of the Underground Railroad in Connecticut.
The Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation has released an educational poster of historic sites in the settlement of African-Americans in Connecticut, for use in grades 4 to 12, illustrating how historical research can be presented to students in an engaging format.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:

Airport Lounge Vetoed
Last week, the new County Executive, Andrew J. Spano, scrapped the previous administration's plans to build a lounge for business executives at the County Airport. In a press conference at the airport on Monday, Mr. Spano, a Democrat who took office on Jan. 1 after a 14-year reign by Republicans, called former County Andrew P. O'Rourke's plans for the lounge "a stealth expansion" of the airport. 
 The 900-square-foot lounge, proposed during the final days of the O'Rourke administration, would have cost about $413,000. Mr. Spano said that even though the contracts awarded by the Board of Acquisition and Contract will be rescinded, companies will be compensated for losses or work undertaken.
Mr. Spano said the move signals "a new era in positive neighborhood airport relations." He said he did not want to expand the terminal "at the expense of the quality of life of our residents, which is our biggest economic-development asset."
 
Legislators' Ratings
With Democrats in the United States House of Representatives scoring significantly higher than Republicans on their environmental record, Sue W. Kelly, who represents the 19th District in Westchester, was a standout among Republicans in ratings issued recently by the League of Conservation Voters.
The league, a political arm of a national environmental coalition, gave Ms. Kelly a score of 81 out of a possible 100 points for her record in 1987, compared with a score of 58 during the 104th Congress the year before.
The organization rated her among the most improved members of the House of Representatives. She received pluses in 13 of 16 categories.
By contrast, the score for Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat representing the 18th Congressional District in Westchester, dropped in 1987 to 88, compared with a 96 the year before. She lost points for being absent during a vote on wildlife refuges and for voting for a radioactive waste disposal site in Texas, the league said. She received 14 pluses.
Representative Eliot L. Engel, a Democrat from the 17th District, received an 81 in 1987, compared with a 96 for the 104th Congress. He lost points last year for several votes the league considered anti-environmental, including two in favor of nuclear waste dumps. He received 13 pluses and 3 minus points.
Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, a Republican from the 20th District, received a 75, up from a 65 for the 104th Congress. While his record showed concern for endangered species, for example, he lost points for voting for a bill that benefits ranching interests at the expense of fish, wildlife and water resources. He received 12 pluses.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican, received a score of 29, in part for positions considered anti-environmental by the league, on a rider to a bill that would have allowed states to build roads across national parks and another that would have provided subsidies to mining companies. He received pluses in two of seven categories applied to Senators. Mr. D'Amato's score was an improvement over the year before, when he received a total score of 4.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat, received an 86, slightly down from the 10th Congress when he got an 89. Mr. Moynihan also favored the hard-rock mining subsidies, presented in an amendment that was eventually killed. He received six pluses.
 
Thruway Crackdown
The State Police's Operation Share, a joint effort by Federal, state and local agencies to catch speeders and other traffic offenders on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, was a resounding success, according to a recently released report. (The acronym Share stands for Statewide Highway Aggressive Regional Enforcement.)
On Jan. 28, about 50 members of the state police collaborated with officers from the following agencies: the United States Transportation Department, the United States Customs Service, the United States Department of the Interior, Fish and Wildlife, the state's Department of Motor Vehicles, the County District Attorney's Office, police officers from Yonkers, New Rochelle and Mount Vernon and others.
Authorities issued more than 500 summonses along the Thruway during a 10-hour period.
As a result, 33 trucks were taken out of service, 23 of which were towed off of the Thruway because their violations were considered severe, David Hebert, a spokesman in the District Attorney's Office, said.
A tractor-trailer operator who was hauling dry goods was arrested for driving while intoxicated near Yonkers, after his blood alcohol level was found to be in excess of three times the threshold of intoxication for commercial vehicle drivers, the District Attorney's office said.
Also, a 34-year-old man and a 24-year-old woman were arrested for criminal possession of a controlled substance after the police said they found 21 grams of crack cocaine on the pair.
 
Economic Development
The Westchester Partnership for Economic Development, a public-private coalition, has begun the Westchester Cities Initiative to assist urban centers.
Five of the county's six cities -- Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, Peekskill, White Plains and Yonkers -- were once all hubs of economic activity.
The new effort will attempt to help them regain some of their former status (Rye is the sixth city).
"In recent years, some of the focus of economic growth has shifted away from these established areas, which is not good for the cities themselves and which also hurts the county," William M. Mooney, the partnership's chairman, said.
Paradoxically, economic growth has shifted to the suburbs, where officials and residents often fight to keep development at bay.
"From a community planning perspective, it makes total sense to have the major economic development initiatives go to the locations that both want them and that have the infrastructure to support them," Mr. Mooney said.
The partnership's cities team includes the following members: Joe Armentano, chairman and chief executive officer of Patsems/Paraco Gas Corporation; Neil DeLuca, former Deputy County Executive; Lawrence Dwyer, president of the Westchester County Association; Robert W. Elliot, Mayor of Croton-on-Hudson and chairman of the Westchester Municipal Officials Association; Margaret Gotti, Pace University's vice president of government and community relations; Joyce Lannert, Planning Commissioner; Robert M. Maccarone, Deputy Commissioner of Corrections, and Peter Puccillo, Finance Commissioner. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: In Suburbia, Unexpected Neighbors

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
RESIDENTS of several upscale New York suburbs have acquired neighbors in recent years that many never expected -- large rental apartment buildings.
A number of suburbs that had vigorously resisted multifamily housing for decades -- towns known in the apartment development industry as "high-barrier-to-entry communities," zoned to protect land from unwelcome development -- are now or are soon to be the sites of apartment complexes with hundreds of rental units. And almost all the units are the work of one deep-pocketed development company, Avalon Properties, whose only business is building luxury apartments for rent. 
 New Canaan in Fairfield County and Bronxville in Westchester County are two such communities in which rental developments are now being prepared by Avalon, a five-year-old company based in Wilton, Conn.
Since 1993 Avalon has built 15 complexes containing from 102 to 932 apartments each in Fairfield and Westchester, on Long Island and in New Jersey -- and it is developing 20 additional complexes in the same areas with the potential for a total of 6,022 units.
Its success has been won at a cost of millions of dollars spent on legal battles with communities that want no part of multifamily housing, no matter how luxurious.
The company is viewed by many local ad hoc groups as a tiger at the gate, bent on destroying their way of life by bringing what they perceive as rootless transients into their tranquil single-family, large-lot, residential neighborhoods.
Such groups become particularly agitated when a designated percentage of the apartments is reserved for lower-income tenants, in accordance with laws in several states that give developers greater density in return for providing units below market rates.
The 1989 Affordable Housing Law in Connecticut allows developers extra units in return for setting aside 25 percent of a project at lower rents. Municipalities seeking to reject these projects must prove in court that they will be injurious to the town's welfare. So far, none has.
Lawsuits brought by Avalon against the Fairfield County towns of Trumbull and New Canaan resulted in four and six years, respectively, of litigation, compromises and eventual victory for the developer.
"It wasn't the project itself or Avalon that we objected to," said Kenneth Halaby, a former chairman of Trumbull's Planning and Zoning Commission. "The complex is a fine addition to the town, beautifully built and very upscale. What we resented was the state telling us how many affordable housing units we must have and where. We have our own master plan to provide for this, and we have to be careful because Trumbull is fully developed."
New Canaan tried to take an Avalon site by condemnation, defying court rulings against its efforts to reject the developer's 104-unit project. Eventually, the town and developer swapped sites and Avalon is now going through the approval process.
"Friction will continue when developers go into more rural communities," said Richard Bond, New Canaan's First Selectman, or chief executive, "but people do have to break out of a box of conventional thinking to make things work for all parties involved. That's what we tried to do."
In Wilton, another affluent Fairfield County community, "they said these apartments are needed for residents to retire to and young people to start out," said Richard L. Michaux, 54, Avalon's chairman of the board and chief executive. But Wilton stiffened its regulations after the 102-unit Avalon Springs complex was built. The town now requires a public hearing solely for site plans in cases where properties like Avalon's are zoned for multifamily development.
Other developers find it difficult to match Avalon's product in size, quality, amenities and service, in part because "it's very difficult to compete with their ability to amass capital," said Clay Fowler, principal of the Spinnaker Companies in Stamford. The company owns and manages 1,300 luxury apartments in Fairfield County, with 400 more for Norwalk and White Plains in the design stage. "They clearly have a predominant position and an insatiable appetite for new projects," said Mr. Fowler.
His Stamford complex, called The Fairfield, has 263 units with a pool, lounge, fitness center, and barbecue area. He is building rentals in Portland, Ore., and Seattle in partnership with Carl Kuehner, a Wilton builder of luxury homes. Mr. Kuehner, who sold a Danbury parcel to Avalon, said Avalon was "better at managing these products than we are, and have a much larger portfolio than we will ever choose to have."
In order to acquire a site in Bronxville, Avalon formed a partnership with Arthur Collins, a developer of high-end residential condominiums in Connecticut, New Jersey, New York and the South. Mr. Collins had entree to the town, which he described as "very hard to deal with in terms of approvals."
"We had the right project at the right time," he said, "and were the right people to do it."
Avalon is obtaining access to land and towns through other builders "because they can't acquire land fast enough to meet their need to use capital," said Mr. Fowler.
Ross Cassata, builder of 3,200 Long Island rentals over 37 years, views Avalon as "one of our main competitors."
"Lately we are refocusing on luxury garden apartments with similar amenities," he said. "Being a public company they have deeper pockets and work on a slim profit margin of 7 or 8 percent, beating us out of some properties."
But Bryce Blair, 40, senior vice president for development and acquisition at Avalon, said his company's profits were 10 to 13 percent.
PROFITS derived from standardized designs and bulk purchasing are supplemented through such details as "gas heating and cooking because what people save on utility bills they can spend on rent," said Samuel B. Fuller, 36, Avalon's Northeast regional vice president of development and acquisitions.
Lately, Avalon has been entering communities closer to New York and other major cities.
"We're being invited in by the New Rochelles of the world," said Mr. Michaux, Avalon's chief executive, "to help revitalize their downtowns with housing. That's something we're seeing more and more of." New Rochelle accepted Avalon's proposal to build a 1,000-apartment complex and ground-floor shops in four buildings near the railroad station.
Michael Barry, vice president of The Applied Companies of Hoboken, a builder of rental apartments in New Jersey for 30 years, said that "Avalon is developing in some of our areas."
"We're just a few blocks from each other in Jersey City, but we view it as friendly competition," said Mr. Barry. "The more development and investment in an area the better it is for everybody."
On Jersey City's riverfront, Avalon is building its first high-rise, a 26-story complex called Avalon Cove South, next door to its mid-rise Avalon Cove, where rents reach $4,000 a month.
A competitor, Roseland Properties of Roseland, N.J., has approvals for 4,360 units over the next decade at Port Imperial in West New York, N.J. "We will have one-, two- and three-bedroom luxury apartments in several mid- and high-rise buildings, with pools, business centers and health clubs," said Carl Goldberg, principal in the firm. Roseland owns 3,500 units around the state and manages 6,000 more. "We completed a second Port Towers in Jersey City close to the Avalon project," he said.
"Avalon Cove is the highest end of the luxury rental market," said Thomas M. Gallagher, director of Jersey City's Department of Housing, Economic Development and Commerce. "Their units are a little larger and they provide a high level of amenities on site. Residents at that income level are willing to pay a premium for that."
"I think other developers have responded," he continued, "and tried to offer more. The Hudson County waterfront is very competitive, and when anyone is willing to test the outer limits of the market and been successful, as Avalon has, you'll see other developers follow."
Mr. Michaux said Avalon had embraced the policy of "smart growth," typically in Stamford, where the company has built its 402-unit Avalon Grove complex near the Stamford Town Center, theaters and restaurants.
"We think there's a better way to enjoy a community environment, where you can walk to work, retail, nightlife, and not have to get in the car to do all your errands."
The term "smart growth" was originated by the Urban Land Institute in Washington a nonprofit educational organization advocating high-density housing in suburban sprawl areas, situated near public transportation and utilizing existing infrastructure.
Some academicians who study the residential construction industry agree with the concept for additional reasons. "Avalon is onto something," said Catherine Pancak, professor of real estate at the University of Connecticut at Storrs. "The state has been underserved by well-built, high-quality rental apartment complexes, so there is a strong demand. Historically we've had high house prices, making ownership less attractive as an option, and that will continue."
Dr. James W. Hughes, professor of planning and public policy at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., acknowledges the demand but recognizes the reasons behind local opposition. "Larger apartments with school-age children produce a net loss to a town," he said. "Communities with limited or no public sewers and water are afraid of having to extend or build them, setting up a model for greater density and the loss of rural character. And in more developed suburbs, the sites being built on are the last greenfields around. A lot of residents want to see them remain that way."
THE only community to date from which Avalon withdrew because of local antipathy and land acquisition problems is Rye Brook, a Westchester enclave of upper income residents that incorporated in 1982, separating itself from the largely working-class Village of Port Chester.
Rejection of multifamily projects is more prevalent in the Northeast than in the Mid-Atlantic region and the South, where garden apartments originated. "Opposition," said Charles H. Berman, 44, president and chief operating officer of Avalon, "comes from what is increasingly referred to in the industry as CAVE, Citizens Against Virtually Everything. It doesn't matter whether it's a new golf course, road, school improvement, or public amenity. Depending on the leadership in a town, a community can be paralyzed to a point that change doesn't occur. That makes some people happy, but I'm not sure it's the majority; it's just the most vocal."
Avalon was organized in 1993 as a real estate investment trust and named after the legendary resting place of King Arthur. Currently capitalized at $2.1 billion, it operates from offices in Alexandria and Richmond, Va.; Braintree, Mass.; Princeton, N.J.; Chicago and Minneapolis, as well as Wilton.
But its genesis goes back to the 80's, when Mr. Berman and Mr. Michaux were regional partners of Trammell Crow, then the largest rental housing developer in the country. Mr. Berman headed the Northeast division, Mr. Michaux was in charge of the Mid-Atlantic region. Given the tortuous process of borrowing what little money was available from insurance companies and pension funds in the early 90's, the two men decided to go public with their own company when Trammell Crow chose to remain private. An amicable arrangement was reached whereby the partners bought out the two divisions that they headed with proceeds from the sale of stock, acquiring 8,500 apartments from Boston to Virginia.
Last month Avalon bought 60 percent of Trammell Crow's Midwest assets for $196 million. Last year Trammell Crow sold off half of its $3 billion in real estate assets to various REITs. The Avalon partners are now larger than their former parent.
"We sold because it's a great year to be a seller," said Ronald Terwilliger, national managing partner of Trammell Crow Residential in Atlanta. "We've watched this REIT phenomenon grow. It looks like it's here to stay, but I enjoy being private. In terms of wealth creation it's a better place to be."
Avalon is currently the largest residential landlord in Connecticut and arguably the sixth largest developer and manager of luxury rental housing in the country, with 19,724 luxury apartments in 66 complexes in 12 states and the District of Columbia. Its stock, a substantial amount of which is owned by the Crow family, rose from the initial public offering of $20.50 to $29.25 at the close last Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange.
Typically, Avalon builds generic low-rise garden complexes designed by Niles Bolton Associates of Atlanta. Units are arranged around landscaped courtyards, or, in more urban areas, contained in mid-rise and high-rise structures, presenting an exterior that is architecturally harmonious with its surroundings.
They are larded with amenities that include pools, indoor basketball and squash courts, clubhouses with kitchens for parties, fitness and computer centers, children's playgrounds, an in-house service staff, and a concierge who will arrange for dry-cleaning and car rental, accept packages, walk the dog and feed the cat.
RENTS range from $1,000 to $4,000 a month depending on location, size and amenities, and dissatisfied tenants are hard to find, perhaps because the management allows them to break their leases, retrieve their security deposits and move out, as long as they do it within the first 30 days of the lease. Occupancy rates average 95.6 percent and tenant turnover is around 50 percent a year.
Last year Britton and Poonam Manasco and their 21-month-old son moved from California to a two-bedroom apartment at Avalon Grove in downtown Stamford. Growing up in Hong Kong and having lived in New York, Mrs. Manasco likes urban life. "We plan to stay a year, but if something bigger comes up we may take it," she said. "The management is so nice. They helped me start a children's play group."
Miguel and Monica Mancevo live at the 504-unit Avalon Cove in Jersey City. "It's only a 20-minute drive to my office on East 40th Street," said Mr. Mancevo, "and when I come home late at night I feel safe, comfortable." Their 11-year-old son, Mark, "loves the pool and the basketball court," Mr. Mancevo said. "He never wants to move."
Looking to the future, said Mr. Michaux, Avalon's chief executive, "we would be comfortable with capitalization of $4 billion or $5 billion by 2002. Over the five years we've been public we have created a product prototype that works, and a strong balance sheet. We feel we can export this to high-barrier-to-entry markets and downtown locations in the West. Over time we will get into New York City and Chicago, but for now we like to feel around the edges."

HEADLINE: The View From/Hartford;
A Revival for Housing, Downtown, of All Places

BYLINE: By R. L. FELSON 

 BODY:
SCULPTORS, painters, musicians, dancers -- in short, artists of all kinds -- are moving into a long-vacant building on the western edge of downtown Hartford that city and state officials, developers and business leaders are hailing as the first step in years to create new housing in the center of the city.
The building, at 555 Asylum Street, known as Artspace, is also being touted as a small step in what many city and business leaders say is the beginning of a resurgence of downtown development in a city that has seen virtually none since the late 1980's. The 46-unit, four-story building, a former office furniture store and before that, an auto dealership in the 1920's and 1930's, offers low- and moderate-income artists living and working space in one-, two- and three-bedroom apartments. "For the city of Hartford, it not only gives the city some refreshing color, but downtown just badly needs housing to spur retail and other services," said Don Walsh, vice president of Imagineers, the management company of Artspace. More than one third of the units have been rented since the building opened in January. 
 Mr. Walsh said he believed Artspace, a $6 million renovation project, would inspire other developers to either recycle vacant downtown space or begin looking at new housing projects downtown, which often feels deserted after business hours.
The idea for Artspace came to Peter DeWilde Shapiro, a Hartford lawyer and one of three developers of the project, from his daughter, Kerith Shapiro, a performing artist who was living in a complex for artists in St. Paul, Minn. "St. Paul was dead downtown and had a lot of the same problems as Hartford," said Ms. Shapiro, who now lives at Artspace as the resident manager. The St. Paul development helped contribute to that city's downtown revitalization, and Ms. Shaprio, who grew up in West Hartford, said, "I really hope this leads to major changes in Hartford."
Marc S. Levine, a partner in Artspace and a Hartford developer and lawyer, said the project probably would not have been undertaken had it not received tax credits and other grants from the city and state. Mayor Michael Peters was able to get the developers a meeting with Gov. John G. Rowland's office. Mr. Rowland has been an advocate of using the arts to spur economic development in Connecticut's cities.
Mr. Levine, who was approached by Mr. Shapiro and the other partner in the venture, Elie R. Pallandre, president of a real estate consulting firm in West Hartford that bears his name, said the development could have been a low-income housing project.
But, Mr. Levine said, "That's not really what Hartford needs. We must have an increase in people living in the central city for revitalization to be successful and it has to be a mixed income strata, including middle and upper classes." Under Federal and state guidelines, those renting the units must earn 60 percent or less of the region's median household income -- $24,720 for one person; $28,260 for two people, and $35,340 for a family for four. Units rent for about $590 for one bedroom, $720 for two bedrooms and $830 for three bedrooms.
The apartments, designed by Tai Soo Kim Partners, a Hartford architectural firm, feature 10-feet-high windows, 14-foot ceilings and spectacular views of the downtown skyline, the State Capitol, Bushnell Park and Union Station, across the street.
Scott Spencer, who lived with Ms. Shapiro in St. Paul, and will co-manage Artspace with her, said the variety of tenants moving in amounts to "a complete panorama of diversity" in terms of ethnicity, age and artistic endeavors. Mr. Spencer, a musician and sculptor, said tenants include other sculptors, painters, musicians, poets, writers, carpenters, dancers and poets. "There are people who survive on painting to costume designers," he said. New residents have come from as far away as New York City and Massachusetts.
Galley kitchens were designed to give residents as much studio space as possible. A ground floor community room features residents' artwork and photography, and it is expected that other residents will use the room as performance space. The room was the site of a grand opening party Jan. 5, at which local and state political and business leaders, including Governor Rowland, attended.
Arthur Anderson, president of Imagineers, the Artspace management company, said that in looking at the party guests, including many from the city's arts community, he was reminded of the parties held downtown 10 years ago in the midst of a downtown building boom. "This symbolizes a demand that people deny exists," he said. "People want to live downtown and they want to feel the vitality."
One incentive to encourage the new residents to stay downtown is that after 15 years, tenants will be invited to buy their units and form a co-op. Mr. Shapiro, one of the partners, said he remembers what a residential community downtown can do to the vitality of a city. He himself used to live in the Goodwin building on Asylum Street before it was converted into an office building and luxury hotel in the 1980's.

HEADLINE: HOME REPAIR;
Spray Painting Safely

BYLINE: By EDWARD R. LIPINSKI

 BODY:
A BRUSH and a roller are sufficient for painting most projects, but for jobs that are large or have intricate surface detail, it's easier to spray the paint onto the work surface. Spray painting is less tedious than brush painting and generally gives a smoother, uniform paint surface.
There are disadvantages to spray painting however; it is not economical and in fact can be downright wasteful. That's because only a fraction of the paint is actually deposited on the work surface. The rest is distributed as airborne particles called overspray. Depending on the spray setup, it is possible for as much as 75 percent of the paint to be lost in overspray. 
 There are two types of sprayer units, air-powered units and airless ones. Air-powered units can be costly because they require an air gun and a compressor unit. (Prices will vary depending upon the size of the compressor, but a basic unit will cost around $200.) Air-powered sprayers allow you to spray a variety of finishes and are a better choice for fine work. Airless sprayers are considerably cheaper than the air units, but they produce sprays with large, heavy paint particles, so they are not good for laying down a really smooth finish.
Air-powered units work by blowing a stream of compressed air at high pressure through the nozzle of the gun. The paint is forced up into the air stream, where it is atomized into a fine mist that is deposited on the work surface. There are two types of air-driven guns: siphon feed and pressure feed.
In siphon-feed guns, the compressed air creates a partial vacuum as it passes though the paint tube near the gun nozzle. Outside air pressure enters the paint cup (the metal can that screws onto the nozzle unit) through a small inlet hole and forces the paint up to fill the vacuum. It is then forced out through the nozzle by the compressed air. Siphon-feed guns are ideal for blowing out lightweight paints and finishes, and therefore they are a good choice for extra-fine work. But they can only draw paint from the attached paint cup, so the user is forced to periodically stop painting and refill the cup when painting large projects.
Pressure-feed guns do not create a vacuum; instead, they channel some of the compressed air directly into the paint reservoir. The increased air pressure forces the paint up into the nozzle where it is propelled out as a mist. These guns create high internal air pressure, so they can be hooked up to a remote pressure tank, making it unnecessary to stop painting to refill the paint cup. They can also handle heavier paints, so they are a better choice for big outdoor jobs.
Spray guns are also classified as bleeder or non-bleeder types. Bleeder guns pass air through the nozzle as long as the compressor is running; only the paint flow can be turned on or off. This type of gun is designed for use with a compressor that does not have an air reservoir. The non-bleeder guns can stop the flow of air with the trigger control and are designed for use with a compressor equipped with a storage tank.
Airless sprayers have an electric motor that drives an internal piston back and forth in the gun. As the piston is pulled back, suction is created and pulls the paint up into the nozzle. The forward piston stroke forces the paint through an orifice that atomizes it into a mist. Airless sprayers do not produce the fine paint mist that air-powered units deliver, so there is less overspray and more paint is deposited.
Regardless of the sprayer you choose, you need to prepare the work surface, working area and even the paint before you can start painting. Preparing the work surface involves scraping, sanding and cleaning it, and also masking areas that are not to be painted. It is not always necessary to mask all areas; you can hold a large piece of cardboard as a shield to block the overspray from hitting places you don't want painted. Preparing the work area entails laying down dropcloths and erecting barriers to keep the overspray confined.
Filter all paints before loading them into the spray gun. Even new paint can have large particles that have coagulated into globs; if they are not removed, they will clog the gun. They can be strained out by pouring the paint through a commercial strainer or through an old nylon stocking.
Spray painting can be dangerous. High-pressure sprayers shoot paint with enough force to penetrate the skin. Protect yourself by donning the proper safety gear. Wear a respirator designed for paint spraying (not a dust mask), a long-sleeved shirt, goggles and gloves.

HEADLINE: P.S.E. & G. Is Honored By Clinton

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A commitment to its hometown of Newark won Public Service Electric & Gas, New Jersey's largest utility company, an award from the White House.
P.S.E.&G. was one of five companies saluted by President Clinton at a reception last week. The utility was recognized for spearheading the South Ward Neighborhood Partnership in Newark, a coalition of more than 50 organizations committed to neighborhood revitalization. 
 The centerpiece of the company's urban initiative in Newark is a $6.8 million, 100,000-square-foot light industrial complex being built with Federal and state financing and a loan from P.S.E.&G. Leaders of the initiative say the building will bring 200 to 300 jobs to the South Ward neighborhood.
The building, scheduled to be completed this fall, will offer special features to lure tenants and employees, including employment training, after-school programs and child care.
Also last week, Public Service announced plans to expand its urban initiative to six other cities: Paterson, Trenton, Elizabeth, New Brunswick, Camden and Jersey City.
Al Koeppe, senior vice president for external affairs at the company, said the effort in those cities, as in Newark, would begin with gauging what the communities want.
"We had a strong base of philanthropy in this company for a long time, but it didn't always ask the cities what they needed," said Mr. Koeppe. "So a premise will be to reach out first in the neighborhoods and the communities."
Joining Mr. Koeppe as guests at the White House yesterday were Shirley Ward, coordinator of public service's urban initiative, and Gail Davis, the urban initiative executive.
At the White House ceremony, President Clinton presented the Ron Brown Award for Corporate Leadership to the International Business Machines Corporation, for work force diversity initiatives, and to Levi Strauss, for an anti-racism program.
P.S.E.&G. won an honorable mention along with Bright Horizons of Cambridge, Mass., and Lancaster Laboratories of Lancaster, Pa.
The Ron Brown Award was named in honor of the former Secretary of Commerce who was killed in a plane crash in Croatia in 1996. While the award was encouraged by the Clinton administration just over a year ago, it is privately financed and administered.

LENGTH: 3323 words

HEADLINE: On the Waterfront

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
TAKE a good look at New Jersey's Hudson River waterfront and you can almost see them. The shimmering ghosts of the Gold Coast are back: phantom luxury apartments and office buildings lining the river in Jersey City, Hoboken, Weehawken and Edgewater.
But this time, it seems, these phantasms are not being blown away, as so many 1980's dreams were, by the variable winds of demographics, economics and politics. In fact, the 90's Gold Coast is building -- sometimes quite literally -- on the groundwork laid in the 80's. 
 "We sold it as the Gold Coast, but it might have been silver or tin at that time," said Thomas Leane, a planner for Jersey City in the 80's who is still deeply involved in the waterfront's fate. "Now, it has sort of reached the massing necessary to be gold."
People with money want to be on the waterfront: Aging baby boomers with empty suburban nests; would-be Manhattanites deflected by ridiculous rents; flourishing Wall Street businesses that want to expand.
Investment money is accessible again. Interest rates are low, and with the Asian crisis, banks are looking for local borrowers. Insurance companies and pension funds have regained enough confidence in real estate to reinvest. A newly fashionable kind of company, the real-estate investment trust, seems to offer boundless capital. And the recession in the late 1980's and early 1990's drove away most of the newcomers; most of the surviving developers have long histories in the clubby, competitive world of construction.
With a few exceptions, the court battles have been settled and the political storms have calmed. So has New York City's combative stance, because there is much less empty office space in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
During the recession, much of the infrastructure along the Hudson River waterfront was quietly upgraded. Sewer systems were revised and replaced; roadways were built or rebuilt and the local ferry system was reinvented. . Now, New Jersey Transit is building -- not planning, building -- a light rail system from Bayonne to Hoboken. Cities are in, and Governor Whitman has promised to help them grow.
"The pioneering is over," said Richard S. LeFrak, the president of the heavyweight Lefrak Organization of Queens. "We're into the developmental phase. It's a lot of chemistry. You can't just plant your flag like Columbus and then all of a sudden you get a Starbuck's."
The reference isn't rhetorical. A Starbucks is opening this month in one of his office towers at Newport City, a development sprouting shopping malls, apartment towers and office buildings that Mr. LeFrak calls "the biggest piece of the pie" on the Jersey City waterfront.

Empires in the Air And a Hedging of Bets
But will the Gold Coast really happen this time? Will 18 miles of abandoned warehouses, railroads and shipyards along the Hudson be transformed into a vast stretch of office towers, vertical neighborhoods and shopping malls? And if it is, what will that mean for Hudson and Bergen counties?
More than a dozen developers contacted for this article discussed project after project, painting empires in the air, talking about New York City's sixth borough.
That's their job. To live, Tinkerbelle needed believers to applaud. To build apartments, developers need believers to loan them money. To build offices, they need corporate believers to sign leases.
It is telling that, of the myriad development dreams hovering along the waterfront, it is residential and retail projects that are under construction. No new office projects have broken ground in five years. And most of the residential units are rentals. The watchword is caution.
"It's easier not to go broke with rentals," explained Fred Daibes (pronounced DAY-beez). His company, Daibes Enterprises, bought waterfront properties cheaply when the first Gold Coast evaporated, and has already spent $22 million out of a projected $100 million to turn the old Alcoa site in Edgewater into St. James Towers, a 460-unit residential complex -- all of it rental.
"If you can't rent an apartment for $2,000, you can rent it for $1,800 or $1,700," Mr. Daibes said, "and as long as you can rent it, you have money coming in to pay off the interest. But with condos, you can wait there a long time with it empty."
In the 80's, new condos went begging for so long that developers turned to auctions, where deluxe suites sold for a fraction of their original asking price.
Another error: bad timing.
The miles where the Gold Coast is supposed to appear were once jammed with shipyards and factories served by railways. But after World War II, the nation began abandoning rail in favor of the federally subsidized interstate highway system. The union-heavy North began losing industry to the Sun Belt. Container shipping consolidated dockwork to fewer and fewer spots.
By the early 80's, much of the waterfront was fenced off, idle and abandoned. Municipalities became major property owners. And the buyers started collecting: Leonard Stern's Hartz Mountain with 75 acres of Edgewater, Arthur Imperatore Sr.'s Arcorp with miles of Weehawken, the Lefrak Organization's 600-plus acres at Newport. Daniel K. Ludwig, one of the world's richest men, bought scores of acres to the south.
During the bad years, Lefrak and Hartz hung on, at a cost. Gene Heller, the president of Hartz's real-estate branch for 25 years, believed in building, not waiting. Leonard Stern, the company's president, was determined that Hartz would lie low until the economy turned. In a rift that fueled real-estate gossip for years, Mr. Heller left Hartz, bought a chunk of its property, and with his son Tod built Edgewater Commons, the first shopping center along River Road. That center, completed in the summer of 1996 with a huge Pathmark, Barnes & Noble, Bed, Bath & Beyond and assorted other stores, has been credited with giving the first breath of revival to the waterfront.
Mr. Ludwig, who earned his billions in part by inventing the supertanker, died in 1992, before the homes and offices he hoped to build next door to Newport City could become reality. With the estate left to charity, the decision to sell the waterfront land was obvious, said Ed McDermott, the president of Mr. Ludwig's trucking company, National Bulk Carriers. "There was simply no market at the time," he said.
Thomas Leane, the former Jersey City planner hired to oversee Harsimus Cove, found himself selling it off to an assortment of the waterfront's current players.
"It was bought for $58 million," Mr. Leane said. "We won't make a tremendous amount. We'll try to get out whole."
Sales are going well, he said. He expects to need a new job by the end of the year.
Of the early buyers, Mr. Imperatore was hardest hit. Even as his ferry company grew from a tiny operation to the impressive NY Waterways, which collects millions of fares every year, his real-estate bid faltered, and Roseland Property Company ended up controlling much of it.
In hindsight, many developers say, financing for buying and for building was just too easy to come by.
"There's an old joke," said Peter Mangin, the president of Garden State Development, which has plans for a Jersey City tower that, at 850 feet, would be New Jersey's tallest by far. "Developer comes back from a meeting at the bank and says to his partner, 'I have some good news and some bad news. The good news is, we got that $20 million loan. The bad news is we have to put up $5,000.' "
Loose lending practices were encouraged by unregulated appraisers, Mr. Mangin said. "They would rate a $5 million project at $7 million," he said, "and then the bank would say, you want $10 million?"
Now, banks don't do that, and appraisers are state-licensed. "Nobody's doing anything stupid," Mr. Mangin said.
The signature Gold Coast failure was Port Liberte, a debacle begun in the mid-80's that was intended to be a vast townhouse and condo development. Jutting out into New York Harbor south of Liberty State Park, it was supposed to have a Dutch streetscape, the feel of a Mediterranean village and a Venetian-style canal system. In 1989, its banker (CityFed of Somerset) reported a $52.7 million loss on the project and was seized by Federal regulators. With about 300 of its 1,674 units built, the project went belly up, leaving scores of pioneering residents in an unhappy partnership with the Resolution Trust Corporation.
That same project stands to become the revival story of the 1990's. The Applied Companies, a Hoboken developer founded by a former tenant lawyer, Joe Barry, has bought Port Liberte, has finished selling the already built units and plans to start construction on a modified version of the original plan this summer. The plan includes a nine-hole golf course.
(No one needs a crystal ball to see golf in the waterfront's future. Bayonne wants to put in an 18-hole course. Plans for an 18-hole course in Liberty State Park were abandoned, after much controversy, in 1995.)
 
Words Don't Make It So (But They Sure Help)
The developers are well aware that talk is talk, not steel and concrete. After estimating current office space in Jersey City at 6.5 million square feet (the equivalent of three World Trade Center towers), Brant Cali, a vice president of the Mack-Cali real-estate investment trust, calculated that if all the Jersey City developers' grand plans were turned into reality, there would be 16 million square feet of new office space.
"Do I think it's all going to get built? Not really," he said. But the point of such outlandish estimates is not prediction. "What fuels the marketplace is what could be, not what is. Realistically speaking, you can't sell pessimism."
Dozens of fantasies were announced with great fanfare in the 1980's, often accompanied by glowing newspaper accounts untouched by skepticism. There was the Harsimus Cove residential project south of Newport, the huge housing-and-office complex along the Weehawken waterfront, the bulky conference center with hotels, offices, and retail and residential space on the Hoboken piers. They didn't happen. Most didn't even get as far as Port Liberte.
"The Gold Coast didn't happen because the economic climate didn't let it happen," said Edwin H. Cohen, a director at Cushman & Wakefield who supervises leasing for Lefrak's Newport office projects. "It started happening and then the recession hit."
Asked if there were any guarantees this time, he laughed. Hard. "Nothing is a guarantee," he eventually said. "But all signs are pointing to its happening, and there are not any signs that it's not happening."
A couple of existing buildings have changed hands, based on expectations that office rents will be rising and that unoccupied spaces can be filled. Lefrak just sold the one-million-square-foot Newport Tower to TrizecHahn, a Canadian company, for $159 million. And miles upriver from "Wall Street West," as developers like to call Jersey City, a Long Island company called Crown Properties just bought 300 Boulevard East, a 300,000-square-foot tower, for $15 million. The tower, built by the junk-bond giant Drexel Burnam in 1987, went into foreclosure when junk bonds collapsed.
A dozen new projects have been designed and approved, but most won't break ground until lease agreements have been signed with anchor tenants. Developers need signed leases to get financing.
A deep-pocketed developer with enough confidence in the market to risk his own capital can build speculatively, without lease commitments. Emanuel Stern, the 34-year-old president of the real-estate arm of his father's company, Hartz Mountain, is the first waterfront developer to announce a speculative office tower, saying that he will break ground in June on a Hartz-financed 400,000-square-foot office tower by the Colgate clock in Jersey City.
There are insiders who say that Mr. Stern is just dangling the start date like a carrot, and that he won't really start building without tenants. Mr. Stern acknowledged, as every developer did when asked, that plans often don't come through as announced.
"But there are two things you can look at," he said. "A developer's reputation. Does he live up to his word? I think, if you look, you'll see that when Hartz said it was going to do something, it did."
The other thing, he said, is money. He paid $10 million for the Colgate property. "Paid!" he said. "Cash!"
"I know one thing," he added. "I know we're going to be in the ground in June."
Further off are plans that would turn Jersey City into enough of a Tallville that somebody might start keeping official statistics. (At the moment developers and architects keep a loose count.) Garden State Development's 850-foot-tall building would upstage 101 Hudson, the 550-foot art deco tower at Exchange Place, as the tallest building in New Jersey, the company says. And that would knock the Newport Tower, at 528 feet, down to third place, and 10 Exchange Place, at 460, to fourth.
The planned skyscraper, the American Financial Exchange, is a joint venture between an up-and-coming youngster, Garden State Development, and a national behemoth, Mack-Cali, which was created at the end of 1997 by a merger of two old, family-run New Jersey developers.
Once office construction begins in earnest, it's a race. Low vacancy means rising rents. That increases the value of stock in investment trusts, the real-estate equivalent of mutual funds. It also gives impetus to new building. But the more office space available, the greater the likelihood rents will stabilize or descend.
So the developer wants to build fast before there's too much competition. "The first guy gets the worm," Mr. Stern said.
 
The Infrastructure: Ready for Prime Time?
Suppose the worm-nabbing moment arrives. What about the residents, new or old, of the waterfront communities?
One focal question is whether the infrastructure is ready for a population gain of thousands. Not everywhere, it seems.
Jersey City started developing a master plan back in the 60's, so that even during slow economic times, the sewers and roadways and substations that major development would require were rolling into place. "Planning takes a long, long time," said Robert D. Cotter, the director of city planning for Jersey City. "And implementation is now into, what, a third of a century?"
But other municipalities didn't get that kind of head start.
Some have played a good game of catch-up, getting developers to install firehouses and sewer systems along with their apartment towers. And most Mayors, like Bret Schundler of Jersey City and Peter LaVilla of Guttenberg, say that the increased tax base more than pays for any increase in municipal services, like garbage collection.
Still, there are big question marks. Concerns about River Road, which runs along the waterfront lowlands, grow with each plan announced for West New York, Guttenberg, North Bergen and Edgewater. The road is being widened and lengthened, but it already carries so much traffic that neighboring Cliffside and Fort Lee are anxious and angry. Cliffside closed off Oxen Hill Road for a while, so traffic from River Road couldn't exit through the town.
Mayor Jack Alter of Fort Lee said he had turned away developers who saw shopping malls in the town's future because it couldn't handle any more traffic.
"It would be ironic," he said, "if we get jammed by their traffic because they build the shopping centers we won't allow. But that's the way it's going."
And what would thousands of new, well-to-do residents mean to politics in Hudson County, where the majority of the waterfront lies?
These municipalities have long been heavy with working-class immigrants. In the old days, they were Irish, German, Polish and Italian. After decades of being blocked, black residents finally won footholds. Newer groups are Indian, Asian and Hispanic -- people who are just starting up the economic ladder.
The economic split will presage a political split, according to James W. Hughes, the dean of Rutgers' Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy and an appointee to the state's Property Tax Commission. "In effect," he said, "you really have two Hudson-Bergen counties, the old parts that are creatures of the industrial economy, and a new waterfront that's part of the information age."
Dr. Hughes believes, surprisingly, that it is the older parts of the county that are the future bastions of political power. New residents are likely to be childless, he said, and lobbying for schools is one major reason citizens bother to vote. The kinds of problems new residents might face -- mail delivery or sanitation, say -- would be addressed with a building manager, not a politician.
There have already been some political shifts. In the optimistic years of the first Gold Coast, the older ethnic groups started feeling left out, and an anti-development sentiment took hold just as development was taking off. In 1985, mayoral elections in Jersey City and Hoboken swung on whether voters thought a candidate was likely to "sell out" to developers.
Development didn't stop, but it took a few unusual turns.
During the "pro-old-timers" term of Mayor Anthony Cucci of Jersey City, it was decided to put at Exchange Place a monument to the 1940 massacre of Polish soldiers in the Katyn forest. The 17-foot statue, a cavalryman with a bayonet through his back, is in the middle of what planners call "the view corridor," framed by the World Trade Center Towers. That placement is itself a sort of memorial to the bygone strength of the old ethnic groups.
 
Interests Converge, And Developers Salivate
Mayor LaVilla says he does not expect much of an electoral impact in Guttenberg when people fill the townhouses on his waterfront that K. Hovnanian, New Jersey's largest homebuilder, just broke ground on. A third of the town's 9,000 citizens already live in one development, the gargantuan, three-building Galaxy Towers, built in 1976.
Inside and outside the towers, Mr. LaVilla said, his constituents care about two things: cutting taxes and reducing crime. The Hovnanian development, he said, will bring more people who want the same -- and will, at the same time, cut taxes and reduce crime.
"Development on dormant land brings in new taxes," he said, "and, assuming the new units don't cost more in terms of municipal services than they pay out, homeowners' taxes should drop. And crime? Well, townhouses selling for a quarter of a million to half a million, that doesn't exactly bring in a bad element."
Mayor Schundler expects new Jersey City residents to slowly switch, as he did, from apartments to brownstones, from renters to homeowners, from singles to married with children. "Their impact to date has been minimal," he said of the new arrivals, "but that's not to say it's not there."
He said that with both an Urban Enterprise Zone designation and new development, Jersey City is moving in the right direction for older and newer residents, with lower property taxes and a fund for refurbishing decaying areas like Central Avenue, Martin Luther King Boulevard, West Side Avenue and Journal Square.
There is at least one down side, he acknowledged. "Rents rise as a function of rising property values," he said, "and property values are rising, no doubt about it." But he said that "rent control should mediate that for most old-time residents."
Such rosy views only brighten the gleam in developers' eyes.
Emanuel Stern, on a tour of Hartz properties along the Hudson, was asked to imagine the best of all possible futures.
"If things go well," he mused as his car whizzed by cranes, "we'll build multi-thousands of units of residential units and large amounts of commercial real estate, and this will become the sixth borough."
And the worst case? He paused. "Basically, I see the same thing," he said, shrugging. "Just taking longer."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Excelsior's Manager Tries to Dodge the Bombs in Latin America

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
ONE night three years ago, as Donald W. Hoskins lay asleep in his small apartment in Lima, Peru, a powerful guerrilla car bomb exploded a block away.
"I found myself underneath my bed at 2 in the morning thinking, 'What am I doing in Peru?' and, 'Maybe there is a reason why stocks here are so cheap,' " recalled Mr. Hoskins, the manager of U.S. Trust's Excelsior Latin America fund. 
 On a recent morning in Manhattan, surrounded by computers flickering the zigs and zags of stock exchanges from Mexico City to Buenos Aires, Mr. Hoskins talked about the kind of risk and turbulence that emerging-markets investors are learning to live with.
"Investing in Latin America is clearly exciting," he said. "You go beyond the Ritz-Carlton world of business."
Exciting indeed. After taking over the fund last February, Mr. Hoskins turned in a sizzling return of 31.9 percent for the second and third quarters of 1997, compared with an average return of 25.8 percent for all Latin American funds, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund trackers in Chicago. "I was beginning to think this was kind of easy," he said.
Then, disaster. His big exposures to Venezuela and steel stocks, particularly Brazil's Gerdau Siderberg, sent Excelsior farther south than most competing funds during the selloff in emerging markets late last year. Excelsior was down 14 percent for the fourth quarter, versus 12.1 percent for its peers. In January, it fell an additional 13.4 percent, versus 10.8 percent for the Latin group, but this month the fund has regained almost half of that loss.
"I learned humility," Mr. Hoskins said, chalking up his losses to falling oil prices, fears that Korean steel would flood world markets, and Venezuela's failure to reduce its government bureaucracy.
Already a jogger, Mr. Hoskins just took up classical guitar. "Hopefully," he said, "it is an antidote to stress."
A better antidote might be improved performance. And with Gerdau Siderberg, at 3.7 percent of his portfolio, and other steel picks suddenly recovering, Mr. Hoskins noted earlier this month that Excelsior was on the rebound. Still, he said, he wants investors to judge him over a two-year period, not week to week.
The cause of Excelsior's volatility -- and, he said, the source of what will eventually be superior returns -- is his concentrated stock-picking strategy. He has only 41 stocks in his portfolio, about one-third the number in most Latin American funds. "What we try to identify is those companies with the kind of strategic competitive advantages that are sustainable," he said. "What we look for is a company that has a price to cash flow that is lower than its long-term sustainable growth rate."
Such thinking has led Mr. Hoskins to take big positions in companies like Telebras, Brazil's telephone giant (12.3 percent of the portfolio), and Grupo Elektra, a Mexican appliance retailer (2.1 percent), which can benefit from urbanization and the expansion of the middle class. He shuns Chile as pricey, except for American depository receipts of Concha y Toro, the winery (1.6 percent), because, as a wine collector, he concluded that Chilean wines have a vast price advantage over American and European competitors.
Mr. Hoskins says he picks stocks, not countries. But he is confident that Latin American governments will continue to push privatization, cut waste and work to keep their currencies stable.
"There is no alternative," he said. "Latin America has gone through every possible avenue, with disastrous results: import substitution, military governments incurring huge inflation with irresponsible fiscal budgets, guerrilla warfare. Asia flu? This, too, shall pass."
BUT he said investors in Latin America should be prepared for volatility, even if bombs aren't shattering the windows, and even if the region's markets have recovered nicely from the collapse of the Mexican peso in 1994 and 1995. Certainly, the Asian crises have made Latin America's markets and currencies look vulnerable again, especially with trade deficits swelling.
How bad can it get? Mr. Hoskins noted that the Bovespa index of Brazilian stocks has fallen 30 percent or more no less than six times since November 1987, plummeting 80 percent in one swing. Still, a dollar invested in the index in late 1987 would be worth $15 today -- nearly four times more than the same dollar invested in the Dow.
"If I'm interested in getting the $15 versus the $4, am I willing to ride through the storms?" he asked. Answering his own question, he said he had invested most of his own money in Latin America.
At 37, Mr. Hoskins has long bounded around the globe. As the son of two diplomats, he attended kindergarten in Saigon at the height of the Vietnam War and lived in Thailand, Burkina Faso and Mauritania. But he did not spend much time thinking about Latin America until he took a consulting job with the World Bank in 1993. A few months later, he tested his entrepreneurial talents in Peru by starting a flower delivery business. He later took a job at a Lima brokerage house.
It is clear that Latin America is more than just another stock play for him. His office is full of Latin American art, including a Peruvian wall hanging he bought while taking a four-day hike on an Inca trail high in the Andes with his wife, Paola, who is Peruvian. He has even acquired a taste for the South American novelists Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Jorge Amado.
Mr. Hoskins likes to travel around Latin America -- and not only to corporate board rooms. He says he believes passionately in face-to-face contact with management. At Pao d'Acucar, a Brazilian grocery chain, he was impressed that the headquarters had been built above one of its stores to keep executives in touch. It is now 2.2 percent of his portfolio. And by drinking tequila with some executives over lunch in the Banamex corporate dining room in Mexico City, he said he avoided a potentially losing investment by getting them to talk about their mortgage portfolio, which he viewed as shaky.
This kick-the-tire approach takes Mr. Hoskins to the tango clubs of Argentina, where the lyrics are somber, pessimistic expressions of lost love, and the samba clubs of Brazil, where love songs are happy. There is an investment lesson to be learned in both types of clubs, he said.
"When an Argentine businessman says, 'We are struggling but we hope to pull through,' that could indicate it's going to be a stellar year," he said. "If a Brazilian businessman said that, be prepared for bankruptcy."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
This Deficit Is Soaring Again

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Remember the twin deficits? A decade ago, the trade and budget deficits were the whipping boys, supposedly joined at the hip and blamed for all the world's economic woes. Unless the United States could bring them down, disaster was said to be assured.
Those dire forecasts proved unfounded. The American economy has performed so well that the budget deficit is set to vanish this year. Alas, the same cannot be said for the trade deficit. It declined for a while -- falling by more than half from 1987 to 1991 -- but since then has grown and grown. The 1997 figure, to be announced this week, is likely to be in the range of $195 billion, breaking the $191 billion record set in 1996. 
 You don't need to memorize that figure. That's because the trends are now solidly in place for the trade deficit to rise rapidly in 1998. And in a year or two, you may hear anguished commentary on the negative effects of such a huge deficit.
For now, though, Washington's concerns are limited. The just-released annual Economic Report of the President has only a brief discussion of the trade deficit, expressing little concern and ending with, "In the strongly expanding full-employment economy that the United States now enjoys, it should be easier for Americans to see that trade deficits do not necessarily reduce output and employment."
This year, we can expect Asia to be exporting things at give-away prices, in a desperate bid for dollars. For a time, anyway, that will help to hold down inflation in this country, as cheap imports flood in. Meanwhile, Asia will be importing fewer capital goods, in part because its access to capital will be limited.
The net effect will be to cause the trade deficit to zoom, slowing the American economy as well. The stock market already reflects part of that move. Consumer stocks have soared in the last few months, reflecting the willingness of Americans to keep buying things. But companies that depend on exports, or those that produce industrial commodities, are not doing so well. Since the October market low, Disney and Wal-Mart are each up more than 40 percent, while companies like International Paper and Union Carbide have done nothing for their shareholders.
Right now, the huge trade deficit -- which effectively means we are buying cars and computer parts with dollars rather than in exchange for goods and services -- is not hurting the dollar. Other countries have their own problems, and the dollar is in great demand. But that could change. Within a year or two, a falling dollar could mean that imports cost more, causing inflation to rise.
The dollar's woes could be exacerbated if the great European currency experiment, a common currency called the euro, looks like a success. Now, the dollar is strong in part because some think the euro will be weak. But that could change. Europeans dream of the euro becoming a reserve currency, and of central banks holding euros as well as bucks. If so, that could lead to a round of dollar selling.
One can then imagine what would happen. The Federal Reserve, now so friendly and unconcerned about inflation, might tighten, seeking to fight inflation and to defend the dollar. Senators would denounce unfair trade practices and push for protectionism. The stock market might fear recession.
For now, the rising trade deficit seems to have no ill effects, and it therefore gets little attention. That situation is unlikely to last forever.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Where Every Worker Is Ruler of the Thermostat

BYLINE: By LISA NAPOLI 

 BODY:
WHEN economists debate how to increase workplace productivity, they discuss many factors: automation, the availability of labor, even the rise or fall of wages. Rarely, though, does anyone mention room temperature.
Yet, according to 10 years of surveys conducted by the Center for Building Performance and Design, the No. 1 complaint of office workers is that the workplace is too cold. The No. 2 complaint? That it's too hot. 
 To Volker Hartkopf, this is more than the punch line of a Dilbert cartoon. Mr. Hartkopf, the center's director, considers it proof of a core principle: that to get more productivity from employees, a comfortable work environment is essential.
"It has to do with lighting, thermal quality, visual quality, air quality," he said, ticking off ingredients of his recipe for a pleasant workplace. "If a person worries five minutes a day about this, and makes just one phone call to facility management to complain about the temperature, that's 1 percent of their productivity."
"The building is only a piece of the whole situation," he acknowledged. "You can have a wonderful building and a terrible boss or an awful organization, and you will be prevented from being productive. But if the building makes you sick or freeze or is acoustically such that you can't concentrate, it keeps you from reaching your potential."
In a $4 million, 7,000-square-foot living laboratory on the campus of Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, Mr. Hartkopf and a team of architects and engineers have created a prototype for what they have called the "intelligent workplace."
Along with a host of other technical improvements, the workplace features raised floors to accommodate air flow and cables that allow work stations to be equipped with individual controls for lighting, acoustics and temperature.
The environmental controls, which the center's staff developed with engineers from Johnson Controls, are installed on each desk, letting a worker cool or heat his area as needed; when the desk is unoccupied, the system automatically shuts down. The controls also let a worker shift the position of lighting or breathe fresh air through individual vents.
But the center, of course, is addressing issues beyond heating and ventilation. The workplace also features "plug and play" technology that allows computers and telephones to be quickly installed and moved, making it easier to make rooms bigger or smaller, without large-scale interior work.
Built on top of the campus's Margaret Morrison Carnegie Hall, the workplace, which houses the center's offices, is an odd bit of office architecture, trying to wed new technology to the original structure, which was constructed in 1904. The office exterior, aiming to blend with the hall's Beaux Arts design, is made of bolted recyclable steel, with high, wide windows that are flanked by solar panels.
Research in the field of construction is unusual, acknowledged Steven Lee, the center's associate director; of the $500 billion spent on capital construction each year, only 1 percent is designated for research. But as increases in productivity slow and as concerns rise about repetitive stress and other workplace injuries, he said, such research reflects a growing interest in ergonomics and efficiency.
"The economic arguments are becoming more and more compelling," he said. "Improving productivity, the fear of being sued, the push from the facilities side for improvements -- it's slowly happening."
The project is backed by a consortium of 18 groups from the public and private sectors. Technology companies like Johnson Controls and Siemens are using the workplace to show off their products and to see them work with one another.
Other corporations, like BankAmerica, are involved because they are looking for better ways to integrate technology into existing buildings, or are interested in workplace concepts like teaming.
Energy efficiency remains a government priority, too. Indeed, in his latest budget, President Clinton proposed tax credits for corporations that invest in several energy-efficient devices, including solar panels. Environmental mandates are also helping to fuel the Government's interest.
"Particularly in view of the Kyoto agreements to reduce energy consumption, this is of interest to the entire world," said John Chamberlain, the director of administration for the Environmental Protection Agency, and a member of the center's board. Other Government agencies that are sponsors include the Department of Energy and the National Science Foundation.
Mr. Chamberlain also said that in the competition for good employees, businesses would likely be forced to give human considerations more weight.
"Companies who are having to compete for skilled workers are going to have to give those skilled workers nice places to work," he said.
EVEN without a new building, Mr. Hartkopf said, many businesses are shortsighted about integrating new technologies -- spending, on average, $8,000 to $10,000 an employee a year for hardware, software, training, and networks but only a fraction of that on how to accommodate the people who use them.
"There is this macroeconomic situation where people are apparently willing to spend that much money for these technologies and be cheap on the building," Mr. Hartkopf said. "To save on construction while potentially suffering multiples of that on every year's basis doesn't make sense."
Mr. Lee said that a new building designed with efficiency principles might cost 50 to 100 percent more than a conventional counterpart, depending on the builders' expertise. The personal environmental control system, for example, costs from $900 to $1,400 a unit, and that excludes the installation costs. But, he added, an "efficient" building could reap as much as 30 percent in energy savings each year.
Proving that such environments increase productivity is still a challenge. There is no simple formula that can calculate all the benefits of the system -- and thus help convince budget-conscious administrators to adopt it for their companies.
One study of the personal environment system alone, at West Bend Mutual, an insurance company in Milwaukee, showed a 4 percent productivity increase, Mr. Lee said. The center is trying to consolidate the results of this and other studies to give companies a clearer view of the potential impact.
Some companies are already using lessons learned at the center. The new headquarters of Owens Corning in Toledo, Ohio, for example, is long and narrow, giving most employees access to natural light. The 400,000-square-foot structure features individual air controls at each work station.
"There's a constant wash of air from floor to ceiling, which improves air quality," said Scott Linville, the company's facilities manager. "People love having control."
Mr. Linville said the plug-and-play feature had proved particularly useful for sharing information.
"It's never a problem to get a team to meet," he said. "There are more than 80 meeting rooms, and they are all equipped so people can show up with their laptops and plug in."
The high-technology center wants to illustrate the benefits of smart design by giving employees from some of its sponsoring companies a chance to use its office space, on a rotating basis.
For now, 10 center employees work in the space. Else Holter, a staff assistant, likes the control panel on her desk, which allows her to regulate the air flow in her area, and the plug-and-play feature gives her the freedom to set up her computer and phone a number of ways.
But she raved most about a nontechnological wonder.
"In some of my previous jobs, I worked in a windowless office, where in the wintertime I would arrive when it was still dark and leave work when it was dark," Ms. Holter said. "Here, I can look out, open my window or the door to get fresh air. Nature is a wonderful think tank."
