HEADLINE: AT THE GATE;
Stepping Out From Its Cubicle

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
OFFICE furniture is not the kind of workplace topic that glues crowds to the water cooler, but that's never stopped Steelcase.
Founded in 1912 as the Metal Office Furniture Company, Steelcase, the world's largest office-furniture maker, churns out high-quality products like ergonomically correct chairs and customized cubicles. 
 Now Steelcase hopes that people will buy into the business, commonplace though it may be. As early as this week, the company, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., will make an initial public offering of 12.15 million shares, at $23 to $26 each. And although Steelcase faces some tough competitors and the industry as a whole is vulnerable to an economic slowdown, investors may find Steelcase a reasonably priced prospect in a now-booming business.
Certainly, the stock performance of some of Steelcase's competitors may prompt many investors to jump in. Last May, for example, one rival, Knoll Inc., went public at $17 a share. Since then, its stock has more than doubled, closing on Friday at $37.125. Herman Miller, another competitor, has also seen its stock zoom, from the mid-30's last May to $59.6875 on Friday.
There is no guarantee, of course, that Steelcase's stock will have a similar snap. But there's little doubt that the office furniture market is zinging along. According to BIFMA International, an industry group, office furniture shipments, which had grown at a compound annual rate of 7.2 percent from 1994 through 1996, sped up to a 14 percent gain in 1997.
A booming economy is fueling much of the growth. But other trends are at work, too.
For example, companies are paying more attention to health, safety and comfort issues, and, for efficiency's sake, integrating technology directly into office work stations. A desire for more collaborative work environments is an impetus, too. "One of the major demands that's driving this market is the need for space that promotes team effort, yet is flexible enough to avoid large reconstruction costs," said Alan Andolsen, president of Naremco Services, a Manhattan consulting firm.
Steelcase's size may help it benefit from this strong demand. According to the latest industry statistics, from 1996, Steelcase had about 20 percent of the office furniture market, nearly twice the share of Herman Miller, its nearest competitor.
And as the whole industry tries to offer furniture that is, in Mr. Andolsen's phrase, "less Dilberty," Steelcase has long experience to draw on. In the 1950's, for instance, it introduced furniture in a variety of colors.
Thanks to its sizable and growing research-and-development budget, Steelcase is still innovative, analysts say. Among its many products are an elegant, ultrathin folding conference table and a high-tech work cubicle. The cubicle, meant to tap into employers' desire to offer more egalitarian, cost-efficient work space without sacrificing too many creature comforts, has amenities like individual temperature controls and piped-in music.
The company has an eye on new markets, too, analysts say. Recently, it rolled out a product line that includes removable, reconfigurable architectural elements like floors, walls and lighting, as well as complementary furniture. Steelcase hopes the line will catch on with real estate developers who are designing or retrofitting buildings.
That target market may welcome the overture, Mr. Andolsen said. "Developers are trying to offer a whole range of services -- like copy shops -- to take a major load off of companies," he explained.
Steelcase's innovation has helped its sales to grow faster than the industry average. From roughly 1994 through 1996, the company's annual sales growth, at 9.9 percent, outpaced the industry's by two to three percentage points.
Moreover, the Steelcase offering is attractively priced -- especially after the recent run-up in the stocks of its public rivals.
Shares of Knoll Inc. and Herman Miller are now trading at 21 and 29 times earnings per share, respectively, over the last four quarters. But at the midpoint of its expected price range, Steelcase has a multiple of just 19, said Eileen Ohnell, an analyst at the IPO Plus Aftermarket fund in Greenwich, Conn.
Measured by enterprise value -- which basically compares market capitalization with sales -- Steelcase stock also "looks fairly good," Ms. Ohnell said. Steelcase has an enterprise value of 1.4, while Herman Miller's is 1.7, and Knoll's, 2.1
Steven Tuen, an analyst at IPO Value Monitor in Manhattan, also believes that Steelcase stock is slightly undervalued.
Given the expected stock price and the company's expected earnings, "We think there's a potential for 10 to 15 percent upside for the company" in the next six to 12 months, Mr. Tuen said.
Still, there are some risks in Steelcase. As with other office furniture companies, Steelcase's business will suffer if the economy softens, causing reduced office construction and slower growth in white-collar jobs.
And the office furniture market is highly competitive. Both Knoll and Herman Miller logged record sales and profits in 1997, not only because of overall industry sales growth, but also because of product improvements and other factors.
With the whole sector booming, such competition is muffled. But if business slows, it may get louder.
And while Steelcase's size may give it a leg up, its competitors have their own edges. According to Todd Brickhouse, an analyst at Wheat First Union, a brokerage firm in Richmond, Knoll is now the industry's lowest-cost company, and Herman Miller's new, modestly priced product line has had great success. Indeed, some investors may prefer these enterprises to Steelcase, despite its less expensive stock.
There is another significant apparent risk to this offering. But it dwindles upon closer inspection.
The nearly $300 million in offering proceeds will go not to Steelcase but to shareholders who are selling out. Often, investors worry that such sales mean that the shareholders, typically company founders or executives, are skedaddling because they see clouds on the company's horizon.
But the portion on the block -- owned by members of one of Steelcase's founding families, the Wege family -- is relatively small, at just 8 percent of the company, and still leaves the Weges with a 20 percent share. Ms. Ohnell says the offering probably speaks more to a desire to diversify the Wege holdings than to any lack of confidence in the firm.
Steelcase managers as a whole seem optimistic, too, holding a collective 40 percent stake even after the offering, Mr. Tuen noted. "There's strong management interest in this company," he said.

HEADLINE: The World;
Forget the Maine. Spain Is Back.

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
THE explosion of the battleship Maine in Havana harbor 100 years ago today set the stage for Spain's retreat from the last remnants of its empire in the New World, and for the emergence of the United States as a global power. Yet as the American Century draws to a close, a resurgent Spain is once again flexing its muscles in Latin America and pushing aside any lingering memories of "El Desastre," as the Spanish-American War is often called there.
If it was the cross and the sword that inspired Spain's initial foray into the Americas 500 years ago, it is the checkbook and the satellite dish that are leading what one Colombian magazine calls "the second Spanish conquest." 
 Though Spain has focused on building trade with its European neighbors since joining the European Community in 1986, Spanish companies have also invested billions of dollars in Latin America in those 12 years. They have bought up telephone companies, banks and airlines in places like Argentina, Chile, Venezuela and Puerto Rico as local governments privatize enterprises once owned by the state.
"In every corner of the continent, you have a Spanish company pushing ahead, building hotels or investing in rail systems," said Antonio de Oyarzabal, Spain's Ambassador to the United States. Just last week, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya announced the purchase of Banco Ponce, a leading bank in Puerto Rico, which became an American possession as a result of the 1898 war.
 
Clout in Europe
At the same time, Spain's political clout in the region has been enhanced by its integration into Europe. Latin American governments know that the European Union's commissioner for Latin American affairs is a Spaniard, as are the Secretary General of NATO and the chairman of the European Parliament. Latin Americans see Spaniards as their natural advocates when approaching Europe, and the Spanish Government seems to like the idea.
"We will be much stronger in Europe as long as we grow in America, where we have a certain strength," Mr. de Oyarzabal said. Spanish policy makers have a phrase for this strategy -- creating an Ibero-American space. It includes state visits by King Juan Carlos I, treaties liberally salted with aid and cultural exchanges, and, since 1991, an annual Ibero-American Summit.
Largely at Spanish insistence, the European Community now has embassies in virtually every Latin American capital that help administer economic and technical assistance and organize joint programs with regional trade groups like Mercosur and the Central American Common Market. On its own, Spain offers aid and trade credits, supplies teachers and helps train new civilian police forces in countries like El Salvador and Guatemala. "For a middle-sized European country, Spain plays a disproportionately large role in Latin America," said Joaquin Roy, director of the Iberian Studies Research Institute at the University of Miami. "A shared language and heritage help tremendously, no doubt about it."
Modern technology has advanced Spain's cultural penetration of Latin America as well, much to the delight of cultural nationalists who dread Americanization of the region. Television Espanola is carried on cable systems almost everywhere, and Spanish magazines like "Hola!" and "Interviu" circulate widely, thanks to gossipy cover stories about the Spanish royal family or celebrities like Julio Iglesias.
On any beach from Cancun to Vina del Mar in Chile, affluent Latin Americans consider it chic to be seen toting around best sellers from Spanish publishers like Seix Barral, or the latest winner of Spain's literary brass ring, the Cervantes Prize. Since 1990, the value of Spanish book exports to Latin America has quintupled.
With that higher profile, however, have come signs of the reappearance of anti-Spanish sentiment. Such feelings have deep roots among Mexicans, who long ago began calling their former colonian masters "gachupines" an epithet akin to "gringos." Still, for much of this century the Spanish immigrant, whether the tailor on the corner, the nun teaching in a rural school or the refugee from Franco's fascism, was generally regarded with affection and sympathy because Spain was a poor country laboring under inept or dictatorial rule, just like most of Latin America.
Now, however, Spain's transformation into a prosperous, democratic and decidedly modern European state has reversed many of those stereotypes and some of the affection. In some places, the stereotypical image of the Castillian businessman with the slick-backed hair, fancy suit and lisping accent now competes with that of the ugly American in unpopularity. "They're barely off the plane from Madrid, and they're flaunting their money in our faces and sleeping with our women," a Havana taxi driver complained. "Let them just stay home."
At the official level, relations between Spain and Cuba have been tense since Spaniards elected Jose Maria Aznar Prime Minister two years ago. He has been pressing Cuba for changes toward democracy, and Fidel Castro's regime has responded with a barrage of personal insults. Last month, with the centennial of the Spanish-American War approaching, Cuban leaders accused Spain of inflicting genocide on Cuba during the 19th Century, and of failing to apologize.
 
Following the Leader
Nevertheless, Spain's transition from backward dictatorship to industrial democracy is widely admired by politicians elsewhere in Latin America, who have often looked to the Spanish experience as a road map. When Gen. Joao Figueiredo, for instance, was Brazil's President in the early 1980's, he evoked two of Spain's champions of democracy by saying he hoped to be remembered as "the Juan Carlos or Adolfo Suarez of Brazil."
And for all the complaining about the new Spain, one essential fact remains: Like it or not, the blood, language and culture of Spain run deep in the Latin American soul. His recent strident anti-Spanish rhetoric notwithstanding, Mr. Castro himself is a son of a Spanish soldier who came to Cuba in the late 19th century to fight the very Cuban rebels Mr. Castro now exalts. The soldier stayed on, becoming a wealthy Cuban landowner.
"An extraordinary number of Cuban leaders are the children of Spaniards, and that puts pressure on them to show they are more revolutionary and nationalist than anyone else," Dr. Roy explained. "It's just like Poles, Jews or Italians who immigrated to the United States. First-generation Americans also feel forced to show that they are more American than the Americans."
Later generations, he might have added, often reconnect to roots in the old country.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3059 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Making Way For Fidelity's Heir Apparent

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
SHE does not carry an electronic organizer, or write with a $200 pen. No flashy touches adorn the hushed tones of the suits -- not Armani -- she favors.
For the billionaire daughter of the billionaire chairman of the world's largest mutual fund company, even a slight display of ostentation runs counter to character -- a character that acquaintances old and new describe as understated, soft-spoken, modest and down to earth. 
 So far, that puts Abigail Pierrepont Johnson, 36, on much the same path as her father, Edward C. Johnson 3d, who is 67 and the chairman of Fidelity Investments.
"I watched her father take over the company from his father," said William J. Hayes, a longtime executive who retired last year after seven years as head of Fidelity's equity mutual fund division. "He took his time learning the operation. He didn't go in the first day and say: 'I'm it. Let's do this.' That's the same way I've observed Abby as she has joined the management side."
Perhaps if she leads Fidelity for 26 years, as her father has, Ms. Johnson will also acquire his reputation for gruff, caustic leadership. Or perhaps she will maintain the genial style of her grandfather, Edward C. Johnson 2d, who led Fidelity from its founding in 1946 until turning it over to his son, then 42, in 1972.
But for now, Ms. Johnson, who one year ago moved into Fidelity's middle-management ranks after eight years as an investment analyst and fund manager, has adopted the roles of both teacher and student.
As a teacher, she shepherds new portfolio managers, offering tips on things as obscure as the economics of oil drilling, or the best time of day to trade certain stocks. At the same time, she is slowly slipping into her role as the company's heir apparent -- learning, at the right hand of several of her father's closest advisers, how to manage people in a business where ego can play an important role in success.
Financial circles from the Charles River to Wall Street have been abuzz in the last year with speculation about whether Abby, as she is known, will succeed her father and, if so, when. But she says she still has not decided whether she will seek to -- or wants to, which is not the same thing -- ultimately take the reins.
She makes it clear, however, that in the turmoil that has surrounded Fidelity for more than a year, she has sensed both the opportunity and the obligation to take a bigger role in the family institution. "I really loved running money, and I wasn't eager to give it up," Ms. Johnson said. But at the time, moving into corporate management "seemed like the right thing to do," she said. "Someone was going to need to make that jump."
Sitting in a modestly furnished office with a view of Boston Harbor, Ms. Johnson, the eldest of Ned Johnson's three children, brightens noticeably when discussing her early memories of Fidelity. As a youngster, she said, she often visited the company's headquarters on Devonshire Street. "I remember going to the trading room and being captivated by the energy, the excitement," she said.
Two dozen toy models of heavy machinery -- dump trucks, tractors, steam shovels and cranes -- sit atop a filing cabinet, remnants of her first full-time assignment, as an analyst and manager of the Select Industrial Equipment fund. A stem of basil is growing in a coffee mug on her desk, watched over by a half-dozen photographs of her daughter, soon to be 3 years old. Outside her 35th-floor window, airplanes headed for the nearby Logan International Airport drift by at eye level.
Fidelity has operated in rarefied air for decades. But more recently, a dense fog has formed around the company. In late 1996, as Fidelity was watching over more than $400 billion of Americans' investments in mutual funds -- nearly twice as much as its nearest competitor -- rafts of the company's esteemed fund managers were departing.
Fidelity controlled 13 percent of the market in an industry where only 10 other companies had more than a 2 percent share, but the performance of its most popular mutual funds, and its reputation for investment acumen, were sagging. All around it, the mutual fund business was changing.
Where employers once offered only Fidelity funds in their retirement plans, they started to demand choices from other fund companies. The company's market share began to dip. And confidence among the company's retail customers was deemed so low that Fidelity, known as relentlessly controlling of the flow of information about its business, sent top executives on a six-city road show to answer questions and reassure individual investors.
Last winter, as Mr. Hayes prepared to retire as her boss, Ms. Johnson realized that "some people would need to step forward to take his place," she said.
"If you had asked me about it six months before I stopped running money, I would have said 'of course not,' " she said of her move to management. "But in this business you have to be opportunistic. It doesn't make sense to lay out a rigid plan and be adamant about pursuing it."
AS Fidelity's largest shareholder, with 24.5 percent of the voting stock of the FMR Corporation, Fidelity's parent, and with a net worth estimated by Forbes magazine at $3.4 billion, Ms. Johnson can do whatever she wants. What she wants to do for now, she insists, is simply to learn how to manage the people who manage America's money.
"I'm concerned that there is a misperception that Fidelty's philosophy has changed, that we are willing to accept poor performance," she said. "Nothing could be farther from the truth. This company was founded on top performance and everything we do is dedicated to achieving it."
To do so, she said, "I think a lot about career paths," referring mainly to those of the fund managers she oversees, but with a nod of acknowledgment that people wonder most about her own. "If you want a group of people to hold together over the long term, you have to think about where each of them is going."
Ms. Johnson said her experience as a Fidelity fund manager helped her fit naturally into her new job as one of three senior vice presidents who assist Robert C. Pozen, the head of Fidelity's mutual fund division.
Her specific roles include overseeing equity information systems -- the vast computer networks that give Fidelity's fund managers access to the reams of research generated by the company's army of investment analysts. In addition, she acts as a liaison with other parts of Fidelity's empire, screening requests for new funds from the marketing department or filtering demands for access to fund managers from brokers and financial advisers who sell Fidelity funds.
"I don't want the fund managers having to worry about whether we should use Unix or Windows NT as our new operating system," Ms. Johnson said. "And I don't want our portfolio managers flying off to East Podunk every week to meet with two brokers. We want the portfolio managers investing and picking stocks."
She shares responsibility for riding herd over three groups of portfolio managers, including those who run some of the company's biggest funds, like Magellan, Growth Company and Low-Priced Stock.
Helping to supervise people who were her peers just a few months ago can make for an awkward transition. But if Ms. Johnson feels natural in the role of coach to those who are still playing in the game, it is probably because she always worked as hard as anyone else.
"You never would have known she was the heir to all of this," said one former Fidelity fund manager, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "She did not want to be regarded as the scion of power. And as an analyst at industry conferences, she was running to visit 300 companies like all the rest of us."
After college, Ms. Johnson spent two years at Booz-Allen & Hamilton, the New York consulting firm. "I thought it would be too bad if I never worked someplace else," she said. She joined Fidelity after graduating from Harvard Business School in 1988, spending five years as a Fidelity analyst, offering investment ideas to more experienced fund managers. Then came three years as the manager of a succession of three general equity portfolios, a tenure that produced a better-than-average record.
In May 1996, as Fidelity's fund management ranks underwent their second big shake-up in three months, prompted by the departure of the Magellan manager, Jeffrey N. Vinik, Ms. Johnson became manager of the $1.3 billion Fidelity Trend fund.
While the Trend fund was smaller than her previous assignment, the move had echoes of the family heritage. It was at this same fund that her father demonstrated his investment prowess from 1959 to 1965, guiding it to average annual gains of 30 percent, more than twice those of the typical growth stock fund.
MS. JOHNSON'S own tenure at the Trend fund was less remarkable. In roughly eight months, the fund, which tries to detect investment currents ahead of the crowd, gained 9.6 percent, well below the 13.4 percent gain in the average growth stock fund tracked by Lipper Analytical Services.
Some Fidelity watchers have noted that Ms. Johnson's departure from the Trend fund (and before that from the OTC fund, which she took over in 1994) occurred as those funds started to struggle. Skeptics carped that the company was protecting its favorite daughter's track record. Fidelity has dismissed the suggestion, saying the changes were dictated by companywide shifts.
While she clearly relishes her new role, Ms. Johnson says she recognizes that Fidelity revolves around its portfolio managers. "In some ways, there is nothing more fun" than being a portfolio manager, she said. "You set your own schedule, set your own priorities, particularly here at Fidelity where you have tremendous resources available to you. You have a lot of autonomy, but you also have individual accountability."
The balance of those two characteristics -- autonomy and accountability -- are what give Fidelity its unique culture, Ms. Johnson said. And the company's core belief -- that mutual funds are best managed by individuals, not teams -- will remain in place, she believes, notwithstanding outsiders' speculation that Fidelity may adopt the team approach favored by a Boston rival, Putnam Investments, and many other management companies.
While the give and take among individuals is key to sharpening their skills, she explained, each person performs better when directly accountable for decisions.
"There is a balance," Ms. Johnson said. "You need individual contributors who work as a team. You have to have your own opinion, but be accountable for your fund. And when discussion groups of fund managers get together to talk about their favorite ideas, that debate is the basis of having an intellectually challenging environment."
That, Ms. Johnson said, was the environment fostered by her grandfather, who in 1946 established the Fidelity Management and Research Company to provide investment management services to the Fidelity Fund, of which he was president, and the hundreds of other mutual funds that followed.
Ms. Johnson acknowledges that Fidelity's growth in recent years has strained the bonds that have held the company together for 50 years.
"People who don't know each other as well don't feel as comfortable challenging each other," she said. Fully half of the company's 25,000 employees have been at Fidelity for less than three years, and many of its fund managers are in their 20's and 30's.
TO deal with the added strain on fund managers, Mr. Pozen, who was named early last year to head Fidelity's mutual fund division, forged a management team that included Ms. Johnson and two others: Robert A. Lawrence, head of the high-income division, who also oversees the asset allocation funds and is the liaison between fund managers and the trading desk, and Richard A. Spillane Jr., who oversees the international fund managers.
Their job, Mr. Pozen said, is more than to simply make sure that fund managers do not stray from their assigned investment objectives. They also serve as mentors.
Ms. Johnson's method is more gentle prodding than overt direction. "Have you considered . . . ?" begins a typical conversation with a junior fund manager. "One thing I've always found helpful . . . ," she adds.
"I'm trying not to tell them what to do, even though part of me desperately wants to," Ms. Johnson said. "I try to get them to think about prioritizing how they spend their time. They need to figure out the right balance of resources -- Fidelity analysts, maybe a little bit from the sell side. They already know how to pick stocks."
In listing the people who have had a significant influence on her life, Ms. Johnson does not stray outside the walls of Fidelity. "Obviously Peter Lynch had a huge impact on me, as he had a huge impact on everybody who worked for him," she said. "He's got his values clearly thought out, and he's very focused on them. So many of the principles that made us successful came from him." Now a vice chairman of Fidelity, Mr. Lynch quit managing the Magellan fund eight years ago to spend more time with his family.
Ms. Johnson also points to James C. Curvey, Fidelity's chief operating officer, the No. 2 executive at the company. "When I got my first summer job at Fidelity, I talked to Jim Curvey, who was head of human resources, about what I thought I could learn to be good at," she recalled. It has been lost to posterity whether Mr. Curvey told her that if she worked really hard, she could end up running the company. But her career path is certainly an issue that she has discussed with her father -- in broad terms, at least.
"If I ever thought about making a change, of course I talked to him," Ms. Johnson said. "I learned everything I learned early on -- about business, the markets, and a lot of things about life -- from him." Now, she lamented, "he cares more about his granddaughter than about me."
Although she misses the travel in her former job, Ms. Johnson lists one big plus in her new one: being able to spend more time with her family, including 3-year-old Julia. Last spring, shortly after starting her new management job and near the height of the turmoil inside the fund business, Ms. Johnson rushed home many evenings to attend to a task she considered as important as work -- reading to Julia from a children's book about weddings, in preparation for her role as a flower girl in the wedding of Elizabeth Johnson, Abby's 34-year-old sister.
UNTIL recently, Abby was the only one of Ned Johnson's three children to work at Fidelity. Last year, her brother, Edward C. Johnson 4th, who is 33, joined Fidelity's real estate division. Elizabeth Johnson's husband, Robert C. Ketterson Jr., works for Fidelity Capital, a venture capital unit. (Abby Johnson's husband, Christopher J. McKown, is the co-founder of a health care services company.)
Since Julia's birth, Abby Johnson has been less active in local charities. But according to people who know her well, what stood out about Ms. Johnson's outside activities was how little time she spent with groups traditionally associated with the wealthy.
Her parents and siblings are fixtures at art openings and society galas, but Ms. Johnson's volunteer priority was Planned Parenthood.
"Providing basic health care is a pretty important thing," she explained. "I like the idea of supporting something that provides a basic necessity -- one that I take for granted but that not everybody can."
Ms. Johnson has a less serious side, as well, one that manifests itself in subtle ways -- as if she coyly wants to see if you, too, see the humor in something.
Something like Jojo, for example, a three-foot-tall piece of folk sculpture, set on a three-foot pedestal, that adorns one corner of Ms. Johnson's office. Actually titled "Shakey Man," the work, by the Massachusetts artist Pat Keck, is a wildly decorated human figure with flame-red hair, a beaded garment and a peculiar way of gyrating when a handle on the pedestal is pressed.
"When the market gets a little shaky, I like to give him a little shake," she said.
Other symbols here and there could be quiet signals of what Ms. Johnson sees as her role at Fidelity -- for example, the slim volume, "Mastering the Public Spotlight," by the Boston media consultant Arnold Zenker. The book is tucked among the business best sellers on her bookshelf.
The men who are tutoring Ms. Johnson have both her father's ear and their own ideas about how Fidelity must operate in the rapidly changing mutual fund industry. Mr. Johnson himself, of course, will play no small part in the decisions. Notorious for his dislike of publicity, Mr. Johnson declined to be interviewed.
"If he had his druthers, he probably would like to see her take over the company," Mr. Curvey said. "But first he wants her to do what makes her happy. If that is to run this company, he'd be all for it. If that is spending time with her family, he'd say 'fabulous.' "
When Mr. Johnson took over the day-to-day management of Fidelity from his father, there were concerns about whether he had the vision to carry the company, or whether, because of its rapid growth, it would stagnate under its own weight. So it is not surprising that similar worries are raised by outsiders about Ms. Johnson.
Perhaps her toughest obstacle may be that Fidelity -- indeed, the entire Boston-based mutual fund industry, if not most of the financial world -- is dominated by men.
Fidelity's operating committee counts no women among its 13 members. Ms. Johnson is the lone woman on the parent company's six-person board, though Fidelity says 24 percent of those in the company's professional investment ranks are women as well as a smaller portion of its senior executives.
Ms. Johnson says she is not worried. "As a female Fidelity executive, I feel comfortable in saying that our goal is to hire on talent and nothing else," she said.
But Ms. Johnson, of course, is not just hired talent; she is Fidelity born and bred.
"As I said, I'm opportunistic," she said. "For now, I have a challenging job where I can have an impact and maintain some kind of normal life. And I've indicated that I care about some balance and some kind of normalcy in my life."
Beyond that, she said, "I just don't know."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Today's Cars and Drivers Can Grow Old Together

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
JUST a quarter century ago, a car that stayed presentable for 100,000 miles was a marvel. By the time the zeros rolled around again on the odometer, the bodies of most cars were scarred by rust and their engines rattled ominously. And each year, it seemed, Detroit ordered up cosmetic changes that made the previous year's model look ancient.
This, in the view of auto industry critics, was "planned obsolescence," a deliberate strategy to build cars that would quickly fall apart or look old-fashioned, forcing customers to buy new models. Auto executives contend that no such strategy ever existed. 
 But the fact remains that for more than a decade, American automobile makers have been producing much more durable cars. They were forced to do so because Americans were turning by the millions to higher-quality Japanese imports, and because of tougher Federal regulations. Planned obsolescence, if it ever existed, was no longer practical.
A car that once might have been headed for the junk heap at 60,000 miles is now just getting its second wind. Polls show growing public acceptance of used cars as alternatives to new cars. All of which is good news for consumers, but not necessarily for the auto industry.
More cars these days are performing like Paul A. Balinski's white 1989 Ford Mustang GT. Mr. Balinski, a 32-year-old machinery leasing agent in Bridgewater, N.J., has put 230,000 miles on the car and had only one major repair, a new transmission. "The only reason the transmission went is that I bought that car when I was 22 years old and I was a speed freak," he said. "All my friends say that given the way I drive, I'm lucky."
But there may be more than luck involved. Car engines are increasingly designed to last for 150,000 miles, and bodies are now made of highly corrosion-resistant steel. Even the seats have more durable fabrics and leathers that do not show wear as quickly.
The average age of cars on the nation's roads is soaring as a result, increasing by two months each year. According to the Polk Company, which tracks registration data in all 50 states for the nation's 201 million vehicles, the median age of registered cars reached 8.1 years in 1997, a record high.
What is truly remarkable is that the average age of cars is rising during a time of economic growth. Americans used to hold onto their old clunkers during recessions, then trade them in when an improved economy brought them raises and promotions. From 1986 to 1989, when the economy was growing at a brisk clip, the median age of cars on the road fell to 6.5 years from 7 years.
 
Rising Expectations
Cars are lasting longer because Americans increasingly expect their cars to keep running a long time and shun brands that fail to do so. New car buyers expect to be able to resell their purchases within several years for at least half of what they paid, or to pass their cars on in reasonably good shape to teen-agers or friends.
As used cars become more reliable, they no longer carry a penurious stigma. The Dohring Company, a market research business, documented the trend in a survey of car shoppers this winter. Given a choice between a $15,000 new car and an identically priced, 3-year-old used car that cost substantially more when new, 62 percent of the respondents chose the used car. Not surprisingly, sales are plunging for small cars, which typically sell for $15,000 or less.
And used cars are becoming easier to buy and sell, because banks now offer loans for used cars at nearly the same interest rates as for new cars, and are even beginning to offer used car leases.
Some car dealers and bankers have a more disturbing explanation for the recent popularity of used cars. Rising income inequality has left fewer Americans able to afford new cars at all, they say, while the few who can afford new cars are choosing more expensive models fully loaded with options. Market researchers say that the most affluent third of the population, whose inflation-adjusted incomes have been rising steadily, now account for a huge and growing share of new vehicle purchases.
These affluent buyers increasingly demand compact disk changers, powerful engines and other amenities. So when dealers fill in their factory order forms to stock their showrooms, they ask for cars with every possible option, even though this makes the cars less affordable.
"It's bizarre. When I order now, I check every box because I'll find someone to buy it," said Daniel Rudolph, a Buick and GMC dealer in Lewiston, Idaho. "In my area, I see a gap opening between the haves and the have-nots. The middle class is kind of disappearing."
 
A Two-Edged Sword
Consumers may be delighted with the greater reliability and appeal of used cars. But for auto makers, it is a two-edged sword. Sales in the United States peaked during the last economic expansion at 16 million cars and light trucks in 1986. But even with very low unemployment, sales have been stuck for the last four years at a strong but steady 15 million vehicles.
The quiet, seldom-voiced worry in the auto industry involves what will happen during the next recession. With many Americans already holding onto their cars so much longer during good times, no one knows how long people will keep driving their cars during bad times.

HEADLINE: The Nation: The Antitrust Dilemma;
Smokestack Doctrine, Digital Age

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
TO the digitally fluent of Silicon Valley, the heartland of America's high-tech economy, the Government's antitrust battle with the Microsoft Corporation has become known, half-jokingly, as "our O. J. trial"-- a high-profile, high-stakes case whose outcome will surely be divisive, whether for or against Microsoft.
The Microsoft case, then, seems destined to fit neatly into the rich tradition of national ambivalence about the doctrine of antitrust. For more than a century, the antitrust laws have been an uneasy compromise between two American values, populism and capitalism. 
 The Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890 was passed in response to worries about the power of the industrial trusts built around the essential business network of the day -- the railways. Opponents warned darkly that the act would legitimize "fearful assaults on capital." Even supporters moved cautiously, producing a law of less than 200 words that, in broad language, prohibits anticompetitive agreements and the abuse of monopoly power.
The Sherman Act and the Clayton Act of 1914, which bans anticompetitive mergers and some predatory tactics like discriminatory pricing contracts, remain the foundation of the nation's antitrust policy. The Microsoft case, begun last October, has started a wide-ranging debate over how the smokestack doctrine of antitrust applies -- or should not apply -- to the information-age fields of computing and the Internet.
Adapting the laws of antitrust to the digital age will be a challenge. Traditionally, the focus of antitrust enforcement by the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission had been to look for a dominant company in a business engaging in raising prices, the surest evidence of monopolistic abuse.
 
A Natural Evolution
But the old rules do not apply so cleanly to high-tech industries like computer software. Recent economic analysis suggests that software markets often evolve naturally toward monopoly. Consumers and suppliers sometimes prefer the efficiency of learning a single industry-standard technology, which one company may own. Once established, the dominant producer benefits from what economists call "network effects" -- meaning a product or service becomes more valuable the more people use it.
So a high market share, even 80 percent or more, is not necessarily a flashing red light to antitrust police. More telling is that prices in the information industries, after adjusting for performance improvements, are generally falling. So there is scant evidence of monopolistic abuse in pricing, the simplest barometer of consumer welfare.
In Washington, the Justice Department and trade commission officials concede that the context may have changed, but they insist that the antitrust issues in the high-tech arena are not new. "There is an accumulation of market power in some of these industries that would be the envy of John D. Rockefeller," observed Robert Pitofsky, chairman of the commission.
In the high-tech field, the antitrust agencies are focusing mainly on two related issues: the use, and possible abuse, of market power as a dominant company in one market moves into a new market; and ways to insure that there is a competitive market for innovation in new businesses.
"We want to make sure that innovation thrives because innovation is the greatest stimulant to economic development in these industries," said Joel I. Klein, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division. "You want an environment where entrepreneurs believe that they can be the next Microsoft."
Such reasoning led the Justice Department to sue Microsoft last fall. The case, in some ways, is a narrow contract dispute, but it has opened the door to the larger debate over antitrust policy. The Justice Department sued Microsoft for allegedly violating its 1995 antitrust consent decree with the Government by forcing personal computer makers to install its Internet Explorer browser as a condition of licensing its Windows operating system, the industry standard.
The consent decree prohibits Microsoft from tying the purchase of one product to another -- precisely, the Justice Department asserts, what Microsoft is doing with its licensing of Explorer and Windows. Microsoft contends that Explorer is not a separate product, but merely a "feature" of Windows.
A Federal judge in December ordered Microsoft to temporarily offer PC makers the choice of installing Windows without its Explorer browser. Microsoft said it could not be done, but eventually offered PC makers the alternative of stripping off the Explorer icon from Windows. Microsoft is appealing. The company says that if the Government wins, it will be a step on the road to Government meddling in the software industry.
The Justice Department insists that Microsoft should be free to become bigger and richer, and vanquish rivals in the process. But, the Department adds, it should not be allowed to use its operating-system monopoly to gain an unfair advantage in the new market of Internet software. The stakes are high, the Government insists, because much of commerce will soon be conducted over the Internet. The Justice Department is also considering a broader suit against Microsoft under the Sherman Act, but it has not decided whether to go ahead.
 
A Threatening Innovation
Yet even the consent-decree case points to the thorny issues facing the Government and the courts as they weigh complex matters of efficiency, market power and consumer welfare. From the internal Microsoft memos presented to the court, it is clear that the company saw the leader in browser software, the Netscape Communications Corporation, as a threat to Microsoft's lucrative operating system business. That is because Netscape's browser could replace Windows as the first screen people see.
So Microsoft, in short, chose to make a potentially threatening innovation a free "feature" of its operating system. To some, the tactic was a powerful display of how Microsoft deploys the market power of its Windows monopoly. That could become an issue only in a broader Sherman Act case. Yet Microsoft would be able to marshal some forceful arguments in its defense. The Sherman Act deals with the intent as well as the effect of market behavior. Microsoft would surely say that while the effect of its strategy may be to harm rivals and reduce competition, its intent has been to improve Windows, generating an efficiency gain for its product and consumers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator John Sherman, author of the antitrust act. (Brown Brothers)
 
Chart: "Monopoly Not"
The text of the Sherman Antitrust Act. Penalties have been increased over the years by a series of amendments. In 1890, when it was written, the maximum penalty for criminal violation was $5,000 and one year in jail.
 Section 1 -- Every contract, combination in the form of trust or otherwise, or conspiracy, in restraint of trade or commerce among the several States, or with foreign nations, is declared to be illegal. Every person who shall make any contract or engage in any combination or conspiracy hereby declared to be illegal shall be deemed guilty of a felony, and, on conviction thereof, shall be punished by fine not exceeding ten million dollars if a corporation, or, if any other person, three hundred and fifty thousand dollars, or by imprisonment not exceeding three years, or by both said punishments, in the discretion of the court.
 Section 2 -- Every person who shall monopolize, or attempt to monopolize, or combine or conspire with any other person or persons, to monopolize any part of the trade or commerce among the several States, or with foreign nations, shall be deemed guilty of a felony, and, on conviction thereof, shall be punished by fine not exceeding ten million dollars if a corporation, or, if any other person, three hundred and fifty thousand dollars or by imprisonment not exceeding three years, or by both said punishments, in the discretion of the court.

HEADLINE: Auto-Lease Disclosure: Simplicity, Please

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Small Print Becomes Large in the New Car and Truck Leases" (Spending It, Jan. 25), which noted new Federal disclosure rules: 
 While some of the new requirements will be useful to consumers, the regulations as a whole, unfortunately, go in the wrong direction. Disclosure to consumers is fundamentally different from disclosure to government bodies or to investment professionals. The latter type of disclosure should provide as much detail as possible, under the assumption that economists, accountants and finance professionals can use the information to piece together a better picture. Consumers, on the other hand, generally do not have the time, expertise, or inclination to do such calculations. The disclosure statement should do it for them.
The new disclosure requirements on leasing include terms like "Depreciation and any amortized amounts," "Rent charge" and "Total of base monthly payments." While the form tries to explain these terms, they still carry little meaning to the average consumer and are not of much use for more sophisticated buyers, either.
A lease disclosure should be shorter. It should contain only a few important numbers. Consumers need to know the value of the vehicle (preferably the latest transaction price), the amount to be paid up front, the monthly payment on the lease and the best estimate of the true market value of such a vehicle at the end of the lease. This estimate can be based on the value of a similar used car in the so-called blue book.
These numbers and an appropriate interest rate are sufficient to provide accurate financial comparisons among all possible transactions. One can compare buying and leasing a given vehicle, different leases for the same vehicle, leases on different vehicles or buying one vehicle and leasing another.
 
S. ABRAHAM RAVID
Manhattan, Jan. 28
 
The writer is a finance professor at Rutgers University and at New York University's Stern School of Business.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: BY PATRICK J. LYONS

 BODY:

INDONESIA
A Flight to Rigor
When in dire straits, don a straitjacket. That seems to be the thinking in Indonesia, where a proposal to peg the value of the badly battered rupiah to the dollar is gathering momentum. Instead of relying on interest rates and central bank intervention to defend the rupiah's value, the plan, called a currency board, would require that every rupiah in circulation be backed by dollars or other foreign exchange kept on deposit in the board's reserves. The method has been used successfully in Hong Kong and elsewhere, but the International Monetary Fund called Indonesia's plan premature, worrying that it would deny the country the flexibility it needs to work its way out of economic trouble. 

SOUTH KOREA
Belabored
South Korea's President-elect, Kim Dae Jung, thought he had a groundbreaking deal with the country's unions to legalize layoffs and inject some flexibility into a smotheringly rigid labor market. Then the deal teetered unexpectedly when a militant labor federation demanded a renegotiation and promised a general strike if it was ignored. Just as suddenly, the federation called off the threatened strike a day later, ostensibly on patriotic grounds. Analysts saw the episode as a warning shot across Mr. Kim's bow; investors were rattled and bid down Korean stocks, swamping the effect of progress on debt rescheduling announced earlier in the week.
 
OWNERSHIP
Whose Rock Is It?
Prudential Insurance can't help but make headlines. With hope that the effects of expensive scandals over dodgy sales practices in its life insurance and securities arms are behind it, the giant insurer made noises last week about going public. Since 1943, the company has been owned mutually by its policyholders, an arrangement that makes it a little harder for the company to raise capital for expansion and a lot harder for top executives to build fortunes for themselves. With $179 billion in assets, Prudential would be by far the biggest company ever to demutualize, and the deal would require a new law in New Jersey, Prudential's home state -- not much of an obstacle, analysts say, considering the company's local influence. Prudential executives, vowing to avoid the egregious examples of some past insurance company conversions, promised that insiders and investment bankers would not cart away big slabs of The Rock, leaving policyholders with gravel.
 
MERGERS
Buy, Buy, Buy
Billion-dollar mergers are getting to be a dime a dozen. CVS, the No. 1 drugstore chain, agreed to buy No. 10, Arbor Drugs, for $1.48 billion. In the water treatment business, United States Filter will swap $1.5 billion in stock for Culligan Water Technologies of "hey, Culligan man" fame. The Canadian National Railway agreed to acquire the Illinois Central Corporation for $2.4 billion, drawing a "T" in railroad tracks across the continent from Nova Scotia to Vancouver and Winnipeg to New Orleans. But the serious money of the week came from Long Island's largest employer, the software giant Computer Associates, which made an uninvited $8.4 billion cash bid for Computer Sciences, a Southern California provider of technology services.
 
NEST EGGS
Betting the House
For the first time in decades, the average American household has more of its wealth invested in stocks than in real estate. An analysis of the latest Federal Reserve figures, for the third quarter of 1997, showed that equities make up 28 percent of household wealth, more than double the levels of 1990 or in the period just before the 1987 market crash. Real estate accounts for only 27 percent. Families, which are richer than ever before, are holding much less in cash than they did seven years ago, down from 17 percent to only 12 percent of household wealth. But Americans also appear to be resting on their laurels. Commerce Department figures released last week showed that Americans saved only 3.8 percent of their disposable income last year, the least since before World War II.
 
STOCKS
About Time
A year ago, the Dow Jones industrial average was way ahead of the overall market. Now it's behind. But investors and the news media still treat it like a lodestar. The Dow finally fought its way back last week to the record heights of last August, regaining all the ground it lost in the October market plunge. Most of its buoyancy has come from just a few members, like AT&T, which has soared more than 50 percent since Aug. 6; many of the rest have been stinkers, dragging the index's performance down south of broader measures like the Standard & Poor's 500 and the New York Stock Exchange composite, both of which matched their preplunge highs in December. Smaller stocks have also been lagging. Neither the Nasdaq composite nor the Russell 2000 has yet regained its preplunge high.
 
TRUCKS
Seeing Other Dangers
Auto insurers are beginning to look beyond a vehicle's occupants when judging safety hazards, and when it comes to light trucks, they don't like what they see. Concluding that pickups and sport utility vehicles pose much greater risks to other drivers than cars do, but don't keep their own occupants a whole lot safer, a group of insurance companies called for major design changes. At the other end of the weight spectrum, the Environmental Protection Agency accused makers of heavy truck engines of designing them to run cleanly during emissions tests but filthily (and thus more cheaply) on the highway. Even when they meet Government standards, heavy trucks generate more than 15 times as much nitrogen oxide air pollution as cars do, vehicle for vehicle.
 
ANALYTICS
Mum's the Word
Macy's didn't tell Gimbels, and Bloomberg L.P. certainly didn't want to share trade secrets with its archrival, Reuters Holdings. Is that a reasonable attitude? Lawyers for Reuters are considering arguing that Bloomberg's standard subscription contract, which obliges customers to keep Bloomberg's secrets secret, is "unreasonable" and thus invalid. This matters to Reuters because one of its subsidiaries has been accused of a bit of skulduggery in its scramble to compete with Bloomberg's highly successful specialty computer terminals for market analysts and traders. The Government is investigating whether Reuters had a consultant subscribe to the Bloomberg service and then pass along data so Reuters could "reverse engineer" Bloomberg's system and replicate its abilities. Reuters isn't admitting anything but allows that such a thing is "possible."
 
TRENDS
Pastryfaced
Twice in eight days, cream pies have found their way into the surprised faces of high-profile chief executives, but for very different reasons. Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, was hit on Feb. 4 in Belgium, apparently by professionals. Microsoft attributed the splat to accomplices of a certain Noel Godin, who makes a living selling videotape of the famous, messy and nonplused to television. By contrast, Thursday's pieing of the Procter & Gamble chairman, John E. Pepper, at an awards banquet in Columbus, Ohio, was the work of an activist protesting P. & G.'s use of live animals in product testing. Mr. Gates's incoming confection was a tasty but fattening Belgian custard; Mr. Pepper got a more politically correct tofu cream, presumably not made with Olestra.

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMING

 BODY:

MONDAY
Presidents' Day holiday. Financial markets and institutions in the United States are closed. 

TUESDAY
Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim and LJR Redbook Research report on weekly retail sales.
The Commerce Department reports industrial production and capacity utilization for January. Analysts expect production to rise by 0.3 percent and factories to be operating at 83.3 percent of capacity, a slight decline from December.
 
WEDNESDAY
The Commerce Department reports the Producer Price Index for January. Analysts expect the index to decline 0.2 percent, the same amount it fell in December; the core index, which excludes the volatile food and energy sectors, is expected to be unchanged from December.
The Commerce Department reports housing starts for January; analysts expect an annual rate of 1,536,000, an increase of 17,000 from December.
 
THURSDAY
The Labor Department reports initial claims for unemployment insurance for the week; analysts expect 305,000, an increase of 2,000 from the previous week.
The Commerce Department reports the merchandise trade balance for December; analysts expect a deficit of $8.8 billion, up from $8 billion in November.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia issues its monthly business outlook survey of manufacturers in its region. Analysts expect companies reporting improving business conditions to outnumber those reporting deterioration by 12.6 percentage points, down from 17.3 points in January.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: POLICY;
U.S. Builds Its Case on Shifting Assertions

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

 BODY:
Last November, after Saddam Hussein allowed United Nations weapons inspectors to return to Iraq, President Clinton made clear just how crucial their work was for global security.
"They must be able to proceed with their work without interference, to find, to destroy, to prevent Iraq from rebuilding nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and the missiles to carry them," he said in a speech at the White House on Nov. 21. 
 But once again, Mr. Hussein has blocked the weapons inspectors from doing that. And on Friday, Mr. Clinton described a far more modest goal.
"What we want to do is to significantly diminish the capacity of the Iraqis to reconstitute, to develop, to deploy their weapons of mass destruction, and to threaten their neighbors," he said.
As the United States moves closer to military action against Iraq, Mr. Clinton and his national security team have shifted from the sweeping language of what they would like to do, voicing a more sober appraisal of what they believe they can do if they start dropping bombs.
On Friday, he and his aides began a campaign to prepare Americans for an air campaign that they say will involve the death of Iraqi civilians and even of American service people. In the process, they are struggling to refine their message.
"The closer you get to a military option," said the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, "the more precise the language must be so that Americans can understand the mission."
Not since the buildup to the American-led war to drive Iraq out of Kuwait seven years ago have American officials waged such an anguished and lengthy effort to prepare the country and the world for the use of force.
But the often inconsistent public statements over recent months on the goals of American policy toward Iraq have left Congress, the American public and even officials within the Administration confused.
Mr. Clinton and his aides know that they will be judged on the basis of whether they succeed in the military mission they set for themselves in public. If people are killed on both sides but there is no visible success, the Administration will face the question: What was the point?
But thus far, by its own admission, the Administration has been unable to make its political and military goals understandable.
In an acknowledgment that the stakes -- and the risks -- of the policy need to be explained better, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen and President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, will conduct an unusual town meeting at Ohio State University in Columbus on Wednesday, to "talk to the American people."
The meeting will follow remarks Mr. Clinton is to make at the Pentagon on Tuesday after he receives a briefing on the military planning. One White House official described his remarks as an address to the American people.
The White House is getting so many questions from Congress and reporters about imprecise goals that it is compiling a record of all public statements on the Iraq crisis as a first step toward articulating a consistent line, a White House official said. Two weeks ago the Administration distributed written "talking points" for all officials who have to speak publicly about Iraq.
Congress seems particularly confused about what the endgame is, and in some cases it questions the value of bombing at all unless the purpose is to get rid of Mr. Hussein. The Administration's position is that achieving that militarily is infeasible and assassinating him is illegal.
Senator Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who heads the Appropriations Committee, which will ultimately decide whether to finance a military operation in Iraq, expressed the frustration of many of his colleagues when he said early last week: "We want a better understanding of what the objective of all this is. That is not clear."
Even some senior and midlevel Administration officials who deal with Iraq in the White House, Pentagon, State Department and intelligence community have expressed frustration that the Administration has not done a consistent enough job explaining the policy.
At one point last November, Mr. Clinton said that the United States would not allow economic sanctions against Iraq to be lifted until Mr. Hussein was out of power, a statement that went beyond United Nations resolutions and stated American policy, and had to be rolled back.
During a news conference with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain on Feb. 6, Mr. Clinton said that the goal of military action was to "substantially reduce or delay" Iraq's ability to develop and use nonconventional weapons. But he left out the crucial second part of the formula, "to limit his ability to threaten his neighbors," which is diplomatic code for striking at conventional military targets as well.
"His answer was not as thorough as it could have been," said one White House official of the President's remark.
On other occasions, midlevel spokesmen have suggested that Mr. Hussein's weapons of mass destruction had to be "eliminated," which White House officials have called an unfortunate word choice.
Part of the difficulty is that the diplomatic and military goals are not identical, and Administration officials sometimes have not distinguished between them. Lawmakers complain not that they cannot get Cabinet-level officials to brief them, but that the officials are talking too much and not all with the same words.
"Different people required to speak publicly have been saying things in their own way," Mr. McCurry said. "The task has been to lock in one formula."
Another White House official put it less diplomatically. "The criticisms are correct," he said. "We don't have a clear, explainable objective like getting Saddam out of Kuwait. Some people are saying we are walking things back. It's more that there's been sloppy speech."
If the United States had its way, diplomacy would prevail. The inspectors would return to Iraq with unrestricted access to all potential weapons sites and carry out a 1991 Security Council resolution that empowers them to destroy all of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction and forbids Iraq from ever developing them again.
When Mr. Clinton laid out "what's at stake" last Nov. 17, he said it was "essential that those inspectors go back to work."
"The children of the world depend on it," he said.
But military planners have made clear that bombs will not necessarily accomplish that. And there is a growing consensus throughout the Administration that the inspectors may never return. Mr. Clinton suggested as much when he said at his Feb. 6 news conference -- twice -- that the inspection regime may be "dead."
Even the limited military goal of substantially reducing or delaying Mr. Hussein's ability to rebuild his chemical and biological weapons arsenal may be overly ambitious. Last November, Gen. Anthony Zinni, the commander in charge of the Persian Gulf, acknowledged at a briefing at the Pentagon that "there is a lot not known about his weapons of mass destruction capability." He added, "I certainly do not feel we have a good sense of what he has."
And Defense Secretary Cohen acknowledged in a hearing with the Senate Armed Services Committee on Feb. 3 that when it comes to Iraq's chemical and biological weapons, "you can reconstitute them in a fairly short period of time."
Those statements complicate the Administration's task in explaining why military action that could result in substantial civilian casualties in Iraq and the death of Americans in uniform is worth it.

HEADLINE: Using Gifts as Bait, Peru Sterilizes Poor Women

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 14

 BODY:
For Magna Morales and Bernadina Alva, peasant Andean women who could barely afford to feed their families, it was a troubling offer but one they found hard to refuse. Shortly before Christmas, Government health workers promised gifts of food and clothing if they underwent a sterilization procedure called tubal ligation.
The operation went well for Mrs. Alva, 26, who received two dresses for her daughter and a T-shirt for her son. But Mrs. Morales, 34, died of complications 10 days after the surgery, leaving three young children and a husband behind. She was never well enough to pick up the promised gifts, and the family was told it could not sue the Government over her death because she had agreed to the procedure. 
 "When you don't have anything and they offer you clothes and food for your kids, then finally you agree to do it," said Mrs. Alva, a neighbor of Mrs. Morales in the northern village of Tocache. "Magna told them that her husband was against the idea, but they told her, 'Don't worry, we can do it right now, and tonight you will be back home cooking and your husband will never realize what happened.' "
Tales of poor women like Mrs. Morales and Mrs. Alva being pressed and even forced to submit to sterilization operations that have left at least two women dead and hundreds injured have emerged from small towns and villages across Peru in recent weeks in what women's groups, politicians and church leaders here say is an ambitious Government family planning program run amok.
Critics of the program, which was begun in 1995, charge that state health care workers, in a hurry to meet Government-imposed sterilization quotas that offer promotions and cash incentives, are taking advantage of poor rural women, many of whom are illiterate and speak only indigenous Indian languages.
The critics, who include many of the program's early supporters, say the health workers are not telling poor women about alternative methods of contraception or that tubal ligation is nearly always irreversible. They also charge that many state doctors are performing sloppy operations, at times in unsanitary conditions.
"They always look for the poorest women, especially those who don't understand Spanish," said Gregoria Chuquihuancas, another Tocache resident. "They make them put their fingerprint on a sterilization paper they don't understand because they can't read. If the women refuse, they threaten to cut off the food and milk programs."
While it remains unclear whether such actions were sanctioned by the Government or were the work of overzealous health workers -- the Government denies there are sterilization quotas, though it acknowledges goals for budgetary purposes -- independent investigations by members of the Peruvian Congress, the Roman Catholic Church, local journalists and a United States Congressional committee have chronicled dozens of cases of abuse.
"The Government's program is morally corrupt because nurses and doctors are under pressure to find women to sterilize, and the women are not allowed to make an informed decision," said Luis Solari, a medical doctor who advises the Peruvian Episcopal Conference, which speaks for the country's Catholic bishops.
"No one has the right to intervene in people's life this way," Dr. Solari said. "It's criminal."
From its inception, Catholic church leaders have vigorously opposed the family planning campaign because it promotes artificial forms of birth control, which the church disavows. Augusto Cardinal Vargas Alzamora of Lima has warned Catholics that they will be committing a "grave sin" if they resort to sterilization. Tubal ligation is still only the third most practiced form of contraception in Peru, after abstinence and the I.U.D., family planning officials say. Abortion is illegal.
The Government has vehemently rejected charges that it is conducting a campaign to sterilize poor women and says that all its sterilization operations are done with the patient's consent, as required by law.
Health Ministry officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that in the last year the program had suffered from "lapses in judgment" by individual health care workers and doctors, who had been reprimanded. But the officials said that such cases were isolated incidents that had been blown out of proportion.
Reached on his cellular telephone, Deputy Health Minister Alejandro Aguinaga, who oversees the program, said he did not wish to speak with The New York Times.
Three years ago, when President Alberto K. Fujimori announced plans to promote birth control as a way to reduce family size and widespread poverty in Peru, family planning experts, feminists and even many opposition politicians expressed broad support for the initiative. But the mounting criticism of the sterilizations has tarnished the image of the family planning program, one of the most ambitious in the developing world.
In 1997, state doctors in Peru performed 110,000 sterilizations on women, up from 30,000 in 1996 and 10,000 in 1995. Last year they also performed 10,000 free vasectomies on men, a slight increase over 1996. However, women remain the main focus of the Government's program because men are less likely to agree to sterilization, on the mistaken ground that the procedure could impair their virility.
Health Ministry officials estimate that the 1997 sterilizations will result in 26,000 fewer births in 1998. This is good news, they say, in a country where the fertility rate -- the average number of children born per woman -- is 3.5, compared with 3.1 for Latin America in general and 2 for the United States.
The rate is 6.2 children for Peruvian women who have little or no education and 7 children for those who live in rural areas. That compares with a rate of 1.7 children for women who have at least some college education and 2.8 for urban residents of all educational levels.
Concern over reports of forced sterilization has led to an investigation by the United States Congressional Subcommittee on International and Human Rights Operations, which is seeking to determine if money from the United States Agency for International Development was used in the Peruvian Government's campaign.
Officials in Washington said in a telephone interview that the agency had no role in the Peruvian Government's family planning program. They said that money and training for family planning services went directly to nongovernmental agencies in Peru that have no connection with the Government's program.
The officials said that they had deliberately taken steps to disassociate the agency from the Peruvian Government's family planning program after it became clear that, while well intentioned, it was too hurried and ambitious to avoid the pitfalls that it has now encountered.
Joseph Rees, the subcommittee's chief council, said that after a recent fact-finding mission to Peru he was convinced that no United States money was directly used to finance the Peruvian Government's campaign.
But he expressed concern that some money may have trickled through in the form of infrastructure, management or training support. Because some United States-sponsored food programs are operated from the same Peruvian Government medical posts that administer family planning in rural areas, Mr. Rees said that it was possible that some of this food could have been used to bribe women to undergo sterilizations.
"The bottom line here is whether the Peruvian Government is more interested in doing family planning or population control and whether the United States wants to risk being associated with a program where that notion is so far unclear," Mr. Rees said.
Meanwhile, despite the reported abuses, the number of women undergoing sterilizations in Peru has remained steady. Preliminary figures for January indicate that at least 10,000 women underwent free tubal ligations by state doctors.
The opposition Renovacion Party, a conservative group that has always objected to the program, says it has collected more than 1,000 complaints from women who say they were either injured by Government sterilization or pressured into agreeing to the operation.
Arturo Salazar, a Renovacion congressman, said the Fujimori Government had given no thought to the long-term effect of so many sterilizations, which if left unchecked, he said, will severely diminish Peru's rural population, deprive the nation of security on its frontiers and impede economic development in the countryside.
But those issues are of little concern to Martha Eras, also of Tocache, who is struggling to care for her new baby girl, who was born in August despite the Government-sponsored sterilization that Mrs. Eras voluntarily underwent eight months earlier. It appears that the doctor was in such a hurry that he did not check to see if Mrs. Eras was pregnant.
"My husband joked that it was immaculate conception," she said.

HEADLINE: Capitol Hill Looks At Issue Of Art Stolen In Wartime

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Members of the House Banking Committee put aside their normal concern for monetary policy and deposit insurance today and turned their attention instead to the plundering of art during World War II -- and what to do about it now.
The unusual hearing, which included the rare appearance on Capitol Hill of the directors of four top art museums, marked a new stage in Congressional efforts to help victims of the Holocaust and their heirs win restitution for lost property. Until now, the efforts had focused primarily on gold, dormant bank accounts and insurance. 
 Experts have estimated that hundreds to tens of thousands of works of art looted during the Nazi reign in Europe remain unidentified and in the hands of museums, dealers and collectors around the world. In recent months, a handful of ownership claims have been lodged for art works in against American museums.
But James N. Wood, director of the Art Institute of Chicago, told committee members that the problem was "one of the most pressing and difficult questions facing American art museums today."
With the recent opening of wartime archives in the United States and Europe and the publication of books on looted art, more claims are expected. Many will be difficult to assess, given the lack of records and the time gap since the Third Reich began its effort to eradicate Jews in the 1930's.
Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said that a new Association of Art Museum Directors' study group, which he leads, would establish guidelines and procedures to help museums deal with claims.
Mr. Wood, Mr. de Montebello and their colleagues from the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the National Gallery of Art in Washington all said that they were continuing to investigate the ownership of works in the collections of their museums.
Although none of the witnesses who testified before the House Banking Committee saw a need for legislation, some suggested ways Congress could help.
Gilbert S. Edelson, the administrative vice president and counsel of the Art Dealers Association of America, pleaded for the unification, or at the least, coordination of groups doing research on lost art, including the World Jewish Congress and the B'nai B'rith Klutznick National Jewish Museum in Washington.
"We should do now what should have been done many years ago," he said. "There should be a central registry and database where claims for the recovery of looted works could be registered, kept on file and where the information would be made available to all interested parties."
Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn said that he and his fellow Democratic Representative from New York, Nita M. Lowey of Rye, planned to introduce legislation to provide $5 million to private organizations helping families trace their losses and $5 million for checking the provenance of Federal art holdings. Their bill would also require anyone who purchased art, including museums, to do a reasonable title search.
In written testimony, Ronald S. Lauder, chairman of the World Jewish Congress's new Commission for Art Recovery, called for the declassification of additional wartime archives. "We need to press other nations to do the same," he added.
Several witnesses also said that international discussions of some type would be useful, largely because European law generally differs from American law in one crucial aspect: In the United States, no one can purchase good title for a stolen piece of art, no matter how many times it changed hands after the theft; in Europe, good-faith purchasers do obtain a clear title.
The purpose of the hearing was less to develop legislation than to raise public consciousness about the problem of stolen art, said Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who heads the committee.
"We need, it seems to me, new structures to come to grips with this problem," Mr. Leach said. "New databases, new clusters of experts, new international covenants."
Mr. Wood, Mr. de Montebello and their colleagues from the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the National Gallery of Art in Washington all said they were continuing to investigate the ownership of works in the collections of their museums.
But despite a consensus in the hearing room to develop some mechanism to resolve ownership claims outside the court system, none of the witnesses had an answer to the major questions of the day, which were asked repeatedly by Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, Democrat of Manhattan: "Who do you see deciding the standards of proof and who will determine whether those standards are met? And who will be the adjudicator and how can we enforce a standard in other countries?"
