HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Five Hotels This Side of the Ritz

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
"I HAD sounded my pocket, and only brought up a few pieces of silver, -- So . . . said I to myself, . . . wherever in your wisdom you may conclude to lodge for the night . . . be sure to inquire the price, and don't be too particular."
The words are those of Ishmael in Herman Melville's "Moby Dick." Call him a budget traveler. 
 Not so long ago, he'd have needed a sea chest of silver had he been looking for accommodations in New York, where the average room rate topped $200 for the first time last September. Prices have been creeping up at old budget chestnuts, too, with doubles for $120 at the Hotel Edison near Times Square, $125 at the Washington Square Hotel and $160 at the Chelsea -- where today, destitute punk rockers like Sid Vicious and Nancy Spungen could never afford to stay.
To contend with high rates, some travelers hunt for midwinter and weekend specials at moderately priced hotels, or they contact discounters like Quickbook, which offered me a $125 room at the Ameritania on Broadway for $99 in late December. Others gravitate to one of the city's three Y.M.C.A. hotels, where rooms start at $43, or check in at the 480-bed hostel on upper Amsterdam Avenue, where 85 percent of the guests are young foreigners and bunks in clean, Spartan dorms start at $22.
But because tourism in New York City is booming, new hotels are springing up everywhere, with plans for about 30 more by the year 2000. Most are in the luxury and moderate categories, but some are modeled on the cheap hotels of European capitals, where the concept of budget travel has long been understood.
In Paris or Rome, such places may be old and shabby, or modern and characterless with constricted cookie-cutter rooms. You'd be wasting your breath to ask for amenities like room service, free toiletries, health clubs and porters. But the rates rarely top $100 a night, and you don't have to sleep in your clothes, standing up.
In late December, I stayed in five of Manhattan's newer economy-class hotels, and toured many more. I sought places with rates for doubles starting near $100, which is why I had to cross off my list a few attractive but slightly higher-priced properties like the Mayfair, near Times Square, and the Best Western Seaport Inn in lower Manhattan. And while I'd have stayed at the tidy pension-style Larchmont Hotel in Greenwich Village in a flash, its 56 rooms have shared baths and toilets. So it seemed unfair to compare it to my other choices, which all offered private baths.
I wasn't expecting all the comforts of my Manhattan apartment -- just a clean, safe, affordable place to spend the night. Which is why the 102-room Gershwin Hotel, which opened in 1993 on East 27th Street, a block north of Madison Square Park, seemed like such a plum.
The digs are basic. But someone there has a sense of style, eking authentic minimalistic fun out of budget trappings, with huge fluted sconces framing the front door, little Andy Warhols and Roy Lichtensteins in the lobby, a floor of dorms for models, and a back room used for screenings, fashion shoots, private parties and auditions.
I arrived three hours before check-in and could have killed time by reading for a role in a movie called "Body Parts," discussing sightseeing options with the gamin at the concierge desk, having coffee in the downstairs cafe, or getting quietly soused in the pocket bar off the lobby with a young hipster from Australia. But the harried front-desk clerk found me something right away and sent me up in the elevator to a moderate-size, irregularly shaped $80 room at the front on the fifth floor. Honking horns blared from a bay window, shrouded in Hitchcockesque Venetian blinds.
The room had a freshly renovated air and a retro color scheme -- greenish carpeting, yellow walls and olive molding. The bathroom was clean but a tight squeeze, with a tiled shower, sink, toilet, soap, two plastic cups wrapped in cellophane and big green towels unaccompanied by washcloths. I didn't bother to call for washcloths because in my experience, their absence is the hallmark of a true budget hotel.
The room seemed reasonably secure, but was sparsely furnished with a double bed covered by a faded paisley spread, two plastic chairs and a cafe table, a TV affixed high on the wall hospital style, and a bedside table with a Princess phone. I tried to make a call, but couldn't get an outside line, and then rang the front desk for instructions. After that, the phone stopped working altogether. Though I was promised a replacement, it never came.
The R train stops two blocks west of the Gershwin, and there are buses on Fifth and Madison Avenues. But I was happy to stay put, because the once-dreary neighborhood around the hotel now has trendy restaurants like Asia de Cuba, the Globe and Joanie's. You can shop for bargains a few blocks downtown at Daffy's and Filene's, visit the flea market down the Avenue of the Americas on the weekend, or head up Madison to check out Robert Redford's class picture at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, between 30th and 31st Streets.

 THERE'S nothing chic about the 100-room Quality Hotel Eastside, in a brick building at Lexington Avenue and 30th Street, at the foot of Murray Hill. But I found a modicum of middle-American-style comfort, a surprising number of amenities and ersatz Early American furnishings to boot.
The place is part of a plucky little chain called Apple Core Hotels, which has converted two other midtown buildings and plans to open a fourth hotel on West 46th Street in March. The rates for Apple Core hotels were listed as starting at $109 but I paid $99 for a small double at the Quality Eastside.
Buses head downtown on Lexington Avenue, and the 28th Street stop of the No. 6 train is a five-minute walk away. To the north, Grand Central Terminal is within striking distance and the Chrysler Building's silver pinnacle looms. Otherwise, the neighborhood is fairly undistinguished, except for a great Viennese pastry shop called Chez le Chef and an abundance of Indian restaurants with cheap lunch specials.
But the spiffy awning out front at the Quality Eastside bodes well, leading to a cafe (where the waitress doubles as the concierge). The lobby beyond has built-in bookcases, trompe l'oeil arbors painted on the ceiling, a big front desk, two elevators and a porter. In the basement, there's a tiny workout room and business center with computers, fax and copier. I never saw another guest, which made me feel slightly unnerved, but the nice receptionist knew exactly where to send me for chicken curry -- $5.95 at the Joy of India, just off Lexington Avenue on East 29th Street.
The most impressive features in my chamber on the fifth floor were the hair dryer and coffee maker in the tiny but spotlessly clean bath, the iron and ironing board in the roomy closet, and the remote-controlled TV with cable and a premium movie channel. The room had a queen bed with a blue spread and pencil post headboard, a duck decoy border and a calico-curtained window. Still, a general lack of warmth and slightly funky smell in the hall kept it from evoking the Ethan Allen catalogue.
Oddly, I felt more at home at the 144-room Portland Square Hotel in the thick of midtown, on West 47th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue. That's because it is a true bare-bones budget spot, like so many of the places where I've stayed in Europe.
Don't let the Portland's handsomely renovated red brick facade and Greek Revival porte-cochere fool you. Inside, the lobby is Pepto-Bismol pink, decorated with security monitors and lockers. There, clusters of young foreigners debate in French and Italian how to divide the bill. The front desk is behind glass, recalling a sleazy liquor store's checkout counter. And I wouldn't be inclined to book a shared-bath room in the west wing, where the toilets looked none too clean and someone had been smoking in the hall.
But I did well enough in a double ($80 for one, or $94 for two) at the back on the second floor of the east wing. The door had two locks and the chamber's quietude was tomblike. The attached bath was quite clean and bigger than a few rooms I've paid $80 to sleep in.
The forest green carpeting looked new, there was a safe beneath the built-in armoire and desk unit, which supported a television, and the curtains at the rear window overlooking the ugly backs of buildings on West 46th Street matched the spread on the double bed. There, I slept as deeply as if in a sensory deprivation tank -- which, come to think of it, is rather what the room looked like.
Of course, there's no lack of stimuli on West 47th Street, with Rockefeller Center to the east and the Theater District to the west. I did a bit of happy-hour dabbling at Cafe Un Deux Trois on West 44th Street and at Shaan, an Indian restaurant on West 48th Street, where drinks come with a plate of delectable fried vegetable and tandoori appetizers. Then, I met a friend who had free tickets to a movie.
You can get just about anywhere in the city from the nearby Times Square subway station. But to reach my next hotel, all I had to do was take a little stroll, stopping at the TKTS Booth in Duffy Square at 47th Street to buy a half-price seat ($36.25) for a preview of the Paul Simon musical, "The Capeman."
The 40-room Broadway Bed and Breakfast occupies several restored red-brick buildings on West 46th Street at Eighth Avenue, with a well-cared-for feeling and a 24-hour doorman. The burnished wood front desk and comfortable sitting room are reached from the ground-floor entrance by a set of steps, San Franciscan in its Victorian style and steepness. There, over a free morning paper and Continental breakfast, I saw couples in from the suburbs and nicely dressed Europeans studying city maps. It soon became clear that they had theater tickets, so I fit right in.
Several hours before check-in, I was given a $105 room with a full-size double bed. Rates for rooms with three-quarter-size double beds started at $95, but the only thing available when I made a reservation was a $135 room with a queen-size bed. I booked that, but asked to be remembered for a cancellation at a lower rate, never imagining I would be. But at the Broadway B & B, where the friendly staff refutes stereotypes of New York meanness, I got the downgrade I wanted.
After the Connecticut coziness of the lobby, I was surprised by the Broadway glitziness of my second-floor double, decorated in greens and golds, above the Acorn Liquor and Wine Store on noisy Eighth Avenue. Inside, there was everything a traveler could want -- a clean, if minuscule, bath with a shower and hair dryer, a TV, a bedside table, excellent lighting, a clothes rack, a director's chair and a little table. All this in a space not much larger than my bath at the Portland Square!
But I really shouldn't complain, because staying at the Broadway B & B turns the Theater District into a neighborhood. When the curtain falls, you can be back in your room in half a block, or sitting down to a late dinner on Restaurant Row, just across Eighth Avenue from the hotel. There, places like Joe Allen and Orso tend to be expensive. So I went to the Hourglass Tavern, where the tables were cramped and the service slapdash, but a two-course prix fixe (I had pork loin) cost only $12.75.
THE 103-room Cosmopolitan Hotel, at the Chambers Street stop of the Broadway express and local subway lines, isn't close to the theaters. But this rare downtown budget hotel at 95 West Broadway is in the heart of an area with its own seductions -- the art galleries of SoHo, Chinatown, South Street Seaport, Wall Street and the marvelous restaurants of TriBeCa.
The sign for the hotel, which opened in 1995, is tiny and rather hidden, on the east side of the street. There's no cafe, concierge or place to sit in the small, blond-wood-paneled lobby -- which didn't pose a problem during my stay, because I saw just a few other guests.
The single elevator moves like molasses, and my $89 double on the seventh floor looked as if it had just come off the assembly line -- with gray walls, red carpeting, a television, a ceiling fan and white motel-style furnishings. In the immaculate little bath, I got a pleasant shock -- washcloths, cleverly folded to resemble fans. And at night, without even moving from the comfortable double bed, I could see that lots of workers were burning the midnight oil in the World Trade Center.
In the afternoon, I took a run to the World Financial Center and Hudson River Park, cleaned up and had a half-glass of Pommery Brut Royal ($5.50) at the Bubble Lounge just up West Broadway. Then I checked prices at restaurants like the Screening Room, Montrachet, Nobu and the Odeon before settling in at a place I could afford, Bodega, for a chicken burrito dinner ($9).
The next morning, I bought a sinfully rich cheese Danish at the new Bouley Bakery, and talked with a young woman from Germany, who wanted to know how I could afford to live in Manhattan.
"It's tough, but worth it," I said, and then toddled home to my apartment.
 
The bottom line
 
The Hotels
The Gershwin Hotel is at 7 East 27th Street; (212) 545-8000, fax (212) 684-5546. Rates for doubles, $60 to $99 through March, then $89 to $129; four- and eight-person dorm rooms are $22 and $25, with bath in each.
For reservations at any Apple Core hotel, including the Quality Eastside, 161 Lexington Avenue at East 30th Street, call (800) 567-7720. Doubles at the Quality Eastside, the most economical, are $79 to $119 this month, then will start at $119.
The Portland Square Hotel is at 132 West 47th Street; (212) 382-0600, fax (212) 382-0684. Doubles: $94 and $104, with private bath.
The Broadway Bed and Breakfast is at 264 West 46th Street, (800) 826-6300, fax (212) 763-2807. Doubles: $95 to $160, suites $185.
The Cosmopolitan Hotel is at 95 West Broadway, at Chambers Street, (888) 895-9400, (212) 566-1900, fax (212) 566-6909. Doubles: $89 and $119.
 
Booking Help
For Quickbook, a discount reservations agency, call (800) 789-9887. Another discounter is the Hotel Reservations Network, (800) 964-6835.
 
Getting There
Gray Line airport minivan shuttles, (800) 451-0455, offer service to these hotels, except for the Cosmopolitan, from the major airports. From La Guardia, the fare is $13, and $13.50 to return; Kennedy $14 and $16.50 return, and Newark $14 and $18.50. The larger Gray Line airport buses are $10 from La Guardia and $12 from Kennedy to either Grand Central Terminal or the midtown Port Authority Bus Terminal.
Olympia Trails buses, (212) 964-6233, cost $10 each way between Newark and Grand Central, Port Authority, Pennsylvania Station and the World Trade Center.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 33; Column 2; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Toys Are We

BYLINE: By Fred Miller Robinson; Fred Miller Robinson is at work on a cross-cultural study of Ireland and America.

 BODY:

KIDS' STUFF
 Toys and the Changing World
 of American Childhood.
 By Gary Cross.
 Illustrated. 283 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $29.95. 
 It is hard to imagine a less fun book about toys. There is nothing in Gary Cross's history of American toys about the psychology of the child's imagination or the cultural meaning of particular toys. There are not even telling descriptions of the low-taste items that clutter the aisles of Toys "R" Us.
Instead, with all the grave lamenting that marks American cultural history these days, Cross offers the following narrative: Since toys became an important item of manufacture in the 19th century, they have gradually been removed from the control of parents to a "fantasy world free of adults," controlled by a "mass consumption economy." The seeds were sown when "parents increasingly accepted play rather than work to teach the young values and skills. And manufactured toys increasingly were the tools of this learning." In the 20th century, as parents became less sure what world they wanted their children to grow up in, what skills they wanted them to imitate, what values they wanted to instill in them, toy makers have created an "ethos of fantasy consumerism" removed from "the experience and expectations of parents" and have sold it directly to children through television and advertising. Building blocks became Barbie's Boutique.
This history is one of many subsets of a broader academic narrative that goes something like this: The high Industrial Revolution began a process of mechanization, commercialism and standardization that has dissipated the values we once had. Family, neighborhood and church have morphed into the Consumer Society. We are adrift in a soulless world of things. And so on, and on. (My fellow academics are especially fond of this narrative because it confirms their sense of themselves as fallen aristocrats, whose refined tastes honor a vaguely feudal past in a world too commercial to appreciate their intelligence, their importance and their books.) Cross, a professor of history at Pennsylvania State University, begins "Kids' Stuff" bewildered and saddened in a contemporary toy store and concludes it adjuring parents to "give meaning to the things of play" -- that is, toys.
Who can doubt the truth of what has become a kind of monomyth? Who can doubt Cross's parochial version of it? The evidence has been all around us for some time. If you doubt Cross's descriptions of the amoral toy business, with its character licensing, program-length commercials and expandable lines of accessories, you can read G. Wayne Miller's "Toy Wars: The Epic Struggle Between G.I. Joe, Barbie, and the Companies That Make Them" (Times Books/Random House, $25). In trashy, fast-moving prose, Miller (a journalist from whom Professor Cross could learn something about narrative) gives a star-struck account of the Hasbro-Mattel conglomerate wars, in which executives with "steel blue eyes" restructure deals after "sumptuous" breakfasts in expensive hotels and make speeches in which "the pure joy of dreams" comes to life, not through toys but through having Steven Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenberg of Dreamworks on either side of you. Or you can read Dan S. Acuff's "What Kids Buy and Why: The Psychology of Marketing to Kids" (Free Press, $28), a sort of Total Quality Management guide to creating, developing and marketing products to the "filiarchy," which I take to mean the Rule of Sons. Acuff, who has a doctorate in education and has been a consultant to Nike and Disney, deploys a Product Leverage Matrix to help companies in the kids business analyze products that will appeal to the "underlying abilities, motivations, needs and behaviors of the young target." Pages like flow charts follow. Miller and Acuff can tell you more about the decline and fall of joy than Cross learned from his sources.
The problem with narratives of lament is that they're too true to be good. To borrow a phrase from Wallace Stevens, the freshness of their insight has been fresh a long time. The evident truth of our culture of consumption is exceeded by its familiarity. Cross needs only to allude in shorthand to the monomyth that gives his story whatever resonance it has. Phrases like "products of the faceless world of machines and commerce," "a complex and rapidly changing world of popular culture," "traditional cultural" are added on to his historical data in discrete paragraphs and not pursued. Indeed, he treats his received ideas as if they were facts. "Kids' Stuff" is filled with interesting information on the history of toys and, to a lesser extent, on the economics of the toy industry, but it is conceptually either uncertain or trite.
Cross mentions, for example, a contradiction in parents' desires to prepare their children for the grown-up world with structured, imitative play and to protect them from that world by allowing the free run of their imaginations. But without a clearer sense of what a child's play is like, we cannot be sure that the contradiction is real. The "child's world of imagination or fantasy" is a phrase, like other phrases, to be assumed, not examined. Is this child's world invariable? What aspects of it might be useful in the adult world? What distinguishes imagination from fantasy? Why did "the young" want "superpower fantasy and excitement" in the 1970's and 80's? And how does he know that superhero fantasy "became more intense and pleasurable the more it was alienated from adult reality"? What aspects of "adult reality"?
Cross puts very little spin on, or passion into, his subject. For him, it seems, toys are merely another means of reinforcing the monomyth, illustrating only what other products and rituals can be made to illustrate: the decline of our way of life. What has happened to toys, he notes, has happened in many aspects of contemporary culture; the "toy problem is the consumer's problem."
In one of his better phrases, Cross says that "playthings are only props on a wider stage of wills and motives." He knows that bigger subjects are there: the changing view of childhood in America, the creation of a culture of children (and adolescents), the meaning of play, the ethos of business conglomerates. But discussing that wider stage requires more engagement with ideas, and more psychology, sociology, popular and material cultural theory than Cross seems to have at his disposal. Since children continue to love the toys they play with and don't seem to be psychologically maimed or imaginatively stunted as a result (Cross offers no evidence of this in any case), the opportunity was there for a complex and bracing story of American cultural development. That opportunity has been missed.

HEADLINE: An On-Line Lesson in Thin Mints and Lemon Pastry Cremes

BYLINE: By INGRID EISENSTADTER

 BODY:
It's time again for that annual celebration of grass-roots entrepreneurship, the Girl Scout cookie sale, when Scouts fan out across America, striking fear in the hearts of the Keebler elves and earning their cookies and dough badges.
But even this seemingly low-tech ritual is being changed by the Internet. Driven by the lure of the new technology badge, some Scout councils are selling cookies on line. 
 More than a third of the country's 319 Girl Scout councils have gone on line in the last two years. And two New England councils -- the Swift Water council in Manchester, N.H., and Patriots' Trail in Boston -- have been among the leaders in moving cookie sales onto the World Wide Web. Both have secure servers, allowing them to take credit card orders. The council in San Francisco is adding an encryption program, too.
In Boston, Prosoft, which provides information technology training, volunteered to teach Web design to the girls. Patrice Buckley, 15, a Scout for nine years, said, "Prosoft taught us Microsoft Front Page 98 and I was part of designing the site."
Amanda Michienzi, 17, a Girl Scout for 12 years, said, "We did the links, learned some HTML coding, and we put our own voices on the site with hyperlinks."
To buy cookies on the Web, one fills out an E-mail form that links to credit card processing services. Scouts working on Web sites track the orders, send E-mail acknowledgments and ship the cookies. A minimum order of three boxes plus shipping comes to about $13.
Each council takes guidance from national headquarters in New York but makes many business decisions itself. Although the New Hampshire Scouts accept orders only within their designated territory, Boston Scouts fill orders from anywhere in the country, as do San Francisco Scouts. Boston-area girls forward names of out-of-area cookie buyers to local councils for follow-up sales, but in San Francisco the Scouts have not made a decision on that.
Janine Carlson, communications director in San Francisco, said: "Territory is still a gray area. Hawaii went on line last year and got inquiries from all over the globe."
What does the future hold? Will thousands of freebooting Girl Scout troops hoist the Jolly Roger on the Internet high seas, pirating away one another's cookie sales? The organization's guidelines on cookie sales speak of "honor" when addressing Internet sales to insure that "competition is fair," and that "sales are made locally."
Even before the Internet, Scouts had begun promoting their cookies using the media, creating press releases or taking public service announcements to radio stations. "The cookie sales teach entrepreneurship," said Beverly Cheuvront, director of public relations for the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, which does not have a Web site. "The girls set up a business plan and figure out how many cookies they need to sell to meet a specific goal, which may be renting a bus or going to summer camp."
This year, the San Francisco-area girls are trying to finance a trip to summer camp in England, and the Patriots' Trail Scouts are hoping to pay for a trip to Ireland. Nationally, income from cookie sales also goes toward scholarships for economically deprived girls, programs for the elderly, recycling efforts and the girls' educational and civic outings.
To be sure, the vast majority of the almost 200 million boxes of thin mints, trefoils and other cookies sold each year are sold door to door. The country's 2.6 million Girl Scouts ring up more than $500 million; in three months, they sell almost as many cookies as Nabisco sells all year of its Oreos, America's best-selling cookie brand.
In Boston, both Patrice and Amanda continue to sell door to door. "I've been selling cookies for 12 years," Amanda said. "I've known my customers since I was a Brownie."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1619 words

HEADLINE: Publisher Finds Dream Role As Chief of Smaller Realm

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL

 BODY:
It is late afternoon, in the dim sunlight of a SoHo bistro, and Peter Mayer is savoring life in a single time zone and the remains of his steak frites.
When he presided over the global empire of Penguin Books, this was his hour of struggle, the moment when his body rebelled against the corporate life of the gypsy chief executive -- frenetic commutes between New York and London; offices with secretaries and back-up secretaries; the weighty travel bag of books and manuscripts that tilted his 6-foot frame. 
 "I was tired all the time, falling asleep in the afternoon, and very often during dinner, I would nod and wake up," Mr. Mayer recalled. "I didn't realize it was that stressful. I think that if anyone had told me then how much better it could be, I wouldn't have believed it."
Even so, many of his closest friends had nagging concerns when Mr. Mayer cheerfully announced plans to depart Penguin in early 1997, after 19 years leading the company, to "begin life again" at 61 in his dream role of independent publisher.
Mr. Mayer, a restless man with a deep, ebullient voice and a cumulus of graying hair, had often confided in friends that he longed to take personal charge of the Overlook Press, the eclectic publishing company he had started with his father in 1971, before leaving for Penguin. He believed that control of Overlook would allow him to pursue his passion for books into his 80's -- well past normal retirement age.
But it meant leaving the corporate cocoon of Penguin -- with revenues then of more than $650 million -- for a publishing house in SoHo with 11 employees and $3 million in sales. It meant shedding the chauffeur, the power and the perks and entering Overlook's airy fourth-floor offices through a service entrance on Broadway and occasionally answering the telephone when his staff was distracted.
"I was concerned," Martin Garbus, a lawyer who is one of Mr. Mayer's closest friends, said. "Could Peter, for Act 3 of his life, be as influential?"
To prepare for corporate decompression, Mr. Mayer devised his own form of boot camp to flex his independence.
Carrying basic necessities in a backpack, he set off to travel alone for six weeks in Southeast Asia, guided by a well-thumbed economy travel book from the Lonely Planet series, which offered tips on youth hostel living.
"This was no grand trip, but a voyage on $3 a day without advance bookings," said Mr. Mayer, who was mugged while riding on a motorcycle taxi in Vietnam. "No running water and bad beds wherever I showed up. I wanted to know if I could still do it -- to help me get ready for noncorporate life, in a way. It worked: using sign language and a phrase book will humiliate anyone."
Corporate life intruded during a side trip to Hanoi, when Mr. Mayer checked in with his old London office and learned from his young Harvard-trained successor, Michael Lynton, about the first hints of something that had gone terribly wrong during Mr. Mayer's tenure at Penguin. Later there would be public disclosures about an accounting scandal involving unauthorized discounts, which ultimately prompted Pearson P.L.C., which owns Penguin, to take a $163 million charge against 1996 earnings and to pay $25 million through Penguin to settle a lawsuit over the issue filed by the American Booksellers Association.
Penguin Books sued Christine Galatro, a credit director for the company in New Jersey, in connection with the scandal. The company accused Ms. Galatro of hatching an elaborate $1.4 million embezzlement scheme that led to a cover-up that Penguin contends grew into exponential losses -- charges that her lawyer has denied.
Mr. Mayer said he did not know the credit manager and pointed out that the problem also eluded notice of the company's auditors, Arthur Andersen & Company. Still, he acknowledged, "I think there's always some kind of technical responsibility in the sense that when you're the chief executive officer, you're responsible for everything, whether in the reality this is something that happened at a very low level."
Still, the scandal mortified him, according to friends.
"That was horrible for him, no question," said Roger Straus, the founder and publisher of Farrar, Straus & Giroux and a longtime friend of Mr. Mayer. "It was on his watch, as they say in the navy."
Those humiliations did not seem to drain the reservoir of respect that Mr. Mayer had built up over the years in the publishing industry, although he was fiercely criticized by newspapers in London, home base for Pearson, for failing to uncover the accounting problems.
He had such a long history in publishing that many of the executives in the corporate suites of major trade houses could claim early apprenticeships and first jobs with Mr. Mayer, in positions from file clerk to publicity director. "He lives and breathes publishing and it was very infectious," recalled Mark Gompertz, the vice president and publisher of trade paperbacks at Simon & Schuster, who worked for 10 years at Overlook Press while Mr. Mayer was juggling Penguin and his own company. "There were constantly authors coming in and out," Mr. Gompertz said. "Some would call it very old world publishing. He had this way of cultivating authors and it just rubbed off."
He was driven, manic and so scattered that fabled stories circulated about times when he was so preoccupied with the press of business that he would go to a restaurant and forget to order or he would dine twice because he had forgotten an earlier meal. His breezy letters -- which often went through several drafts before they went out to far-flung employees -- were legendary for their pointed lessons in publishing.
"I honestly believe I learned more as a file clerk at Overlook reading his correspondence," said Ira Silverberg, the editorial director at Grove Press, who said Mr. Mayer's second career offered new inspiration. "It's the romance of the industry. It shows that a publisher is not just a multinational conglomerate game and that people can return to the roots of publishing."
Since Mr. Mayer has returned to his roots, he has moved Overlook Press to larger quarters in SoHo, with offices whose white walls, blond wood floors, exposed pipes and African sculptures give them the air of a hip art gallery. Mr. Mayer has also exchanged his corporate pinstripes for a more casual uniform of blue denim shirt and khaki pants. His blood pressure is low and he has shed 20 pounds.
But the plunge from corporate to independent publishing is still causing some adjustments. Information for sales projections is harder to come by with a small staff.
"There are not enough bodies around to do all the ideas you have," Mr. Mayer said. "I think I made some mistakes in my first six months because I thought, now that I'm a small publisher, I have to do everything like a small publisher. I suddenly realized that you can be small, but if you have a big idea, there's no reason you can't do something large."
At the annual Frankfurt book fair in Germany -- where the world's elite publishers hold their clubby reunions every autumn -- Mr. Mayer's once vast trading space shrank to the size of a New York studio, with two chairs and a table and a sausage stand for a neighbor.
"I did worry that no one would stay and talk to me," Mr. Mayer said. "You never know whether some of them are talking to you because of your company or because of you."
Space was cramped, but Mr. Mayer observed his standards. Others made do with plastic cups; Mr. Mayer served white wine in glass goblets to visitors and peddled big ideas -- the foreign rights for publication of a sweeping fictional saga of the Central Intelligence Agency by Robert Littell, which sold for more than $600,000.
The concept for the book was Mr. Mayer's idea, one of the big notions that he said small publishers can achieve. The idea appealed to Mr. Littell and his longtime agent, Ed Victor, who has also recently steered David Wallechinsky, the author of "The Complete Book of the Olympics," to Overlook.
"You go to some of the big houses and they're on auto-pilot," Mr. Victor said, explaining why his authors moved to Overlook. "They do what they always do: print copies and send them on the well-worn grooves. There are so many things a company can do, and Peter is doing it for us."
Mr. Mayer remains on the watch for books for his company that -- naturally -- have been overlooked. Overlook has had notable successes in the past with books on ceramics, graphic design and the martial arts, including a perennial seller, "A Book of Five Rings," a Japanese guide to ancient wooden sword fighting that is on the reading list for Newt Gingrich's Congressional staff.
Since his return, Mr. Mayer has endeared himself to the "Friends of Freddy," a fan club for devotees of Freddy the Pig, the hero of Bean Farm, by pledging to rescue the pig from out-of-print obscurity. Overlook is planning to publish all 26 titles in the children's series by Walter R. Brooks, who chronicled Freddy's exploits from 1927 to 1958.
Along with titles like "Freddy the Detective," and "Freddy Goes to Florida," Mr. Mayer has been hunting for other unusual titles in obscure topic areas. He is particularly proud of one of his latest discoveries, a book that claims to be the definitive bible of falconry.
He talks about these titles with the same sort of enthusiasm that he has for a coming biography of Gustav Mahler or a Singapore novelist's tale of a young girl sold into slavery in the 1950's.
"I'm happy as a book publisher," he said. "I loved my 19 years being a C.E.O. I loved it to distraction, but I couldn't do it till I'm 80. So I love being big and I love being small."

HEADLINE: A Nation of Traders?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Feb. 11 front-page article on the increase in stock ownership creates the misimpression that most households have substantial portfolios. But the most recent data show, not surprisingly, significant concentration among the most wealthy and relatively meager holdings among middle- and low-income families. 
 Half of the stock market is held by the richest 5 percent of American households. In contrast, the bottom 75 percent of households own less than 20 percent of all stock, and those in the bottom 50 percent own less than 5 percent. (These figures include stocks held through pension plans.) American families continue to depend on their paychecks, not on the stock market.
 
JARED BERNSTEIN
Washington, Feb. 11, 1998
 
The writer is an economist at the Economic Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: West Fears Bosnia Funds Aid Hard-Line Serbs

BYLINE: By MIKE O'CONNOR 

DATELINE: SOKOLAC, Bosnia and Herzegovina

 BODY:
Late last year, as United States and World Bank officials were negotiating the details of a $17 million aid program for Bosnian Serbs, they were given an unnegotiable demand, the officials say. Bosnian Serb authorities linked to the former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic, who has been charged with war crimes, insisted that unless areas they controlled received 15 percent of the money they would block the whole deal.
With the Bosnian Serb member of the three-person Bosnian Presidency threatening to veto the aid plan, they got what they wanted and the deal went through. It became another chunk of the increasing flow of loans and grants to the part of Bosnia where the authorities are seen as implacable opponents of Western policy. 
 As the American Government throws its weight behind a new group of Bosnian Serb politicians it says are more cooperative, Western Governments are preparing to spend some $130 million on new aid projects in Bosnian Serb areas.
Diplomats in Bosnia and human rights monitors in Washington say they fear that some of the aid will strengthen leaders who oppose Western efforts to promote peace and ethnic tolerance or, through lax auditing, make those leaders richer.
The situation sharpens a dilemma long present in Western policy in Bosnia: the conflict between principle and practicality -- whether aid should go to hard-core nationalists, even criminals, in hopes of enticing them to become more moderate or merely as the unfortunate price of carrying out broader goals.
Following the United States' lead, the West leapt to give financial support to Dr. Karadzic's successor, Biljana Plavsic, after she split with other nationalist politicians. American diplomats call the new Bosnian Serb president a moderate, though they acknowledge that her actions fall short of her promises to back Western efforts to carry out the peace accord that ended the Bosnian war two years ago.
That a lot of the aid goes to authorities who routinely renege on commitments is acceptable for now, in the view of the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, Brian Atwood. Money is a tool for gaining influence and encouraging political change, he said.
"If we're too rigid on the terms we'd never move any money," he said. "You do the best you can, but it does no good to be so rigid you basically don't engage."
A senior American official who is helping shape policy said, "Moral absolutism will not get us very far in Bosnia policy." He said that in the last few months some Bosnian Serb leaders had become less difficult to deal with because they want Western aid.
 
A Town Controlled By a Few Serbs
In this small town, Sokolac, an agricultural center in mountains dabbed with sheep herds and rustic cottages that Bosnians consider the heartland of Serbian nationalism, local leaders are pleased to have been selected for a $750,000 World Bank loan to remake the water system.
They can't explain, though, how they met the criteria for the loan. They say the water system is not below the level needed to satisfy basic human needs or protect the health of its 12,000 customers. Nor is it insufficient to supply water for initial economic recovery. Only a leap in the town's growth would substantially tax the system.
"We're hoping to have 30,000 people living here in a few years," said Mitar Odvic, the water system manager. "Considering that, what we have now is not adequate."
In Sokolac, the small group of Bosnian Serb men who control almost all government, business and daily life have defied pressure to share power or allow thousands of refugees from other ethnic groups to return home.
In the benefits they will get from the World bank loan, and in their opposition to the peace accord, they are typical of many authorities to whom financial aid is being directed.
Officials of Western assistance programs say money is always precisely targeted and scrupulously monitored. It is supposed to be for urgent needs, and only for areas where local authorities can be trusted to unify and stabilize the country by doing what was promised in the peace accord.
That accord recognized a Bosnian Serb Republic and a Bosnian-Croat Federation in Bosnia. Two important elements of it that are nearly universally ignored in the Serb Republic are the arrest of war crimes suspects and the return of refugees.
 
Aid That Helps The Wrong People
But many experts say that without aid the Serb-controlled region of Bosnia they control will remain an economic wilderness.
"Their part of the country cannot make it back with the previous level of assistance," said Rory O'Sullivan, head of the World Bank mission in Bosnia. "If half of the country is dead economically, the whole country cannot survive."
Criticism of the aid programs comes from the belief that much of the money is going to the worst Bosnian Serb leaders, either through oversight, or so that they will not obstruct the aid that might help moderate leaders.
"There is always the temptation to push out money to get economic results," said Nina Bang-Jensen of the Coalition for International Justice, a nonprofit organization based in Washington. "But economic results on a corrupt foundation will fail," she said, "You have to support the right people."
In the United States Congress there is also concern that foreign aid money in Bosnia may not be achieving American goals as well as it should. Thirteen lawmakers wrote Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright asking her not to approve the World Bank loans.
One of them, Senator Frank Lautenberg, the New Jersey Democrat, said in a telephone interview that Congress sees little payoff for the money being spent. "They'd better start showing results soon," he said. "There's not a lot of patience around here."
In the last two years, even as foreign diplomats condemned Bosnian Serb authorities for their refusal to carry out essential tenets of the 1995 peace agreement, the World Bank lent about $15 million and the European Union donated about $80 million for projects in the area those authorities controlled. The United States Agency for International Development provided $19 million in loans and grants, most of it for economic development, to the same area.
With the formation recently of a new Serb Republic Government that foreign diplomats say will be more amenable to the peace agreement, Western officials want to distribute much more money. The United States alone expects to contribute about $5 million dollars a month.
There are no exact figures, but estimates are that about 900,000 people live in the Serb Republic.
New World Bank loans were approved by the United States in December. Congressional critics objected, but Secretary of State Albright issued a waiver to legislative restrictions on giving aid where authorities have not done enough to arrest suspected war criminals. Most of the more than 50 people under indictment on charges of war crimes are thought to be living in the Serb Republic.
 
Refugees Kept Out As Suspects Go Free
World Bank officials, like officials of other Western aid programs, said their projects were approved after careful research, and with the towns ranked according to need. Even so, 15 percent of the World Bank money went to towns like Sokolac, in the eastern part of the Serb Republic, where many officials are under the sway of Dr. Karadzic, who is considered a principal barrier to peaceful reunification of the country.
The loans had to be endorsed by the three-person Bosnian presidency, where the Bosnian Serb representative threatened to block all loans unless communities in the eastern part of the Serb Republic got a share, according to Western officials.
"It is necessary to include a portion of the aid to the eastern Serb Republic because of the veto Karadzic has over the entire process," said a senior American official.
"That's the way business gets done," said a State Department spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity.
Foreign consultants to the World Bank who oversaw the research into which towns qualified for assistance say most of the data were collected by local officials who work for the same hard-line politicians the West is trying to marginalize.
All the towns receiving American, World Bank or European Union money were reviewed by the office of the chief Western monitor in Bosnia to insure the aid would help only communities where there is a reasonable hope that officials may become cooperative.
But in Sokolac, international refugee officials said not a single Muslim or Croat refugee has returned, nor did they expect local political leaders would allow any to return soon.
In the town of Bijeljina, also to benefit from the new batch of World Bank loans, American soldiers recently detained a well-known war crimes suspect who had been living there openly. His friends say he was under the protection of local officials.
Another Bosnian Serb-controlled town, Foca, cleared to get World Bank money, was dropped in late December after human rights groups in Washington pointed out to the State Department that officials in Foca are thought to be harboring several men indicted on charges of war crimes.
For United States assistance in the Serb Republic in the last two years, nearly every project required a memorandum of understanding in which local authorities agreed to follow the peace accords by allowing refugees to return and arresting war crimes suspects. But, Bosnian Serb authorities have arrested no war crimes suspects. Of the 560,000 Muslims and Croats expelled by Bosnian Serbs during the war, only about 3,000 have been allowed to return, according to the United Nations.
Senior American diplomats, including Secretary of State Albright, insist they will only support Bosnian Serb political leaders who support the peace accords. But American aid officials say they don't have the staff to monitor compliance when it comes to loans and grants.
A senior United States aid official conceded American funds in Bosnia could easily go to companies controlled by opponents of American policy. Often, said the official, the money is disbursed without a close check on the company.
"It's a concern," the official said. "We don't have resources to look at the bona fides of every company."

HEADLINE: U.N. Team Mapping Iraqi Leader's Palaces

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 15

 BODY:
A United Nations team began mapping Iraq's presidential compounds today, attempting to help resolve one of the main disputes in the crisis over United Nations inspections of suspected weapons sites, Iraqi sources said.
The teams are not actually investigating the compounds, which Iraq has said are off-limits to United Nations weapons inspectors. Instead, United Nations officials hope to use the maps to determine which areas of the sprawling compounds are legitimate targets for inspections and which areas should remain closed. 
 Iraq has said unrestricted inspections would violate its sovereignty.
The United States, which has threatened military action against Iraq if it does not open the compounds to inspectors, did not immediately comment on the map-making team.
But Iraq called the development a "positive step," and warned that a United States military strike could destroy a well-functioning United Nations monitoring system of suspected weapons sites.
"The military attack would practically destroy the system, which relies on communications, cameras," said Gen. Amir al-Saadi, an Iraqi presidential adviser.
He also denied assertions that Deputy Prime Minister Tarik Aziz ever described presidential palaces as "absolutely forbidden." The claim was made earlier today by the chief United Nations weapons inspector, Richard Butler, in a CNN interview.
General Saadi said that Mr. Aziz, in a meeting with Butler, had in fact pleaded for a postponement on the discussion about presidential sites.
Asked if the Iraqi Government is open to inspection of at least part of the restricted sites, General Saadi said: "We are flexible." He did not elaborate.
Access to the presidential sites is at the core of the current crisis. The United States and Britain have threatened to attack Iraq if President Saddam Hussein does not completely open his palaces to United Nations inspectors.
The inspectors, working under United Nations Security Council resolutions passed at the end of the Gulf War, are responsible for overseeing the elimination of Iraq's long-range missiles and weapons of mass destruction. Iraqi compliance is needed for United Nations economic sanctions to be lifted.
The United Nations and the United States say the inspectors can search any place they want. Iraq has refused, citing national sovereignty.
Under pressure to resolve the crisis, the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, ordered the map-making team to Iraq on Friday.
The team, led by Staffan de Mistura of Sweden, arrived today and visited one of the eight disputed sites, Iraqi sources said.
Mr. de Mistura, a former United Nations humanitarian coordinator for Iraq, and the two Austrian map-makers accompanying him are expected to finish charting the eight sprawling presidential compounds in three or four days.
There have been growing calls for Mr. Annan to head to Iraq to end the standoff. Mr. Annan was to meet Monday afternoon in New York with United States Ambassador Bill Richardson and envoys of the other four permanent members of the Security Council -- Britain, China, Russia and France.
Russia, France and China have been urging the United States not to attack.
If the meeting produces an agreement, Mr. Annan could leave by mid-week.
The Clinton Administration is under growing pressure in Congress to set a deadline for an attack. But on NBC television today, White House National Security Adviser Sandy Berger said the Administration "has been very careful not to set an artificial deadline."
He repeated the United States position that the timeline for commencing military action is "not measured in days but it's also not measured in months."
Also today, Russian officials continued their efforts to resolve the standoff.
In Baghdad, a Russian envoy, Viktor Posuvaluk, went into a third week of talks with the Iraqi Government on trying to reach a diplomatic solution to the crisis.

HEADLINE: Mr. Suharto's Extended Run

 BODY:
Indonesia, battered by economic crisis and unprepared for the eventual departure of its dictator, President Suharto, is jittery over increasing unrest. Well it might be. The last time the country changed rulers, in the 1960's, half a million people died in the upheaval, most of them ethnic Chinese. Another violent transition can be avoided by planning now for an orderly and swift shift to democratic rule.
For that to happen, Washington must register its objections to the 76-year-old Mr. Suharto's plan to have himself re-elected to a new five-year term next month. America has complex interests in Indonesia. It needs to promote wiser economic management, calm investors, maintain regional security relationships and minimize the pain suffered by the poor. But discouraging Mr. Suharto's re-election by a compliant Parliament should be part of the mix. Recovery has been set back by his shifting responses to the financial crisis, including his new proposal to lock in exchange rates with a currency board before putting in place reforms that could make fixed rates sustainable. 
 Democracy can only come about through Indonesian efforts. Mr. Suharto has perpetuated his grip by eliminating rivals in the military or officially tolerated parties and insuring that no plausible successor is ever groomed. If he is to be peacefully eased from power, it will likely require the consent of Indonesia's armed forces, which have played a dominant role in politics and the economy since independence. That role should be rapidly phased out, for the sake of military professionalism as well as democracy. Members of Indonesia's civic, labor, environmental and religious associations should be allowed to compete freely for political leadership.
Moving toward democracy will not be easy in a country that has known only dictators in its 48 years of independent life. But the costs of a blocked political system are already visible in recent threats made against the Chinese minority as food prices and unemployment have risen. The Chinese account for less than 4 percent of Indonesia's 200 million people but own as much as 70 percent of the country's private wealth. Yet for every international tycoon among them, like Mochtar Riady, there are thousands of small shopkeepers and merchants threatened with losing all they have to angry mobs.
Increasing democracy will not eliminate tensions between Indonesia's Muslim majority and Chinese minority. But it can provide more constructive outlets for public fear and anger than now exist. It also opens new possibilities for replacing an economic system based on cronyism and corruption with an honest, accountable marketplace.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Statehouse Journal;
Georgia's Chief Reveling In His Sky-High Ratings

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The joke making the rounds under Georgia's gold dome these days is that Gov. Zell Miller has achieved an extraordinary approval rating of 77 percent, and that he has somehow managed to do so without being accused of having sex with an intern.
Some governors limp out of office, bruised by years of scandal, legislative warfare and political miscalculation. Southern Democratic governors often end up fleeing the rising Republican tide. Mr. Miller, by contrast, is skipping homeward like a schoolboy on the last day of class. 
 In his eighth scandal-free year in office, the 65-year-old Democrat has received the highest approval ratings of his tenure, in a Georgia State University poll released this month. His ratings, which have risen gradually and consistently throughout his two terms, hardly varied by sex, race, age, income or political party. Though the booming economy has buoyed many incumbents, no governor in the country enjoys comparable popularity, said Thad Beyle, a political scientist at the University of North Carolina who compiles ratings of governors.
Mr. Miller burst on the Georgia political scene as an aide to Gov. Lester Maddox, the arch segregationist. He went on to become the darling of progressive Democrats, watched the coronation of New South politicians from Jimmy Carter to Newt Gingrich, and ultimately proved one of the most durable politicians in the region. More than anyone, Mr. Miller realizes that political popularity can be fleeting, and that it ultimately may play little role in history's assessment. But he suggests that his success holds some lessons for other Democrats, particularly in the South, where his once dominant party is struggling to maintain relevance in the face of steady Republican gains.
Georgia, in fact, is the only state in the region that has not elected a Republican governor since Reconstruction, a distinction that gives this year's election special symbolic weight. Mr. Miller is prohibited from running for a third consecutive term, and he has rejected entreaties to run for the United States Senate against Senator Paul Coverdell, choosing instead to return to his earlier calling as a college professor. Though Mr. Miller predicts that his successor will be a Democrat, many political experts maintain that the race will be closely contested.
When Mr. Miller explains his formula for Democratic success in a bipartisan world, the tenets sound so simple as to seem self-evident.
He has focused his energies and his lobbying on a narrow agenda of innovative proposals with broad appeal, many of them supported by extensive polling. He has created ground-breaking educational programs -- entitlements, really -- designed deliberately to benefit all Georgians, not just the poor.
With great calculation, he seized on initiatives that he knew would yield visible, tangible results. After winning support for a state lottery -- not an easy task in a religiously conservative state -- he dedicated the proceeds to creating the nation's only publicly financed prekindergarten program and a Hope scholarship program that pays full college tuition for any Georgia student who maintains a B average. The Hope scholarship program, which stands for Helping Outstanding Pupils Educationally, was the model for a similar plan recently proposed by President Clinton.
Since 1993, more than 300,000 students in a state of 7.5 million people have received Hope scholarships, and more than 60,000 4-year-olds have enrolled in prekindergarten. "They are broad-based and you can see them," Mr. Miller said of his education programs. "It touches your family, or touches someone's family that you know."
Mr. Miller has paid little attention to claims of partisan ownership of issues, unabashedly co-opting Republican proposals when he sensed they were popular. And ever since losing a nearly ruinous fight to remove the Confederate stars and bars from the state's flag in 1993, he has studiously avoided divisive social issues that distract attention from his core goals of creating jobs, improving schools, cutting taxes and fighting crime.
Around their kitchen tables, he argues, Georgians are talking about jobs and health care and schools, not about partial-birth abortion, gay rights and school prayer. When the General Assembly debated a proposal to eliminate race-based preferences in state programs this month, the Governor remained conspicuously mute.
"When I was growing up in the mountains of Appalachia, the most valuable thing a family could have was a good hunting dog, a good hound dog," said Mr. Miller, who was raised in the tiny mountain town of Young Harris. "And what made that dog good was that it didn't chase rabbits. It stayed on the trail and it didn't go off on all these little rabbit trails. It stayed focused. It's awful easy to get off on chasing rabbits."
Of course, Mr. Miller has also enjoyed the benefit of a sterling economy, a factor for which he says he deserves some, but not all, of the credit. The state's unemployment rate is 3.8 percent, compared with 4.7 percent nationally.
"There are some places that are doing better than others, and there are some governors that have put more emphasis on the economy and job creation and attracting business than others," he said. "That's always been a very, very big area with Georgia governors. Probably I spend more of my time than any other way on job creation."
Mr. Miller's Republican critics snicker that they are not surprised that the Governor is so popular. After all, they say, he, like President Clinton, has borrowed their agenda.
But Mr. Miller dismisses that evaluation as simplistic. Philosophically, he says, he is very much a Democrat.
"I happen to believe that government, if used in the right way, can make a great difference in an individual's life, and I think that has been more clearly enunciated by Democrats than by Republicans," he said. "I listened to F.D.R.'s fireside chats on an old Philco radio during the Depression in Appalachia, and I saw changes. I myself received the advantage of the G.I. Bill, which is one of the best Government programs ever conceived."
That being said, Mr. Miller has sounded traditionally Republican themes by placing reasonably tough restrictions on welfare recipients, by building more prison beds than any previous Georgia governor, by passing a two-strikes-and-you're-out law for violent felons, by calling for the elimination of parole and by enacting two large tax cuts, one in 1996 and one this year.
"They are not Republican programs," Mr. Miller said. "They're programs that are important to a majority of the citizens, regardless of what their political party affiliation may be. It's where the people are. And that's the most important thing."

HEADLINE: In Flush Times, New York City Wants Unpaid State School Aid

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The Capitol rings these days with calls for spending the state's record surplus, but in that happy din, barely a word is said about a growing concern for New York City officials: the state owes the city at least $600 million, and much more by some reckonings, for expenses in the city school system over the last decade.
No one doubts that the city deserves the money, yet no one seems to think that anything but a small fraction of it will ever be paid. It is a story of disarray at the city's Board of Education, the state's disregard of its debts, and a city accounting system, supposedly the most rigorous of its kind, that allowed officials to ignore the growing problem for years. 
 The board has long failed to file its claims for state aid on time, and in the last recession, just as the late claims began to mount, the state simply decided it would not honor them. Now, the debt has swelled to an amount equal to at least 8 percent of the city school system's $7.5 billion budget, or enough to build more than 20 new elementary schools for 20,000 students.
The City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, has begun warning that it is no longer possible to pretend that the unpaid school aid is of no concern. His alarm sounds discordant at a time when the city is running a record surplus, but he insists that unless state lawmakers suddenly decide to make good on the debt, the city will soon be forced to acknowledge that it has a hole of more than $600 million in its $34 billion budget. That, he added, could harm the city's bond rating.
The problem dates to the 1989 fiscal year, and is primarily rooted in the Board of Education's chronic practice of submitting bills late for reimbursement by the state. Other school systems around the state have had similar problems, but never as routinely. The state's unpaid obligations -- dating from 1996 or earlier -- to all the other districts around the state total $80 million, about one-eighth the amount owed to New York City.
In the early and mid-1990's, in some aid categories, the Board of Education filed only about 50 percent of its reimbursement claims on time, Mr. Hevesi said. That record has improved significantly in the last few years, he said, but late billing remains a problem.
To understand the problem, it helps to know a few things about state budgeting. Each year, the Governor and the Legislature decide on a complex series of formulas for calculating school aid. Using those formulas, the lawmakers estimate how much the school systems will ask for, and appropriate that amount.
Until the late 1980's, if the requests exceeded the appropriation, the state simply appropriated more money. And if a school system submitted its bills a year or two late, the state usually paid them anyway.
But lawmakers ended both practices in 1990, the start of a period of yawning state budget deficits. Since then, any money appropriated for school aid but not spent is rolled over into the next year, in effect wiping clean the previous year's legal duty to pay expenses. Even bills submitted within the year have sometimes gone unpaid when the state did not appropriate enough.
Although the state's days of penury have eased, it has not gone back to its once-lenient treatment of school aid bills. Each year, the budget includes some money to pay off those old debts, but usually no more than a token.
"At the beginning, it was just maladministration by the Board of Education, but it was taken advantage of by the people in Albany," said Mr. Hevesi, who was an influential member of the Assembly when the problem took hold. "This was a subsidy to the state. It allowed them not to pay the bills."
In recent hearings here on the state budget, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew called payment of the old debts his first priority among his dealings with the state. "It is an outrage that local governments and school districts across the state cannot get paid for the services they have provided on behalf of the state, pursuant to state law," he said.
The state has accumulated large surpluses three years in a row -- for the fiscal year ending March 31, it is expected to be $2 billion -- yet it is unusual to hear lawmakers talk about old debts. In his proposed 1999 budget, Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, would allocate just $16 million to paying the Board of Education's prior claims. When asked, the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, said he would favor making larger payments, but he rarely raises the issue on his own.
"There's a psychological element to all of this," said Stephen K. Allinger, the Board of Education's representative in Albany. "The legislators got the school aid approved, they bragged about what their communities got. So now there's new money, but they can't bring themselves to pay for what they feel they already bought a couple of years ago, when they could use it to buy new goodies."
Mr. Hevesi reached the same conclusion, but said the problem was politics more than psychology. "The pressure on the Legislature to spend the money on other things is enormous," he said. "Why would they say, 'No, you can't have this $100 million for new projects because we have to pay our bills'?"
For the most basic forms of school aid that it has requested for decades, the Board of Education has generally submitted its bills on time. But the state's new, tight-fisted treatment of old bills coincided with the arrival of major new expenses that proved particularly challenging to the board's creaky bureaucracy.
Enrollment in the city system has climbed steeply in the 1990's, creating a pressing demand for new schools. The city created a new School Construction Authority to handle the building binge, but that agency has persistently been a troubled one.
In 1989, state law greatly expanded the school system's responsibility for preschool and summer school programs for disabled children, and enrollment in those programs boomed. And in the 1990's, the demand grew for expensive, special education programs for which the Board of Education is required to pay, but is not equipped to provide.
All of these new and rising expenses -- for construction, special education and the disabled -- have one thing in common: The Board of Education relies mostly on outside contractors to provide them. And that, officials say, has made it harder to account for all the expenses and submit the bills on time.
For fiscal years 1989 through 1992, the unpaid expenses averaged $22 million a year. But in 1993, as the construction and programs for the disabled got under way in earnest, the figure soared to $128.3 million, and it has remained over $100 million a year since.
For the fiscal years 1989 through 1996, the city has billed $633 million in school aid that has not been paid. Bills are still being paid under the state's fiscal 1997 appropriation, so it is not clear how much of the state's obligations for that year will go unpaid.
Some of the claims that have been filed might be rejected by the State Department of Education and the State Comptroller's office, which must approve them before they are paid, but in the past, all but a small fraction of the bills have been found valid.
The unpaid bills have not created a cash flow crisis for the city schools, for a number of reasons. Most of the state's school districts are independent entities, but the Board of Education is an arm of the city, and when the state fails to pay bills, the city still makes good on them. The city's budget is large enough to absorb some fairly large problems, and in recent years, the city, riding the booming financial markets, has been flush with cash.
Mr. Hevesi contends that the city's stringent accounting rules helped mask the problem. The rules, known as generally accepted accounting principles, were imposed on the city by state law in the 1970's, after the city nearly went bankrupt.
One feature of the accounting principles is that they show money that is owed to the city as an asset, an "account receivable." So even as the state's debts to the city went unpaid, the city's books appeared to be balanced. Those same rules, however, require that the city must eventually stop listing money as an asset on its balance sheets if there is no real expectation that it will be paid.
City and state officials say it is inevitable that some day soon, one of the city's fiscal monitors -- the Financial Control Board, or the outside auditors the city is required to hire each year -- will call an end to the pretense and declare the city's budget out of balance. That could threaten the city's credit rating, and under state law, it would require budget-balancing moves by the city, like cutting expenses or increasing taxes.
Mr. Hevesi says that this year he will begin writing off as a loss any state claim that is 10 years old or more.
"Look, there's plenty of blame to go around on this thing," an influential Assembly member from the city said. "The Board of Ed was sloppy, the city people didn't notice, and we just looked the other way."
