HEADLINE: Bills Regulating Managed Care Benefit Doctors

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Ill.

 BODY:
The debate over managed health care and consumer rights that is just beginning in Congress has been stirring a populist backlash in state capitals for several years. It is shattering historic alliances, turning doctors against doctors, doctors against business and business against otherwise pro-business Republicans.
Politicians and lobbyists frame the debate as a conflict over consumer desires for good quality care and for affordable care. But they say that in the back rooms of lawmaking, the debate is only tangentially about consumers. Mostly, they say, it is about protecting the incomes, jobs and turf of the health care system's biggest and richest vested interests. 
 Under the banner of consumer protection, legislators are wrestling with the complaints of specialist physicians who have been losing their patients, fees and autonomy, those of insurance and managed care companies whose profits have sunk in competition for patients, and those of employers who pay for much of the coverage.
"It's all over the place, all under the guise of consumer bills of rights," said Trish Riley, executive director of the National Academy for State Health Policy in Portland, Me., an association of state health officials and lawmakers.
So far, said Paul R. Ginsburg, president of the Center for Studying Health System Change, a research group in Washington supported by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, the providers, primarily doctors, are winning. "Elected officials feel their unhappiness," Mr. Ginsburg said. "It's the providers who are organizing and saying, 'This is what you want to do.' The quip going around is that this is physician protection, not consumer protection."
Probably no state illustrates the conflicts more clearly than Illinois. The State House of Representatives passed a sweeping managed care law last April, thanks to the nearly solid support of specialist physicians, and it now faces dismembering in the Senate, where business lobbies are stronger.
"We called it a patients' bill of rights," said Barbara Flynn Curry, a Democrat and House majority leader. "But it was certainly as much about the protection of physicians."
"The real issues in Illinois have nothing to do with patients," said Donna Ginther, the Springfield lobbyist for the American Association of Retired Persons. "They have to do with insurance companies and providers. How a bill will look depends for the most part on discussions between the providers and the health plans. We can influence the outcome. But is the debate about us? No."
Lawmakers, business and consumer advocates say that managed care is entrenched today, with 60 percent of the nation's insured population covered by it. By imposing businesslike disciplines on health services, they say managed care has wrung excess from the system and stopped the rising cost of care.
But many also condemn the industry for going too far, with delays, denials and limitations on essential care. So in the aftermath of Congress's rejection of President Clinton proposed overhaul of the health care system four years ago, state politicians have been seizing upon consumers' and doctors' complaints of abuses under managed care.
Molly Stauffer, a senior policy analyst for the National Conference of State Legislatures, said that 17 states enacted comprehensive consumer rights laws last year, and she predicted that at least six more would this year. Ms. Riley said most of the provisions states were enacting were high on the agendas of specialist physicians.
She said more than half of the provisions let women choose obstetrician-gynecologists as personal physicians, bypassing primary care doctors who act as gatekeepers under managed care plans, and mandate hospital stays, typically of at least two days, for childbirth. Many also require plans to make quicker referrals to specialists and to let patients appeal rejections of care to outside arbitrators.
Now the Federal Government has joined the debate. In his State of the Union Message last month, President Clinton urged enactment of a "Consumer Bill of Rights," and in Congress, improbable alliances of liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans are weighing similar bills.
Ms. Ginther said that in Illinois, as in most states, the rights that consumers are winning are a few that all the lobbies can live with, like allowing some emergency room visits without a health plan's prior approval.
But on other issues, consumer groups are losing out to the large special interests. Examples include Government-subsidized health care for all, access to official records of complaints against doctors and health plans, expanding consumer rights to sue both for malpractice, or penalties for overbooking patients and keeping them waiting.
"When you cut through all of this, there are certainly some things that are helping consumers," said Jay Dee F. Shattuck, lobbyist for a coalition of employers that includes the Illinois plants of General Motors, Ford and John Deere. "But when you get down to the political fight, it's about physicians' rights and a business community that's saying, 'Whoa! We remember the days when there was double-digit inflation.' "
In Springfield as in Washington, lawmakers describe the conflict in predictable ways. "We're struggling here with a balance of public sentiment and affordable coverage," said State Representative William E. Brady, Republican of Bloomington, who voted against the House bill. "My personal fear is that if the Government gets overly involved, we would eliminate the free enterprise aspects of the issue."
Representative Mary E. Flowers, Democrat of Chicago and one of the bill's two chief sponsors, said, "To be a roofing contractor in this state, you have to be licensed and regulated. Health maintenance organizations are not regulated. They are dealing with people's lives. They would have to comply with some kind of rules. They would have to be accountable."
For the most part, however, lawmakers are grappling less with matters of big and small government and consumer rights than with the conflicting agendas of physicians and business. "What this issue has done," Mr. Shattuck said, "is put two very strong Republican interest groups at loggerheads."
Managed care is shredding the physicians' image as independent entrepreneurs allied closely with business. As they lose prerogatives in dispensing care and submit to cuts in their fees to hold onto managed care patients, their perspective has changed from button-down white to factory-floor blue.
"When I see a patient," said Dr. Jane Jackman, president of the 18,000-member Illinois State Medical Society and a family doctor in Springfield, "she needs a quick diagnosis. But I have to get permission for any test that costs more than $100 that I don't do in my own office. I have to call an 800 number to the managed care office for a decision of whether it can or cannot be done. Quite often you're asked for more documentation and about why you have to do it."
In the debate over consumer protection, doctors promise better quality care, which they equate with consumer desires for a choice of doctors and easy access to specialists. But for doctors outside a patient's health plan, choice also means a patient's right to choose them and thus to assure them work.
Managed care plans, for their part, warn that tighter regulation and provisions like those in Ms. Flowers's House Bill 626 expanding consumer and physician rights jeopardize their control of the cost of care.
Bob Burger, executive vice president of the Illinois Association of Health Maintenance Organizations, cites one provision in the bill requiring each H.M.O. to appoint an independent medical staff to share medical decisions with management.
Mr. Burger said the law also gave doctors special privileges. "We'd have to provide them with legal due process before dismissing them," he said. "That's very expensive. We can't operate like that."
In the face of such constraints, managed care companies warn that they would have to charge much more for premiums, co-payments and deductibles, making insurance less affordable for all consumers.
Were it not for the inclusion of the Illinois State Medical Society's agenda, the House consumer protection bill would have died aborning. Ms. Flowers and Representative Carolyn Krause, Republican of Cook County, developed most of the initial provisions with the Campaign for Better Health Care.
But in a house in which Democrats have just a two-seat majority, most Republicans and some Democrats opposed the bill. Then on the night of April 24, on the eve of the vote, doctors agreed to drop a bill of their own and persuaded the authors to remove provisions from their bill that doctors opposed.
One of those provisions gave subscribers access to consumer satisfaction surveys of physicians; another let an ombudsman intervene with doctors in health care decisions on behalf of consumers. Both provisions were retained, however, as restraints on H.M.O.'s.
With that agreement, 19 Republicans, mostly supporters of the medical society's bill, joined most Democrats in approving Bill 626 by a 73-to-34 vote.
Now the bill is before the Illinois Senate, where Republicans have a 31-to-28-seat majority. There, the H.M.O.'s, the Chamber of Commerce, the Illinois Manufacturers Association, the National Federation of Independent Business and Mr. Shattuck's Employment Law Council, along with family doctors who serve as the H.M.O.'s gatekeepers, are putting together a very different version of their own.
Michael Murphy, chief lobbyist for the H.M.O. Association, said his industry had asked for the anti-consumer image that has fueled the popular backlash. "We became green eyeshade accountants," he said. "We need to do whatever we can to show we care about prevention and good care." But, he added, "we're not about to die on the cross of specialist physicians' rights to get there."
A bill that excludes provisions deemed to protect doctors might have little left for consumers. House Speaker Michael J. Madigan of Chicago predicted that a compromise bill that the House and the Senate ultimately write might still wear the label of consumer protection, but it would be a dim shadow of 626.
"Do we stand our ground?" he asked. "That could mean no bill at all. My expectation would be to accept a watered down version."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Reception Courts Black and Hispanic Legislators

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 15

 BODY:
With a bounce in his step, Assemblyman John J. Faso, a Republican, made his rounds at a popular reception in the Omni Hotel ballroom, shaking hands at the conference of a group dominated by Democrats: the New York State Association of Black and Puerto Rican Legislators.
But in contrast to the other social gatherings of the conference, this reception was something of a landmark -- the first to be held by Republicans in the 27-year history of the conference. The hosts of the gathering on Saturday night were the Republican State Committee and the New York Black Republican Council. 
 The conference, which brings together black and Hispanic elected officials from throughout the state, has been the weekend's epicenter of activity for the politically ambitious in this year of races for governor, lieutenant governor, state comptroller, the United States Senate and the House of Representatives.
Mr. Faso of Kinderhook, who is considering running for State Comptroller against H. Carl McCall, the Democratic incumbent, said that the Republican reception gave him a forum to make his name better known.
"It's a great opportunity to meet people, network and, potentially, lay the groundwork for a campaign," Mr. Faso said, standing in a room of hundreds of black Republican political activists and business people.
"I think this shows that the Republican Party recognizes that we need black Republicans," said Mr. Faso, whose potential opponent, Mr. McCall, is the state's highest-ranking black official. "There is a Republican Governor and a Republican Senator," the Assemblyman said, "and we want people to know that the Republican Party is a path to opportunity."
For Democrats as well -- a great number of them -- the conference, informally known as the Caucus, provided many opportunities to forge alliances and make an impression.
There was Representative Charles E. Schumer, a candidate for the United States Senate seat held by Alfonse M. D'Amato, dancing to vintage rhythm and blues. There was Mark J. Green, the New York City Public Advocate and fellow Senate candidate, swaying to music in a church service this morning.
There was Richard Kahan, a former state economic development official who is seeking the Democratic nomination for governor, at virtually every event, stopping attendees and introducing himself. And there was James L. Larocca, a former State Transportation Commissioner, holding his own reception to draw attention to his campaign for Governor.
There was State Senator Catherine M. Abate of Manhattan, who is running for Attorney General, walking through a hotel lobby and restaurant, shaking hands and asking a district leader or two for support. At several points, Ms. Abate nearly bumped into G. Oliver Koppell, a former Attorney General who is trying to recapture his old job.
Not all the candidates attended. More than a few attendees commented on the absence of former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, a Democratic candidate for the Senate, and District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn, who is running for Governor. Gov. George E. Pataki sent a letter apologizing for not being able to attend.
The widest and most eclectic array of political aspirants could be seen at the banquet tonight for nearly 2,000 elected officials, party district leaders and activists, and union leaders.
Before taking his seat at the table with Don King, the boxing promoter, the Rev. Al Sharpton walked by Representative Edolphus Towns, against whom he is considering running, without exchanging any words. Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco, a Republican, spoke to an audience that included two Democrats seeking his job. While Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the New York City Council and a candidate for governor, greeted guests on one side of the hall, another gubernatorial candidate, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, shook hands on the other.
"This gives the opportunity to everyone who is running for something to get some visibility," said State Senator Larry B. Seabrook, Democrat of the Bronx, who is chairman of the black and Hispanic legislators' association. He is considering running this year against Representative Eliot L. Engel, another Democrat from the Bronx. "For politicians," Senator Seabrook said, "visibility is what's it's really all about."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK STATE;
Crowd Halts Plan to Vote On Casino Gambling

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CATTARAUGUS INDIAN RESERVATION

 BODY:
A vociferous crowd of casino opponents halted a proposal Saturday to hold a referendum on a proposal under which the Seneca Nation of Indians would purchase land in Niagara Falls and legalize high-stakes casino gambling on it. But Michael Schindler, president of the Seneca Nation, left open the possibility that the issue could be reconsidered. 
 "It is not a dead issue," Mr. Schindler, who was elected on an anti-casino platform in 1996, told the crowd of more than 300 people.
The Niagara Falls Redevelopment Corporation wants to make an Indian casino the centerpiece of its $140 million plan for the city.

LENGTH: 113 words

HEADLINE: The Zen of Shopping

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The Buddha is quoted as saying, "Life is suffering." More accurately, his first noble truth reads, "There is no lasting satisfaction." Therein lies the answer to the question of Stanley Lebergott's Feb. 10 Op-Ed article: "What's wrong with buying stuff?" 
 Material consumption as the answer to the mystery of life leads to an endless escalation, because all things do grow old. "But," one might fairly ask, "what's the problem with that in an escalating economy?" The answer, it should be obvious, but obviously is not, is that the web of life can't support six billion humans on a spending spree.
 
ROBERT B. LEVIN
Morristown, N.J., Feb. 11, 1998

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: FRESH HAZARDS -- A special report.;
For Oystermen, a Harvest of Risk and Burden

BYLINE: By DONNA ST. GEORGE 

DATELINE: EMPIRE, La.

 BODY:
Blessed by a gentle breeze, Mitchell and Frank Jurisich stand on the deck of their wide, white fishing boat as it scuds across a Louisiana bayou. Beneath them lies a bed of rock-heavy oysters, ready to be wrestled from the sea, in a rite of harvest handed down three generations.
"In the early days they couldn't get people to do this work," Mitchell Jurisich, a beefy man of 34, says as he culls and sacks the black-shelled bivalves with his brother. "To get these oysters from the bottom to the oyster bar takes a lot of heartache." 
 These days the struggle is more complex than the oystermen of the Louisiana bayou ever imagined. In an era of growing concern about hidden dangers in the nation's food supply, their way of life depends on a shellfish blamed for more severe illness than any other seafood. Since Federal officials started cataloguing cases in 1989, an average of 10 people a year have died from eating raw Gulf oysters that carried a little-known bacterium, Vibrio vulnificus.
Millions of people eat Gulf oysters with no ill effect, and here, as in many other industries, health officials are grappling with a kind of moral arithmetic of regulation, weighing lives potentially lost, workers displaced and traditions ended.
"You get into these societal, ethical questions," said Glenn Morris, an epidemiologist at the University of Maryland School of Medicine in Baltimore. After being steeped in the oyster issue for 18 years, Dr. Morris said, "I'm still on the fence."
In Louisiana, the top processor in a region that harvests nearly 60 percent of the nation's oyster crop, the livelihood of about 900 oystermen is at stake. The coastal version of family farmers, many work as their fathers and grandfathers did, on water bottoms leased from the state and inherited like liquid land.
From 1991 to 1996, they have seen the price they get for oyster meat come in 35 to 40 percent lower than expected as a result of public alarm over health issues, according to a study at Louisiana State University.
Here in Empire, 55 miles southeast of New Orleans, oystermen are battling a paradox of the Gulf: the same warm, brackish waters that make it the nation's most abundant oyster grounds create ideal conditions for Vibrio vulnificus.
Vibrio vulnificus, first reported in medical journals in 1979, is natural in the water and harmless to most people. Its presence cannot be detected by smell, sight or taste in the fleshy, gray-skinned morsels that people savor. But when the Gulf gets warmest in the summer and early fall, the benign bacterium turns deadly for a small group of people with chronic medical conditions.
"The most commonly affected are people with liver disease and more specifically alcoholic liver disease," said Sean Altekruse, an epidemiologist at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
Liver ailments like hepatitis and cirrhosis are a factor in 80 percent of cases.
The Food and Drug Administration has shifted its approach to this new threat several times, buffeted between industry leaders who have opposed major restrictions and consumer advocates who want Gulf oysters either pasteurized or taken off the market during warm-water months. For now, the F.D.A. has settled on a program of public education and fishing rules.
Still, Vibrio vulnificus is not widely known. As a result, people like Daniel Gregor, 46, can become its unknowing victims.
Mr. Gregor, a construction contractor from Cape Coral, Fla., was meeting his fiancee's family for the first time over lunch in a New Orleans restaurant on Aug. 15, 1996, when he ate raw oysters. A recent blood donor, Mr. Gregor had been told he might have hepatitis C but had no idea it could be a problem, said his fiancee, Elizabeth Lyle.
Ms. Lyle recalled that she had asked the waitress about the wisdom of eating oysters in a month without an R, in violation of the adage. " 'We eat them all year-round here,' " Ms. Lyle recalled the waitress as saying. A health warning at the raw bar was not pointed out. By the next morning, Mr. Gregor was in an emergency room with a high fever. A day later, he was in a coma.
"It happened so quickly that I never had the chance to say any last words," said Ms. Lyle, a teacher, who watched in horror as her intended husband -- with his "merry blue eyes" and rich storyteller's voice -- died 10 days after the lunch.
Vibrio vulnificus is the worst of the pathogens linked to raw oysters, and it has not been found to cause illness in oysters outside the Gulf. The vast majority of people who become ill from raw oysters endure nothing as traumatic as Mr. Gregor did and are reacting to more innocuous pathogens, primarily a group called Norwalk-related viruses.
These viruses, spread when sewage is dumped into the water, have sickened at least 440 people in four reported outbreaks in the last four years, causing flu-like symptoms -- vomiting and diarrhea -- that pass in a day or two. Experts say they believe that thousands of other cases have gone unreported.
Unlike oysters that are cooked to high heats, those served raw can contain pathogens ingested in the waters where they grow. Coastal states have instituted educational programs to prevent sickness. But in the Gulf, the problem is trickier: the greatest hazard has nothing to do with pollution.
Mr. Gregor was one of 35 people nationally who fell ill from Vibrio vulnificus in oysters in 1996, when the most illnesses were recorded, and he was one of 24 who died. In 1997, 15 people fell ill and 8 died.
Those numbers are small in the context of the 170 million half-shell Gulf oysters harvested yearly from April through October, when nearly all Vibrio vulnificus infections occur. Even in the worst year, 1996, there was only one illness for every 812,000 servings of 6 raw Gulf oysters. But the remarkable death rate -- 56 percent of those who get sick -- creates a quandary in public health.
"It's a difficult societal question when the risks are to relatively small subpopulations and even the incidence within that small subpopulation is relatively small," said Philip Spiller, director of the seafood office of the F.D.A.
 
The Traditions
Croatian Immigrants Arrived in 1800's
Frank Jurisich, 33, slows the boat to a near-stop at one of his family's oyster beds, marked by tall white plastic poles bearing a yellow tip. Working the winch, he lowers a dredge into the water and, turning the wheel again, drags the dredge along the bottom, five feet below.
Within minutes Mr. Jurisich reels up a dark, briny load, spilling it onto a bare aluminum table. It lands with a clattering thud: rough, mottled, misshapen shells, no sign of the delicate oysters within.
"They're just like rocks until you open them up and see how they taste," Mitchell Jurisich says, opening a silvery round beauty and eating it with a smile.
The brothers work with many third- and fourth-generation farmers of the marsh in the heartland of oyster country, Plaquemines Parish, a rural outpost where the Mississippi converges with the Gulf of Mexico in an expanse of bays and bayous.
Here, Croatian immigrants settled in the 1800's, building houses on stilts in a remote area swarming with mosquitoes and alligators.
"It was harsh country out there in the marshland -- this was not prime real estate -- but the immigrants were perfectly satisfied to do what they had learned in Yugoslavia: fish," said Ron Dugas, a state biologist.
Generation after generation, families anchored their lives to the oyster. Paid $10 to $22 per sack of 200 to 300 oysters, often working six- or seven-day weeks, oystermen have made a living that often improves with each generation. On average, they earn $25,000 to $40,000 a year.
Much of the harvest is trucked to the oyster-loving mid-Atlantic region, where environmental problems in the Chesapeake Bay have reduced its oyster crop to a small fraction of its glory days.
Even today there is continuity in the oystering life -- in the grit and muscle it demands, in the hardy families who embrace it -- but the relationship between man and mollusk is more complicated than it once was.
"It was physically tougher for our fathers and grandfathers," Frank Jurisich said as he planted his rubber boots at the helm of the family's 69-foot boat, named St. Ann, the patron saint of the local Catholic church. "But with all of the regulation and politics, it is harder for us."
 
The Threat
Bacterium Grows In Warm Waters
Oystermen have always had worries: predators, hurricanes, poachers, luck. But since the 1980's, oystermen along Louisiana's 350-mile coastline have confronted a threat they could neither see nor control: Vibrio vulnificus.
The bacterium has been a mysterious foe. Researchers know that it multiplies in warm waters -- and that illnesses have risen as the Gulf's summer harvest has grown. They know that sickness peaks in August, September and October and that the vulnerable are a small group among the 12 million to 30 million people with liver disease, alcoholism, weakened immune systems, insulin-treated diabetes, advanced cancer, H.I.V., severe kidney disease, chronic hepatitis B and C, hemochromatosis and a history of gastric surgery.
But researchers still cannot explain why one liver-diseased person dies from Vibrio vulnificus while a multitude of others feel nothing. The researchers do not know what the infectious dose is, or enough about hypervirulent strains.
As scientists look for answers, the bacterium has made headlines. Florida, Louisiana, California and North Carolina have passed laws requiring that consumers be warned of the dangers where the seafood is sold.
The growing fear has hurt the reputation of Gulf oysters, as have outbreaks of more ordinary food poisoning. Making matters worse, a recent health report found that oystermen had caused several hundred of the cases of ordinary food sickness by dumping their sewage overboard.
Consumers backed off in many areas. In New York, some restaurants have given up on Gulf oysters.
"There's just so many other kinds of oysters out there; there's no reason to use them," said Mark Abrahamson, of the Oyster Bar and Restaurant at Grand Central Terminal.
While prices have made a partial rebound, said Dr. Walter R. Keithly Jr., a fisheries economist at Louisiana State University, "I think the industry's lost a segment of the population and it will not come back."
 
The Regulations
F.D.A. Seeks to Find A Middle Ground
The phone rings and as Pete Vujnovich listens to the caller's voice his leathery face wrinkles with a frown. Another customer wants more oysters, and he has none to sell.
"It's the way the board of health's got us working," complains Mr. Vujnovich, 75, a broad-shouldered man with a gray stubble beard.
Mr. Vujnovich, the Jurisichs' uncle, followed his father into the bayou 63 years ago and expanded by opening a shucking house in 1951. In this era of new regulations, his two oyster boats, each operated by a son, must deliver oysters to the dock to be refrigerated every six hours in the summer. But with reefs 90 minutes to four hours away, his catch is down.
"Tell me why we can't be out there 30 hours?" he lamented.
Mr. Vujnovich and other oystermen are working under refrigeration standards imposed in 1995 to minimize illness from Vibrio vulnificus. Keeping oysters on ice does not kill the pathogen, but it does keep it from multiplying, researchers say. But after two years it is unclear that the measures have prevented more illnesses, said Mr. Spiller of the F.D.A.
The F.D.A. supports a compromise plan -- 10 hours instead of 6 -- despite protests from consumer advocates. As such standards are debated, a larger question looms: How much death is too much?
"This is only a $50 million industry, and these are problems way beyond its value," said Caroline Smith DeWaal, director of food safety for the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a consumer advocacy group in Washington.
But Mark Tamplin, a food scientist at the University of Florida, asked, "If you build a case for closing it down for 10 to 15 deaths a year, then why aren't we closing down the poultry industry?"
The Federal Government itself is not of one mind. In the early 1990's, the F.D.A. urged the public not to eat raw shellfish. Several years ago, the agency toned down its approach, proposing a ban on half-shell Gulf oysters from April 1 through Oct. 31, when bacteria is most abundant.
After an outcry from oystermen and their political leaders -- and a study that showed the value of the Gulf harvest would plummet 54 percent -- the F.D.A. changed course again, opting to educate those at risk and require refrigeration, tagging and other safeguards.
"I don't think the agency thinks there is a single right answer," Mr. Spiller said.
While not happy about restrictions, many oystermen realize the need for extra care. Through four generations of working the water in Golden Meadow, 40 miles west of Empire, no one in the Collins family had known of anyone who had become ill, said Wilbert Collins Sr., 60. Then several years ago, Mr. Collins said, he was told about a cancer patient who he said ignored a health warning and died after eating his oysters.
"It really makes you feel bad," he said. "You don't want anyone dying off the oysters you caught."
 
The Future
Possible Answer Lies In Pasteurization
John Tesvich, 40, is a fourth-generation oysterman whose great-grandfather perished in the Gulf Coast hurricane of 1893. With his industry facing this new natural disaster, Mr. Tesvich started looking for solutions.
With two partners, Mr. Tesvich hired researchers and in Empire founded Ameripure, which processes oysters with a mild pasteurization to eliminate detectable levels of Vibrio vulnificus. But oysters still look and taste raw. After 20 months, the company sells in 26 states, at 6 to 8 cents more an oyster wholesale. Some experts say the oysters taste just as good; critics argue that they are less juicy and a little rubbery.
Impressed with the technique, consumer advocates argue for mandated pasteurization for Gulf oysters. But the F.D.A. is reluctant.
"It would be a rather profound step," Mr. Spiller said, given the brief track record of the process and its few practitioners.
Oystermen have mixed feelings, but many accept that they may be forced to adopt new ways if they are to reconcile the work started by their grandfathers with modern realities about risk and sickness.
That is surely true for Sam Slavich, 47, a fourth-generation oysterman who has a college degree but never applied for another job.
"This is what I was born to do," Mr. Slavich said. "I know what the farmer who harvests corn or wheat feels because I feel the same thing about oysters."
Vibrio vulnificus has been a vexing problem, he said, because "more people are struck by lightning." But Mr. Slavich also concluded that the debate might make life more stable for the next generation.
"Hopefully," he said, "we can get to a place where nobody gets sick."
In these complex times, the Jurisich brothers look to the resilience of their forefathers.
"It's a cyclic thing," Mitchell said. "We learned that from our father."

GRAPHIC: Photos: A potentially deadly bacterium in Gulf Coast oysters is threatening a way of life for people like Frank Jurisich, at left, who works the family's 69-foot boat in Louisiana. "It was physically tougher for our fathers and grandfathers," Mr. Jurisich said. "But with all of the regulation and politics, it is harder for us." (Photographs by Alex Brandon for The New York Times)(pg. A14)
 
Chart: "AT A GLANCE: Threat in Oysters"
 
VIBRIO VULNIFICUS -- A bacterium that exists harmlessly in many coastal waters but can in rare cases cause food poisoning when raw oysters are eaten from the Gulf of Mexico in warm-water months. An occasional case has been traced to raw clams.
 
INCIDENCE -- Since 1989, 167 illnesses reported; 87 of those were fatal, or about 10 a year. (To compare, 85 people a year die after being struck by lightning.)
 
SYMPTOMS -- Chills, fever, nausea, blood poisoning.
 
AT RISK -- People with liver disease (from viral hepatitis, excessive alcohol use or other causes). Also those with weakened immunities, insulin-treated diabetes, advanced cancer, H.I.V. infection, hemochromatosis, severe kidney disease and a history of gastric surgery.
 
SAFETY TIPS -- Thorough cooking kills vibrio vulnificus or other pathogens. The Food and Drug Administration recommends boiling, frying or broiling oysters for three minutes, or baking at 450 degrees for 10 minutes.
If eating raw, realize that vibrio vulnificus is more abundant in the warm waters of summer and early fall.
 
OTHER PATHOGENS -- Other vibrio strains, the family of Norwalk-related viruses and hepatitis A. They generally cause brief bouts of fever, diarrhea and vomiting.
 
MORE INFORMATION -- F.D.A. hot line, (800) FDA-4010. DONNA ST. GEORGE (pg. A14)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Americans Show Signs Of Tapping Brakes on Debt
American consumers, often portrayed as fecklessly mired in high-cost debt, appear to be saying enough is enough.
Though signs of strained budgets continue to grab more attention, automobile, credit card and other installment debt, which excludes mortgages, rose just 4.7 percent last year, compared with 6.9 percent in 1996 and 14.2 percent in 1995. Page D2. 

Insurer in Talks on Sale
Anthem Health, an insurer, has begun discussions on a sale of its business to the United States subsidiary of a big Canadian insurer, Great-West Life Assurance. D4.
 
Phone Equipment Deal
Tellabs agreed to buy Coherent Communications Systems for $670 million in stock to bolster its presence in overseas markets for phone equipment used to transmit data, video and voice signals. D6.
 
Sony Pictures Executive Quits
Jeff Sagansky, co-president of Sony Pictures Entertainment, resigned, citing differences over the company's direction. D4.
 
New Tack on Mental Health Drugs
The pharmaceutical industry is increasingly marketing mental health drugs directly to consumers, using tactics that would have been unthinkable a few years ago. A1.
 
Nashville Paper to Be Shut Down
The Nashville Banner, an afternoon newspaper, said that it would close on Friday after 122 years of publication. A10.
 
Soaring Biotechnology Stock
Terren Peizer, once Michael R. Milken's left-hand man and later a star witness against him, is now president of a fledgling biotechnology company with a stock that has soared 170 percent this year. Market Place. D5.
 
Analog: Not Dead Yet?
A computer designer says he has found a way to take advantage of 30-year-old research with analog communications to offer low-cost, high-speed alternatives to digital networks. D6.
 
Turnaround for VW Unit
Financial trouble followed the opening of a new plant by SEAT, Volkswagen's Spanish subsidiary, in 1993, amid the European economic slump. Since then, however, the highly automated factory has become one of the most productive in the Volkswagen group, and the zippy little SEAT cars made there started showing modest profits in 1996. D6.
 
Winner Expected in REIT Bidding
Investors are expected to know as early as tomorrow which of three bidders will acquire Corporate Property Investors, a closely held New York-based real estate investment trust, for an estimated $4.5 billion. D2.
 
U.S. Markets Reopen
Financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Presidents' Day, but will reopen today. Most markets overseas were open.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: VOICES;
For Ohioans, Hussein Must Go, But Bombs May Not Be the Way

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Wearing the annoyed look of a man recalling a half-forgotten enemy, Paul Ward, a retired accountant, put down his shopping bag at the mall and pondered whether America should bomb Iraq.
If the United States could put an end to the leadership of President Saddam Hussein, Mr. Ward said, he was all for it. 
 "Should have been done right the first time," Mr. Ward said, contending that the United States could have driven Mr. Hussein from power during the Persian Gulf war in 1991. "But if we're going to do it, let's do it right. None of this fiddle-faddling around. I don't want to see them bomb and then a few years down the road, he's back at us. Let's go in and get it done."
With Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Defense Secretary William S. Cohen scheduled to hold a town meeting here on Wednesday on possible military strikes against Iraq, the people in Columbus have been weighing their sentiments on war and peace.
In talks with dozens of people at a shopping mall, it is plain that the people here, a largely white-collar region of one million people, have been following the accounts of the standoff with Iraq, which center on the Iraqi leader's refusal to allow inspection of weapons sites, and grappling with hard choices.
While most people seem to believe the United States should take action against Iraq, there is plenty of doubt, and almost universal exasperation that American forces might once again be placed in harm's way.
 "You wonder, 'Is it really worth American lives?' " asked Kelly Armstrong, a 28-year-old barber, as he carried his six-month-old son. "But if we don't do something now, then there's going to be a lot more lives lost later on."
No matter what their stance on military action, almost everyone says they have grown weary of the image of a dangerous despot tweaking the United States.
"He's just like a little bully on the playground," said Walter Cain, a 61-year-old social worker. "He's kicking sand in our face, and we've got to do something about it. We can't just let him get away with it."
That same sense of outrage, and strong demand for American respect, rang as a familar theme among people who supporter military action immediately.
"I'm really mad we've waited so long," said Renee Moos, a 35-year-old cosmetics clerk, complaining that the United States looks weak if it does not act in the strongest way possible. "They should go in and get it done now. We can't just let this go on and on."
While Gallup polls in mid-January and again in early February showed Americans divided over whether to use military action against Iraq, the surveys indicated that support for an armed attack is growing.
Still, there is plenty of anguish over what course to follow, and some voices that say America should stay out of the Middle East.
"I'm not sure it's the American people's responsibility to take care of a place so far away," said Liji Zhao, 33, who stays at home to care for two children.
This view is shared by Jodi Bacon, a 36-year-old mother of four children, who pushed a stroller through the mall. She noted that Arab allies are unwilling to help, and said some countries would condemn military aciton by the United States.
"If we take a really aggressive stance, the reaction around the world against America will be negative," Ms. Bacon said. "We need to be careful what other countries think. The world's getting smaller, and we depend on each other more."
The last time the United States prepared to take military action against Saddam Hussein, Steven Leist, a young college student, traveled to Washington to protest against it.
But Mr. Leist, now a 27-year-old clothing store worker, said he has become convinced that bombs should be dropped on Iraq.
"I used to be very idealistic, and I thought you could reform people," said Mr. Leist, who had been a theater and English major at Ohio State University during the Persian Gulf war. "But this guy is insane. And he needs to be gotten rid of."
Many people said they wished there were a way for American intelligence forces to covertly topple President Hussein so innnocent lives might be spared among both Iraqis and American troops.
"The poor people of Iraq -- they don't have much of a say in all this," said Dimitri Karmagiannis, 38, who works in computer operations. "They've got machine guns at their backs."
For all the talk in Washington about whether the sex scandal in the White House would color the Iraq situation, almost nobody here mentioned it. The one or two people who did talk about it did so almost flippantly, dismissing the notion that President Clinton's decision-making would be affected by it.
"The problem with Iraq was on the drawing board long before anyone heard of Monica Lewinsky," said Byron Peasley, a 55-year-old banker, "so I don't think it's fair to link the two."
Mr. Peasley, who gives Mr. Clinton high marks for his handling of the economy, said the President had been mostly untested on international matters.
"This would be his biggest action on the world scene," he said, "and I'm not entirely confident in his ability to handle international affairs."
To Eric Duhlen, a 25-year-old music store worker, there are no good paths to follow in the stand-off with Iraq.
"It's kind of a no-win situation," said Mr. Duhlen, his arms crossing his chest. "If he's got these terrible weapons, we can't just ignore it, and let him go.
"But everybody knows that when the bombs start falling, he's going to be safe somewhere. And then he's going to come out, and still be in power."
Nancy Ward, the wife of the retired accountant, said she had hoped after the gulf war that Mr. Hussein would eventually lose power. Now she believes the United States must crush his military.
"Sanctions and diplomacy and all that, they don't always work," said Mrs. Ward, a 66-year-old bookkeeper. "How long were we waiting for Castro to fall from power? And he's still there."

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Slowed in 1997, Rising Only 4.7%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY 

 BODY:
American consumers, often portrayed as fecklessly mired in high-cost debt, appear to be saying enough is enough.
Their automobile, credit card and other installment debt, which excludes mortages, rose just 4.7 percent last year, compared with 6.9 percent in 1996 and 14.2 percent in 1995. 
 The slowdown in borrowing was easy to overlook in a year when personal bankruptcies set a record, the debt burden hovered near a decade high and the nation's savings rate established a half-century low.
While signs of strained budgets grabbed attention, the consumer kings and queens whose spending accounts for two-thirds of national output responded by throttling back. And they ended the year on a particularly sober note.
In dollar terms, consumers owed no more at year's end than they had two months earlier. Installment debt grew at a modest 3.9 percent annual rate in December, after falling 3.6 percent in November. Until then, there had been an unbroken string of increases dating to May 1993.
Though monthly numbers can be volatile and gauges of consumer confidence remain strong, the October stock market decline could have taken some of the wind out of consumer borrowing. So could the prospect of deflation pressures and economic slowdown reverberating from the Asian financial crisis.
"Consumers as a group are very responsible borrowers," said James F. Smith, a finance professor at the University of North Carolina and a former credit specialist at Sears, Roebuck & Company. "They typically pull in their horns before they cause a problem," either overextending themselves or destabilizing the economy at large.
Because consumer spending has helped fuel the economic boom, and much of that spending has been through borrowing, a drastic slowdown could be worrisome. The flip side of spending is saving, and the national savings rate fell to 3.8 percent last year, its lowest level in 58 years.
To some degree, Americans have been forced to be more frugal. Banks have been tightening their lending standards every quarter for about two years, according to a survey of senior loan officers by the Federal Reserve.
Consumers also have a heavy debt load already. Measured as a percentage of disposable income, installment debt has hovered at 20 percent for the last three years, near its highs of the late 1980's.
"Consumers seem to be sensitive to their debt levels," said James Chessen, chief economist at the American Bankers Association. The debt trouble that pushed bankruptcies to a high last year is abating by one measure. Late payments on eight types of consumer installment loans retreated during the third quarter of 1997 -- the latest data available -- to 2.52 percent of accounts from a five-year peak of 2.55 percent the previous quarter.
The relatively high interest rate on loans other than home mortgages has probably helped curb consumer appetites for loans. The Federal Reserve has kept its benchmark short-term interest rate at 5.5 percent -- justification enough for banks to keep their prime rate at a lofty 8.5 percent -- even as inflation has virtually disappeared.
Should the decline in inflation, known as disinflation, give way to deflation, or a general decline in prices, debt repayment would become far more burdensome for consumers. That is because much of the borrowed money has been used to buy assets, from homes to cars, whose value would fall. An example on a limited scale is the real estate downturn of the 1980's in which some homeowners in depressed markets suddenly found themselves with negative equity, owing more on their homes than those homes would bring at sale.
Most economists say the prospects of deflation, which is readily fought by opening up the Fed's money spigot, are very slim.
Nor do they fear that the current business expansion, expected to reach the seven-year mark next month, is in jeopardy because of overextended or satiated consumers or from worried lenders.
For one thing, the economy has terrific momentum, growing at an annual rate of 4.3 percent in the final quarter of 1997 and 3.8 percent for the full year.
Another reason is history. For all their power, consumers rarely bring on recession. The obvious exception was spring 1980, when the Carter Administration, faced with double-digit inflation, slapped controls on credit and suggested that using plastic was unpatriotic. The economy plunged into a recession, which led to swift removal of the controls.
Downturns are nearly always the result of imbalances in corporate America, overheated economic conditions that force the Federal Reserve to raise rates or external shocks.
High levels of consumer borrowing have been partly explained by increased convenience spending on credit cards, for frequent-flier miles and such. If a credit card bill is paid in full each month, it may not represent an increase in borrowing, just an easier method of payment.
Demographic shifts may also play a role. An increasing share of the population has reached the ages when borrowing is heaviest, for homes, cars and education. And the rise of home values and stock investments has encouraged consumers to take out a loan, rather than sell assets, when they want to enjoy some of the fruits of prosperity.
While rising wealth provides a cushion for some consumers, for others it inspires disproportionate spending, a process that David A. Levy, director of forecasting at the Jerome Levy Economics Institute at Bard College, calls "wealth euphoria," which may or may not continue. Moreover, many of these assets are not so readily available to pay bills since they are tied up in 401(k) retirement and other savings plans, said Susan M. Sterne, a consumer specialist in Greenwich, Conn. "It's not liquid," she said.

HEADLINE: Anthem Health in Sale Talks With Canadian Insurer's Unit

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Anthem Health, an insurer with headquarters in Piscataway, N.J., has begun discussions on a sale of its business to the United States subsidiary of a big Canadian insurer, in another illustration of the consolidation that is sweeping the health insurance industry.
Executives of Anthem Health, a wholly owned subsidiary of Anthem Inc., which operates Blue Cross Blue Shield programs in several states, have been told in briefings and company memos that their organization is in talks with the Great-West Life and Annuity Insurance Company in Denver, a subsidiary of the Great-West Life Assurance Company, one of the leading health insurers in Canada, according to some of the Anthem executives. 
 Analysts said the combining of Anthem Health, which has been losing money for the last two years, with Great-West would extend Great-West's reach in New Jersey, Florida, Georgia, Texas and California and increase its bargaining power with doctors and hospitals.
It would also enable Anthem's parent to concentrate more on its profitable Blue Cross business where it has about 25 percent of the market in Indiana, Ohio, Kentucky and Connecticut.
Increasing market share to achieve economies of scale and getting out of markets where companies do not have major shares, as is the case with Anthem's New Jersey subsidiary, have been two hallmarks of the current consolidation wave.
Spokesmen for the companies refused to comment on any pending sale.
Anthem Health, which has about 483,000 customers, down from about 672,000 a year ago, has a book value of about $150 million. Investment bankers say health insurers have been selling for about 1.5 times book value, which would put an Anthem sale in the vicinity of $225 million.
Even though Anthem has been losing money, it could add to Great-West's profits as market share increased, said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, an analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
Larry Mayewski, a senior vice president at A. M. Best Company, the rating agency, said Great-West is "a very strong player" in the United States, and Mr. Abramowitz said it was about the 10th-largest health insurer in the United States.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Spanish Company Is a Star Of Volkswagen's Universe

BYLINE: By AL GOODMAN 

DATELINE: BARCELONA, Spain

 BODY:
Managers at SEAT S.A., the Volkswagen auto maker in Spain, miscalculated when their new $2 billion factory opened near here in 1993 in the midst of a European economic slump, giving them the capacity to produce 50 percent more cars than they could sell.
The investment led SEAT to four consecutive years in the red, 1992-95, the largest being a huge $1.1 billion loss in 1993 that included provisions for a $375 million early retirement buyout to help reduce the work force. 
 Since then, however, the highly automated factory, 18 miles northwest of Barcelona at Martorell, has become one of the most productive in the Volkswagen group, and the zippy little SEAT (pronounced SAY-ott) cars finally started showing modest profits in 1996.
"SEAT has recovered very strongly and very fast," said Pierre-Alain de Smedt, 53, who was tapped in late 1996 to run SEAT after heading Volkswagen operations in Brazil and Argentina.
"A tremendous amount of work has been done inside the company," said Pedro Nueno, a professor at the University of Navarra's I.E.S.E. graduate school of management in Barcelona, which holds an annual conference on the automotive industry. "Now the company has excellent models. They are in a strong position worldwide."
Volkswagen bought 75 percent of the state-run company in 1986 and the rest in 1990. VW has remained committed despite SEAT's slow profits, confident that it can position the brand abroad as a sporty car and upgrade its image in Spain, where for years SEAT was the only affordable car and the butt of comments about poor quality.
But in the Volkswagen group, which includes the luxury Audi of Germany and the practical Skoda from the Czech Republic, a corporate spokesman conceded that SEAT still had more work than the other brands to carve out its own identity.
"Volkswagen is a brand with an image going back many years," said the spokesman, Kurt Rippholz, at corporate headquarters in Wolfsburg, Germany. "SEAT is at the beginning. It has the longest way ahead."
SEAT had profit of $42 million in 1996 on sales of $4.8 billion and will have higher profit in 1997 on sales of about $5.4 billion, Mr. de Smedt said, avoiding specifics until Volkswagen approves the 1997 accounts. But profits are still below the 6.5 percent return on sales that SEAT aims to achieve within five years.
SEAT will not enter the United States market anytime soon, preferring to consolidate its 2.5 percent market share in Europe. It had double-digit sales growth last year in Germany, Italy, Britain and Portugal, and also in Spain, where it has a 12 percent market share. In all, 70 percent of SEAT's production of 400,000 cars is sold abroad.
But it was not always so. The Franco dictatorship started SEAT in 1950, ceding a 7 percent stake to Fiat S.p.A. of Italy, and concentrated on building affordable cars for Spain's emerging middle class. The company was baptized as S.E.A.T., a Spanish acronym for the Spanish Company for Touring Automobiles; later it became known simply as SEAT.
Even before Volkswagen's entry, SEAT had tried to polish its image. It quit calling its models only by numbers, like the ubiquitous SEAT 600, and started naming them for chic Spanish locales. SEAT's Ibiza, the best-selling car at home in 1997, is named after Spain's jet-set Mediterranean island.
Volkswagen pushed for more improvements in SEAT performance and styling. The Ibiza racing version made its debut in world rally competition in 1996 and in 1997 won in its small-car category. And the engineering staff has doubled, to 400, at SEAT's secretive, gated research and design center on a bluff overlooking the sprawling 740-acre Martorell factory.
The factory makes five SEAT models, which are sold in 60 nations, and three Volkswagen models, sold mainly in Europe. Two other SEAT models are produced at Volkswagen plants in Germany and Portugal, and another model is assembled at SEAT's old factory, 20 miles from Martorell in Barcelona's port area.
SEAT's emphasis is increasingly on the Martorell factory, which cuts costs by using common undercarriages and a large percentage of common components to build various models of cars. An army of outside suppliers situated nearby deliver parts right to the assembly line, and the factory recently reached a rate of 60 vehicles per worker annually, one of Europe's most efficient.
The factory employs 8,100 workers, representing 62 percent of SEAT's total work force. Martorell's daily production of 2,040 cars may soon increase to 2,200, and for the first time in SEAT's history the plant stayed open last August during Spain's traditional vacation month.
But Manuel Gallardo Mendez, a leader of SEAT's highly unionized 13,000 employees, cautioned that while strikes were rare during the crisis years, the unions are worried about their aging members and want another early retirement buyout to make way for younger employees. In the 1993 buyout, the 3,000 longtime workers who accepted the offer received $125,000 each.
Management is cool to another buyout, preferring instead to expand sales. But it did cooperate lately with the unions to redesign the factory uniform in beige, symbolic of a move to modernize in a nation where the blue worker outfit is still the norm.
SEAT aspires to compete with Alfa Romeo and Lancia of Italy, company spokesmen said. But although it is planning for a more luxurious car, SEAT's most expensive car now is the fully equipped family-size Toledo, which costs only about $19,000, considerably less than similar Alfa and Lancia models.
Despite the upmarket aspirations, SEAT's focus in the first half of 1998 will be on small cars. Its mini-car, the Arosa, retailing for $7,300, will switch production from a Volkswagen plant in Germany to SEAT's factory in Martorell.

HEADLINE: Newspaper In Nashville Dies at 122

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Feb. 16

 BODY:
The Nashville Banner today became the latest casualty in the continuing battle between morning and afternoon newspapers, with the publisher of the afternoon daily announcing that it would close on Friday after 122 years of publication.
Like many afternoon newspapers, The Banner had suffered through years of declining circulation, despite steady population growth and a booming economy in middle Tennessee, and it simply could not find a formula for reversing the trend. 
 Last month, the locally owned newspaper's circulation was 39,839, down from about 63,000 a decade ago. It had dropped by nearly 6 percent just since September, and was projected to decline to 25,000 or less within two years, said Irby C. Simpkins Jr., The Banner's publisher.
"Nothing has been more frustrating to me during the past 18 years than to receive such solid reader feedback about our work, and yet to watch our circulation steadily decline," Mr. Simpkins wrote in a letter to readers in today's editions. "When our circulation went from 42,100 in September to 39,839 in January 1998, it was clear too many readers were no longer choosing our product."
Mr. Simpkins said in an interview that he and his partners chose to close The Banner now because of the irreversible circulation trends and because the health of the economy made it a good time for his 94 staff members to seek work elsewhere. He announced the news at a 7 A.M. staff meeting.
Afternoon newspapers, he said, have been the big losers in the rapid expansion of information services, including all-news cable television stations and Internet Web sites. "Our time slot is such that we're much more vulnerable to those competing products," Mr. Simpkins said. "You have to raise the question of how relevant is a second newspaper anymore because you've got so many competing voices in the community today."
Since 1937, The Banner has published under a joint operating agreement with Nashville's morning newspaper, The Tennessean, which has a circulation of about 150,000. Under the agreement, the newspapers operate independent editorial and reporting staffs, but The Tennessean, which is owned by the Gannett Company, handles the circulation, marketing, advertising, printing and other business functions for both newspapers. The newspapers are in the same building.
The Tennessean's publisher and president, Craig Moon, said in a statement that he regretted the loss of The Banner. "When the owners of The Banner made the business decision to close their newspaper, it mirrored the situation of many afternoon newspapers around the country that faced the challenges of changing life styles and readership patterns," he said.
Bill Kovach, an alumnus of The Tennessean and the curator of the Nieman Foundation, a journalism center at Harvard University, said the Nashville area would particularly miss The Banner's conservative editorial voice.
"It's a continuation of that trend toward the disappearance of alternative voices in major metropolitan communities," Mr. Kovach said, noting that The Tennessean traditionally has been far more liberal.
Mr. Kovach said that the two newspapers had such conflicting editorial views that The Banner even disagreed with The Tennessean in the early 1960's over the wisdom of daylight savings time. The Banner, Mr. Kovach said, "urged staying with God's own time, and Time magazine noted the conflict by saying that these two newspapers couldn't even agree on the time of day."
Patrick S. Embry, the executive editor of The Banner and a veteran of the paper for all of his 19 years in journalism, said there were some tears in the newsroom after Mr. Simpkins broke the news this morning.
"We've seen all the circulation numbers and read the obituaries of P.M. newspapers across the country, but you always hope that you'll be the one that single-handedly can right the trend," Mr. Embry said. "Such was not to be the case."
Mr. Embry, who wrote today's Banner story about the closing, did take some pride, however, in the timing of the announcement.
"At least we got to break the story on our time," he said.

HEADLINE: Asians Worry That U.S. Aid Is a New Colonialism

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 16

 BODY:
From America it may seem as if the United States is rescuing Asia from its economic mess, but gratitude is not the most striking emotion here in the region.
Instead, the rumblings of resentment and the stirrings of anti-Americanism seem most prominent. 
 "Just as the fall of the Berlin wall represents a political and ideological victory for the U.S. over socialism, the collapse of the economies in Asia marks another more subtle triumph of U.S. financial imperialism over the rest of this region," declared The Nation, a Thai newspaper.
Another Thai daily, Matichon, warned that the West is aiming at the "intellectual colonialism" and "economic colonialism" of Asia, and denounced the "financial and economic wars" that it said the West had mounted to humble the region.
Many people do indeed feel gratitude toward the United States for its help, and there is more annoyance at the politicians in their own capitals than at those in Washington. But although the anti-American sentiment so far is mild, many diplomats and scholars warn that a prime risk in Asia in the coming months is a heightened nationalism and hostility that could complicate American business and diplomacy in the region for years to come.
"There is a lot of pain here, and the pain is turning to anger," David Shambaugh, director of the Sigur Center for Asian Studies at George Washington University in Washington, said during a recent visit to Asia. "But the anger has yet to be vented at the United States. Still that could happen, because there's latent anti-Americanism in a lot of the countries."
For now, nations like Thailand feel annoyed that the United States has not done more to help its old friends in Asia. Throughout the region there is also aggravation that the United States is using the crisis as leverage to force countries to open up previously closed markets.
Even in Japan, which these days is one of the least nationalistic countries in the region, there is talk that the opening of financial markets starting this year will lead to a "second period of American rule," parallel to the American Occupation at the end of World War II.
"Inevitably, I think there will be resentment," M. Y. Yoshino, a professor at Harvard Business School and expert on Asia, said by phone during a visit to Singapore. "Many people in this part of the world are grateful for American help, but they also resent what they see as strong-arm tactics."
Indeed, there are even various conspiracy theories making the rounds. One is that the Central Intelligence Agency and the State Department, which are regularly given much more credit in Asia for effectiveness than they are at home, plotted Asia's crisis to win trade negotiations, put down China and bolster their influence in the region.
"The United States is certainly not offering a new Marshall Plan to East Asia," declared China's Communist Party newspaper, The People's Daily. "By giving help, it is forcing East Asia into submission, promoting the American economic and political model and easing East Asia's threat to the American model."
The upshot is that while Americans fret over whether it has been worthwhile to support the International Monetary Fund and its bail-outs of Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia, the fear in Asia is that the United States has gained too much.
So far this is just one strain in a wide-ranging debate. It is notable that in South Korea -- where many analysts had been particularly apprehensive about anti-Americanism -- the mood has swung the other way.
Suspicion of United States policy is deep-rooted in South Korea, and when the country was teetering on the verge of collapse in November and early December, it was routine to hear blame piled on the United States. Now there is much less of that, and newspapers and politicians regularly say the economic restructuring and more open markets will be in Korea's interests.
"In the past, we might have thought that it was economic colonialism," said Lee Shin Bom, a member of the Korean National Assembly. "But now the question is how we can feed 45 million people in this country and 20 million in the North."
As a result, Mr. Lee said, Korea will accept foreign investments that once would have rankled.
The turnabout in South Korean public opinion appeared to come after the nation's leading newspaper, Chosun Ilbo, ran a remarkable series of editorials that defied the conventional wisdom of the time and laid the blame for the economic crisis squarely on Korea's own shoulders. In addition, the dissident Kim Dae Jung was elected President in December and immediately began to work to build a consensus for economic reform.
Mr. Kim calls on Koreans to accept foreign investment and other changes not because they are forced to, but because this is the best way to rebuild the nation's economy. Mr. Kim's spokesman, Ben Q. Limb, said one result would be a welcome mat for foreign companies interested in setting up shop in South Korea.
"They will be a much greater presence here," Mr. Limb said. "And they should be. We're living in a world of globalization."

HEADLINE: New Orleans Mayor Thrives on Lower Crime and Lifted Spirit

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16

 BODY:
In the B. W. Cooper housing project, where politics and bullets alter lives, Marc Morial's performance as a mayor can be measured, quite literally, with a yardstick.
Here, as in other inner-city New Orleans neighborhoods, some worried mothers routinely had children sleep on the floor to protect them from stray bullets. Now, say people who live here, more of them sleep in their beds and even venture outside, with less risk, less fear. 
 A lot of dignity is gained, in the distance of a few feet.
"I see people coming out more; they're not on the floor as much," said Donna Johnigan, who lives in the neighborhood. She credits Mr. Morial's reform of the legendarily corrupt Police Department, and the fact that he actually seems to care whether the people here live or die, with making it a safer place to live.
"There's not a time we call him for a meeting that he doesn't come," Ms. Johnigan said. "He's there and he listens. That means everything to poor people."
With loyal support from such poor pockets in this majority black city -- Mr. Morial, a Democrat, won 93 percent of the black vote in his re-election here last week -- it was no wonder that this 40-year-old black Mayor's run for a second term was more like an evening stroll along the Mississippi riverfront.
But what is remarkable, as the demographics of his easy re-election have become clear, is how much support he pulled from all colors and economic corners of what had come to be seen as a city in trouble, especially in influential white communities and business circles that were, historically, color-conscious.
Combine that history-making white support -- he drew an estimated 43 percent of the white vote this time, almost five times the 9 percent that he won four years ago -- with that almost blanket support among black people, and the painfully neat, highly starched and smooth-talking Mr. Morial finds himself with the widest and deepest mandate in this contentious city in four decades. Almost 9 out of 10 people who bothered to vote, voted for him.
"This city was in the prone position," said Mr. Morial, who ran nonstop in the last four years not only to put in place programs to protect the people most at risk but also to rebuild this city's battered, bullet-riddled image as a dangerous place to live and visit. "It was like a patient and the family was sitting around, trying to decide whether to pull the plug. It was plagued by this coffee table rhetoric of, 'I'm frightened, I'm getting out.' Well, you don't hear that anymore."
Not even his legendary father, Dutch Morial, a two-term Mayor, ever had anything close to his son's mandate. The city's government now includes only friendly faces -- people Marc Morial supported -- on the City Council.
Mayor Morial's political coattails, at first suspect in an election in which he was confronted by two political unknowns, proved powerful enough to unseat a last significant nemesis, Councilwoman Peggy Wilson, a Republican. It is a long way from past races in which even token white candidates carried a huge white majority.
Times, from an improving economy to a significantly reduced crime rate, are just too good. And while some will argue that national trends have as much or more to do with that as anything Mr. Morial has done, others say no, he can take a bow. His re-election bid did not draw one single serious challenger.
Bill Metcalf, chairman-elect of the New Orleans Chamber of Commerce and publisher of New Orleans Daily Business, endorsed him this time, but had not done so in 1993, when Mr. Morial defeated a white candidate, Donald Mintz, in what turned out to be an ugly, racially charged campaign.
"I was not sure if Marc Morial had the fire in his belly," Mr. Metcalf said. "I was wrong."
The fact is, Mr. Morial has been good for business.
The city's most destructive demon was its image. From front page stories in national newspapers to vivid images on national televison, it was one of runaway crime: people murdered in armed robberies outside popular restaurants; bullets fired into the air that killed tourists when they came down; a Miss Louisiana carjacked.
And there was nothing being done about it, because, residents here say, the police were committing some of the most soul-killing of those crimes: a police officer murdered her own partner and two young Vietnamese immigrants in a robbery; an officer ordered the contract killing of a woman who reported his drug dealing to Internal Affairs; officers were caught in a sting in which they were hired to guard a warehouse of drugs.
Mrs. Johnigan said her crime-ridden neighborhood went virtually unprotected.
People there were "tired of burying our children every day," she said.
Any resurrection of New Orleans had to begin with the Police Department. Mr. Morial brought in Richard Pennington, a veteran with the Washington force, to serve as police chief.
Higher standards were established for officers, and a new "public integrity" unit replaced the comically ineffective Internal Affairs division.
But for the poorer people of New Orleans, it was the simple installation of mini-precincts in the housing projects themselves that began, immediately, to save lives.
When Mr. Morial took office in 1994, there were 425 killings in New Orleans, such an amazing rate in a city of about 484,000 people that National Geographic magazine dispatched a reporter to chronicle the city's culture of death.
But by 1996, that number had fallen to 350. And by the end of 1997, it had dropped again, this time to 266. That means that in Mr. Morial's first term, the murder rate fell about 38 percent.
From 1996 to 1997, the city's violent crime rate -- murder, rape, armed robbery and assault -- fell 24 percent.
"People trust the police force a lot more than they used to,"said James Wright, a sociologist at Tulane University here.
Such declines in violent crime were also seen in other major cities, but experts on crime, as well as the people who endured it here, said that Mr. Morial was not just the beneficiary of a national trend.
"You can argue that he was in the right place at the right time, but he made some very visible decisions that panned out," said Wayne Parent, a political science professor at Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge.
Mr. Morial's critics, and they are largely quiet now, say there is a danger in his popularity. Some of them jokingly call him "the czar." A political cartoon in The Times-Picayune here recently showed the new City Council as just a row of Morials.
Some politicians who have been adversely affected by Mr. Morial's popularity have even accused his political organization of stealing one election. When Mary L. Landrieu, a Democrat, defeated Louis (Woody) Jenkins, a Republican, for a United States Senate seat, Mr. Jenkins attributed his loss to Ms. Landrieu's connection to Mr. Morial and voter fraud. A Senate panel found some irregularities but none that warranted reversing the outcome.
Mr. Morial has always been one of the crown princes of this city, a lawyer whose father, often at odds with the white establishment, served as mayor from 1978 to 1986 and is one of its political legends. But Mr. Morial's popularity has eclipsed his father's.
He has not so much evaded scandal as he has just ignored it.
He has never been married, but has a 16-year-old daughter, Kemmah, whom he calls his "shining light." Efforts by political foes to use that against him have fallen flat.
In the previous election, news reports -- which he denied -- that he had once been admitted to a hospital for an emergency related to cocaine use never seemed to hurt him.
"The scandals were highly publicized, and he still won," said Ed Renwick, a political science professor at Loyola University.
In this most recent election, his popularity just buried any hint of scandal, Mr. Renwick said, adding, "It was never mentioned."
But now, as Mr. Morial ponders his future in a state that has been unashamedly racial, and some would say racist, in its attitudes, the young, wildly popular Mayor must wonder if his political career is at an end.
"It's hard to step from New Orleans to Louisiana as a whole," said Mr. Parent, the Louisiana State professor. "He would have to confront the politics of race."
Other political scientists say it is all but impossible for Mr. Morial to win a statewide race.
Mr. Morial is painfully realistic.
"New Orleans has evolved," he said, giving him the greatest mandate since 1961, when Victor Schiro drew 81 percent of the vote against a virtually unknown Republican. "I think the South has evolved. How far is hard to say."
He could wind up in a President's Cabinet -- he is that popular, too, among national Democrats. Or he could pull off something his father never could, and, with the weight of that popularity, force a change in the way the city elects its mayors.
Now, there is a two-term limit. He concedes that it is possible that he could try to change the city's charter and extend his career as Mayor for a few more years. Surveys have shown that, if he asks, a majority of voters would support such a change.
"Otherwise, his options are limited," Mr. Parent said.
