HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: THE OPTIONS;
The G.O.P. Is Urging Hussein's Ouster

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Before the first bomb is even dropped on Iraq, Congressional leaders are telling the Clinton Administration what it should do after that.
If diplomacy fails to resolve the crisis in Iraq, the Administration says, its strategy is not to topple President Saddam Hussein but to contain him and his elusive chemical and biological arsenal. 
 But a Republican-dominated chorus in Congress and in foreign-policy circles is demanding a long-term strategy to oust Mr. Hussein.
"Air attacks will do limited damage," said Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican and member of the Armed Services Committee. "But following that, there has to be this effort to destabilize and overthrow him. Otherwise we'll end up in the same situation a year or two years or three years from now."
Few if any lawmakers are even hinting at a replay of the 1991 Persian Gulf ground war to settle things. As another committee member, Senator Dan Coats, an Indiana Republican, said, "There are alternatives other than simply sending hundreds of thousands of ground troops into Baghdad."
Republicans from Speaker Newt Gingrich to the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, tick off a to-do list for President Clinton and his national security lieutenants.
The options include enlarging the existing no-flight and no-drive zones in Iraq, tightening the economic embargo, disbursing the billions of Iraqi assets frozen after the 1990 invasion of Kuwait to a provisional government and setting up a "Radio Free Iraq" to stir public opposition and arming.
"The doctrine here has to be roll back, not containment," Mr. Lott said on the Senate floor last week.
Not that the Administration is closed to new ideas. The national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, met for more than hour at the White House on Thursday with a dozen national security experts, including a former Under Secretary of Defense, Paul D. Wolfowitz, and a former Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey, who advocate ousting Mr. Hussein.
"Getting rid of Saddam is not a fairy tale," said Mr. Wolfowitz, who was a top-ranking official in the Bush Administration. "It's doable. But they're afraid of the same thing that Bush was afraid of: declaring a goal and not achieving it."
But as Phebe Marr, a national security expert on Iraq, put it, "There are no good options in Iraq, only less bad ones."
Until the recent crisis intensified, allied aircraft flew 20 flights a day over northern Iraq and 80 flights a day over the south to enforce no-flight zones that date from the end of the Persian Gulf war of 1991.
Proponents of enlarging the zones to cover all of Iraq say doing so would deny Mr. Hussein sovereignty over his skies and prohibit him from using helicopter gunships to help suppress any rebellions.
But the Joint Chiefs of Staff fear that patrolling the California-size area would be too costly, tying up three to four times as many aircraft as the military does now.
Mr. Hussein would be likely to test any edict by putting women and children aboard helicopters, military experts say.
Another idea is to expand the "no drive" zone in southern Iraq. Iraqi troops and tanks are forbidden to mass south of the 32nd parallel, and experts say the cost of patrolling a larger area would be prohibitive.
The Administration has also been trying to figure out whether they can tighten the already tight screws on Iraq's economy with additional financial freezes and economic sanctions. The embargo has already cost Baghdad $110 billion in oil sales alone, Mr. Berger said last week.
After a meeting on Iraq at the State Department on Wednesday, one official paraphrased the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, Thomas R. Pickering as asking, "If you think of anything we haven't done, let me know."
The black-market flow of oil and other goods is hard to stop, a State Department official said, and the United States is not particularly eager to stop illicit oil flows to Jordan, because Iraq is Jordan's only source.
Moreover, Iran turns a blind eye to small trading ships that run along its hundreds of miles of coastline. Blocking this illicit commerce would be difficult for the marginal additional pressure on Mr. Hussein, naval experts say.
"I'm sure some young pimpled staffers on the Hill think tightening sanctions is a good idea, but not any of the adults who've looked at it seriously," said one White House official.
Finally, many critics have urged the Administration to foster the Iraqi opposition, inside and outside the country. But that option has flaws too. The opposition groups are relatively disorganized, poorly financed and decimated by Iraq's security forces.
Forces from two Iraqi opposition groups that received covert aid from Washington, the Iraqi National Congress and the Iraqi National Accord, were routed in a crackdown in September 1996 in northern Iraq by Mr. Hussein's security forces.
The United States response to that crackdown, a handful of cruise missile attacks on military targets in southern Iraq, embittered the opposition groups, who felt betrayed by Washington.
"Survivors are understandably bitter and reluctant to cast their lot with us again," Senator McCain conceded last week. "But we must prepare the groundwork for a process that may take years to bear fruit."
Indeed, leaders from the Iraqi National Congress are to meet with State Department, White House and Congressional officials on Wednesday. Washington's allies are decidedly cool to this option, at least publicly. Senators who received a private briefing from Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright last week said that even Britain, Washington's closest ally in the gulf crisis, has signaled discomfort in openly embracing a plan to topple Mr. Hussein.
"Iraq is only one bullet away from a new regime," said one senior Administration official. "The trouble is, we don't know when it's coming and where it's coming from."

HEADLINE: Wall St. to Pay To Add a Base For the Police

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

 BODY:
In an unusual arrangement allowing private businesses to pay for additional protection from the city police force, Police Commissioner Howard Safir has agreed to open a new police substation in the financial district paid for in part by $5 million from a downtown business group.
The plan calls for 200 officers to be based in the new station, which will be provided and maintained by the Alliance for Downtown New York, a business improvement district representing a number of influential companies in the Wall Street area. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said the substation would provide additional security in an area that could be a target for terrorists, and he contended that the private financing was a good deal for the city. 
 But some City Council members and leaders of community groups assailed the plan, saying it was unfair to assign additional police officers to Wall Street, one of the city's safest areas, rather than to more dangerous but less affluent neighborhoods.
"This is the sort of thing you would have expected 100 years ago during the days of Tammany Hall," said Councilman Sheldon S. Leffler, chairman of the Public Safety Committee. "It raises very disturbing questions about whether city resources are going to be allocated where they're needed or auctioned off to the highest bidder."
The debate over the substation is the latest controversy involving the city's business improvement districts, which levy an assessment on business owners to pay for services like security and street cleaning. Proponents say the districts play an important role in supplementing public spending, but critics have complained that the business groups essentially create a two-tier system of haves and have-nots for vital municipal services.
Mr. Leffler also said he was concerned about the involvement of Carol Safir, the Commissioner's wife, in the substation deal. Mrs. Safir, who holds an unpaid position as head of the Police Museum Foundation, initially approached the business group seeking donations to finance a new home for the museum, according to police officials who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Under the arrangement eventually worked out between the business group and the Police Department, police officials agreed to open and staff the new substation, at 104 Washington Street, in the First Precinct, while the businesses agreed to provide $5 million for the station as well as funds for the new museum site at 25 Broadway. It was not clear who first proposed linking the two issues.
Michael O'Connor, the former Transit Police chief who is now vice president of operations for the business group, did not return calls for comment about the proposal yesterday.
Police officials said neither the Commissioner nor Mrs. Safir would comment on the plan, which was first reported yesterday in Newsday.
Deputy Inspector Michael E. Collins, a police spokesman, said the plan for the downtown facility was similar to the department's Times Square substation, which is also underwritten by a business group.
"We are looking at other sites throughout the city that have been offered in an effort to reduce costs and cut down on overcrowding in current department facilities," he said.
Deputy Inspector Collins said the 200 officers assigned to the substation would be taken from a variety of task forces and scooter units and would be used to respond to calls throughout Manhattan. He said overall patrol strength in the First Precinct, which is headquartered at 16 Ericsson Place, would remain essentially unchanged, but the written agreement between the department and the business group specifies that at least 50 officers will be dedicated to patrol the immediate area.
Mr. Leffler said residents of his district in Queens had been trying to establish a substation in the 105th Precinct for nearly 20 years without success.
"It looks like the Police Commissioner thinks he's responsible to only two people in the city: the Mayor and his wife, not the city at large," Mr. Leffler said.
"This is a sweetheart deal for the Commissioner's wife, who is active in the business community, and the Mayor, who has been supported by Wall Street businessmen in the past and would certainly like their help in the future."
While Mr. Giuliani defended the plan, he also took pains to point out that it had been initiated by police officials and that similar plans had been discussed under the administration of David N. Dinkins.
Mr. Safir is also moving ahead with a plan to allow city police officers to work in uniform, off-duty, for businesses that receive the Police Department's approval. Although similar plans have been tried and rejected in several other cities because the moonlighting created conflict-of-interest issues, Mr. Safir said it would benefit officers, business owners and the city in general.
The Alliance for Downtown New York is one of 39 business improvement districts in the city. While the groups have been widely praised for improving many of New York's commercial areas, some City Council members have argued that the districts have become mini-governments that act with little oversight and give unfair advantages to wealthier areas.
Peter D. Salins, provost of the State University of New York and a former professor of urban planning at Hunter College, said such arrangements were a creative way for cities like New York to provide essential services without raising taxes to a level that would drive off existing businesses.
"The people that make that argument about fairness would rather have a city that would decline everywhere," Mr. Salins said.
But many community organizers say services like police protection are too important to be doled out according to a neighborhood's ability to pay. Patricia Dolan, the vice president of the Queens Civic Congress, said two of the civic groups in her organization have been lobbying for substations for years but would never be able to outbid Wall Street business owners.
"Last year, my own civic association, with a great deal of effort that almost broke the bank, gave $1,000 to buy a bicycle for the 107th Precinct," she said. "We should have saved a little more and bought a substation."

HEADLINE: Black-White Income Inequalities

 BODY:
The income gap between black and white families closed slightly between 1993 and 1996, according to the White House's Council of Economic Advisers. But the gap remains huge and may have only temporarily receded. Indeed, black and Hispanic families are further behind whites today than they were 20 years ago. The yawning gaps between rich and poor and between blacks and whites are not going away anytime soon.
The typical white family earned about $47,000 in 1996, almost twice that of blacks. Worse, the typical black household had a net worth of only about $4,500, a tenth of the white figure. A New York Times analysis of Government data shows that American households have loaded up on stocks, doubling the equity share of their savings since 1990, as stock prices soared. But blacks have taken virtually no part in the recent doubling of stock prices. About 95 percent of black families own no stock or pension funds. 
 Poverty among black children fell last year to its lowest level in decades. But at 40 percent, the level remains horribly high. Unemployment among black men fell last year to 8.6 percent, the lowest in 23 years, but nevertheless twice the jobless rate of white men.
Since 1972 black family incomes have risen less than 10 percent, at a time when white family incomes have risen almost 15 percent. Such inequality is more a problem of poor education, weak skills and the rise in single-parent families than of race. The plight of low-skilled workers has been decades in the making and will not be turned around by the temporary flush of economic recovery.

HEADLINE: Over 200 Die as Taiwan Jet Crashes in Bad Weather

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Feb. 16

 BODY:
A China Airlines flight from the Indonesian resort of Bali crashed and burst into flames while trying to land in fog and rain at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taipei, Taiwan, this evening, killing all 197 passengers and crew members, including Taiwan's Central Bank governor, and at least 7 people on the ground.
The bank governor, Sheu Yuan-dong, was returning from a meeting of regional finance and banking officials with his wife, Huang Mian-mei, and three Central Bank officials. 
 The cause of the crash was not immediately clear, although Hsu Lu, the general manager of the Voice of Taipei radio station, said in an interview that her news staff was reporting that visibility was bad and that the control tower had asked the pilot not to land. Her account could not be immediately confirmed.
There appeared to be no survivors.
"In view of the gravity of the disaster, it would be very difficult for anyone to survive this disaster," Wei Hsun-chih, the deputy director of the airport, was quoted as saying by Taiwan's Central News Agency.
Ms. Hsu, the radio station official, said that there were early reports that 45 passengers had been scheduled to transfer to a flight bound for San Francisco, suggesting that some Americans may have been on board.
 "Seven foreigners were killed in the plane crash," a China Airlines spokeswoman said Tuesday, Reuters reported. Five were American, one was French and one was Indonesian. The Americans were identified as Laurence Smith, Christopher Cory, Kenneth Cowan, Jacques Augustin and Tom Hadel, but no home towns were given. The French citizen was identified as Rachel Liu and the Indonesian as Nyoman Sakadarma.
As the plane, an Airbus 300 jumbo jet, attempted to land it slammed into at least four houses several hundred yards short of the airport runway, setting them on fire.
Flames poured from the first and second floors of the buildings as firefighters sought to extinguish fires from the airplane wreckage and the burning homes, according to pictures broadcast by the BBC. Thick smoke billowed from pieces of the plane, including what appeared to be its engines.
A Central News Agency reporter at the scene described seeing charred body parts scattered near the airport. A woman surnamed Chen who was watching her home burn was quoted as saying, "There were people in the house, but it's totally finished."
As Central Bank governor, Mr. Sheu has been credited with adhering to a conservative monetary policy that has helped Taiwan thrive despite the region's economic crisis. Born in 1927 in Taipei, Mr. Sheu worked in a series of banks before being elevated to the post of Central Bank governor in 1995.
China Airlines, which is based in Taipei, has had a history of safety problems. In 1994, an Airbus identical to the one lost this evening crashed at Japan's Nagoya airport. And in 1993 at Hong Kong's Kai Tak airport, a new China Airlines Boeing 747-400 skidded into Victoria Harbor. No one was killed, but the $140 million plane was destroyed.
The jet that crashed tonight, China Airlines Flight 676, went down at 8:05 P.M., according to the China News Agency.
A boy was pulled alive from the wreckage, according to Ms. Hsu of the Voice of Taipei, but he died later.
"It seems like there was no visibility," said Ms. Hsu, who said she was repeating what her news reporters from the scene had told her. "The tower staff asked them to fly around and not to land. But after that they lost contact with the airplane."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bodies covered with sheets were lined up along a road at the scene of the crash at Taipei's airport in a heavy fog yesterday. All 197 passengers and crew members were killed, along with at least 7 people on the ground. (Associated Press)(pg. A3)
 
Map showing the location of Taipei: The China Airlines jet was en route from Bali to Taipei.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Madeleine's Folly

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
With a U.S. bombing of Iraq now increasingly likely, the question being raised by those uneasy with such a strike is: What is the endgame? Is America just throwing its weight around to punish Saddam Hussein?
The answer is really very simple. It comes down to two words: weapons proliferation. If Iraq -- already a repeat user of poison gas -- is able to snub its nose at the U.N. weapons inspectors, then the world's ability to fight the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction elsewhere would be fundamentally compromised. Libya and its friends would all be less afraid to develop germ weapons and nukes. We would all end up in a much more dangerous world. That's why Saddam has to be stopped. 
 But it is precisely because stemming weapons proliferation should be the centerpiece of U.S. foreign policy in the post-cold-war era that the Clinton Administration's policy of NATO expansion is so stupid. The U.S. should be doing everything it can to work with Russia, not only on Iraq but to shrink Russia's own nuclear arsenal, which is the greatest proliferation threat in the world today. Attention shoppers: Russia has thousands of weapons of mass destruction. It has hundreds of unemployed or underemployed nuclear scientists. And it has only the loosest controls over its nukes and nuclear materials, and it has a signed nuclear arms reduction treaty with the U.S. that has not been implemented.
But instead of dealing with this problem, the Clintonites are making it worse. They are expanding NATO to counter a threat that doesn't exist -- a Russian invasion of Europe -- and thus undermining America's ability to work with Russia on the threat that does exist -- Russia's loose nukes.
"Halting the proliferation of nuclear materials, missiles and technology is clearly our number-one foreign policy challenge since the breakup of the Soviet Empire," says former Senator Sam Nunn, who was the expert in the Senate on this issue. "But because it is number one, we should be measuring all other policies by how they affect proliferation. Not only does NATO expansion not help us deal with Russia on this issue, it is counterproductive."
The Clinton team has never had an integrated foreign policy. It treats Iraq and NATO expansion as if they were totally disconnected. One day Secretary of State Albright gives a speech telling Russia that NATO is moving right up to the Baltic-Russian border. The next day she complains that Russia isn't being helpful on Iraq. Gosh, I wonder why not?
"Thanks to NATO expansion, we have convinced the Russian political elite that they are not our partner and that their security is not as important to us as the security of the Czechs," says Jack Matlock, President Reagan's Ambassador to Moscow.
We are already paying a price for this. NATO expansion has prompted Russia's Parliament to stall its ratification of the Start 2 nuclear arms reduction treaty, which would shrink Russian and U.S. nuclear arsenals from around 7,000 apiece to 3,500 apiece. That's 3,500 fewer Russian nukes pointed at us. But the deal has been frozen by NATO expansion. If the Clinton team loses the Start 2 treaty, in order to add the Czechs to NATO, it will go down as one of the greatest blunders in the history of U.S. foreign policy: Madeleine's folly.
As Mr. Matlock notes, the more we expand NATO, "the less willing Russia's Ministry of Atomic Energy is to work with us on cooperative measures" to keep its atomic scientists constructively employed -- so they don't end up in Iraq and Iran -- and the less willing Russia's military is to let us in to help it better control and destroy its nuclear materials.
Moreover, if Ms. Albright is serious about extending NATO to the Baltic States, the only way NATO can possibly defend them is with nukes. Baltic membership in NATO will, therefore, only encourage Russia to continue altering its defense doctrine -- moving to a greater reliance on nuclear weapons for defense, on more of a hair trigger, because the closer NATO gets to Russia's border the less warning time Moscow will have. But don't worry, sleep well, Latvia will be in NATO.
The Clintonites are rightly ready to go to war with Iraq to halt the spread of weapons in the Middle East. But their expansion of NATO will only increase the threat of proliferation in Russia -- where there are a lot more weapons, under a lot less control, and all pointed at us.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Psychiatric Drugs Are Now Promoted Directly to Patients

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Using tactics that were unheard of a few years ago, the pharmaceutical industry is increasingly marketing mental health drugs directly to consumers.
In a break with past practice, which was simply to advertise in medical magazines and buttonhole doctors, manufacturers of antidepressants began advertising in general-interest magazines last year. And several companies have promoted psychotherapeutic drugs to mental health patients and their families through the Internet and personalized direct mailings. 
 The marketing of mental health drugs to consumers, which surged last year, added to the explosive growth of direct-to-consumer advertising of prescription drugs.
Drug companies say the advertising and other marketing tactics provide information that helps patients overcome their problems. Spokesmen for the industry add that patients are protected because only a doctor can write a prescription. But critics say patients who are influenced by the marketing programs may seek out doctors who might be willing to prescribe drugs that are not right for them.
Some doctors and advocates for patients say that people with certain mental illnesses are much more susceptible to being manipulated than those with other medical problems. "People who are seriously mentally ill often have impaired judgment," said Dr. Sidney Wolfe, executive director of the Health Research Group of Public Citizen, a consumer advocacy group in Washington.
And while the problems of ill-advised self-medication and invasion of privacy may apply to any patient taking medication, doctors say that the mentally ill are especially vulnerable. "There continues to be a clear stigma against the mentally ill in America," said Dr. Harold Eist, a former president of the American Psychiatric Association.
In the most aggressive example of approaching patients directly, Eli Lilly & Company said recently that it would offer scholarships to some schizophrenic patients who took Zyprexa, its new antipsychotic drug.
The scholarships, Lilly said, would help people with schizophrenia prepare for normal lives by taking college or professional school classes. But critics said the marketing pitch could encourage patients to risk the ill effects that can follow a switch in medication and could raise unrealistic expectations because few people with schizophrenia can cope with higher education.
In a second approach, a number of drug companies are finding new ways to collect the names of people with mental health problems as well as other information -- data that can be used for marketing purposes. Janssen Pharmaceutica, for example, urges visitors to its Internet site to register for updates on psychiatry and schizophrenia "relevant to your personal interests."
In a related program, Janssen, a unit of Johnson & Johnson, urged users of Risperdal, its schizophrenia drug, to call a toll-free number to join a "person to person" program that includes reminder calls to take the Janssen medicine. Spokesmen for the companies said the aim was to provide patients with information that they could then discuss with their doctors.
But critics said that a drug company could follow up on the initial contact with personalized letters to patients. Such letters could suggest that they demand a particular drug from their doctors, whether or not it was appropriate.
Yet another tactic involves drugs for depression, a more widespread and typically far less disabling disease. Several companies began advertising such drugs in general-interest magazines last year.
Lilly has sponsored the most extensive of the campaigns for antidepressants for Prozac, whose American sales exceeded $1.9 billion in 1997. Some Prozac ads have included postcards that invited readers to send for information kits. They were also asked to provide information about any treatment for depression and to agree, in a box labeled "Privacy Respected," to permit Lilly "and its business partners" to use the information, which the company said it would use to develop products and services.
Lilly declined to be interviewed on the campaign, but a spokesman for the drug industry strongly defended the ads. "Direct-to-consumer drug advertising is a First Amendment right," said Jeffrey Trewhitt, an official of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, a trade group in Washington.
Dr. Eist, the former head of the American Psychiatric Association, did not object to advertising of such drugs but said the collection of patient information was "intrusive."
"The information could be sold to an insurance company or H.M.O. that would then refuse to sell the person insurance or charge them a higher premium," he said. Or it "could also be used by head-hunting people" to screen candidates for executive jobs and by contestants in divorces to discredit a spouse seeking custody of children. Dr. Eist said that his concerns were based on "real examples that I know about."
Advertising prescription drugs to consumers is prohibited in Canada and most of Europe. In the United States, the propriety of the ads has long been debated by doctors, Government officials and patient advocacy groups. As recently as the 1980's, when the advertising of prescription drugs began in general-interest publications, "the feeling was that advertising was fine for an antihistamine" but that it would never do for a mental health drug, said William Castagnoli, a retired agency executive who worked on early ads for an allergy drug.
Lilly's scholarship promotion, which was withdrawn from the Internet last month after an inquiry about it from The New York Times, had said applicants for the grants "must be diagnosed with schizophrenia and be in treatment with Zyprexa."
Zyprexa competes in a tight race to dominate the $1.7 billion market for treatments for schizophrenia, an often-disabling disease that affects more than 800,000 Americans. Sales of Zyprexa, which was introduced in October 1996, rose above $500 million within 12 months, according to IMS America, a market research firm.
After The Times asked about the scholarships, a Lilly spokeswoman said that "upon re-examination of that program," applicants would no longer be required to be taking Zyprexa. Just yesterday, Lilly announced that applications were available for individuals who were being treated for schizophrenia and would be judged by an independent panel of psychiatric care professionals. The company said it had not decided how many scholarships would be awarded; it said the amounts would vary depending on applicants' financial needs and other factors.
Dr. David Kessler, who recently stepped down as head of the Food and Drug Administration and is now dean of the Yale Medical School, said the offer "could end up affecting good care -- if you are taking a drug that you shouldn't be taking, or if you would be better off not taking one."
Dr. E. Fuller Torrey, a psychiatrist and schizophrenia researcher in Washington, also criticized the scholarships for promoting "unrealistic expectations by both the families and patients."
"There is an unfortunate implication that many, maybe even most, patients put on Zyprexa will be able to go back to college," he said.
While drug industry spokesmen say the products, no matter how expensive, are more economical than other types of therapy, managed care executives say that marketing has significantly added to costs.
Dr. Sam Ho, a vice president of Pacificare Health Systems, a big California-based health maintenance organization, said direct-to-consumer advertising fueled growth in drug costs, which now account for 10 percent of the premium dollar for many health plans, up from 7 percent a few years ago. He said Prozac costs "at least 50 percent more, around $70 a month, than drugs in the same therapeutic class."
But patients may be more strongly motivated to take their medicines, advertisers say, and the doctor will always have the last word on writing a prescription.
"This is the information age, and more information empowers patients to be able to have more meaningful conversations with their doctors about cures and treatments," said Alan F. Holmer, president of the pharmaceutical manufacturers association.
Still, in a 1996 survey of 5,400 physicians, 51 percent had negative views of direct-to-consumer advertising of any drugs generally, 20 percent were positive, and 29 percent neutral, according to Scott-Lewin, a drug marketing research firm.
To be sure, not all offers of information on the Internet are come-ons to gather names for marketing purposes. Dr. Brad Tanner, president of Clinical Tools, a Government-financed private company, said 75,000 people a month visit Healthguide, its Internet site, which offers mental health mailings. "We don't share that mailing list," he said.
Pharmaceutical companies have long donated money for research and education to patient support and advocacy groups of all kinds, which often provide opportunities to promote drugs at workshops and through newsletters.
Janssen, for example, lined up endorsements from the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, the American Psychiatric Association and other professional and advocacy groups for its Risperdal support system. 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 24, 1998, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Feb. 17 about the marketing of mental health drugs directly to consumers understated the number of Americans believed to have schizophrenia. The National Institute of Mental Health estimates that the disease affects more than two million Americans, not 800,000.

HEADLINE: The Fed Reports Slowdown In Industrial Production

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Industrial production unexpectedly stalled in January as utility output fell 4 percent, the Federal Reserve said today.
Manufacturing production alone rose, but at a slower pace than in previous months, indicating that the Asian financial crisis could curtail growth in this country. 
 The Fed said output at factories, mines and utilities was unchanged in January compared with December -- the first month without an increase since October 1996, when production was also unchanged -- after having risen a revised four-tenths of 1 percent in December. Analysts had expected a January increase of three-tenths of 1 percent.
"There's no doubt we're slowing down," said Brian Wesbury, chief economist at Griffin, Kubik, Stephens & Thompson Inc., a Chicago investment firm. "Asia's having an impact."
Additionally, he said, the Fed's effort to keep down inflation by holding the overnight bank lending rate unchanged is eating into growth.
The plant-use rate, which measures the amount of industrial capacity in use, fell to 83 percent in January from a revised 83.3 percent in December.
Production at utilities fell 4 percent in January, the Fed said, as many parts of the country experienced springlike warmth while ice storms in the Northeast caused widespread power failures.
Production by manufacturers grew three-tenths of 1 percent in January, slower than increases of four-tenths of 1 percent in December and 1 percent in November.
Auto and truck production fell 2.2 percent, the second consecutive monthly decline, although the Fed said vehicle output remained at a high level.
The General Motors Corporation has cut planned first-quarter production at its North American factories. Sales of small cars are slowing as customers buy larger cars amid low gas prices.
As 1998 progresses, the effects of the Asia crisis will become more pronounced, according to a forecast by two economists at the Northern Trust Company, Paul Kasriel and Asha Bangalore. "With slower export growth will come slower production, employment and personal income growth," they said. "A slowdown in export and consumer spending growth will induce businesses to cut back on their capital spending."
Still, in many ways, the economy is well prepared to weather the storm. Jobs are plentiful, inflation is low and businesses have invested heavily in equipment to improve efficiency.
David Orr, chief economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., said about the January data: "You have to look past the utilities number. I don't think anybody should read into a flat headline number that the economy is all of a sudden slumping. The Fed will not view this as a dramatic slowdown but a moderation."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Up Sharply in Rally Linked to Asian Events

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday, pushing long-term yields to the lowest level in more than a month, in a rally powered by new turmoil in Indonesia and data suggesting that Asia's economic problems have slowed United States growth.
The 30-year bond rose 22/32, to a price of 104 22/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.79 percent, the lowest since Jan. 15, from 5.84 percent Friday. The market was closed Monday for Presidents' Day. 
 An important component of the rally yesterday was a wave of purchases by foreign investors on news that President Suharto of Indonesia had dismissed his central bank governor and was proceeding to change how the Indonesia currency is valued, in defiance of the International Monetary Fund. The uncertainty in Indonesia spilled into South Korea, where stocks fell for a seventh day.
Bonds also advanced on the Federal Reserve report that the rate of industrial production was unchanged last month, compared with expectations of a three-tenths of a percent gain. It was the first time in 15 months that industrial output did not expand.
Elliott Platt, director of research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said the weaker industrial production figures might have reflected a decline in exports to Asia, which many forecasters believe will worsen in coming months.
The bond market tends to rally on signs of economic weakness because they diminish the possibility of higher inflation. Even with the weaker-than-expected output data, the Fed report suggested that productivity gains continued to improve, as seen in the one-tenth of a percent decline in factory hours worked.
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, an economic consulting and forecasting firm, said the evidence of improved productivity was a healthy sign because it suggested the economy could produce more goods and services without raising labor costs.
"Productivity growth sets the speed limit for the economy," he said. "The faster productivity grows, the faster the economy is capable of expanding without inflation."
In the Treasury's weekly auction yesterday, the average rate for a three-month bill was 5.075 percent, down from 5.095 percent last week. The six-month bill sold at an average rate of 5.070 percent, down from 5.075 percent.

HEADLINE: Sudan to Loosen Islamic Rule a Bit

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Nine years after it seized power in a military coup, the Islamic party that has molded the Sudan into a religious state is enacting a new constitution that officials here maintain will allow a return to party politics and greater political freedom.
Skeptics among opposition leaders and diplomats say it remains to be seen if the reforms being debated this week will be carried out. But the Sudanese National Congress met this week to approve a raft of constitutional reforms that Government leaders say will guarantee freedom of speech and assembly, as well as religion. 
 Meeting under an enormous tent behind a conference hall here in the capital, the 6,500 members of the congress, which is dominated by the governing party, debated and passed several constitutional proposals today that try to marry the principles of an Islamic state with the principles of free speech and party politics.
"We want to build a model state where you can act out fully what we profess as a Muslim and at the same time, because it is part of the religion, give everyone else their freedom," said Sayed al-Khateeb, the congress's foreign secretary. "We want to prove that you can be an Islamic state and still at the same time grant freedom to others that have different beliefs."
Political parties have been banned since 1989, when the National Islamic Front seized power in a military coup and toppled a democratically elected Government. Since then, the front's leaders have labored to create a state ruled according to the Koran's tenets, enforcing its vision of an Islamic revolution with a sophisticated security apparatus.
But a protracted civil war with Christian and animist rebels in the south, who are fighting for greater autonomy, racial equality and religious freedom, has drained the Government's resources and shackled the economy with low wages and skyrocketing prices.
For the Government, the war worsened two years ago when several northern opposition leaders in Khartoum went into exile and opened an eastern front, sending rebel cadres to attack the Sudan from Eritrea.
At the same time, most Western democracies, led by the United States, have cut off aid to the country and isolated the Government because of allegations that the Sudan harbors Islamic terrorists from all over the Middle East.
The pressure has taken its toll. Most people in Khartoum grumble openly about the Government's handling of the economy and the war, which consumes hundreds of lives and at least $1 million a day.
Against this backdrop, there have been some tentative signs that the Government is loosening its grip on the political debate. In the last year, for instance, more and more criticism has appeared in the eight newspapers published in the capital, and in one case the courts struck down a ban on an opposition newspaper.
The Government has also shown a new willingness to end the war through negotiations. In April 1997, Khartoum signed a peace agreement with several small rebel factions, promising for the first time that the south would be exempt from Islamic laws and that a referendum on independence for the southern provinces would be held.
And the Government has agreed to resume peace talks in Nairobi with the main rebel group, led by John Garang, who says he will accept nothing less than a secular system.
Still, the constitutional proposals being discussed contain several loopholes and caveats. For instance, while freedom of assembly is guaranteed, the Government could still crack down on opposition parties if the courts determined that they received money from other countries, advocated violent conflict or "go out of the bounds of religion."
Hassan al-Turabi, the Speaker of the Parliament and the ideological architect of the 1989 coup, said political parties in theory would be allowed to operate as soon as the new constitution was passed by Parliament in April. But he added that the National Islamic Front would fight hard to undercut the political appeal of other parties. "There will be a campaign against anything like that -- a political, moral, social, cultural campaign -- but no legal bar," he said. In a sense, the reforms are an invitation to northern opposition leaders like Sadeq al-Mahdi, a former Prime Minister, to give up the rebellion in the east and return to Sudanese politics as outsiders, officials of the governing party say.
Mr. Khateeb said, "Theoretically the makings of a multiparty system are here, but it depends on whether Sadeq al-Mahdi and others want to take up the challenge."
Some opposition leaders have dismissed the new constitution as a ruse intended to improve the Sudan's image abroad and entice Western democracies to resume the $800 million in foreign aid this country used to receive each year before the coup. No constitution, they argue, can be considered legitimate unless opposition leaders from the north and south take part in drafting it.
"This Government has established a reputation of saying one thing and doing the opposite," said Abel Alier, a former Vice President and a leading critic of the Government. "They can say there is freedom. But if they want to do it, they can't do it alone. They must do it with us."
Diplomats in Khartoum said the Government's motivation for passing the reforms was probably to pacify an unhappy public exhausted by repressive politics, economic hardship and war. Many Sudanese still support the two main opposition parties that were banned after the coup; the National Islamic Front attracted no more than 20 percent of the vote in the only all-party election in 1985.
"The people do want to see pluralism, and if the Government does not say these things, it shows they have no interest in the future," a diplomat said.

HEADLINE: Pratt & Whitney to Introduce New Engine

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Hoping to regain its once-leading share of the global market for jet engines, Pratt & Whitney announced yesterday that it would introduce a radical new engine design that it said would be quieter, cleaner, more efficient and more reliable than anything currently offered by its competitors.
The new engine, which is expected to enter service in 2002, is designed to propel a single-aisle jetliner holding 120 to 180 passengers, like the Boeing 737 or the Airbus A320. If it performs as Pratt & Whitney promises, it will reduce emissions by 40 percent and widely surpass noise restrictions set to take effect at the end of the decade. 
 "This really kicks off the next round of the engine wars," said Wolfgang Demisch, an aerospace industry analyst with BT Alex. Brown in New York.
But Mr. Demisch and others also said that Pratt & Whitney, which is a division of the Hartford-based United Technologies, still faced some daunting challenges, not least of which is the new design. For one thing, the new engine is not yet wedded to a specific airplane, a considerable gamble given the $350 million that the company has already spent on development.
The problem is that Boeing already has an exclusive agreement with CFM International, the joint venture between the General Electric Company and Snecma of France, to supply engines for the 737, the most popular plane in the world. And Pratt & Whitney is already involved in a joint venture with Rolls-Royce and others to supply engines for the A320.
Robert F. Leduc, a senior vice president at Pratt & Whitney, said that the new engine would not compete with its current offering for the A320 and that the company had a plane in mind for the new engine but had agreed with the manufacturer not to identify it.
Pratt & Whitney helped usher in the jet age and led the industry until it decided not to develop a new engine for the 737 in the early 1980's. That opened the door for CFM International, which now dominates the market for narrow-body jets, leaving Pratt & Whitney with less than 10 percent.
It has been estimated that narrow-body planes will constitute 60 to 65 percent of the jetliners to be sold over the next 19 years. "There is only one way to fix this problem," Mr. Leduc said. "We have to make a pre-emptive strike."
The new Pratt & Whitney design, which was first proposed by the company a decade ago, employs a gear box that enables the large turbofan, which creates most of a jet engine's thrust, to spin slowly while still letting the turbine that powers it to spin fast. The result is improved fuel economy and less noise.
Richard L. Kennedy, the spokesman for CFM International, said that Pratt & Whitney still had to prove that the design would work, while CFM continued to make its engines more reliable. "This doesn't come as a surprise," he said. "We have been making preparations for some time."

HEADLINE: Loan-Rate Discrimination Case Is Settled by Long Island Bank

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: ROSLYN, N.Y., Feb. 17

 BODY:
A Long Island bank has reached a $3 million settlement of allegations that some borrowers who are members of minority groups were charged inflated interest rates.
Under the agreement, more than 550 qualified borrowers will soon be receiving letters from the Roslyn Savings Bank notifying them that they are entitled to one-time payments of $5,000 each. Most of the affected borrowers are in Brooklyn and Queens, with smaller numbers in Nassau and Suffolk counties. 
 In addition to the payments, the bank and its subsidiary, Residential First Inc., have agreed to institute a training program for loan officers and tighten management oversight of all loan practices. The goal is to prevent a repeat of the unfair lending practice in which some borrowers were charged a slightly higher interest rate or additional points because of their race or national origin.
"This is an historic agreement that demonstrates New York's national leadership among states with regard to fair lending," said New York State's acting banking superintendent, Elizabeth McCaul.
"On average, if you were a minority borrower, you paid about $1,000 more for your mortgage during the life of your loan than you would if you were a nonminority borrower," Ms. McCaul said.
Noting that the Federal Department of Justice traditionally settles this type of fair-lending case, Ms. McCaul said the state was pleased with the steps to be taken by Roslyn Savings and its subsidiary. "Their efforts should serve as a model to other institutions throughout the state," she said.
The pattern of higher loan charges to minority-group members was first discovered by state banking examiners conducting their normal annual compliance examination at Roslyn and its subsidiary, said Michael Barry, a spokesman for the State Banking Department.
He said the agreement, which was announced today by Gov. George E. Pataki, covered qualified minority-group members who obtained their mortgage loans from Roslyn and its subsidiary between August 1995, when the bank purchased Residential First, and December 1997.
Mr. Barry said the basis for the violation was the Community Reinvestment Act, adopted by the state in 1979, which requires banks to help meet the credit needs of the low- and middle-income residents of the communities they serve. He said the affected borrowers would be receiving letters from the bank as early as April.
Both Roslyn Savings and its subsidiary, in agreeing to the settlement with the state, denied any violations of law. Roslyn insists that its own economic and statistical analyses demonstrated that the differences in mortgage charges were attributed to non-discriminatory factors.
Roslyn's chairman and chief executive, Joseph L. Mancino, said Roslyn entered into the settlement agreement in order to put the issue behind it.
"For more than 100 years Roslyn has maintained an unsurpassed record of financial commitment to supporting home ownership and the fullest and fairest service to every customer. I reaffirm that commitment," Mr. Mancino said in a statement released by the bank.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
With New Freedom, Choosing a Power Supplier

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
As the date for partial deregulation of electrical power nears, managers of major properties in New York City appear divided over how to approach the impending freedom to choose a power supplier.
The choice appears to be twofold: build up an internal expertise in energy management in hopes of wringing out the maximum savings possible or turn the whole business over to a third party, an energy service company, on the theory that an outside expert can do a better job than internal managers with other things on their mind. 
 Since electrical power is the largest single cost of running commercial buildings, managers are eagerly awaiting deregulation, though some energy specialists say the savings, at least initially, may be quite modest.
Consolidated Edison will start accepting applications for what it calls its retail choice program on April 1 for the 500 megawatts, or 5 percent of the power it delivers in the city and northern suburbs, that is to be deregulated.
Those selected for the first phase will be able to choose their energy supplier, the way they now choose a long-distance telephone carrier, as of June 1. Larger blocks of power will be included in later phases, with complete deregulation scheduled by the end of 2001.
David Schirmacher, director of technical services at Compass Management and Leasing, which manages 10 million square feet of office and retail space in the city, said his company was taking a hands-on approach. "We think there is a lot of opportunity," he said. "The companies that will do well are the ones who do their research internally."
He said the company has a system that can track patterns of power use and predict future demand. Armed with that information, the company can shop for power, which will still arrive over Con Edison's wires. The supplier may even be Con Ed, because it is assumed that the power generating arm of the company will bid to protect its home market. Power bought from remote locations will also be subject to transmission fees to get it to New York.
But accurate forecasts are essential, because Con Ed can impose financial penalties if the actual power use is too much above or below the prediction. "It can be a dangerous game if you do not know what you are doing, and nobody has done it before," he said.
Charles Leonardi, general manager of Con Edison's retail choice program, agreed that it was the responsibility of the service companies or property managers to forecast power demand and schedule delivery at the proper time. Timing is important, because electricity must be used as it is generated and cannot be stored like oil or gas.
"The concern is about reliability," he said, with the company not wanting to deal with unexpected surges or drops in power. He said managers were allowed to err 5 percent above or 5 percent below their forecasts without charge.
One of the largest property managers in the area, Cushman & Wakefield, with a portfolio of 62 million square feet in the metropolitan region, has chosen to team up with a service company.
"It was a choice between building an internal staff or forming an alliance with someone who is in the market every day," said John Santora, the company's manager of asset services. Cushman & Wakefield chose Enersave of Manhattan.
He said that his company managed 200 million square feet of property nationwide and that electrical costs averaged $2.50 per square foot a year.
"That is a big annual bill and we are leaning on Enersave to get us first in line" for deregulation programs in California and Pennsylvania, he said.
Meg Carey, a vice president of Enersave, said earlier forecasts that deregulation might cut power costs 15 to 40 percent now appeared to be out of reach. "We are saying 5 to 15 percent, and 15 percent is on the high side," she said.
In addition to those savings, Ms. Carey said building managers could lower the cost of power by reducing consumption. The single biggest power drain in large buildings, she said, is for the motors that drive fans moving air internally. Installing variable-speed motors can trim that cost, she said.
Energy analysts caution that the cost of generating power is only a fraction of the final customer cost and say this will limit the savings from deregulation.
"Of the 16 cents a kilowatt you pay Con Ed for power, only about 4 cents is for generation," said Ashok Gupta, an economist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group. He added that Con Ed buys much of the power it delivers to customers, rather than generating it on its own. "With deregulation, people will be trying to beat Con Ed at buying power," he said.
Nevertheless, some managers say a detailed knowledge of how properties operate will give them an advantage over third parties in buying power. "1515 Broadway has been 100 percent occupied for several years, but it is using more power now than in the past," Mr. Schirmacher of Compass Management said.
He noted that MTV, which is at 1515 Broadway at 45th Street, opened a live music studio there last year. "And we know that MTV is going to start another studio this summer," he said. "Someone who did not know that could run into trouble."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Taiwan Pushes for Role in Southeast Asia Rescue

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Shunned internationally, ignored by the International Monetary Fund and technically at war with China, Taiwan has been given a rare opportunity to flex its financial muscles by the economic calamities in Southeast Asia.
Through a whirlwind of economic diplomacy, Taiwan's leaders and its business sector have planted the island's flag in Manila, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur and Bangkok, a flag festooned with promises of aid, investment and debt guarantees. 
 In trips shrouded in semi-secrecy, Prime Minister Vincent Siew, along with a top economic planner and about 50 business leaders, visited the four capitals in Southeast Asia last month to assess the region's needs. Because China insists that none of the countries -- the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand -- maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan, Mr. Siew's discussions with other prime ministers and presidents were so low key that they often went unnoticed by the press.
Taiwan has $36 billion (United States) invested in the region, said the economic planner, Chiang Pin-kung, the chairman of Taiwan's Council for Economic Planning and Development, a Government department that has broad responsibility for economic policy making. "We are fortunate we don't have their problems," he said. "We are going to help them."
"We want to organize several holding companies to study and acquire companies listed on regional exchanges, hopefully including banks," Mr. Chiang continued. "We also want to increase imports from these countries and want to increase the opportunities for foreign workers from these nations."
Regional leaders are acutely aware that Taiwan is not merely a major investor in Southeast Asia but also possesses the financial strength to contribute to recovery efforts. Indeed, this week Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, the man who is responsible for economic policy, made a two-day visit to Taipei to explore the extent of possible Taiwan aid.
 The death of Sheu Yuan-dong, governor of Taiwan's central bank, in a plane crash on Monday night is not expected to have any immediate effect on Taiwan's strategy in the Asian crises.
But because Taiwan is barred from most international organizations, particularly the I.M.F., the extent and the character of its aid to Southeast Asia are somewhat restricted. A proposal by Taiwan last month to the 18-member Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum to establish an "Asia fund," a sort of free-standing loan entity for the region, was scuttled by the United States, which insisted that the I.M.F. maintain its lead role in the regional rescue plans.
Undeterred, Jeffrey L. S. Koo, the chairman and chief executive of Chinatrust Commercial Bank, Taiwan's largest private bank, said there were still broad areas in which both the Taiwan Government and the island's private sector intended to exert influence.
"I went around the region with the Prime Minister," Mr. Koo said, "and I found that the real problem with these countries was government, a lack of long-term policies, no continuity in decision-making. There were no regulations against overborrowing. They let the private sector borrow as much as possible."
"The I.M.F. or any single country cannot solve these problems," Mr. Koo continued in a late-evening interview in his office. "It needs the whole world to help. And the only way is to have the private sector's confidence restored in individual governments and economies."
As a member of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation's private sector Business Advisory Council, Mr. Koo said he would present the body with a proposal on debt guarantees and reducing corporate credit problems.
"The only way I can think of managing this is for these countries with problems to issue sovereign debt guaranteed by Apec countries," he explained. He said the Asian Development Bank in Manila, of which Taiwan is a member, "would be the locomotive" of this proposal.
Mr. Koo and the Taiwan Government envision two types of assistance: countries like Taiwan or Japan guaranteeing new sovereign debt issues of troubled countries, and regional banks in healthy economies like Taiwan's creating a convertible bond to provide loans to major companies facing credit squeezes. The bonds would ultimately be exchanged for equity in the companies.
"This was overwhelmingly supported by the heads of the four countries," Mr. Koo said, referring to Presidents Fidel Ramos of the Philippines and Suharto of Indonesia, and Prime Ministers Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia and Chuan Leekpai of Thailand, all of whom met with Taiwan's Prime Minister, Mr. Siew. "Taiwan," Mr. Koo said, "is in the position where we can do something for our neighboring friends, to salvage them. We want to help these troubled countries. And if it earns friendship, too, why not?"
And even though the United States remains cool to any plan to create an Asian-based rescue fund, Mr. Koo and other leading financiers are also planning a new investment fund for the region. "We will propose the emergency fund at the ministerial meeting in Mexico," he said, referring to the Apec meeting of finance ministers to be held in March. Although a participant in Apec, Taiwan has always had a lower-level role than other members. "The fund will invest in listed and unlisted companies," he said. "For listed companies we will invest in high technology."
Even as Taiwan's private sector is pushing its ideas at Apec, the Taiwan Government remains concerned that the United States has largely ignored its efforts. Paul C. H. Chiu, Taiwan's Finance Minister, urged that the Government be directly involved in regional recovery efforts.
"We would like to see what part we could play," he said in an interview at his office. He added that Taiwan wanted to be included in efforts by Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy United States Treasury Secretary, to organize a 21-country meeting to deal with Southeast Asia, "but we were not invited."
Despite Taiwan's immense foreign exchange reserves, now about $83 billion (United States), and a strong banking system, the Government's wielding of its financial clout more publicly than in the past has been attacked by Beijing as part of a plot to assert its independence.
China, which regards Taiwan as a renegade province, is intent on hemming in Taiwan's international stature. But the crises in Southeast Asia have created a dilemma for Beijing: It needs the region's economies to recover to remove strains on its own economy, and it recognizes that its nemesis Taiwan can do much to contribute to Southeast Asia's recovery.
"We have no objections to the countries concerned having nongovernmental economic and trade cooperation with Taiwan," Zhu Bangzhao, a spokesman for the Chinese Government, said at a recent news briefing. But, he declared, "We are strongly opposed to countries which have diplomatic relations with China carrying on any governmental activities with Taiwan."

HEADLINE: Textile Maker to Close South Carolina Mill

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ROCK HILL, S.C., Feb. 17

 BODY:
Springs Industries said today that it would close its textile mill in Rock Hill, dismiss about 480 workers and take a $23 million pretax charge.
The charge against first-quarter earnings will be about $1.14 a diluted share. The company said it expected an additional $8 million in equipment-moving and other expenses. 
 The 69-year-old plant in Rock Hill, which dyes and prints fabric, will probably be closed by midyear.
Springs, which is based in Fort Mill, S.C., said the business, which serves the home-sewing and crafts markets, continued to drag down results.
"We regret having to take this step, but continuing profit drains in this part of our business leave us no choice," Robert Moser, head of the company's specialty fabrics group, said in a statement.
The Rock Hill mill was built in 1929 by M. Lowenstein & Sons, one of many companies acquired by Springs in the last 20 years. At one time, 5,000 people worked at the plant.
Repeated efforts to sell the plant failed, and modernizing it is not economically feasible, the company said.
Springs, one of the United States' largest textile makers, said it would consolidate Rock Hill's production into more modern facilities. Springs will demolish the plant and move the 290 employees it is keeping.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Another Record for Dow as Investors Dismiss the Negatives

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average continued its trek into record territory yesterday, posting its fifth consecutive high as an economic report pointed to slower economic growth while a new round of merger news heartened investors.
But in moving stocks higher, investors chose to focus on the positives and seemed to show little concern about either the impact that Asia's faltering economies could have on American corporate profits or about the possibility of a military strike in the Persian Gulf. 
 After trading as high as 8,446.32 -- its first time over 8,400 -- the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 8,398.50 yesterday, up 28.40 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.67 points, to 1,022.76, still shy of the record of 1,024.14 set on Thursday.
Stocks gained after the Federal Reserve reported that the rate of industrial production was unchanged in January, the first stagnation in the barometer since October 1996. The report suggested that the downdraft from Asia's financial crisis might be beginning to slow economic growth in the United States, reducing the chances that the Federal Reserve would need to raise interest rates.
Indeed, continued low interest rates have helped lift the Morgan Stanley 30-company index of cyclical stocks 7.75 percent this year, outpacing broader indexes like the Dow and the S.& P. 500.
But some market analysts are wary of the continued exuberant stock-buying spree by investors, pointing to the impact of Asia's financial crisis on American companies and to a possible attack on Iraq. In a sign of the Asian impact, Conagra, the American food giant, warned yesterday that second-half earnings would not meet expectations because of diminished Asian sales of poultry and meat.
"The market is expecting the best of all scenarios," said Thomas McManus, an independent investment strategist and publisher of The Strategy Connection, a market newsletter. "But the stock market will be taken aback if there is some type of military action without a resolution."
Still, crude oil prices fell yesterday, as oil traders sold on expectations that Iraq might cooperate with the United Nations on weapons inspections. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for March delivery fell 36 cents, to $15.66 a barrel, a four-year low.
Shares of oil companies were mixed. Exxon, Mobil, Amoco and Chevron were lower, but British Petroleum and Royal Dutch/Shell had modest gains.
Another boon for investors yesterday was news of several large deals. Computer Associates said it would proceed with a $108-a-share hostile bid for Computer Sciences, and the SPX Corporation, an auto parts maker, offered $48 a share for its rival Echlin.
Those deals and others lifted the total announced mergers and acquisitions through yesterday to more than $110 billion this year, topping the $107.4 billion in the corresponding period last year, when such transactions were at a record high, according to the Securities Data Company.
While merger news and the industrial production figures lifted the Dow and the S.& P. 500, smaller-company shares slumped. The Nasdaq composite index fell 6.99 points, to 1,703.43. Leading the declines were Microsoft, Oracle, Applied Materials and 3Com. Despite yesterday's decline, the Nasdaq is still up 8.47 percent this year.
And after a 10-session rally, the Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks slipped 1.10 points, to 453.19. That barometer is now 12.02 points away from its record of 465.21 reached on Oct. 13.
Some analysts saw the weakness in those small-stock indexes as another red flag for investors.
"I'm nervous because the rally has a narrow focus when there's so much money coming in," said Ron Reuss, chief economist at Piper Jaffray Inc. "It means we're getting kind of long in the tooth in this business expansion.
"I'm just surprised at how blase the market is about how great everything is," he added. "We've been running the economy in overdrive, but everybody's just yawning."
Asian governments may be stabilizing their currencies, he said, but "we haven't seen the resultant pain that's going to come from the economy as they try to pay down their bad loans."

LENGTH: 1417 words

HEADLINE: Havana Journal;
Divided Loyalties Tugging at Cuba's Children

BYLINE: By MIRTA OJITO 

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
More than eight years after the cold war melted in the rubble of the Berlin wall, the children of Cuba continue to dive under desks in schools all over the island.
The drills serve to reinforce the most pervasive ideological lesson in Cuba's schools: that the United States is evil and that Cubans must always be ready to defend themselves. 
 That old message, fashioned after the Bay of Pigs invasion and the missile crisis in the early 1960's, is fed constantly to children here even when there are no tensions between the United States and any other country, as there are with Iraq now.
But it is an especially poignant message today when most families in Cuba have relatives in the United States and when, faced with enormous economic difficulties, the Cuban Government has allowed dollars to circulate freely on the island.
Nowadays, when children come home from the war drills, they slip on shoes bought with dollars sent by their grandparents in Miami or, in some cases, they work odd jobs catering to American tourists to earn dollars themselves.
In the mornings, William Jose Diaz, a 12-year-old Pioneer who is in eighth grade, swears to defend the Cuban flag against "los Americanos." In the evenings, he rushes to open the doors of tourists cars. He works outside Pain de Paris, an expensive bakery in Vedado. Most nights, he makes at least $2. When someone handed him $1 recently, the boy rushed home to buy bananas for dinner.
Years ago, it was easier for parents to keep their children blissfully unaware of both their true political feelings and the hardships they went through. But now, with the country's economy in chaos, even young children know that once they turn 7 they lose the right to buy milk.
They know that the Government issues only two school uniforms during elementary school -- one in kindergarten and the other in fifth grade. And that they are no longer able to buy toys because the Government did away with the yearly ritual of selling toys to children on the 26th of July, the anniversary of the beginning of Fidel Castro's armed uprising in 1953.
The contradictions of their young lives -- hearing one message in school and another, radically different, at home -- confuses some children. Their teachers want them to fight the Americans; their parents want to join them or, at least, to get some of their dollars.
"Mom," a 7-year-old girl recently asked her mother, "if William Clinton is so bad, why do we want to go live with him?"
Trusting their children and thinking them ready to absorb contrasting messages, many parents openly discuss their beliefs in front of them and even mock the revolutionary slogans and songs they bring home. But then they ask their children to keep it to themselves.
Some parents fear that their children will be ostracized if their teachers know that they live in a non-revolutionary home. Parents who make a living in what the Government considers illegal activities -- renting a room or selling cigars without a license -- also fear that, if their children talk, the Government may confiscate their goods, fine them or, in some cases, jail them.
The burden of living in two distinct realities affects some children in psychological and physical ways. Teresita, a 14-year-old ninth grader who lives in Old Havana, said she had never told her best friend that her parents desperately want to leave the country.
She has also never told anyone that, when the doors are locked, her mother rants against President Castro, blaming his Government for the scarcities in their home. Two months ago, Teresita began to shed the hairs of her arms and legs. The doctors told her that she lacked some essential vitamins in her diet; the mother thinks it is a result of stress.
A 52-year-old writer who insisted on being identified only by his first name, Angel, cannot stand a song praising the revolution that his 9-year-old daughter has been singing lately. He tells her to stop and his daughter obeys. The mother, worried about her daughter, intercedes.
"You want your children to be a full member of the family, to know how you feel about everything," said the mother, a member of the Communist Party who long ago grew disenchanted with the revolution but outside the home pretends to be as enthusiastic as ever. "But I worry sometimes how all this is going to affect her and how much contradiction she can really absorb in her young mind."
Yet the girl's mother, in a fit of anger, recently ripped to pieces her red Communist Party ID and threw it out the window. It was her daughter who ran three flights downstairs in a panic to retrieve the picture from the sidewalk so that no one would ever know what her mother had done.
While Angel helps his daughter with her homework, he systematically deconstructs everything she has been taught at school. She is now learning about Jose Marti, a 19th-century patriot who fought to free Cuba from Spanish colonialism. In Cuba today, Marti is also regarded as the intellectual precursor of the revolution. Angel tells his daughter that Marti would never have supported Mr. Castro's Government. The little girl giggles and rolls her eyes.
But there is very little that parents can do to shape their children's education. In a country with no private schools and compulsory education until ninth grade, parents are forced to send their children to state-run schools. They also have no say about the curriculum and, more and more these days, very little about their children's extracurricular activities.
Some parents try to exert control by taking their children late to school to avoid the morning ritual where students salute the flag, sing the national anthem and repeat revolutionary slogans. Others are turning to religion, hoping that lessons in catechism will open their children's minds to other points of view.
The Roman Catholic Church is taking full advantage of it. To make the shift easier for the children, it is incorporating some of the messages children hear in school into Sunday sermons. It is not unusual for priests now to somehow link Cuba's patriots to religion.
At a recent Mass here, Jaime Cardinal Ortega Alamino drew cheers from his mostly young listeners when he reminded them that the full name of Antonio Maceo, one of Cuba's most revered martyrs, was Antonio de la Caridad, a clear reference to Cuba's patriot saint, Our Lady of Charity.
Priests in some churches are also enticing children to attend Mass and catechism classes through a system of bonuses and rewards. Children receive bonuses for every Mass and catechism class they attend. Once a week, they can exchange the bonuses for gifts like gum, clothing, pencils and toys, all donated from churches abroad.
"They get things they want and need and we get an opportunity to show them the church's way," said the Rev. Jesus Maria Lusarreta, a priest at La Milagrosa, where more than 400 children attend catechism weekly.
During his five-day visit to Cuba in January, Pope John Paul II referred to Cuba's youth in two of the four Masses he held. At the first, in Santa Clara, some parents nodded in silence when the Pope said, "Parents must be acknowledged as the first and foremost educators of their children."
But it is difficult for parents to heed the Pope's words. Elementary school children go to school here from 8 A.M. to 4:20 P.M. On Saturdays, they often return to school for sports or political events. Sometimes they sleep over in the school to await so-called Domingos de Defensa, Sundays of Defense, days in which the children practice what it is like to be under attack and receive their lessons in a bunker.
Marta Perez Herrera, deputy director of Pepito Tey, an elementary school in Old Havana, said that, beginning in third grade, children are trained by members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces, who teach them everything from patriotic symbols to military moves. At a recent practice session in a park, uniformed men were training young children to march as one.
While the children marched, a 16-year-old girl in tight pink shorts stood in a corner a few blocks away eyeing foreigners. The girl, Yanel Noa, said she dropped out of school because she did not want to work in the fields, a requirement for all students in high school.
Had she continued in school, she would have become a dancer, she said. For now, she lives off the charity of a special friend: a 32-year-old married American man who often travels to Cuba loaded with cash.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Suharto Defies I.M.F., Removing Central Banker
President Suharto of Indonesia dismissed the head of his central bank, an act of defiance toward President Clinton and the I.M.F. that moved the country closer to possibly losing its economic rescue package.
The central bank chief had opposed a risky plan by Mr. Suharto to strengthen the Indonesian currency, saying it would subvert the I.M.F.-backed recovery plan. Page A1. 

Industrial Output Stalls
Industrial production was unchanged in January, the first time in 15 months that there was no expansion. The data suggested that the Asian financial crisis had started to impede United States economic growth. D2.
 
The uncertainty in Asia and the indication of slowing growth in the United States drove investors into Treasury securities, sending the yield on the 30-year bond down to 5.79 percent from 5.84. In the stock market, the Dow industrials hit a fifth consecutive record, 8,398.50 points, up 28.40. D8.
 
SmithKline Earnings Up Slightly
Earnings rose 5 percent at SmithKline Beecham, despite unfavorable currency rates, which may have hurt sales of new drugs. D2.
 
Hostile Bid for Parts Maker
SPX, an auto-parts maker, made a $3 billion hostile takeover offer for Echlin, which is four times its size and one of the biggest companies in the industry. Echlin shares soared on expectations of higher offers. D4.
 
Hewlett-Packard Profit Steady
Hewlett-Packard reported essentially flat quarterly earnings, falling slightly short of analysts' expectations, as strong sales growth was offset by pricing pressure in computers and printers. D4.
 
Higher Offer on Implant Settlement
Dow Corning, seeking to emerge from bankruptcy, raised its offer to settle claims from 177,000 women who contend that its breast implants injured them. D4.
 
New Jet Engine Design
Pratt & Whitney plans a radical new airplane engine design that it says would be quieter, cleaner, more efficient and more reliable than current models, but that also faces hurdles to acceptance. D4.
 
U S West Plans Flank Attack
U S West plans to ask regulators for permission to build a big new data network, executives close to the company said, joining a new form of attack on rules that keep the Bells out of the long-distance market. D4.
 
Unsinkable Marketers
Realizing that Leonardo DiCaprio action figures or Kate Winslet dolls might founder, marketers were slow to pick up on the success of the movie "Titanic" with merchandise tie-ins. But some companies, like J. Peterman, responded with imagination, selling replica items like clothing, life jackets, blueprints and even a 13-foot anchor. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D7.
 
Kellogg won F.D.A. approval to advertise that cereals containing the fiber psyllium may reduce the risk of coronary heart disease. Kellogg's Bran Buds will qualify. D2.
 
No Food Defamation, Judge Says
A judge ruled that Texas cattlemen do not have a case against Oprah Winfrey based on a state law that protects perishable food products from false and defamatory statements. But the case, stemming from comments on her talk show about mad cow disease, will be allowed to proceed as a simple business disparagement case. A10.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk; Education Page
